{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08977", "title": "FedLoGe: Joint Local and Generic Federated Learning under Long-tailed Data. (arXiv:2401.08977v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Federated Long-Tailed Learning (Fed-LT) focuses on data imbalance issue in global model, neglects local performance. FedLoGe optimizes local and global models using representation learning and classifier alignment. Shared backbone captures global trends, while individualized classifiers refine local features. SSE-C classifier prunes noisy features, GLA-FR aligns features with client preferences. Outperforms pFL and Fed-LT in CIFAR-10/100-LT, ImageNet, and iNaturalist experiments."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08984", "title": "A GAN-based data poisoning framework against anomaly detection in vertical federated learning. (arXiv:2401.08984v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Vertical federated learning (VFL) faces the challenge of malicious poisoning attacks. An innovative poisoning framework called P-GAN addresses this challenge by training a surrogate target model using semi-supervised learning and using a GAN-based method to produce adversarial perturbations. An anomaly detection algorithm based on a deep auto-encoder (DAE) is also developed for a robust defense mechanism in VFL scenarios. Extensive experiments are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of P-GAN and DAE."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/Qw5kwJhgbr6HSWHsJ/some-heuristics-i-use-for-deciding-how-much-i-trust", "title": "Some heuristics I use for deciding how much I trust scientific results", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Key ideas from the article:\n\n- The author has no empirical evidence for the heuristics they are listing but they will still write them.\n- Experimental evidence in fields like chemistry and physics is easier to test, while causal inference from observational evidence is harder.\n- The level of practitioners using a result can indicate its reliability, with auction design being a widely used example. Political science research is less widely used and less reliable.\n- The size and techniques used in the literature supporting a result can also indicate its reliability.\n- External validity, or the generalizability of a result, is a big concern in development economics.\n- Statistical power and the risk of lucky significant results are factors to consider when assessing replication.\n- Social desirability bias may influence the likelihood of certain results being published.\n- Formal tests for publication bias can provide more confidence in a field's reliability."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/5gKgByyepNxDHC8nJ/announcing-the-sos-research-collective-for-independent", "title": "Announcing the SoS Research Collective for independent researchers", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Seeds of Science is a research project that aims to promote creativity and diversity of thought in science. They have published 26 papers and recruited 303 peer reviewers. They are launching a new experiment called the SoS Research Collective to support independent researchers and address issues in the current state of science. The collective offers the title of SoS Research Fellow, payment for articles, editing services, and promotion. They value inclusivity and prioritize unique ideas. Collaboration is not the main goal, but may emerge organically. They expect fellows to publish once a year and continue as independent researchers. They offer paid subscriptions to sustain their operations but don't put ideas behind a paywall. Their vision is to pioneer a style of science that favors risk-taking and subjectivity."}

TAI resembling Language Models (LLMs) with slow takeoff and few big actors using AI.\n2. TAI resembling humans, animals, and RL agents, with online learning and robotic bodies.\n3. Vision 1: TAI as helpers guided by humans.\n4. Vision 2: AIs with higher autonomy, making complex decisions independently.\n\nApproaches like whole brain emulation and reverse-engineered human social instincts have been proposed for Vision 2. Technical and social questions, embodiment of AIs, and the level of autonomy are important considerations. Control and supervision over AI actions are key differences between Visions 1 and 2. Historical trends and forecasts suggest that civilization-ending catastrophes from advanced biotechnology pose the most significant risk. However, other risks do not outweigh the historical benefits of science. The debate centers on the potential for faster science to derail advanced civilization, with differing estimates of risks from superforecasters and domain experts. The author's personal view is that faster science is unlikely to have a negative net impact and investing in science has a significant social impact. The preferred policy stance is to accelerate science while mitigating risks from new technologies."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/CKYhsD2xCw48DwJiD/forecasting-accidentally-caused-pandemics", "title": "Forecasting accidentally-caused pandemics", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The risk of accidental pandemics is growing due to research activities. A simple model predicts a lower rate of accidental pandemics compared to zoonotic pandemics. Historical data suggests 1-2 accidental pandemics have occurred, with the 1977 Russian flu being one example. Indicators like lab accidents, BSL-4 lab construction, and virology papers show a growth rate of 2.5% per year. However, the model may overestimate accidental pandemics, and complex models are needed. Assumptions include proportional risky research units, exponential growth, constant probability, and independence of pandemics. Accidental pandemics are currently not the majority, but biosafety improvements are necessary. The severity of accidental pandemics and the types of researched pathogens are important considerations. Zoonotic pandemics pose a greater current threat. Further research and biosafety measures are necessary to address accidental pandemic risks."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://news.mit.edu/2024/stratospheric-safety-standards-how-aviation-could-steer-ai-health-regulation-0117", "title": "Stratospheric safety standards: How aviation could steer regulation of AI in health", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "MIT researchers, inspired by the safety regulations in the aviation industry, are exploring ways to regulate artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare. They propose using the model of extensive pilot training in the airline industry as a framework for training medical professionals to effectively use AI tools. The researchers also suggest implementing mechanisms for reporting unsafe AI tools and creating an independent auditing authority to ensure the safety and reliability of malfunctioning health AI systems. They emphasize the need for a comprehensive governance framework and collaboration between existing government agencies to regulate AI in healthcare effectively."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/yEvEbbiMWGRsqWE5H/chinese-and-us-semiconductor-competition", "title": "Chinese and US Semiconductor competition", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "China's semiconductor industry is trying to catch up to Taiwan and other leading countries, but US sanctions are hindering its progress.\n\nChina aims to de-Americanize its supply chain and develop its own capabilities for manufacturing advanced chips, but it faces challenges in obtaining the necessary equipment, such as lithography machines.\n\nSemiconductor production involves processes like photolithography, doping, and ion implantation, which require precise equipment and expertise.\n\nSMIC, China's leading semiconductor fabricator, has hired former TSMC and Samsung employee Liang Mong Song to boost its capabilities. However, US sanctions limit its access to equipment.\n\nASML, a Dutch company that makes photolithography machines, is prohibited from selling its advanced machines to China due to sanctions.\n\nBuilding an indigenous semiconductor supply chain is challenging due to the complexity of the equipment and dependence on foreign parts.\n\nThe US also faces challenges in semiconductor manufacturing, as it has lost its ability to produce significant amounts of chips. The CHIPS Act aims to support domestic manufacturing, but it is unlikely to regain leadership.\n\nTrailing-edge chips are important for many devices, and China plans to increase its capacity in this area, which will strengthen its supply chain for goods produced for Western economies.\n\nEnsuring peace in East Asia is crucial to maintaining a stable global supply of semiconductors, as military equipment heavily relies on chips.\n\nChina's attempt to domesticate semiconductor manufacturing is unlikely to succeed, and any claimed domestication will likely depend on foreign components.\n\nLeadership in semiconductor manufacturing is likely to remain in Asia, with the US facing challenges in regaining its position."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ebcwjBJqXYhwA8Y4s/does-a-daly-approach-underrate-the-badness-of-mental-illness", "title": "Does a DALY approach underrate the badness of mental illness?", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "This research project reviewed the literature on mental health and consulted experts in the field. The importance of averting mental illness depends on philosophical assumptions. Measures like QALYs and DALYs attempt to quantify the burden of disability and early death, but may not capture the full extent of mental illness. Well-being measures, such as life satisfaction, offer an alternative but also have limitations. Converting between measures introduces uncertainty. Mental health interventions should measure mental health before and after treatment. Comparing the badness of mental illness to physical illness is difficult and depends on philosophical assumptions. Mental illness is a major cause of suffering globally. Mental health work becomes more valuable for those who prioritize preventing suffering."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/myXY6FuZz8JGrXoEG/mental-illness-is-growing-as-a-proportion-of-the-global", "title": "Mental illness is growing as a proportion of the global disease burden", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "This research project highlights the global burden of mental health conditions, excluding certain disorders, and emphasizes their impact on health and the economy. Mental illness affects education, employment, productivity, and healthcare costs. Mental health spending does not match the problem's size, with high-income countries allocating more funds. Data reliability and methods used may affect estimates, but anxiety and depression correlate with a country's wealth. Identifying those in need is not a challenge in low- and middle-income countries, but other obstacles exist. The burden of depression and anxiety is expected to increase in the future. Data accuracy is limited in LMICs, affecting estimates, and interventions need to be more cost-effective. Mental illness burden impacts health and economy significantly and must be addressed with improved data quality and research."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/dajqGiunuTkrCFL6C/mental-health-report-cearch-executive-summary", "title": "Mental Health Report (CEARCH) [Executive Summary]", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "- Limited data on mental health burden in low-middle income countries (LMICs).\n- Depression and anxiety projected to increase by 50% by the end of the century.\n- Existing health measures may not capture the severity of mental illness.\n- Cost per person treated is important for treatment interventions, particularly in LMICs.\n- Psychotherapy via internet and smartphones shows promise but is in early stages.\n- Access to antidepressants and pain medication is limited in poor countries.\n- Prevention interventions and risk factors have limited impact on mental health.\n- Banning deadly means of suicide could have a significant impact.\n- More research and refinement needed for cost-effective mental health treatments."}

Interpersonal group therapy (IGT) shows promise in treating anxiety and depression. Antidepressants reduce depressive symptoms, but more research is needed. Cash transfer programs have a modest positive effect on mental health. Other interventions like pain relief and physical activity have their own benefits and challenges. SIIA wants to educate policymakers and the public on data policy without bias and welcomes input from various perspectives. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/questioning-openais-nonprofit-status", "title": "Questioning OpenAI's Nonprofit Status", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Recently, there have been concerns raised about the corporate governance issues and for-profit incentives within OpenAI, particularly regarding its relationship with Microsoft and the deletion of its language prohibiting military use of its technology. Robert Weissman, the president of Public Citizen, has written a letter to the California Attorney General questioning OpenAI's nonprofit status and calling for an investigation into its structure. Weissman argues that if OpenAI is primarily pursuing profit, it should forfeit its nonprofit status. The valuation of OpenAI, which is approaching $100 billion, is also discussed, and Weissman speculates about what would happen if OpenAI were to lose its nonprofit status, suggesting that its assets could be used to establish new charitable foundations. The conversation broadens to the topic of technology regulation and who should have control over AI development and deployment, with Weissman emphasizing the need for public control and decision-making rather than leaving it primarily to large for-profit corporations. The interview concludes with a discussion about the influence of tech companies in policymaking and the potential dangers of prioritizing profits over safety and ethics in AI development."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.44?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Bus Rapid Transit: End of trend in Latin America?", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges faced by Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) systems in Latin America, including overcrowding, lack of reliability, and safety issues. It mentions that ongoing management and investment are necessary for BRT to meet growing demand and maintain quality. The article emphasizes the importance of data, technology, urban integration, and public participation in ensuring the success of BRT. It compares the growth of BRT to the decline of tramways before their resurgence as light rail transit systems. The article also mentions the positive impacts of BRT, such as improved mobility and reduced emissions. It concludes with recommendations for improving BRT service quality and increasing public acceptance."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-unveils-its-new-street-level-surveillance-hub", "title": "EFF Unveils Its New Street Level Surveillance Hub ", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has launched a new website called Street Level Surveillance, providing information on privacy-invading technologies used by law enforcement. EFF aims to be a reference source and news feed on police surveillance technology. They document the use of technologies like drones and automated license plate readers and have been described as relentless by a police lieutenant. EFF also focuses on the impact of machine learning, artificial intelligence, and algorithmic decision-making. They have documented surveillance technologies at the U.S.-Mexico border and joined a coalition opposing surveillance affecting migrants. EFF warns of a ballot initiative in San Francisco that could undermine privacy rights. Sound Thinking, the company behind ShotSpotter, is acquiring Geolitica, known for PredPol, a predictive policing technology criticized for exacerbating inequalities."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.siia.net/what-is-rights-safety-impacting-ai/", "title": "What is Rights &amp; Safety Impacting AI", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The White House released a draft memorandum regarding the use of AI in the federal government. The memorandum classifies AI into two categories: \"safety-impacting AI\" and \"rights-impacting AI.\" However, the definitions provided are broad, which may discourage the adoption of new technologies. It is suggested to adopt a more risk-based approach and refine the definitions. The use of AI in making decisions about government services should be considered \"rights-impacting AI\" and require greater scrutiny. Comments on the memorandum are now closed."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-pennsylvania-supreme-court-find-keyword-search-warrant-unconstitutional", "title": "EFF Urges Pennsylvania Supreme Court to Find Keyword Search Warrant Unconstitutional ", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and other organizations argue that keyword warrants used by the police to search through search engine databases are unconstitutional and violate privacy rights. These warrants target free speech, lack probable cause, and can implicate innocent people. The case at hand involves a massive invasion of Google users' privacy and sets a dangerous precedent that could be applied to any search engine user. The EFF, along with other groups, filed a brief challenging the constitutionality of these warrants, highlighting their incompatibility with privacy and freedom of speech. The warrants allow police to access users' most private thoughts and opinions without targeting specific individuals or accounts. It is argued that these warrants violate both the Pennsylvania Constitution and the Fourth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. They also pose a threat to protected speech and the right to receive information. The EFF emphasizes the importance of anonymous and unrestricted use of search engines for a free society and warns that dragnet warrants will deter users from seeking information on certain topics."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/ai-watermarking-wont-curb-disinformation", "title": "AI Watermarking Won't Curb Disinformation", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Watermarking AI-generated content is a proposed solution to distinguish it from human-generated content to prevent misinformation. Current watermarking schemes can be easily removed and future schemes may face similar issues. Watermarking digital images with visible text is slightly more effective but still not foolproof. Using metadata and cryptographic signatures to prove the authenticity of camera-generated images is a more feasible method. Watermarking text-based AI content is challenging due to rewording. Watermark detection tools can either aid in removing watermarks or hinder the process if kept secret. OpenAI and Google have provided guidelines for website owners, and the US Copyright Office is seeking comments on copyright laws. AI image generators raise concerns for artists, and AI may assist law enforcement in the future."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/eff-asks-court-uphold-federal-law-protects-online-video-viewers-privacy-and-free", "title": "EFF Asks Court to Uphold Federal Law That Protects Online Video Viewers\u2019 Privacy and Free Expression", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) argues in court to uphold the federal Video Privacy Protection Act (VPPA), which requires written consent before disclosing viewing history, stating that it protects freedom of expression and privacy. In a lawsuit brought against Patreon for allegedly sharing user information with Facebook, Patreon argues that the law is unconstitutional on First Amendment grounds. EFF argues this is wrong and that the VPPA advances First Amendment and privacy interests. Courts have protected against government intrusion into people's reading and viewing habits, recognizing the importance of private media consumption in fostering diverse ideas and robust debate. The VPPA is not overbroad, as it targets commercial disclosure of viewing history, which has no public interest. Possible unconstitutional applications of the law can be addressed without invalidating it entirely. The EFF highlights the importance of protecting viewing history to safeguard privacy and free expression."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/victory-police-drone-footage-not-categorically-exempt-californias-public-records", "title": "Victory! Police Drone Footage is Not Categorically Exempt From California\u2019s Public Records Law", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The California Court of Appeal ruled that video footage captured by police drones in response to 911 calls should be made accessible to the public. The ruling came after journalist Arturo Casta\u00f1ares sought access to videos created by the Chula Vista Police Department's drone program. The court stated that drone footage should not be categorically exempt from public disclosure and that each video should be evaluated under the California Public Records Act. This ruling sets a precedent for other California agencies with similar drone programs. Additionally, the article mentions the need to balance privacy concerns and benefits when it comes to the use of drones, as well as unrelated topics such as artist Trevor Paglen's exploration of the internet as a surveillance technology and the upcoming FAA decision on regulations for Beyond Visual Line of Sight drones."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/digital-rights-lgbtq-people-2023-review", "title": "Digital Rights for LGBTQ+ People: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance is increasing worldwide, impacting individuals both online and offline. Countries are passing initiatives restricting LGBTQ+ rights, leading to self-censorship and data surveillance. Student monitoring tools in the US flag LGBTQ+ content, creating a harmful environment. Cybercrime and surveillance legislation in the Middle East and Africa threatens LGBTQ+ rights. Colonial-era laws have been used to imprison and harass LGBTQ+ individuals. Proposed laws in Uganda, Ghana, and Kenya further criminalize homosexuality. The Electronic Frontier Foundation opposes these laws and calls for the protection of digital rights. Legislators have also attempted to limit young people's use of social media, while comprehensive data privacy reforms have been lacking. The Supreme Court should clarify government interference in social media censorship cases. The EU Media Freedom Act has flaws and creates a privileged status for certain media outlets."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/year-review-googles-corporate-paternalism-browser", "title": "Year In Review: Google\u2019s Corporate Paternalism in The Browser", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Google and its subsidiaries, including Chrome and YouTube, have made significant changes that prioritize their own interests over user privacy. Chrome's Manifest V2 is being replaced by Manifest V3, limiting what all extensions can do and putting Google in control of browser privacy tools. Google's \"Privacy Sandbox\" project replaces third-party cookies with the \"Topics API,\" allowing Chrome to track users and share data with advertisers. YouTube is now blocking users with ad-blockers unless they disable them. Privacy Badger, a privacy tool, is working to empower users and protect their privacy. Ultimately, users should have the right to decide their own privacy settings, not advertisers like Google."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/lock-and-code-dna-data-deserves-better-with-suzanne-bernstein/", "title": "Lock and Code: DNA data deserves better, with Suzanne Bernstein\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "An informed consumer can make choices about online risks; EPIC protects privacy and democratic values."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/how-fight-bad-patents-2023-year-review", "title": "How To Fight Bad Patents: 2023 Year In Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is fighting against patent trolls and advocating for a more balanced patent system. The inter partes review (IPR) process has been effective in canceling invalid patents, but patent trolls are trying to roll back the IPR process. The Alice v. CLS Bank case has helped to eliminate bad patents in the computer technology field, but there are attempts to reverse the Alice framework. The PREVAIL Act would limit the public's right to challenge bad patents. The U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Intellectual Property will be debating the bill. Landmark Technology's U.S. Patent No. 7,010,508 has been widely abused. The patent examination process has flaws and often supports unwarranted monopolies. Patent trolls pose a threat to innovation and the free speech on the internet. Efforts are being made to investigate patent trolling companies that file numerous lawsuits."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/taking-back-web-decentralization-2023-review", "title": "Taking Back the Web with Decentralization: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The internet is witnessing a swing towards decentralization as users push back against the concentration of power and violation of privacy and free expression on major social media platforms. This movement is seen in the growth of new social media projects such as Mastodon and Bluesky. Meta's launch of Threads, a microblogging site using the federated ActivityPub protocol, also contributed to the decentralization trend. The federation of social news aggregation has also gained traction as users turn to alternatives like Lemmy and Kbin in response to changes in platforms like Reddit. The sustainability and safeguarding of these decentralized projects against government overreach remain challenges. There is ongoing work on protocols and libraries that enable decentralized services, such as Veilid and Spritely, promising secure and private data exchange. The European Union's Digital Markets Act and the More Instant Messaging Interoperability working group are pushing for open interoperability and end-to-end encryption in messaging platforms. The DWeb Camp and EFF's testimony on blockchain highlight the importance of policy discussions and exploration in the decentralized web space. Content moderation in decentralized social media is a complex issue being addressed by initiatives like the Task Force for a Trustworthy Future Web. Overall, the decentralization movement is gaining momentum with the exploration of alternatives, the development of protocols, and policy discussions shaping its future."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/exposing-the-rotten-reality-of-ai-training-data", "title": "Exposing the Rotten Reality of AI Training Data", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "A report revealed thousands of instances of child sexual abuse imagery in a dataset used to train AI systems. The report emphasizes concerns about generating realistic harmful content and calls for better curation and safety mechanisms. The dataset used machine learning to analyze alt tags, and there may be more harmful content that is inaccessible. Models based on the dataset should be deprecated, and transparency and collaboration are needed. Legal implications and retrospective scanning of content are discussed, along with proposed legislation for AI system transparency. Ongoing research and collaboration are vital in addressing these challenges."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/states-attack-young-peoples-constitutional-right-use-social-media-2023-year-review", "title": "States Attack Young People\u2019s Constitutional Right to Use Social Media: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Legislatures in many states tried to restrict young people's social media use, but some laws were blocked for violating the First Amendment. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposed these laws, citing privacy and free speech concerns. EFF advocates for comprehensive data privacy legislation instead. They also fight against anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives and corporate control of the internet. EFF continues to protect digital rights and demand accountability from lawmakers, institutions, and tech companies."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/fighting-european-threats-encryption-2023-year-review", "title": "Fighting European Threats to Encryption: 2023 Year in Review\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "In 2023, European politicians tried to undermine encryption, but a key EU committee adopted a position that protects end-to-end encryption. EFF opposed the U.K.'s Online Safety Act, which passed despite opposition. EFF also launched a coalition to protect the privacy of migrants in Latin America. The right to free expression is fragile, and EFF will continue advocating for digital rights and privacy."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/first-lets-talk-about-consumer-privacy-2023-year-review", "title": "First, Let\u2019s Talk About Consumer Privacy: 2023 Year in Review ", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EFF emphasizes the importance of strong consumer data privacy legislation to tackle online harms and protect civil rights. They advocate for comprehensive privacy laws, fight against bad laws, and protect existing sectoral privacy laws. They filed amicus briefs in lawsuits challenging laws that required age verification and plan to do the same in a case challenging California's Age Appropriate Design Code. They also support existing sectoral laws that protect data like video watch history and biometrics. EFF highlights the increase in anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance online and offline and the tightening grip of corporate paternalism and ad-tracking technology by Google. They also mention the attempts to undermine encryption and the pushback against legislation that threatens students' privacy and free speech."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/fighting-your-digital-rights-across-country-year-review-2023", "title": "Fighting For Your Digital Rights Across the Country: Year in Review 2023", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EFF worked to protect digital rights in multiple states, with a focus on California. Two significant laws passed in California: S.B. 244, the right-to-repair law, and S.B. 362, the CA Delete Act. EFF also supported other laws in California related to immigration status data protection and better broadband access. EFF collaborated with reproductive justice activists and digital rights advocates in California and other states to protect data related to reproductive health care. Several states passed consumer privacy laws, but EFF did not support most of them. Oregon and Montana passed strong privacy bills that EFF commended. EFF will continue to fight for digital rights in state legislatures."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/trenches-broadband-policy-2023-year-review", "title": "In the Trenches of Broadband Policy: 2023 Year In Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "- EFF advocates for affordable, accessible, future-proof internet access for all\n- ISPs are trying to maintain control over the broadband market, hindering progress in closing the digital divide\n- New York City Mayor Eric Adams abandoned plans for public fiber infrastructure and introduced a subsidy plan for existing ISPs\n- California's Department of Technology reduced the number of miles for fiber infrastructure, leaving underserved communities without access\n- The FCC is addressing net neutrality and digital discrimination, recognizing the link between historic underinvestment and ISP practices\n- The fight for broadband implementation will continue, with questions about funding, infrastructure, and inclusion of marginalized communities."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/protecting-students-faulty-software-and-legislation-2023-year-review", "title": "Protecting Students from Faulty Software and Legislation: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The EFF fights against legislation and software that threaten students' privacy, free speech, and social media access. Student surveillance software like GoGuardian inaccurately flags useful material as harmful. Problematic bills like KOSA and the Eyes on the Board Act would increase surveillance and restrict access to educational content. Multiple states have introduced legislation to control students' online access. The EFF opposes using AI detection tools to identify students' use of generative AI, as it carries the risk of false plagiarism flags. The EFF encourages students to defend democracy and offers a guide on privacy for students."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/kids-online-safety-shouldnt-require-massive-online-censorship-and-surveillance", "title": "Kids Online Safety Shouldn\u2019t Require Massive Online Censorship and Surveillance: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Federal legislation in 2023 failed to pass comprehensive data privacy reforms and instead focused on limiting young people's use of popular sites and apps under the guise of child protection. The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) and the Protecting Kids on Social Media Act were proposed but faced opposition due to concerns of censorship and privacy invasion. Several state-level bills restricting social media and online access for minors were passed, raising concerns about online censorship and surveillance. The fight against these bills has activated young people to advocate for their digital rights. Increase in anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives globally restrict freedom of expression and privacy, leading to offline intolerance and self-censorship. Google and its subsidiaries tightened their control over online innovation while portraying it as beneficial for users. Efforts were made in Europe to undermine end-to-end encryption, threatening private communication. EFF worked to protect digital rights at the state level across the country."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/equitable-access-law-got-stronger-year", "title": "Equitable Access to the Law Got Stronger: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Nonprofit organization Public.Resource.Org won a court battle giving them the right to copy and share codes and standards incorporated into law for non-commercial purposes. The court ruled that Public Resource's actions served a different purpose than the plaintiffs and did not cause significant harm to the standards organizations. The decision also highlighted the importance of equitable online access to the law. Meanwhile, the Internet Archive argued against criminalizing fair-use library lending, and the Electronic Frontier Foundation argued against an overly broad law that limits access to digital works for lawful purposes. The United States Copyright Office also sought comments on the interplay between copyright laws and generative AI technologies. A federal appeals court ruled that technical standards incorporated into public law can be freely disseminated without copyright infringement liability. Furthermore, there is debate about the responsibility of companies in allowing people to remove criticism from the internet, and the boundaries of software copyright protection remain a difficult task."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/2023-year-review-us-supreme-courts-busy-year-free-speech-and-tech-cases", "title": "The U.S. Supreme Court\u2019s Busy Year of Free Speech and Tech Cases: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The U.S. Supreme Court has been involved in internet free speech cases, showing restraint in protecting speech rights on social media but declining to overturn an overbroad immigration speech law. Next year, hopes are for the court to uphold individuals' right to comment on officials' social media pages and strike down government overreach in online content. Pending cases involve officials blocking individuals on social media and whether state laws violate the First Amendment. The court is also considering government involvement in social media moderation. Elsewhere, there are trials in the UAE relating to terrorism, anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance is increasing, and attempts to restrict social media use for young people are happening. There are no comprehensive data privacy reforms in Congress. The EFF wants the Supreme Court to clarify government involvement in social media censorship and strike down laws in Florida and Texas. The EU has negotiated a controversial special status for media outlets on online platforms."}

They also gained strong support and new members at security conferences in Las Vegas, raising funds for their work. They ended the year with an online speakeasy discussing \"child safety\" laws that threaten privacy and encryption. The support of EFF members is crucial for their work in creating a better digital future."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/surveillance-self-defense-2023-year-review", "title": "Surveillance Self-Defense: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Surveillance Self-Defense (SSD) has made updates and tackled new topics to help protect against online spying. SSD is divided into four sections: Security Education, Expert Guidance, Signal and WhatsApp updates, and New Guides. They provided guidance on passkeys and quirks in encrypted messaging apps. They also addressed the 23andMe data breach, Google's Privacy Sandbox, a risky Android tablet, advanced data protection for iCloud, and end-to-end encryption for Messenger. EFF aims to explain security technologies and provide guidance for secure communication in 2024."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/recent-surveillance-revelations-enduring-latin-american-issues-2023-year-review", "title": "Recent Surveillance Revelations, Enduring Latin American Issues: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Surveillance abuses and privacy loopholes continued to be a challenge in Latin America in 2023. Examples include intelligence agents monitoring politicians and journalists in Brazil, leaked documents revealing negotiations for spying technologies in Peru, a surveillance scheme during Argentina's presidential elections, and controversial data requests in Mexico. The use of location tracking software, exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Signaling System n. 7 (SS7) protocol, and the lack of oversight and regulation were key issues. There were concerns about malicious parties using surveillance tools, ongoing abuses with Pegasus spyware in Mexico, and the need for stronger privacy protections and transparency in the region."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/year-review-last-mile-encrypting-web", "title": "The Last Mile of Encrypting the Web: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The HTTPS Everywhere web extension has been discontinued because major browsers now offer default HTTPS. The \"Encrypt the Web\" initiative has made security the default and reduced the need for VPNs. Most of the web is now encrypted, but there are still some unencrypted websites. Let's Encrypt played a crucial role by providing free and short-lived certificates. The CA/B Forum is working to reduce certificate lifespans. Chrome is adopting the ACME protocol and expanding HTTPS-First Mode. Challenges include government-mandated certificates and insecure mobile apps. The goal is 100% encryption, but infrastructure must be monitored for user benefit."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/protecting-encryption-and-privacy-us-2023-year-review", "title": "Protecting Encryption And Privacy In The US: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EFF has been fighting against three Senate bills in the US that would weaken encryption and privacy rights. EARN IT would allow providers to be sued, STOP CSAM would broaden the definition of child exploitation, and S.1080 would force providers to report suspected drug sales. EFF has opposed these bills and is working to protect privacy rights. In addition, there has been a rise in anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives globally and corporate control of online advertising and tracking. Many states have also introduced bills to restrict young people's access to social media. EFF has been working at the state level to protect digital rights."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/corporate-spy-tech-and-inequality-2023-year-review", "title": "Corporate Spy Tech and Inequality: 2023 Year in Review ", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is fighting against corporate data surveillance practices that lead to discrimination against marginalized groups, advocating for data privacy legislation as civil rights legislation. The EFF has also provided guidance to users affected by data breaches and highlighted how lower-income individuals suffer the most from such incidents. The organization has also raised concerns about the collection and use of vehicle and location data, as well as the flawed use of facial recognition technology by governments. The EFF calls for reducing data collection by corporations and implementing effective privacy legislation that includes private enforcement and prohibits \"pay for privacy\" schemes. They emphasize that data surveillance is a civil rights problem and urge continued efforts to address it. In addition, the EFF discusses the rise of anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives restricting freedom of expression and privacy worldwide, and highlights efforts by Google and its subsidiaries to control online ad-tracking technology. Furthermore, they highlight that many legislatures in the United States introduced bills to limit young people's use of social media, and they challenge attempts to undermine encryption, particularly in Europe. The EFF actively works to protect digital rights at the state level across the US."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/an-fda-for-ai", "title": "An FDA for AI?", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The FDA's regulatory model is being considered as a potential framework for governing AI systems. However, applying the FDA model to AI raises several challenges due to the differences between the two domains. The FDA has a long history of overseeing novel and high-risk technologies, which can serve as inspiration for AI governance. FDA-style approval and oversight would involve risk and novelty-driven oversight, continuous engagement with developers, wide-ranging information access, burden of proof on developers, and a balance between innovation and safety. The FDA model's cost of compliance and limitations are acknowledged, but adjustments can be made to reduce costs while ensuring risk reduction. It is important to consider other regulatory agencies, such as the FAA and NHTSA, for their expertise in specific sectors. International cooperation and standard-setting could also play a role in AI governance, with mutual acceptance of regulatory approvals across jurisdictions. The EU's AI Act has some elements that align with the FDA model, such as a co-developed code of practice for safety and efficacy. Overall, there is a need to find regulatory approaches that address the unique risks and challenges posed by AI technologies."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/sketchy-and-dangerous-android-childrens-tablets-and-tv-set-top-boxes-2023-review", "title": "Sketchy and Dangerous Android Children\u2019s Tablets and TV Set-Top Boxes: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EFF researchers have found dangerous malware on low-end Android TV set-top boxes and children's tablets. The devices, manufactured by AllWinner and RockChip, were found to have malware that could potentially expose users to legal risks and compromise their privacy. The researchers urged the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to take action against vendors who sell such devices, including Amazon and AliExpress. In addition, the investigation also revealed sketchyware on a tablet marketed for kids from the manufacturer Dragon Touch. The findings highlight the security risks associated with cheaper devices from lesser-known manufacturers, putting those who can only afford such devices at greater risk. The article emphasizes the need for better digital product testing and regulatory oversight to mitigate these risks."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/eff-continues-fight-against-unconstitutional-geofence-and-keyword-search-warrants", "title": "EFF Continues Fight Against Unconstitutional Geofence and Keyword Search Warrants: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EFF fights against high-tech general warrants that require extensive personal data searches. Colorado upheld the constitutionality of keyword warrants. EFF challenges keyword warrants in Pennsylvania. EFF urges Google to resist warrants and minimize data accessible to law enforcement. Apple resists geofence warrants and has no data to provide. EFF argues that witnesses without algorithm knowledge shouldn't testify to reliability. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/fcc-adopts-updates-to-data-breach-rules/", "title": "FCC Adopts Updates to Data Breach Rules", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The FCC has updated its data breach rules, now requiring telecommunications providers to report breaches of customer proprietary network information and personally-identifiable information. The rules treat breaches as presumptively causing harm and allow providers to refrain from notifying consumers if they can prove otherwise. The order also offers a safe harbor for encrypted data. Providers must notify consumers within 30 days of determining a breach. Similar protections are extended to telecommunications relay service providers. EPIC and other organizations have filed comments advocating for stronger data security."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/epic-urges-ninth-circuit-to-reverse-decision-that-threatens-the-future-of-privacy/", "title": "EPIC Urges Ninth Circuit to Reverse Decision That Threatens the Future of Privacy", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EPIC filed a brief supporting the California Age-Appropriate Design Code (AADC), which aims to protect children's privacy online. The AADC includes data protection assessments and privacy mandates. NetChoice, representing tech companies, challenged the law, claiming it violated their First Amendment rights. The district court ruled in favor of NetChoice, but EPIC argues against this decision and defends the AADC's privacy goals. Age estimation, not verification, is a key component of the AADC, and EPIC provides non-invasive methods as examples. EPIC regularly supports tech accountability measures."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-supreme-court-set-standard-how-government-can-and-cant-talk-social-media", "title": "EFF Urges Supreme Court to Set Standard for How Government Can and Can\u2019t Talk to Social Media Sites About Censoring Users\u2019 Posts", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has called on the Supreme Court to clarify standards for government communication with social media companies regarding content censorship. EFF argues that while government agencies should be allowed to advise or persuade sites about user speech, coercion or threats of censorship should be prohibited. EFF submitted a brief in support of clarifying the First Amendment test in the Murthy v. Missouri case, which alleges illegal government pressure on platforms to censor certain content. The Supreme Court's guidance would help differentiate between permissible persuasion and impermissible coercion in government-platform communications."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/ftc-proposes-rules-to-strengthen-childrens-privacy-law/", "title": "FTC Proposes Rules to Strengthen Children\u2019s Privacy Law\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Federal Trade Commission proposed changes to COPPA, aiming to strengthen online privacy protections for children under 13.\n- The proposed rule expands the definition of personal information to include geolocation data and media.\n- A new category of \"child-directed\" platforms would require enhanced privacy protections, even without collecting personal information.\n- Verifiable parental consent methods would be strengthened, including the use of facial recognition technology with safeguards.\n- Companies would be required to delete children's personal data within a reasonable timeframe.\n- EPIC has supported robust children's privacy protections and its comments were favorably cited by the FTC.\n- EPIC, along with other organizations, argued against the use of age-estimation technology for verifiable parental consent.\n- The public can submit comments on the proposed rule to the FTC within 60 days.\n- Contact EPIC for more information or support in protecting privacy and democratic values."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/assessing-the-field-of-section-702-reform-and-anti-reform-bills/", "title": "Assessing the Field of Section 702 Reform (and Anti-Reform) Bills", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The debate over reauthorizing Section 702 remains heated; four bills have been proposed. EPIC's key reform priorities include reforming surveillance under Section 702 and Executive Order 12333, closing the data broker loophole, and not expanding surveillance authorities. The Government Surveillance Reform Act and Protect Liberty Act meet some of these criteria, while the FISA Reform and Reauthorization Act by SSCI and HPSCI do not and would even expand surveillance authorities. Congress should prioritize real reform rather than compromising on important areas."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/yec23", "title": "EFF Has a Guiding Star \ud83c\udf20", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) works to protect people's digital rights and relies on donations to continue its work. Donations made by December 31 will unlock bonus grants for EFF in 2023. EFF defends digital rights through legal, activist, policy, and technological efforts. By donating to EFF, you support digital freedom and can receive tax deductions. Visit their website to learn more about their work and top ratings from Charity Navigator."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/great-interoperability-convergence-2023-year-review", "title": "The Great Interoperability Convergence: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Regulators worldwide are converging on solutions to tackle Big Tech dominance and promote user choice and protection. The current approach of making tech platforms responsible for policing their users has failed. Interoperability and smaller platforms offer relief and protection for users. Recent developments include the Digital Markets Act in Europe, the AMERICA Act in the US, and the Digital Markets, Competition, and Consumers Bill in the UK. These approaches center around user choice and user protections, representing a turning point in tech regulation. Additionally, the Electronic Frontier Foundation argues that a federal law criminalizing access to digital works violates the First Amendment and is unenforceable. The US Senate Subcommittee on Intellectual Property will debate a bill that limits challenges to granted patents, hindering the public's rights."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/surveillance-and-us-mexico-border-2023-year-review", "title": "Surveillance and the U.S.-Mexico Border: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "EFF staff completed trips to the US-Mexico border, releasing a map and dataset of surveillance towers installed by CBP, and published a report on an aggressive new surveillance system called Plataforma Centinela. They filed an amicus brief in a court case arguing against the collection of personal information by the government. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/2023-year-review", "title": "2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The EFF reflects on digital rights progress in 2023, advocating for a \"privacy-first\" approach. They address the root cause of internet problems: corporate surveillance and data collection. The focus should be on restricting data held by tech companies, rather than resorting to censorship. EFF emphasizes transparency from governments and big corporations, defending the Internet Archive and advocating for the overturning of orders preventing transparency reports. The EFF continues to fight for digital rights with support from members and supporters. In other news, the EFF argues that a 1998 federal law violates the First Amendment, and the debate on the PREVAIL Act is set to limit challenges to patents."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://policyreview.info/articles/news/road-regulation-artificial-intelligence-brazilian-experience/1737", "title": "The road to regulation of artificial intelligence: the Brazilian experience", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Brazil is developing a comprehensive bill on AI regulation to address challenges and disparities in the country, including the impact of technology on income, race, gender, and territories. The bill is currently being examined by the Senate and adopts a rights-based approach alongside a risk-based framework, guaranteeing individual rights and providing mechanisms for enforcement. However, there are debates and disputes in the Brazilian Congress regarding the content of the bill, with some proposals removing chapters on human rights considerations. Future discussions should cover areas such as generative AI, transparency in data management, social media content moderation, and platform regulation. It is essential to involve public and democratic scrutiny in decision-making around AI regulation in Brazil."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/ai-is-changing-the-internet-again", "title": "\ud83c\udf2a\ufe0f AI is changing the internet AGAIN", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The New York Times vs. OpenAI lawsuit highlights the issue of AI companies using copyrighted content and personal data for training language models. OpenAI's argument of fair use is unlikely to hold up in court. GDPR requirements for legitimate interest and transparency are not being met by most companies. US platforms are implementing barriers against scraping, forcing individual agreements. Privacy and AI compliance will be a hot topic in 2024. The GDPR applies to training AI datasets, but many tech companies are ignoring it. OpenAI's claim of legitimate interest in processing personal data for training purposes is questionable. The three-part test for legitimate interest includes purpose, necessity, and balancing. The GDPR requires that individuals be notified and given the opportunity to opt out of their data being used to train AI models. Privacy professionals and regulators need to get involved."}

The meeting resulted in a report summarizing key themes and takeaways. Australia's Online Safety Act requires industry codes for certain online content, but some proposed codes were rejected, leading to the drafting of industry standards. {"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/five-big-questions-and-zero-predictions-for-the-u-s-state-privacy-landscape-in-2024/", "title": "Five Big Questions (and Zero Predictions) for the U.S. State Privacy Landscape in 2024", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "In 2023, state-level privacy laws in the United States saw significant developments, with the number of states with comprehensive privacy laws increasing from five to twelve. However, there is still no national framework governing personal data collection and use. California remains a key player in privacy legislation, while other states have taken unique approaches. The regulation of artificial intelligence (AI) systems is also becoming a priority for lawmakers, with California leading the way. Enforcement of privacy laws has been limited so far, but there are indications that enforcement actions may increase in 2024. The landscape of state privacy laws is constantly evolving, and further legislative developments can be expected in the coming year. Concerns about the constitutionality of state privacy laws have also arisen, with ongoing litigation challenging California's Age-Appropriate Design Code Act."}

A stakeholders workshop provided valuable input into improving the search engine and tools. {"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/survey-of-current-universal-opt-out-mechanisms/", "title": "Survey of Current Universal Opt-Out Mechanisms", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "This blog post discusses Universal Opt-Out Mechanisms (UOOMs) for targeted advertising and data sales. Seven state privacy laws require businesses to honor opt-out preferences transmitted through UOOMs. The Global Privacy Control (GPC) is the leading UOOM specification endorsed by California Attorney General. Policymakers should provide clarity and consistency in UOOM requirements and default settings. Privacy tools need guidance on how to configure UOOMs and ensure valid expression of individual intent. Different jurisdictions may fracture privacy rights and create conflicts. Policymakers must strive for clarity and consistency to shape consumer privacy standards."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/future-of-privacy-forum-and-leading-companies-release-best-practices-for-ai-in-employment-relationships/", "title": "Future of Privacy Forum and Leading Companies Release Best Practices for AI in Employment Relationships", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum, along with ADP, Indeed, LinkedIn, and Workday, released a guide with best practices for integrating AI tools into hiring and employment processes. The guide emphasizes the need for ethical and responsible use of AI, addressing issues like data privacy, non-discrimination, transparency, and human oversight. The responsible use of AI can lead to better job matches, increased access to diverse candidates, and opportunities for all members of the global workforce. Workday has been actively involved in promoting responsible AI and co-developed these best practices. The guide may be updated as regulations and standards evolve."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/eus-digital-services-act-just-became-applicable-outlining-ten-key-areas-of-interplay-with-the-gdpr/", "title": "EU\u2019s Digital Services Act Just Became Applicable: Outlining Ten Key Areas of Interplay with the GDPR", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The European Union's Digital Services Act (DSA) aims to regulate online intermediaries and improve online safety. It sets legal obligations for content removal, prohibits manipulative design and targeted online advertising, and requires audits of algorithms and assessments of systemic risks. Very large online platforms and search engines face stricter obligations, while smaller platforms still have significant requirements. The DSA interacts with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in areas such as intermediary services, applicability timelines, manipulative design, protection of minors, transparency, feed access, content removal, risk assessment, compliance function, and enforcement. Enforcement involves multiple authorities and coordination is crucial for consistent application. Overall, the DSA and GDPR seek to protect fundamental rights in the digital environment."}

Examples of dark patterns in cookie banners are discussed, along with the convoluted privacy settings on Facebook. The article emphasizes that privacy laws lack guidance on privacy UX, and a company's approach to it reflects its commitment to privacy. Privacy is crucial for tech companies in the age of data and AI, and brands must adapt to changing compliance standards."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08925", "title": "RandOhm: Mitigating Impedance Side-channel Attacks using Randomized Circuit Configurations. (arXiv:2401.08925v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Physical side-channel attacks exploit changes in current or voltage to compromise integrated circuits. Countermeasures like masking are inadequate against backscattered side-channel attacks, specifically impedance analysis. To address this, RandOhm proposes a defense mechanism using moving target defense and partial reconfiguration of FPGAs. By constantly randomizing circuit placement and routing, RandOhm mitigates information leakage through impedance and enhances IC security."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08984", "title": "A GAN-based data poisoning framework against anomaly detection in vertical federated learning. (arXiv:2401.08984v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Summary:\n- Vertical federated learning (VFL) allows commercial entities to collaboratively train a model while preserving data privacy.\n- A malicious participant can perform a poisoning attack to degrade the performance of the collaborative model.\n- The absence of access to the server-side top model is a challenge for the attacker.\n- A framework called P-GAN is introduced to address this challenge by training a surrogate target model and using GAN-based methods to produce adversarial perturbations.\n- An anomaly detection algorithm based on a deep auto-encoder (DAE) is developed to defend against VFL scenarios.\n- Extensive experiments are conducted to evaluate the efficacy of P-GAN and DAE and analyze influencing factors."}

IBM's quantum computers and Qiskit backend are utilized. The article analyzes success probabilities and resilience under different noise conditions, finding promising results even in the presence of maximum noise."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09027", "title": "Exact Homomorphic Encryption. (arXiv:2401.09027v1 [quant-ph])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "This article introduces Exact Homomorphic Encryption (EHE), a framework that enables exact computations on encrypted data using quantum gates. EHE utilizes invertible and noncommuting gates to ensure both encryption and decryption are exact and secure. The framework includes message encryption and computation encryption, both achieved through polynomial sets generated by quantum gates. EHE can be implemented on both quantum and traditional computing environments, offering hyper quantum-resilient security. It is seen as a tangible implementation of noncommutative cryptography."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09209", "title": "Username Squatting on Online Social Networks: A Study on X. (arXiv:2401.09209v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Researchers conducted a study on online social networks (OSNs) and found that thousands of squatted usernames, many likely to be bots, exist on OSN X. The study also discovered that squatted accounts are mentioned mistakenly in tweets and prioritized in the network's search recommendation algorithm. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09221", "title": "Multiple Subset Problem as an encryption scheme for communication. (arXiv:2401.09221v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Encryption using well-known mathematical problems like the subset sum problem (SSP) is popular for its computational difficulty and security. The multiple-subset problem (MSSP) is a variant of SSP that involves distributing items among bins to maximize total weight without exceeding bin capacity. We introduce a new problem where the sum of subsets from a set of sets must equal a specific integer. This problem is NP-complete but can be efficiently solved for known private keys using an algorithm that discards irrelevant sums. We present an encryption scheme based on MSSP, highlighting its unique applications in communication."}

The weights remain unchanged during training, ensuring secrecy and indistinguishability. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2112.08487", "title": "Differential Privacy in Aggregated Mobility Networks: Balancing Privacy and Utility. (arXiv:2112.08487v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The article proposes a privacy model based on differential privacy to protect user privacy when releasing aggregated location datasets. It injects Planar Laplace noise to user GPS points and uses a link-matching algorithm to transform them into a link representation. The noise level is determined using the Sparse Vector Mechanism, resulting in query responses that closely resemble the raw data. The model outperforms baseline models in terms of network length deviation. Overall, it presents an effective solution for preserving privacy while providing valuable insights."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01291", "title": "SoK: A Stratified Approach to Blockchain Decentralization. (arXiv:2211.01291v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Key ideas:\n1. Decentralization in blockchain systems is crucial for security.\n2. There is no agreed-upon definition of decentralization, causing debates.\n3. Researchers propose a systematic method to define and measure decentralization.\n4. Blockchain systems are analyzed in layers (hardware, software, network, consensus, etc.).\n5. The Minimum Decentralization Test (MDT) quickly assesses decentralization.\n6. Bitcoin's decentralization is analyzed using the methodology.\n7. Further research is needed to improve understanding and measurement of decentralization for better blockchain systems."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14822", "title": "MGTBench: Benchmarking Machine-Generated Text Detection. (arXiv:2303.14822v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Powerful language models like ChatGPT raise concerns about the detection of machine-generated texts (MGTs) and potential biases. Existing methods lack a comprehensive evaluation framework for MGT detection against large language models. A benchmark framework called MGTBench is proposed, showing effective detection methods with fewer training samples. Text attribution is also explored, and adversarial attacks highlight the need for more robust detection methods."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07735", "title": "Permutation Equivariance of Transformers and Its Applications. (arXiv:2304.07735v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Transformer-based models have shown great performance in deep learning, and they are robust to shuffling. This research proposes a broader concept of permutation equivariance, covering both inter- and intra-token permutation in neural networks. The property can be satisfied in most vanilla Transformer-based models without much adaptation. The study examines this property in state-of-the-art models like ViT, Bert, and GPT, and explores its potential applications in privacy-enhancing split learning and model authorization."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09666", "title": "A Smooth Binary Mechanism for Efficient Private Continual Observation. (arXiv:2306.09666v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The article discusses the problem of releasing private prefix sums in continuously evolving datasets. The binary mechanism is commonly used but has limitations in efficiency and noise variance. The authors propose a simple alternative that improves efficiency, reduces noise variance, and maintains a uniform noise distribution. Empirical evaluations show the superiority of their method over existing approaches."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.16149", "title": "A Novel DDPM-based Ensemble Approach for Energy Theft Detection in Smart Grids. (arXiv:2307.16149v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "This article discusses the problem of energy theft in smart grids and the need for effective detection methods. It introduces the Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM)-based ETD approach, which shows impressive performance on high-variance smart grid data. The article also proposes an ensemble method that combines reconstruction error and forecasting error to enhance the robustness of ETD methods. Overall, this research aims to mitigate the risks of energy theft and ensure the integrity of smart grids."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.06513", "title": "A Study of MEV Extraction Techniques on a First-Come-First-Served Blockchain. (arXiv:2308.06513v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The paper discusses Maximal Extractable Value (MEV) on blockchain networks, specifically focusing on its applicability to First-Come-First-Served (FCFS) blockchains like Algorand. It suggests that arbitrage MEV can be extracted through backruns on pending transactions in Algorand, but no latency optimizations were found. The paper also explores how network clogging attacks can be used for MEV extraction in FCFS networks. Further research is needed to understand MEV extraction in FCFS blockchains and develop optimization strategies."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.08821", "title": "Experimental quantum e-commerce. (arXiv:2308.08821v2 [quant-ph] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The study proposes a quantum e-commerce scheme that ensures information-theoretic security against attacks and shows resistance to imperfect devices. It achieves a signature rate of 0.82 times per second with maximum attenuation of 25 dB, offering a promising solution for secure e-commerce."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08230", "title": "A Duty to Forget, a Right to be Assured? Exposing Vulnerabilities in Machine Unlearning Services. (arXiv:2309.08230v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The right to be forgotten in MLaaS requires unlearning data, but retraining is difficult. Striking a balance between unlearning, utility, and security is crucial."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07958", "title": "Towards Causal Deep Learning for Vulnerability Detection. (arXiv:2310.07958v5 [cs.SE] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "Deep learning vulnerability detection struggles with robustness and generalization to out-of-distribution data, as the model learns non-robust features. The authors introduced causality with their CausalVul approach, using novel perturbations and causal learning algorithms to eliminate spurious features and improve accuracy, robustness, and generalization. CausalVul outperformed state-of-the-art models and datasets, showcasing the effectiveness of do-calculus-based causal learning in software engineering. (For further information and replication package, visit: https://figshare.com/s/0ffda320dcb96c249ef2)"}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.02102", "title": "Mitigating Data Injection Attacks on Federated Learning. (arXiv:2312.02102v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "A novel technique is proposed to detect and mitigate false data injection attacks in federated learning systems. It involves a local scheme implemented by the coordinating node, which periodically evaluates and ignores suspicious agents' data. The approach guarantees eventual detection and isolation of all attackers while maintaining trust in honest agents. Simulations show that the model recovers and converges to the truthful model when all attackers are detected and isolated."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.02708", "title": "Provable Adversarial Robustness for Group Equivariant Tasks: Graphs, Point Clouds, Molecules, and More. (arXiv:2312.02708v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-17", "summary": "The article proposes a new notion of adversarial robustness that considers task equivariance. It suggests two steps to achieve provable robustness: selecting a model aligned with task equivariances and certifying traditional adversarial robustness. To address the limitation of certification methods, the article introduces equivariance-preserving randomized smoothing. Architecture-specific graph edit distance certificates are also developed for isomorphism equivariant tasks. This contributes to a sound notion of robustness and lays the foundation for future research in robust and geometric machine learning."}

FreqFed proves to be effective in various domains without compromising the model's utility."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/uKSzxotix6ARBYijg/when-safety-is-dangerous-risks-of-an-indefinite-pause-on-ai", "title": "When safety is dangerous: risks of an indefinite pause on AI development, and call for realistic alternatives", "date": "2024-01-18", "summary": "Artificial Superintelligence (ASI) is expected to arrive in the next few decades, raising concerns and debates among AI experts and society. Some propose implementing an indefinite pause on AI research to reduce existential risks, but it poses challenges in terms of technical feasibility, perverse incentives, and political coordination. While an indefinite pause may temporarily reduce accident risks, it may not effectively reduce overall AI risks due to political and technological factors. Political risks include government coordination, non-participatory nations, and lack of enforcement power. Technological risks involve the rapid advancement of AI capabilities and the oversupply of computing hardware. The article suggests exploring alternative strategies to ensure safety and long-term outcomes in the age of AI."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/qpsmghAnyhmJescSk/could-poverty-interventions-in-the-us-be-cost-effective-for", "title": "Could poverty interventions in the US be cost-effective for global health?", "date": "2024-01-18", "summary": "- 5.3 million Americans live below global poverty line of $4 a day.\n- 18 million Americans live in deep poverty, making under 50% of the bare subsistence poverty line.\n- Income level significantly affects life expectancy, with a 14.6-year gap between the richest and poorest individuals.\n- Policy interventions in the US may be as cost-effective as direct health interventions in low-income countries.\n- Existing welfare programs in the US have a large budget, making them potential targets for improvement or expansion.\n- Improving or expanding existing programs could have a significant impact on poverty and health in the US.\n- OpenPhil explored this area of research 10 years ago, but it hasn't been actively pursued since."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/8zzmZD5vsEkuDe24m/when-does-altruism-strengthen-altruism", "title": "When Does Altruism Strengthen Altruism?", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Joey Savoie believes that being altruistic in small actions can increase the likelihood of making important altruistic choices. Motivation differs for each person, and both approaches of conserving resources for important actions or engaging in smaller actions have their own merits and drawbacks. Savoie explains this through an analogy of carrying heavy things. He acknowledges that prioritization is a challenge, but considering the growth of altruistic \"muscles\" can help in making sustainable choices. Exploring activities to increase the drive to help others is also beneficial, but it's important to be cautious of becoming cause-specific. Savoie suggests focusing on general altruistic exercises as a starting point. The concept of becoming stronger in altruism deserves further exploration."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/jkcv43Ts9xEXuo6m4/what-is-more-important-blood-platelet-plasma-donation-or", "title": "What Is More Important - Blood/Platelet/Plasma Donation Or Veganism?", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Donating blood is important, but deciding to sacrifice veganism is personal. Plant-based sources of iron can help raise levels. Prioritize health and consult with a healthcare professional. Donating is voluntary, explore other ways to contribute. The choice is yours, consult a professional and follow your values."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/jdCXyhp8vSjHxbTLT/a-longtermist-case-for-directed-panspermia", "title": "A longtermist case for directed panspermia", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Longtermism advocates evaluating actions based on their impact on future beings. \"Biotic hedge\" involves spreading life to other planets to protect against Earth's extinction. Directed panspermia is intentional seeding of life in the galaxy, motivated by the sun's future expansion. Objections include potential irreversible harm. The trolley problem analogy supports taking action to save morally relevant beings. Moral value extends to future beings and all species. Uncertainty about directed panspermia's consequence does not absolve responsibility. Scientific advancements and existential risks strengthen the case for directed panspermia. From a longtermist perspective, it is morally permissible and has implications for space exploration."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/CEr5ugg5KmnZzLoPH/question-for-longtermism", "title": "Question for longtermism", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Longtermism argues that moral value should be based on the impact on future individuals. Parfit's book explores actions that influence the number of persons. Abortion may be permissible based on anticipated suffering. Longtermism assigns equal moral value to future and existing persons. An ethical dilemma arises when existing individuals' well-being conflicts with potential persons. Feedback is requested on how longtermism addresses this dilemma."}

It involves a two-step process where the agent takes an action and then observes the state of a shutdown button. The hope is that others will build upon this proposal to tackle more complex problems and failure modes."}
