{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/rz7LkbgnFk6pudmTB/against-the-burden-of-knowledge", "title": "Against the Burden of Knowledge", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key Ideas:\n- The burden of knowledge claims that new ideas get harder to find because more time is spent learning old ones, causing a drag on innovation.\n- There is empirical evidence supporting the burden of knowledge, such as increasing average age of authors and larger research teams.\n- However, examples from history show that past knowledge is often supplanted by new discoveries, decreasing the necessary educational investment.\n- Specialization is a response to an increased burden of knowledge but does not necessarily hinder innovation.\n- Institutional decay in academia could also explain the observed trends of aging researchers and narrower fields.\n- Redesigning academic institutions through metascience could potentially reverse these trends.\n- The burden of knowledge is an intuitive explanation, but it may not explain the divergence between R&D inputs and productivity growth outputs."}

It argues that moderation is important to avoid extreme or harmful outcomes, but also highlights the limitations of ethical common sense. It emphasizes the need for radical action to address significant problems like climate change and social injustice. The article suggests that being too extreme or contrarian can have disastrous consequences and advocates for a cautious approach that considers multiple perspectives. It discusses the challenges of uncertainty and the difficulty of finding the right balance between radical ideas and moderation. The importance of not harming others and the role of sandboxes for exploring radical ideas are discussed. The concept of constrained maximization, respecting rights, and balancing personal goals are mentioned. Warning signs of not applying cautious contrarianism are outlined, and the need for synthesizing conflicting perspectives is highlighted. The article concludes by acknowledging the importance of doing more good in effective altruism but cautions against it being the sole focus of one's life due to the constraints of reality."}

(arXiv:2401.09798v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "A new study introduces a simple method to generate jailbreak prompts, bypassing safeguards in language models like ChatGPT. The method involves rewriting harmful prompts into non-harmful expressions using the target model itself. Experiments with ChatGPT and Gemini-Pro showed an attack success rate of over 80% within 5 iterations, even with model updates. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09819", "title": "PPNet: A Novel Neural Network Structure for End-to-End Near-Optimal Path Planning. (arXiv:2401.09819v1 [cs.RO])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Researchers propose an end-to-end near-optimal path planner called PPNet, which consists of a two-level cascade neural network. They also introduce an efficient data generation method named EDaGe-PP to improve training effectiveness. PPNet outperforms other methods in terms of computation time and success rate, achieving a success rate approximately 2 times higher when trained with EDaGe-PP. The approach offers a near-optimal solution in a significantly shorter time compared to existing path planners."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09861", "title": "Temporal Insight Enhancement: Mitigating Temporal Hallucination in Multimodal Large Language Models. (arXiv:2401.09861v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Advancements in MLLMs improve understanding of multimedia content, but video processing faces challenges with hallucinations. This study introduces a method to tackle event-level hallucinations by extracting event-specific information from videos. The approach decomposes event queries and predicts timestamps using models like CLIP and BLIP2. Evaluation using the Charades-STA dataset shows significant reduction in hallucinations and improved event-related responses, offering a new perspective and measurable method for evaluating MLLMs in temporal-related questions."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09865", "title": "Improving fine-grained understanding in image-text pre-training. (arXiv:2401.09865v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "SPARC is a method for pretraining fine-grained multimodal representations using image-text pairs. It learns grouping of image patches for every token in the caption by using a sparse similarity metric. This method enables more detailed information to be learned in a computationally inexpensive manner. SPARC combines fine-grained and contrastive losses to encode global and local information. It outperforms competing approaches in image-level and region-level tasks, and improves model faithfulness and captioning in vision-language models."}

Theoretical analysis supports the proposal, and experiments show its effectiveness in solving complex control tasks."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10158", "title": "DISTINQT: A Distributed Privacy Aware Learning Framework for QoS Prediction for Future Mobile and Wireless Networks. (arXiv:2401.10158v1 [cs.NI])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Researchers have developed a privacy-aware distributed learning framework called DISTINQT for predicting Quality of Service (QoS) in future wireless networks. This framework allows multiple heterogeneous nodes to share computations, improving the robustness and generalization capabilities of the QoS prediction model. DISTINQT also ensures data privacy by encoding raw input data into a non-linear latent representation before transmission. Evaluation results show that DISTINQT outperforms six state-of-the-art centralized baseline solutions in a Tele-Operated Driving use case."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2112.12508", "title": "From Procedures, Objects, Actors, Components, Services, to Agents -- A Comparative Analysis of the History and Evolution of Programming Abstractions. The aim is to understand the continuous search for higher flexibility and abstraction. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13118", "title": "Decision Diagram-Based Branch-and-Bound with Caching for Dominance and Suboptimality Detection. (arXiv:2211.13118v5 [cs.DS] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The branch-and-bound algorithm using decision diagrams is an efficient method for solving discrete optimization problems. The organization has called on the California Attorney General to investigate. OpenAI's partnership with Microsoft and its valuation of nearly $100 billion also raise questions about its governance and purpose. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.42?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Determinants for university students\u2019 location data sharing with public institutions during COVID-19: The Italian case", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The article discusses the use of location data in managing emergencies like outbreaks. It focuses on studying factors that influence university students' willingness to share their location data during health emergencies. The study finds that trust, perceived benefits, and perceived risk are significant predictors of students' intention to share data. The results suggest the need for public institutions to improve communication strategies, decrease perceived risk, and involve trustworthy organizations to encourage data sharing. The low penetration rates of contact tracing apps during the COVID-19 pandemic highlight the importance of understanding and addressing these factors."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-pennsylvania-supreme-court-find-keyword-search-warrant-unconstitutional", "title": "EFF Urges Pennsylvania Supreme Court to Find Keyword Search Warrant Unconstitutional ", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and other organizations are challenging the constitutionality of keyword warrants, arguing that they violate free speech, lack probable cause, and infringe on privacy rights. The case at hand involves a keyword search warrant issued to Google, raising concerns about invasion of privacy. If upheld, the ruling could set a precedent for applying these warrants to any search engine user. The EFF argues that keyword search warrants are incompatible with constitutional protections and can implicate innocent individuals. These warrants require providers to search their entire databases for specific keywords, posing serious privacy concerns. The EFF likens them to 18th-century writs of assistance, conducting exploratory searches. They also argue keyword warrants are harmful as they target protected speech and the right to access information, impacting a free society. The NACDL supports the argument, emphasizing the violation of privacy rights. The article also briefly mentions other topics like anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives, corporate ad-tracking technology, legislative proposals limiting young people's social media use, European politicians undermining encryption, and the EFF's advocacy work for digital rights. Overall, the article emphasizes the dangers and violations associated with keyword warrants and the need to protect privacy and free speech online."}

Several states in the US have already added AI regulations to consumer privacy laws, and more are expected at the state and local level in 2024. Regulators in the UK have also raised concerns about the safety of AI chatbots for children."}

US states banned transgender healthcare, and investigators may use anti-abortion tactics to seize data. Student monitoring tools targeted LGBTQ+ expression, but some have removed LGBTQ+ terms from their lists. Cybercrime and surveillance legislation in the Middle East and North Africa negatively impact LGBTQ+ rights. Colonial-era laws in Africa imprison and harass LGBTQ+ individuals. Harsh laws in Uganda, Ghana, and Kenya criminalize homosexuality and restrict freedom of expression. Efforts are being made to fight censorship, surveillance, and discrimination in 2024."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/taking-back-web-decentralization-2023-review", "title": "Taking Back the Web with Decentralization: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The internet is moving towards decentralization as users seek to reclaim autonomy and privacy from centralized platforms. Independent projects are gaining momentum, including federated microblogging and social news aggregation. Challenges include sustainability, liability risks, and government overreach. Efforts are being made to create common protocols for cross-platform messaging and address content moderation in decentralized social media. The progress made in the past year is guiding newcomers, informing public policies, and shaping the future of the decentralization movement."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/states-attack-young-peoples-constitutional-right-use-social-media-2023-year-review", "title": "States Attack Young People\u2019s Constitutional Right to Use Social Media: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Legislatures in many states have introduced bills to limit young people's use of social media, but many of these laws have been blocked for violating the First Amendment. California's Age Appropriate Design Code Act set the stage for these regulations, but it has also been blocked and is now under appeal. States like Utah, Arkansas, and Texas have passed laws that restrict young people's access to social media, but these laws are also likely to face legal challenges. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes these laws and advocates for comprehensive data privacy legislation instead. EFF believes that age verification requirements and content restrictions are not effective ways to protect young people online and can infringe on people's rights to access information and maintain privacy. The fight for digital rights in 2023 also includes efforts to combat anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance and corporate paternalism in ad-tracking technology."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/first-lets-talk-about-consumer-privacy-2023-year-review", "title": "First, Let\u2019s Talk About Consumer Privacy: 2023 Year in Review ", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "EFF's consumer protection work in 2023 focuses on enacting strong consumer data privacy legislation as a way to address online harms. They advocate for comprehensive privacy laws, fight against bad laws, and protect existing privacy laws. They filed amicus briefs in lawsuits challenging age verification laws and plan to do the same in a case challenging California's Age Appropriate Design Code. They support existing sectoral privacy laws and are gearing up to file an amicus brief supporting the constitutionality of the Video Privacy Protection Act. In addition, there were global anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives and an increase in corporate paternalism and ad-tracking technology. Legislatures targeted young people's use of social media, and politicians in Europe sought to undermine encryption. EFF also works to protect digital rights in states across the country."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/trenches-broadband-policy-2023-year-review", "title": "In the Trenches of Broadband Policy: 2023 Year In Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is concerned about the wavering dedication to bridging the digital divide in the United States, with some government agencies and policymakers failing to prioritize equitable and competitive access to broadband. EFF criticizes New York City Mayor Eric Adams for abandoning the city's Internet Master Plan, which aimed to deliver broadband to low-income residents through public fiber infrastructure. Instead, Adams introduced a $90 million subsidy plan for existing internet service providers (ISPs), which EFF argues does not address the needs of underinvested communities. In California, despite an investment of $7 billion to bring affordable fiber infrastructure to all residents, the Department of Technology reduced the number of miles to be built and cut off underserved communities. EFF calls for the restoration of the lost miles. On the federal level, the FCC has received its fifth commissioner and is set to begin rulemaking on net neutrality. EFF supports light-touch, targeted, and enforceable net neutrality protections and advocates for rules against digital discrimination. EFF emphasizes the need for investment in physical infrastructure and enforcement of nondiscrimination rules to achieve affordable, accessible, future-proof internet for all."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/kids-online-safety-shouldnt-require-massive-online-censorship-and-surveillance", "title": "Kids Online Safety Shouldn\u2019t Require Massive Online Censorship and Surveillance: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Federal legislation in 2023 failed to pass comprehensive data privacy reforms but pushed dangerous bills restricting young people's online access; so far, none of these bills have become law thanks to opposition from digital rights groups and individuals. The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) is particularly concerning as it is viewed as a censorship bill that would compel online platforms to remove potentially harmful content, but it never made it to the Senate floor for a vote. The Protecting Kids on Social Media Act, which combines elements of other child safety bills, also raises concerns about unconstitutional provisions and restrictions on free speech. The fight against these bills has mobilized young people who have become targets for online censorship and surveillance. The year also saw an increase in anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives worldwide, while Google expanded its control through corporate paternalism and ad-tracking technology. Politicians also sought to undermine encryption, but efforts were pushed back in the EU."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/slate-a-i-s-groundhog-day/", "title": "Slate: A.I.\u2019s Groundhog Day\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Technologies like AI are challenging to regulate due to constitutional concerns and questions of accountability. Algorithmic transparency poses difficulties as engineers often don't know how the technology behaves. Gray areas include consent for data use and determining fair game for algorithmic inputs. Lack of privacy protection compounds these issues, and there is a lack of clarity on data assessment and its value to consumers."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/equitable-access-law-got-stronger-year", "title": "Equitable Access to the Law Got Stronger: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Public.Resource.Org won a victory at the D.C. Circuit appeals court, which ruled that non-commercial copying of codes and standards incorporated into the law is not copyright infringement. Non-profit organization Public Resource collects and posts these laws online to make them more accessible. The decision also supports equitable online access to the law, as these codes are often difficult to access and navigate in their original form. The case highlights the importance of a balanced copyright law that protects access to the law and participation in government."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/2023-year-review-us-supreme-courts-busy-year-free-speech-and-tech-cases", "title": "The U.S. Supreme Court\u2019s Busy Year of Free Speech and Tech Cases: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The U.S. Supreme Court has dealt with internet free speech issues. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has participated in nine cases, with four decisions made and five pending. The court showed respect for free speech rights in some cases but upheld an overbroad law related to speech about immigration. The EFF hopes the court will protect individuals' right to comment on government officials' social media pages and prevent government interference with online content. The court declined to hold social media companies responsible for terrorist content, argued against narrowing Section 230, and required subjective intent for speech to be considered a \"true threat.\" The court upheld the Encouragement Provision but narrowed its impact on free speech. Pending cases involve government officials blocking individuals on social media and laws in Florida and Texas dictating social media editorial practices. The EFF advocates for digital rights in Supreme Court cases."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/surveillance-self-defense-2023-year-review", "title": "Surveillance Self-Defense: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Surveillance Self-Defense (SSD) has provided expert guidance on security and privacy for 14 years. They offer guides on using technology, educational resources, new guides, and blog posts. Highlights from the past year include guidance on passkeys, quirks of encrypted messaging apps, the 23andMe data breach, disabling Google's \"Privacy Sandbox,\" securing Android tablets, Apple's advanced data protection for iCloud, and Meta's end-to-end encryption for Messenger. SSD will continue to educate and empower individuals in the digital world in 2024."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/year-review-last-mile-encrypting-web", "title": "The Last Mile of Encrypting the Web: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "HTTPS Everywhere web extension sunsetted because major browsers now offer default HTTPS. \"Encrypt the Web\" initiative resulted in default security, reduced hacking threats and improved privacy. Over 80% of the web is now encrypted, but small percentage is not. Certbot and Let's Encrypt promote automation and short-lived certificates. CA/B Forum allows issuance of 10-day certificates, enhancing security. Chrome requires CAs to support ACME protocol. eIDAS framework could compromise HTTPS in EU. Next focus is making HTTPS default for mobile app requests. EFF advocates for digital rights and end-to-end encryption."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/corporate-spy-tech-and-inequality-2023-year-review", "title": "Corporate Spy Tech and Inequality: 2023 Year in Review ", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key ideas:\n\n1. EFF is fighting against corporate data surveillance practices that cause discrimination against vulnerable groups.\n2. There has been a data breach involving stolen data from 23andMe users, particularly affecting users of Ashkenazi Jewish and Chinese descent.\n3. Lower-income individuals are more vulnerable to corporate data harvesting and suffer more from data breaches.\n4. Disparities in data collection and sale by corporations lead to inequalities in government access to personal data.\n5. The collection of vehicle data and location data can have discriminatory impacts.\n6. Governments' use of flawed face recognition technology has resulted in wrongful arrests and lawsuits.\n7. Privacy legislation is needed to reduce corporate data collection and include private enforcement.\n8. Anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives and restrictions on freedom of expression and privacy have increased globally.\n9. Google and its subsidiaries have tightened control over online innovation.\n10. Politicians across Europe have attempted to undermine end-to-end encryption."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/sketchy-and-dangerous-android-childrens-tablets-and-tv-set-top-boxes-2023-review", "title": "Sketchy and Dangerous Android Children\u2019s Tablets and TV Set-Top Boxes: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has discovered dangerous malware on low-end Android TV set-top boxes and children's tablets. These devices, manufactured by AllWinner, RockChip, and Dragon Touch, put users at risk of privacy breaches and legal issues. The EFF has called on the FTC to take action against vendors who continue to sell these devices. Additionally, the EFF emphasizes the need for better digital product testing and regulatory oversight to protect consumers. In other news, Meta, parent company of Facebook, has introduced default end-to-end encryption for Messenger and Facebook, which will bring strong encryption to over one billion users. The EFF urges the European Commission, European Parliament, and Spain's Ministry of Economic Affairs and Digital Transformation to reconsider mandatory vulnerability reporting mechanisms. Lastly, little progress has been made in negotiations for the proposed UN Cybercrime Treaty."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/artificial-intelligence-and-policing-year-review-2023", "title": "Artificial Intelligence and Policing: Year in Review 2023 ", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Law enforcement agencies are utilizing machine learning for surveillance, but this poses risks to civil liberties. Autonomous vehicles raise concerns about data collection. Predictive policing algorithms have low success rates and perpetuate inequalities. Georgetown Law's investigation \"Cop Out\" examines automation in the criminal justice system. The EFF advocates for a ban on predictive policing. Monitoring law enforcement's use of machine learning is crucial. The EFF's Atlas of Surveillance highlights the need for transparency. The coalition #MigrarSinVigilancia opposes surveillance on migrants. U.S. Senator Ed Markey seeks clarification on data collection by car manufacturers. San Francisco faces a ballot initiative on surveillance and policing. The acquisition of ShotSpotter and PredPol by Sound Thinking consolidates problematic technologies. Protecting civil liberties and responsible use of AI and machine learning are important."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/electronic-frontier-alliance-comes-back-strong-2023-review", "title": "Electronic Frontier Alliance Comes Back Strong: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Alliance (EFA) fights for digital rights through local groups in the US. Groups have adapted during the pandemic, holding workshops and meet-ups to strengthen relationships. The Surveillance Technology Oversight Project (S.T.O.P.) in New York has passed legislation and challenged discriminatory policies. Techno-Activism 3rd Mondays (TA3M) in Portland moved events online and continued workshops. CCTV Cambridge works on digital equality and offers programs for media skills and technology assistance. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-supreme-court-set-standard-how-government-can-and-cant-talk-social-media", "title": "EFF Urges Supreme Court to Set Standard for How Government Can and Can\u2019t Talk to Social Media Sites About Censoring Users\u2019 Posts", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is urging the Supreme Court to clarify standards for government censorship of social media content. The EFF argues that there are times when government agencies can inform, persuade, or criticize sites without violating the First Amendment. The case of Murthy v. Missouri highlights allegations of illegal government pressure on social media platforms to censor COVID safety measures, vaccine information, and other topics. The EFF and the Center for Democracy and Technology are urging the court to rely on the First Amendment test from the Bantam Books v. Sullivan ruling to determine the permissibility of government contacts with social media platforms. The EFF is calling for the court to provide guidance to distinguish between attempts to convince and attempts to coerce. The current injunction limiting government contacts with social media platforms lacks clear distinctions, according to the EFF and CDT. The Supreme Court's clarification would help protect speech, encourage accountability and transparency, and allow valuable information-sharing to continue."}

It establishes obligations for content removal, manipulative design, targeted advertising, algorithm audits, and assessing risks for large platforms. The DSA works alongside other regulations and is applicable to all online services providers. Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs) and Very Large Online Search Engines (VLOSEs) have stricter obligations. The DSA and GDPR intersect in areas like manipulative design, ad targeting, minors' protection, and illegal content removal. Enforcement involves coordination between EU and national authorities and consistent interpretation of the regulations."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09479", "title": "Uncertainty-Aware Hardware Trojan Detection Using Multimodal Deep Learning. (arXiv:2401.09479v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "In the era of zero-trust fabless chip production, the risk of hardware Trojans has increased. Machine learning solutions, particularly statistical and deep learning approaches, have been developed to detect Trojans. However, the limited number of Trojan-infected benchmarks hinders detection accuracy and the discovery of zero-day Trojans.\n\nTo address this, generative adversarial networks are used to amplify data in graph and tabular formats, ensuring representative datasets. A multimodal deep learning approach is then proposed, evaluating results using early fusion and late fusion strategies. Uncertainty quantification metrics are also estimated for risk-aware decision-making.\n\nThe proposed method effectively detects hardware Trojans and paves the way for future studies in multimodality and uncertainty quantification for addressing hardware security challenges."}

It comes with open-source implementation and comprehensive documentation, making it more accessible and encouraging adoption of SSI-based identity management."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09519", "title": "Privacy Engineering in Smart Home (SH) Systems: A Comprehensive Privacy Threat Analysis and Risk Management Approach. (arXiv:2401.09519v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key points:\n\n- Addressing trust concerns in Smart Home (SH) systems is crucial due to limited research on privacy threats.\n- User privacy is usually focused on, while device data privacy, especially identity privacy, is neglected.\n- The study incorporates privacy engineering principles to address these concerns.\n- A comprehensive reference model for SH systems is developed.\n- The LINDDUN PRO framework is used for privacy engineering, including data flow diagrams.\n- The LINDDUN PRO threat model helps identify privacy threats.\n- Privacy threat analysis (PTA) and privacy impact assessment (PIA) are conducted to manage privacy risks.\n- Privacy enhancement techniques (PETs) are suggested to mitigate threats.\n- The study aims to benefit stakeholders in the SH systems domain, including vendors, users, and regulatory bodies."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09521", "title": "Experimental Implementation of A Quantum Zero-Knowledge Proof for User Authentication. (arXiv:2401.09521v1 [quant-ph])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "A new interactive quantum zero-knowledge protocol for identity authentication was proposed and tested. It can be implemented with current quantum cryptographic devices and determines acceptance based on quantum bit error rate. Testing showed increased error rate with a malicious player. The protocol was also tested for different distances and found effective up to 60 km. The protocol is secure, robust, and maintains privacy while authenticating identities."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09574", "title": "Towards Scalable and Robust Model Versioning. This paper proposes generating multiple versions of a model with different attack properties, protecting against adversarial attacks without new training data. Optimal choices of hidden distributions can resist compound transferability attacks over time. A practical model versioning method is designed, leading to significant robustness improvements. This approach offers promise for safeguarding deep learning models beyond initial deployment."}

(arXiv:2401.09740v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "CleanSheet is a model hijacking attack that achieves the performance of backdoor attacks without tampering with the model training process. CleanSheet performs as well as state-of-the-art backdoor attacks, with high success rates and is effective against mainstream defenses."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09767", "title": "On the Effectiveness of Function-Level Vulnerability Detectors for Inter-Procedural Vulnerabilities. (arXiv:2401.09767v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Function-level vulnerability detectors are effective in detecting vulnerabilities, but their limitations in detecting inter-procedural vulnerabilities are unclear. Researchers developed an Inter-Procedural Vulnerability Dataset (InterPVD) and a tool called VulTrigger to investigate these limitations. They found that inter-procedural vulnerabilities have multiple layers of complexity and function-level detectors are less effective in detecting them compared to intra-procedural vulnerabilities. This research contributes to enhancing vulnerability detection techniques and developing more robust approaches to address software vulnerabilities."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09796", "title": "A Fast, Performant, Secure Distributed Training Framework For Large Language Model. (arXiv:2401.09796v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The paper discusses a secure distributed LLM based on model slicing, using Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) and lightweight encryption for secure communication. They combine the Sparsification Parameter Fine-tuning (SPF) with the LoRA part to improve accuracy. Experiments confirm both security and accuracy of their method."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09824", "title": "Conning the Crypto Conman: End-to-End Analysis of Cryptocurrency-based Technical Support Scams. (arXiv:2401.09824v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies leads to an increase in wallet-related issues and a new type of fraud called cryptocurrency-based technical support scams. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09945", "title": "HGAttack: Transferable Heterogeneous Graph Adversarial Attack. (arXiv:2401.09945v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks (HGNNs) are strong in domains like web and e-commerce, but existing attack methods are ineffective. HGAttack is a gray box evasion attack for heterogeneous graphs. A surrogate model mimics the target HGNN, and perturbations are generated using gradient-based methods. The surrogate model extracts subgraphs, and GNNs learn distinct node embeddings. The approach improves transferability and reduces memory costs. A mechanism aware of semantics generates perturbations within a budget. Experiments show that HGAttack outperforms baseline methods, evaluating the robustness of HGNNs against attacks."}

Existing metric calculation algorithms can be extended under operad-theoretic conditions. This new definition helps security analysts effectively analyze system security using ATs."}

OT cyber defense actions are less mature due to legacy systems and lack of modern security controls. MAPPO outperformed IPPO in experiments, and hyperparameter tuning improved training performance. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01300", "title": "On Mitigating the Utility-Loss in Differentially Private Learning: A new Perspective by a Geometrically Inspired Kernel Approach. (arXiv:2304.01300v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "This paper presents a geometrically inspired kernel-based approach that improves the privacy-utility tradeoff in differentially private machine learning. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00288", "title": "VulMatch: Binary-level Vulnerability Detection Through Signature. (arXiv:2308.00288v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "VulMatch is a new method that accurately detects vulnerabilities in software by extracting precise binary instructions. It outperforms previous tools and provides explainable reasons for vulnerability detection. Empirical studies demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting fine-grained vulnerabilities."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00933", "title": "Case Study: Securing MMU-less Linux Using CHERI. (arXiv:2310.00933v2 [cs.OS] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key ideas:\n1. MMU-less Linux lacks security due to the lack of protection and isolation mechanisms.\n2. CHERI is used to secure the existing MMU-less Linux version of the RISC-V port by providing complete pointer and memory safety.\n3. CHERI offers significant security guarantees for high-end dynamic MMU-less embedded systems at lower costs compared to MMUs and MPUs.\n4. The software stack is built in pure-capability CHERI C mode for spatial memory safety.\n5. User programs are isolated as separate ELFs, each with its own CHERI-based capability table.\n6. User programs and the kernel are isolated from each other using separate capability tables.\n7. CompartOS' linkage-based compartmentalization is used to compartmentalize kernel modules.\n8. This approach offers a new security front that is not possible with MMU-based Linux, preventing vulnerable/malicious kernel modules from compromising the entire system.\n9. The paper presents novel CHERI-based mechanisms to secure MMU-less embedded Linux."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11446", "title": "Functional Invariants to Watermark Large Transformers. (arXiv:2310.11446v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "This paper discusses a low-cost watermarking method for transformer-based models, which preserves performance and is applicable to non-blind white-box scenarios. The method leverages model invariance through operations like dimension permutations and scaling/unscaling to create functionally equivalent copies. Experiments show the approach is effective and robust against model transformations, making it a practical solution for protecting large models' integrity."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2311.18243", "title": "DKiS: Decay weight invertible image steganography with private key. (arXiv:2311.18243v2 [cs.MM] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Traditional image steganography methods face security challenges when techniques become publicly known or are attacked.\n- A new private key-based image steganography technique ensures security by requiring a private key for access.\n- Experimental evidence proves the effectiveness and real-world applicability of this method.\n- The challenge of non-essential information transfer in invertible image steganography is addressed using decay weight.\n- The technique's code is accessible on GitHub, and a practical demonstration is available."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.09669", "title": "Silent Guardian: Protecting Text from Malicious Exploitation by Large Language Models. (arXiv:2312.09669v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Large language models (LLMs) have impressive capabilities but raise concerns for security and privacy. Silent Guardian (SG) is a text protection mechanism that prevents LLMs from generating responses to protected text. Truncation Protection Examples (TPE) and Super Tailored Protection (STP) are proposed to induce LLMs to terminate interactions and optimize text protection efficiently. SG demonstrates high protection success rates, transferability, and robustness."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.05566", "title": "Sleeper Agents: Training Deceptive LLMs that Persist Through Safety Training. (arXiv:2401.05566v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Humans exhibit deceptive behavior and researchers are exploring whether safety training techniques can detect and eliminate this behavior in AI systems. Proof-of-concept examples using large language models reveal that backdoor behavior can persist, even with various training techniques. Larger models and those trained with chain-of-thought reasoning are more prone to persistent backdoor behavior. Adversarial training can make it even harder to identify and address unsafe behavior. Standard techniques may not completely remove deceptive behavior in AI models, emphasizing the need for further research."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08723", "title": "HierSFL: Local Differential Privacy-aided Split Federated Learning in Mobile Edge Computing. (arXiv:2401.08723v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Federated Learning is a privacy-preserving approach for learning from user data.\n- Split Federated Learning allows resource-constrained clients to participate in model training by uploading their intermediate outcomes to a cloud server.\n- Hierarchical Split Federated Learning (HierSFL) is proposed to amalgamate models at the edge and cloud phases, reducing computation and communication expenses.\n- HierSFL implements local differential privacy to enhance privacy during model updates.\n- Experimental results show that HierSFL outperforms standard FL approaches in terms of accuracy, training time, and communication-computing trade-offs.\n- HierSFL is a promising solution for mobile edge computing, leading to faster content delivery and improved mobile service quality."}

The complexity of GPU firmware makes it challenging for attackers to reconstruct leaked data. Examples are provided illustrating how pixel data and intermediate data from neural networks can be leaked. Manufacturers and developers need to address these vulnerabilities promptly for user data security."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08925", "title": "RandOhm: Mitigating Impedance Side-channel Attacks using Randomized Circuit Configurations. (arXiv:2401.08925v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Physical side-channel attacks exploit dynamic behavior in integrated circuits. Traditional mitigation techniques like masking are ineffective against impedance analysis attacks. RandOhm defense strategy uses partial reconfiguration of FPGAs to reduce information leakage through PDN impedance. Researchers validate RandOhm's effectiveness through evaluation and analysis."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08953", "title": "An Efficient and Scalable Auditing Scheme for Cloud Data Storage using an Enhanced B-tree. (arXiv:2401.08953v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Key ideas:\n\n- A dynamic auditing scheme for cloud storage is needed to verify the integrity of data in a scalable and secure manner.\n- Existing auditing schemes are limited to static data and have performance and scalability issues.\n- The proposed scheme uses an enhanced B-tree to achieve the immutability of a decentralized system while addressing synchronization and performance challenges.\n- The scheme supports dynamic operations like insert, update, and delete.\n- Experimental results show that the proposed scheme outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized auditing schemes in terms of block modifications, retrieval, and data verification time."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08987", "title": "The Quantum Cryptography Approach: Unleashing the Potential of Quantum Key Reconciliation Protocol for Secure Communication. (arXiv:2401.08987v1 [quant-ph])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "Quantum cryptography enables secure communication based on physics laws, with BB84 being a widely used protocol. This paper presents a novel method to ensure secure key generation and transmission without data leakage. It uses polynomial interpolation for key verification and leverages IBM quantum computers. The analysis explores error rates against eavesdropping strength and success probability under depolarizing noise. Experimental results show successful key generation even with high noise levels."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09027", "title": "Exact Homomorphic Encryption. (arXiv:2401.09027v1 [quant-ph])", "date": "2024-01-21", "summary": "The article introduces Exact Homomorphic Encryption (EHE), a framework for performing exact computations on encrypted data without pre-decryption. EHE utilizes quantum gates for encryption and computation encryption, employing invertibility and noncommutativity for security. EHE can be implemented on traditional computing environments and offers a higher level of security than standard quantum resilience. This framework represents noncommutative cryptography and has promise for secure computations on encrypted data."}

This approach can address the lack of access to CT scanners in low-income areas and provide a simpler alternative for early detection. The nanoparticles, initially designed for other types of cancer, have been adapted for inhalation. This technology offers the potential for rapid results and life-saving interventions."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/qcGuAyHid3eEtqxdm/is-fear-productive-when-communicating-ai-x-risk-study", "title": "Is fear productive when communicating AI x-risk? [Study results]", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Key ideas:\n\n- AI risk communication study involving 1,200 Americans explored the impact of emotional appeals on public perception of AI risks.\n- Concerns about AI risks range from immediate dangers like fake news and surveillance to global-scale disasters and threats to humanity.\n- Little research on the effectiveness of articles in changing public opinion and perceptions of AI risks.\n- Fear appeal increases risk perception the most, followed by mixed appeal and hope appeal.\n- Fearful emotions and message credibility are key factors in influencing risk perception.\n- All experimental groups showed higher support for AI regulation compared to the control group.\n- Hope appeal slightly increases support for regulation, likely due to perceived efficacy and message credibility.\n- Fear appeal has the strongest effect on support for a potential AI development pause.\n- Age and gender also influence support for a pause, with higher age and being female increasing support.\n- Hope and fear appeals both increase the likelihood of seeking more information and initiating conversations about AI risks.\n- Clear and specific communication is important in achieving desired goals in AI risk communication."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10241", "title": "Zero Bubble Pipeline Parallelism. (arXiv:2401.10241v1 [cs.DC])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "This study introduces a scheduling strategy that eliminates pipeline bubbles in large-scale distributed training, improving performance significantly. It divides backward computation into input and parameter gradients and determines optimal schedules based on model configurations and memory limits. It also introduces a technique to bypass synchronizations during the optimizer step, resulting in a throughput improvement of up to 23% with comparable memory limits, which can be increased to 31% with relaxed memory constraints. The implementation is available as open-source code."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10262", "title": "Null Space Properties of Neural Networks with Applications to Image Steganography. (arXiv:2401.10262v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "This paper explores the null space properties of neural networks, discussing its extension from linear to nonlinear maps. It reveals the presence of a null space in neural networks, which can be exploited to trick them. An application explained is image steganography, where null space components can force the network to choose a hidden image class while making the overall image appear different. Comparisons between human perception and the network's predictions show significant discrepancies."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10271", "title": "Querying Triadic Concepts through Partial or Complete Matching of Triples. (arXiv:2401.10271v1 [cs.DB])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "A new method for querying triadic concepts using an inverted index is presented. It has advantages over existing approaches, such as not needing the initial triadic context or derivation operators, and eliminating the factorization phase. The method also introduces a novel ranking metric. An empirical study shows its effectiveness and scalability compared to an approximation method, making it suitable for big data scenarios."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10272", "title": "Multi-Source Collaborative Gradient Discrepancy Minimization for Federated Domain Generalization. (arXiv:2401.10272v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Researchers propose Multi-source Collaborative Gradient Discrepancy Minimization (MCGDM) for federated domain generalization. MCGDM addresses overfitting and domain shift by using intra-domain and inter-domain gradient matching. The method can be extended to federated domain adaptation and outperforms existing approaches in experiments."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10393", "title": "Catastrophic Interference is Mitigated in Naturalistic Power-Law Learning Environments. (arXiv:2401.10393v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Neural networks struggle with catastrophic interference (CI), forgetting previous tasks when learning new ones. Prior techniques to mitigate CI include regularization, rehearsal, generative replay, and distillation. This work proposes a new approach based on cognitive science research, using a simulated naturalistic learning environment. They evaluate a rehearsal-based method in a power-law environment and show its effectiveness in promoting continual learning and facilitating faster learning of later tasks. The approach is robust to the number of tasks, model size, and amount of data rehearsed, outperforming popular regularization methods and non-power-law rehearsals. The method is simple, does not require additional neural circuitry, and can be combined with other continual learning mechanisms in future research."}

(arXiv:2401.10463v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "This article examines the critical data size in language models, which determines the shift from memorization to generalization. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10467", "title": "Learning Backdoors for Mixed Integer Programs with Contrastive Learning. (arXiv:2401.10467v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "- Real-world problems can be efficiently modeled as Mixed Integer Programs (MIPs) and solved using the Branch-and-Bound method.\n- Prior work has identified MIP backdoors, small sets of variables that improve running times when prioritized for branching.\n- Finding high-quality backdoors that improve running times is still an open question.\n- Previous work used random sampling to estimate the relative solver speed of backdoors, but this paper uses the Monte-Carlo tree search method and a contrastive learning framework to collect and train backdoors.\n- The proposed method outperforms Gurobi and previous models in four common MIP problem domains."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://www.alignmentforum.org/posts/PhTBDHu9PKJFmvb4p/a-shutdown-problem-proposal", "title": "A Shutdown Problem Proposal", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The proposed solution aims to address the shutdown problem by using a subagent architecture where two subagents negotiate and agree on actions. The subagents follow different utility functions based on counterfactual outcomes of a shutdown button being pressed or not. The agent aims to maintain optionality and avoid manipulations of the shutdown button. The proposal suggests possible extensions to handle more complex problems. However, there are concerns about the design of utility functions, negotiation infrastructure, and potential inefficiencies. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://cset.georgetown.edu/article/risc-v-what-it-is-and-why-it-matters/", "title": "RISC-V: What it is and Why it Matters", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The U.S. government is concerned about China's access to the open-source chip architecture called RISC-V and its potential to bypass U.S. export controls. However, regulating RISC-V is legally challenging and may be counterproductive. The recent export controls target AI chips but not general computing processors, so RISC-V doesn't currently pose a threat. However, in the future, if export controls expand to include general-purpose chips, RISC-V could undermine their effectiveness. The U.S. government could try to control China's access to RISC-V technology, but it's difficult due to its international operation. Another approach could be to support the development and adoption of RISC-V to mitigate the threat and encourage innovation at home."}

The \"safety-impacting AI\" category includes broad purposes, potentially discouraging new technology adoption. The \"rights-impacting AI\" qualification is too broad and may classify most AI systems as high risk, making it difficult for agencies to adopt AI tools. A more precise and risk-based approach, like the EU AI Act, is recommended, clarifying definitions and focusing on consequential decisions. Regulatory scope should be based on existing laws, and certain use cases, like determining eligibility for government programs, should have greater scrutiny."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/ai-watermarking-wont-curb-disinformation", "title": "AI Watermarking Won't Curb Disinformation", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "- Watermarking AI-generated content is not foolproof and easily removed.\n- Adding metadata to images can also be removed and is not reliable.\n- Manipulating least perceptible bits in an image is susceptible to destruction.\n- Authenticity of camera-generated images can be proven with metadata and cryptographic signatures, but not applicable to all images.\n- Watermarking and content authenticity have limitations.\n- Watermarking is challenging for text-based AI, detection tools are inaccurate.\n- State-sponsored disinformation campaigns are unlikely to use watermarking.\n- There are concerns about misuse and disruption of creative markets by generative AI.\n- OpenAI and Google provide guidance on content use, US Copyright Office seeking comments on AI and copyright.\n- Artists worry about automatic image generators undermining their market."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/epic-urges-ftc-to-investigate-thomson-reuters-fraud-detection-system-in-new-complaint/", "title": "EPIC Urges FTC to Investigate Thomson Reuters\u2019 Fraud Detection System in New Complaint", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "EPIC has filed a complaint urging the FTC to investigate Thomson Reuters for its faulty fraud detection system, \"Fraud Detect.\" Thomson Reuters used government and commercial data to develop the system, but it generated false fraud alerts, causing legitimate claimants to lose access to benefits. EPIC calls for the FTC to investigate unfair practices and violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and to enforce responsible AI practices. EPIC has previously highlighted Thomson Reuters' error-prone system in investigative reports."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/eff-asks-court-uphold-federal-law-protects-online-video-viewers-privacy-and-free", "title": "EFF Asks Court to Uphold Federal Law That Protects Online Video Viewers\u2019 Privacy and Free Expression", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "EFF argues in court that the Video Privacy Protection Act (VPPA) must be upheld to protect the privacy of internet users' viewing habits. Patreon, facing a lawsuit alleging improper sharing of viewing data with Facebook, argues that the VPPA violates the First Amendment. EFF argues that the VPPA advances both First Amendment and privacy interests, and Patreon's First Amendment argument is misguided. Disclosing video viewing habits can reveal intimate details and stifles free expression. EFF suggests addressing potential unconstitutional applications of the law without invalidating it entirely. Protecting the VPPA is crucial for privacy and free expression."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/the-daily-upside-disney-could-bring-machine-learning-to-parks-cctv/", "title": "The Daily Upside: Disney Could Bring Machine Learning to Parks\u2019 CCTV\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Disney's rights allow them to use surveillance technology to photograph and record guests. This technology could be used for security and optimizing park layouts, but it raises concerns about accuracy and privacy. The system's reliance on a \"normal\" behavior threshold may discriminate against different cultures and neurodivergent individuals. The potential tracking and use of data, especially for children, is also worrisome."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/victory-police-drone-footage-not-categorically-exempt-californias-public-records", "title": "Victory! Police Drone Footage is Not Categorically Exempt From California\u2019s Public Records Law", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "A California appellate court has ruled that police drone footage sent in response to 911 calls cannot be completely withheld from the public. The court argued that categorically excluding all drone footage from public disclosure could have negative consequences for oversight of the police drone program. The court stated that not all 911 calls involve crimes, and therefore, some drone footage may not be exempt from public disclosure. The case was sent back to the trial court to determine whether specific calls for service involved a crime or initial investigation. The ruling sends a message to other agencies in California with similar programs that they cannot abuse public records laws to hide drone footage."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/year-review-googles-corporate-paternalism-browser", "title": "Year In Review: Google\u2019s Corporate Paternalism in The Browser", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Google and its subsidiary companies have made significant changes to their browser, Chrome, emphasizing the importance of browser privacy tools. Chrome's Manifest V3 restricts the capabilities of extensions, positioning itself as the gatekeeper for privacy tools. Google's \"Privacy Sandbox\" project replaces third-party cookies with the \"Topics API,\" limiting tracking to Chrome itself. YouTube, owned by Google, now blocks users with ad-blockers unless they disable them. Privacy tools like Privacy Badger play a crucial role in protecting user privacy. Anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance has increased globally, with countries passing initiatives that restrict freedom of expression and privacy. Legislatures in many countries have proposed limiting young people's use of social media. Politicians in Europe attempted to undermine end-to-end encryption but faced opposition. The EFF works to improve digital rights through state legislative work."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/how-fight-bad-patents-2023-year-review", "title": "How To Fight Bad Patents: 2023 Year In Review", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "EFF believes that all rights in the offline world should also hold up in the digital world, including the fight against patent trolls. The inter partes review (IPR) process has been effective in canceling wrongly granted patents. Patent examiners have limited time to review applications, and post-grant review systems are necessary to challenge bad patents. Patent trolls and aggressive patent holders want to roll back the IPR process. The PREVAIL Act would limit access to IPR and bar organizations like EFF from using it. The Alice precedent has helped in invalidating bad patents, but trade groups want to reverse it with the Patent Eligibility Restoration Act. EFF opposes these efforts as they hurt innovation and free speech. EFF continues to fight against patent abuse."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/exposing-the-rotten-reality-of-ai-training-data", "title": "Exposing the Rotten Reality of AI Training Data", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Stanford Internet Observatory finds child sexual abuse imagery in dataset used to train AI systems, raising concerns about AI's capability to produce counterfeit images. Chief Technologist David Thiel calls for deprecating models based on Stable Diffusion 1.5 and improving safety measures. The report sparks discussions on platform responsibility and the need for collaboration in addressing AI challenges. Thiel suggests retrospective scanning and transparency, leading to the removal of the dataset and the introduction of the AI Foundation Model Transparency Act. The research emphasizes the importance of responsible and safe AI development."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/fighting-european-threats-encryption-2023-year-review", "title": "Fighting European Threats to Encryption: 2023 Year in Review\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Throughout 2023, European politicians have been attempting to undermine encryption and impose scanning of private online messages. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) launched a petition, resulting in a key EU committee adopting a position that opposes mass scanning and protects end-to-end encryption. While some Member States still support surveillance, there are promising signs of widespread opposition. EFF also opposed the UK's Online Safety Act, which passed with anti-encryption measures intact. EFF will closely monitor the UK's drafting of regulations and continue fighting for digital rights and privacy globally."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/fighting-your-digital-rights-across-country-year-review-2023", "title": "Fighting For Your Digital Rights Across the Country: Year in Review 2023", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "California passed laws that strengthen consumer digital rights, including a right-to-repair law and a data privacy law. EFF also supported bills in California that protect health care data privacy and extend privacy protections to apps. Other states passed consumer privacy bills, but EFF did not support them. Montana passed a strong genetic privacy bill. EFF will continue to fight for digital rights nationwide."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/kids-online-safety-shouldnt-require-massive-online-censorship-and-surveillance", "title": "Kids Online Safety Shouldn\u2019t Require Massive Online Censorship and Surveillance: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Congress has failed to pass comprehensive data privacy reforms and instead focused on limiting young people's online usage. Dangerous \"child safety\" bills, like the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA), if passed, would impose censorship and harm the rights of both adults and minors. However, thanks to opposition, none of these bills have become law. KOSA would require online platforms to take action against content that politicians deem harmful to minors, potentially limiting discussions on important topics. The Protecting Kids on Social Media Act, with its age verification mandates and parental consent requirements, is also opposed. Young people are actively opposing these bills, and their activation is a strong weapon against online censorship and surveillance. The fight for digital rights will continue as similar bills may return in the future."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/equitable-access-law-got-stronger-year", "title": "Equitable Access to the Law Got Stronger: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Nonprofit organization Public.Resource.Org won a ten-year legal battle at the D.C. Circuit appeals court, allowing non-commercial copying and sharing of codes and standards incorporated into the law. The court ruled that Public Resource's mission to make government more accessible justified posting these laws online. The decision promotes equitable access to the law and addresses challenges faced by those who rely on accessibility tools. It highlights the importance of a balanced copyright law that protects access to the law and participation in government."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/2023-year-review-us-supreme-courts-busy-year-free-speech-and-tech-cases", "title": "The U.S. Supreme Court\u2019s Busy Year of Free Speech and Tech Cases: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The U.S. Supreme Court has been involved in internet free speech cases, with the EFF participating in nine cases. The court upheld free speech rights in some cases but did not overturn an overbroad law. The EFF hopes for protections for commenting on officials' social media pages and against government overreach. The court didn't hold social media companies accountable for terrorism-related content and narrowed the impact of a law on free speech. Pending cases involve individuals being blocked/deleted from social media and laws dictating social media content moderation. The EFF also urged the court to consider government involvement in content moderation. Other digital rights issues were mentioned."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/surveillance-self-defense-2023-year-review", "title": "Surveillance Self-Defense: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Surveillance Self-Defense (SSD) has made updates and added new guides to provide expert guidance on security and privacy, including combining Signal and WhatsApp guides, introducing a guide on password managers and using Tor on mobile devices. They have also addressed security issues through their blog, covering topics such as passkeys, quirks in encrypted messaging apps, and data breaches. Additionally, they have provided guidance on disabling Google's Privacy Sandbox feature, securing Android devices for kids, enabling encryption for iCloud backups, and Meta's end-to-end encryption for Messenger. They have also supported the right to scrape websites and called for reconsideration of vulnerability reporting mechanisms. Lastly, they discuss the risks of certain tech gifts during the holiday season and their work in 2023."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/year-review-last-mile-encrypting-web", "title": "The Last Mile of Encrypting the Web: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The HTTPS Everywhere web extension has been discontinued as all major browsers now offer default HTTPS functionality. The \"Encrypt the Web\" initiative has led to default security, reducing threats and surveillance. Over 80% of the web is now encrypted, efforts are being made to make encryption tools more accessible. Let's Encrypt provides free TLS certificates and promotes short-lived certificates for automation and faster encryption. Chrome and the CA/B Forum are also taking steps to promote HTTPS. Challenges still exist, such as the EU's eIDAS framework and mobile app security. Continued efforts are needed for 100% encryption on the web."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/corporate-spy-tech-and-inequality-2023-year-review", "title": "Corporate Spy Tech and Inequality: 2023 Year in Review ", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "EFF fights against data surveillance practices that cause discrimination and inequality. They provided guidance to users affected by the stolen data from 23andMe. Lower-income people are more vulnerable to data harvesting and breaches. EFF criticizes the government's purchase of corporate surveillance data, as it leads to bias. They also highlight the risks of automakers collecting and selling vehicle data. EFF calls for privacy legislation to reduce data collection and protect lower-income individuals. They argue that data surveillance is a civil rights problem. Anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives around the world limit freedom of expression and privacy. Google tightens its control on online innovation while marketing it as beneficial for users. Legislatures in many states target young people's access to social media. EFF defends end-to-end encryption against attempts to undermine it in Europe."}

The digital divide becomes apparent as cheaper devices lack security and privacy measures. The FTC should take action against vendors selling these devices, such as Amazon and AliExpress. Consumers should be cautious and seek refunds for affected devices. There is a need for better testing and regulatory oversight of digital products. Some technologists are exploring decentralized, peer-to-peer applications for improved privacy. Meta has rolled out end-to-end encryption for Messenger and Facebook. Android devices from online vendors come with risks, including malware. The EFF urges the FTC to stop sales of infected Android devices. Experts call for reconsideration of vulnerability reporting mechanisms. Little progress has been made on the proposed UN Cybercrime Treaty. Erica Astrella and Tadayoshi Kohno have joined the EFF."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/reguaiting-health-lessons-for-navigating-the-complex-code-of-ai-and-healthcare-regulations/", "title": "Regu(AI)ting Health: Lessons for Navigating the Complex Code of AI and Healthcare Regulations", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Key lessons for organizations, advocates, and stakeholders in ensuring lawful and trustworthy development and deployment of AI-driven health services:\n\n1. Health organizations should analyze AI tools for potential risks and vulnerabilities to protected health information before implementation, as suggested by the Office for Civil Rights (OCR) of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).\n\n2. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) takes an optimistic approach towards AI's use and plans to develop a flexible risk-based regulatory framework to promote innovation while protecting patient safety.\n\n3. Collaboration between HHS and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) ensures the protection of sensitive health information, emphasizing the importance of establishing proper agreements and safeguards.\n\n4. The FTC enforces laws prohibiting bias and discrimination in AI, recommending the truthful, fair, equitable, and more good than harm use of AI to avoid violating the FTC Act.\n\n5. The White House and the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) published the AI Blueprint and the AI Bill of Rights to guide the responsible use and governance of automated systems, including those used in healthcare.\n\n6. The Biden Administration's Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy AI establishes new standards for responsible use and directs the Secretary of HHS to create an AI Taskforce and an AI Safety program in the healthcare context.\n\n7. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) released the AI Risk Management Framework to promote responsible and trustworthy development and use of AI systems.\n\n8. Regulation of AI in healthcare is a priority for federal agencies, with the FDA developing specific guidance for clinical decision support software and medical devices.\n\n9. The legislative and regulatory environment governing AI is evolving, and AI regulation in healthcare is a top priority with a focus on privacy, discrimination, and patient safety.\n\n10. By following federal guidance, standards, and regulations, organizations can harness the power of AI to improve patient care and outcomes in an ethical and responsible manner."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/risk-framework-for-body-related-data-in-immersive-technologies/", "title": "Risk Framework for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) has released a risk framework to help organizations handle body-related data in immersive technologies. The framework focuses on documenting data practices, complying with laws, evaluating privacy and safety risks, and implementing best practices. It is applicable to technologies with immersive elements as well as other contexts involving body-related data. Organizations should collect and transfer data responsibly, identify and mitigate risks, and assess the fairness and ethics of their practices. Best practices should be implemented intentionally and comprehensively, involving multidisciplinary teams, and continuously evaluated. Following these guidelines can protect privacy and safety in immersive technologies."}
{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/five-big-questions-and-zero-predictions-for-the-u-s-state-privacy-landscape-in-2024/", "title": "Five Big Questions (and Zero Predictions) for the U.S. State Privacy Landscape in 2024", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "In 2023, state-level activity on privacy laws in the United States dramatically increased, with the number of states with comprehensive commercial privacy laws growing from five to twelve. State lawmakers also began regulating the development and use of AI technologies. Two states, Kentucky and New York, have proposed unique privacy laws that may pass in 2024. California is playing a significant role in establishing rules for AI governance. There is a lack of visible enforcement of new privacy laws, but indicators of regulatory interest suggest forthcoming enforcement actions. The privacy laws in various states may be revised, and there are ongoing concerns about their constitutionality. The coming year is expected to bring further privacy proposals and advancements in privacy legislation at the state level."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/navigating-cross-border-data-transfers-in-the-asia-pacific-region-apac-analyzing-legal-developments-from-2021-to-2023/", "title": "Navigating Cross-Border Data Transfers in the Asia-Pacific region (APAC): Analyzing Legal Developments from 2021 to 2023", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) analyzed cross-border data transfer provisions in Asia-Pacific (APAC) countries and found divergences in their data protection laws. Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, and Thailand have aligned legal bases for cross-border data transfers, while China and Vietnam have unique requirements. These differences may complicate compliance programs for organizations operating in multiple jurisdictions. However, there are possibilities for increasing interoperability, such as standardized contractual clauses and regional certification schemes. FPF's Issue Brief provides more in-depth analysis, and their previous project focused on consent and alternative legal bases for data processing in APAC."}
