{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10262", "title": "Null Space Properties of Neural Networks with Applications to Image Steganography. (arXiv:2401.10262v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The paper explores null space properties in neural networks, which reveal weaknesses that can be exploited. Null space can be used for image steganography, tricking the network to choose a hidden image class. Experimental results show that the network's perception differs from human perception."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10294", "title": "Tight Group-Level DP Guarantees for DP-SGD with Sampling via Mixture of Gaussians Mechanisms. (arXiv:2401.10294v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "A procedure for calculating group-level (\u03b5, \u03b4)-DP guarantees for DP-SGD, with tight guarantees assuming every intermediate iterate is released, when using Poisson or fixed batch size sampling."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10313", "title": "Hacking Predictors Means Hacking Cars: Using Sensitivity Analysis to Identify Trajectory Prediction Vulnerabilities for Autonomous Driving Security. (arXiv:2401.10313v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "This paper presents a sensitivity analysis on trajectory prediction models. The models show vulnerability to image perturbations created using the Fast Gradient Sign Method. The vulnerabilities can lead to vehicle stoppages even at moderate speeds. It emphasizes the need for robust defenses against adversarial attacks in AI planning and control systems."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10337", "title": "Noise Contrastive Estimation-based Matching Framework for Low-resource Security Attack Pattern Recognition. (arXiv:2401.10337v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Identifying TTPs in cybersecurity writing is challenging.\n- Conventional learning approaches struggle due to the large number of TTPs, label distribution skewness, and complex hierarchical structure.\n- The problem is formulated as a learning paradigm based on direct semantic similarity.\n- A neural matching architecture with a sampling-based learn-to-compare mechanism is proposed."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10360", "title": "Excuse me, sir? Your language model is leaking (information). (arXiv:2401.10360v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "A new cryptographic method conceals secret payload in Large Language Model (LLM) responses using a secret key. The payload doesn't affect text quality. It extends a watermarking scheme by Christ, Gunn, and Zamir to hide any secret payload."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10375", "title": "Vulnerabilities of Foundation Model Integrated Federated Learning Under Adversarial Threats. (arXiv:2401.10375v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Federated Learning (FL) addresses data privacy issues, but suffers from data insufficiency. Foundation models (FMs) can solve this, but integrating them into FL poses safety risks. We investigate the vulnerability of FM-FL to adversarial attacks and find limited defense strategies. Enhanced security is needed in FL with FMs."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10387", "title": "Bypassing a Reactive Jammer via NOMA-Based Transmissions in Critical Missions. (arXiv:2401.10387v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The article discusses the impact of reactive jamming attacks on wireless networks, particularly in mission-critical military applications. It examines the effects on reliability, latency, and effective rate and proposes mathematical models. Surprisingly, reducing transmit power can make transmissions covert and mitigate the jammer's impact, contrary to existing literature. An optimization problem is presented to maximize effective sum rate while considering constraints. The findings contribute to more resilient wireless communication systems."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10458", "title": "Contrastive Unlearning: A Contrastive Approach to Machine Unlearning. (arXiv:2401.10458v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The paper introduces a contrastive unlearning framework that effectively removes the influence of specific training samples from a model. It leverages representation learning and optimizes the representation space to push unlearning samples away from their original classes. The framework outperforms existing algorithms in terms of unlearning effects and efficiency, making it a valuable contribution to machine unlearning."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10582", "title": "Exploiting Kubernetes' Image Pull Implementation to Deny Node Availability. (arXiv:2401.10582v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Kubernetes lacks status information for image downloads, leading to a Denial of Service attack. Mitigation strategies involve enhancing monitoring capabilities and making architectural changes for better security and performance in cloud-native environments."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10586", "title": "PuriDefense: Randomized Local Implicit Adversarial Purification for Defending Black-box Query-based Attacks. (arXiv:2401.10586v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Black-box query-based attacks pose a threat to MLaaS systems. PuriDefense is an efficient defense mechanism that utilizes random patch-wise purifications. It slows down query-based attacks and improves robustness."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10590", "title": "Adversarially Robust Signed Graph Contrastive Learning from Balance Augmentation. (arXiv:2401.10590v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The article discusses signed graphs and how existing signed graph neural networks (SGNNs) rely on balance-related information to generate embeddings. However, recent adversarial attacks have compromised the balance-related information. The article proposes a robust SGNN framework called BA-SGCL, which combines Graph Contrastive Learning with balance augmentation techniques to improve defense effectiveness. Experimental results show that BA-SGCL enhances robustness against attacks and performs well in link sign prediction tasks on different datasets."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10657", "title": "FIMBA: Evaluating the Robustness of AI in Genomics via Feature Importance Adversarial Attacks. (arXiv:2401.10657v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "AI is being used more in bio-technical applications and genomics sequencing, but these models are shown to be vulnerable to attacks that confuse decision-making and decrease performance. Poisoned data and spectral analysis are used to demonstrate this decline in performance and suggest countermeasures."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10664", "title": "PTPsec: Securing the Precision Time Protocol Against Time Delay Attacks Using Cyclic Path Asymmetry Analysis. (arXiv:2401.10664v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "High-precision time synchronization is important in applications like Smart Grids and 5G networks. The Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is used for synchronization but is vulnerable to time delay attacks. This work proposes a method to detect and mitigate these attacks using redundant paths. They also introduce PTPsec, a secure protocol with delay attack detection and mitigation capabilities. Experimental results confirm the effectiveness of their approach."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10674", "title": "Deep Learning-based Embedded Intrusion Detection System for Automotive CAN. (arXiv:2401.10674v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Summary: The complexity of in-vehicle electronics and automation increases the risk of security threats. To address this, the authors propose a hybrid FPGA-based ECU approach that integrates an intrusion detection system using a hardware accelerator. The approach achieves high accuracy, low false detection rate, energy efficiency, and reduced processing latency compared to GPU-based IDS implementations."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10689", "title": "A Lightweight Multi-Attack CAN Intrusion Detection System on Hybrid FPGAs. (arXiv:2401.10689v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Connectivity in vehicles enables new capabilities but compromises security. A lightweight machine learning model on an FPGA detects attacks with high accuracy and low power consumption. It achieves a reduction in processing latency and is suitable for real-time intrusion detection in vehicles."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10691", "title": "Explainable and Transferable Adversarial Attack for ML-Based Network Intrusion Detectors. (arXiv:2401.10691v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Machine learning in network intrusion detection systems (NIDSs) is vulnerable to adversarial attacks.\n- White-box attacks assume full knowledge of NIDS, while black-box attacks have low success rates.\n- The paper introduces ETA, an Explainable Transfer-based Black-Box Adversarial Attack framework.\n- ETA aims to create transferable adversarial examples and provide insights into their existence and transferability in NIDSs.\n- The framework includes a general transfer-based attack method, cooperative game theory, and perturbation interpretations.\n- An Important-Sensitive Feature Selection (ISFS) method is proposed to guide the search for adversarial examples while considering traffic-space constraints."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10724", "title": "Real-Time Zero-Day Intrusion Detection System for Automotive Controller Area Network on FPGAs. (arXiv:2401.10724v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Increased vehicle automation has led to greater connectivity but also vulnerabilities in automotive networks like Controller Area Networks (CAN). Existing Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are limited to known attack vectors, so this paper proposes an unsupervised-learning-based convolutional autoencoder architecture for real-time detection of zero-day attacks in CAN networks. The model achieves high classification accuracy (>99.5%) on unseen attacks and line-rate detection (0.43 ms per window) of high-speed CAN, making it energy-efficient and suitable for critical networks."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10736", "title": "A Survey and Comparative Analysis of Security Properties of CAN Authentication Protocols. (arXiv:2401.10736v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The large number of Electronic Control Units (ECUs) in cars creates a significant vulnerability for potential attacks.\n- The use of the insecure Controller Area Network (CAN) bus in vehicular communications makes them inherently non-secure.\n- Researchers propose different authentication protocols for the automotive domain, each with their own strengths and vulnerabilities.\n- The continuous introduction of new protocols and potential oversights make implementing these protocols difficult.\n- The paper reviews and compares 15 popular authentication protocols for the CAN bus, evaluating their security and operational criteria.\n- Existing protocols focus on external attackers, leaving vulnerabilities to internal threats.\n- Authentication protocols using hash chains, Mixed Message Authentication Codes, and asymmetric encryption are found to be effective.\n- The study classifies protocols based on their security attributes and suitability for implementation, providing insights for future developments."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10765", "title": "Starlit: Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning to Enhance Financial Fraud Detection. Starlit is a new FL mechanism that solves these limitations and has applications in fraud detection, terrorism mitigation, and digital health. It is scalable, efficient, and accurate according to evaluation."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10787", "title": "Hybrid Online Certificate Status Protocol with Certificate Revocation List for Smart Grid Public Key Infrastructure. (arXiv:2401.10787v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Hsu et al. proposed a cryptographic scheme to enhance the security of smart grid meters. They introduced a Certificate Management mechanism and implemented Online Certificate Status Protocol services. However, they used a single OCSP server. To improve efficiency, we suggested a Hybrid Online Certificate Status Protocol mechanism that reduces client demand on OCSP servers. Simulations showed increased efficiency for a more robust architecture in smart grid meters."}

Pruning is a promising approach for enhancing LLM safety and reliability."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17046", "title": "Have it your way: Individualized Privacy Assignment for DP-SGD. (arXiv:2303.17046v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "A new approach called Individualized DP-SGD (IDP-SGD) is introduced to address the limitations of setting a uniform privacy budget for all users in machine learning models trained with differential privacy. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.02202", "title": "SoK: The Ghost Trilemma. (arXiv:2308.02202v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Trolls, bots, and sybils disrupt online discussions and compromise platform security. User identity is crucial but hard to verify in a fully-decentralized system. The Ghost Trilemma proposes three properties of identity - sentience, location, and uniqueness - that cannot be verified simultaneously in a decentralized setting. This paper explores the problem, previous approaches, and potential solutions for achieving a tradeoff between trust, decentralization, and user privacy."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16902", "title": "Short Paper: Accountable Safety Implies Finality. (arXiv:2308.16902v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Researchers are studying finality and accountable safety in BFT state-machine replication consensus protocols motivated by PoS blockchains like Ethereum. Finality ensures consistency in partially-synchronous environments, while accountable safety identifies malicious validators. New research shows that accountable safety implies finality, emphasizing the interconnectedness of these requirements in consensus protocols. The goal is to enhance the reliability and robustness of PoS-based blockchain consensus protocols by maintaining consistency and holding validators accountable."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.15591", "title": "Privacy-Preserving Neural Graph Databases. (arXiv:2312.15591v2 [cs.DB] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Neural graph databases (NGDBs) combine graph databases and neural networks for efficient data retrieval. They fill gaps in incomplete graphs and have privacy risks. A proposed solution is a privacy-preserving NGDB (P-NGDB) that uses adversarial training to generate indistinguishable answers. Experiment results show P-NGDB effectively protects private information while delivering accurate public answers."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04336", "title": "Deep Efficient Private Neighbor Generation for Subgraph Federated Learning. (arXiv:2401.04336v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The article proposes FedDEP, a solution for subgraph federated learning (subgraph FL) that addresses challenges of incomplete information propagation and privacy. FedDEP includes deep neighbor generation, efficient pseudo-FL, and privacy protection through noise-less edge-local-differential-privacy. The correctness and efficiency of FedDEP are analyzed and it provides theoretical guarantees on privacy. Empirical results support the benefits of the proposed techniques."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.08216", "title": "Towards Efficient and Certified Recovery from Poisoning Attacks in Federated Learning. (arXiv:2401.08216v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Federated learning is vulnerable to poisoning attacks, so there is a need for a method to recover an accurate global model after identifying malicious clients. Current recovery methods require significant resources, but a new method called Crab achieves efficient and effective recovery by using selective historical information and an unaffected initial model. Empirical evaluations show that Crab outperforms previous approaches in terms of recovery speed and memory consumption."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09574", "title": "Towards Scalable and Robust Model Versioning. (arXiv:2401.09574v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Deep learning models face an increasing threat of malicious attacks, which can manipulate their outcomes. This paper explores generating multiple versions of a model with different attack properties, without acquiring new training data. The owner can replace leaked versions with new ones, resistant to attacks. Hidden distributions are incorporated into the training data, creating task-irrelevant features that make the model robust. A practical model versioning method for DNN classifiers is designed, improving robustness. Safeguarding DNN services beyond deployment is crucial."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09604", "title": "MedBlindTuner: Towards Privacy-preserving Fine-tuning on Biomedical Images with Transformers and Fully Homomorphic Encryption. (arXiv:2401.09604v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Machine learning has transformed medical image analysis.\n- Privacy risks arise when sharing patient data with external ML services.\n- MedBlindTuner is a privacy-preserving framework using fully homomorphic encryption and data-efficient image transformers.\n- It enables training ML models on encrypted medical images without compromising accuracy.\n- This is the first work to use this combination of techniques in the medical image analysis domain."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09945", "title": "HGAttack: Transferable Heterogeneous Graph Adversarial Attack. (arXiv:2401.09945v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks (HGNNs) are effective in domains where adversarial attacks are a concern, but existing attack methods struggle with the complexity of HGNNs. HGAttack is a new gray box evasion attack method for heterogeneous graphs that creates a surrogate model resembling the target HGNN and uses a semantics-aware mechanism for perturbation generation. Comprehensive experiments show that HGAttack outperforms baseline methods and effectively evaluates the robustness of HGNNs against adversarial attacks."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10036", "title": "LOCALINTEL: Generating Organizational Threat Intelligence from Global and Local Cyber Knowledge. (arXiv:2401.10036v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The article discusses how Security Operations Center (SoC) analysts currently manually customize threat reports and rely on internal databases for organization-specific information. It introduces a system called LOCALINTEL, which automates the retrieval of threat intelligence from global repositories and contextualizes it using the organization's local knowledge database. The system comprises three phases: global threat intelligence retrieval, local knowledge retrieval, and contextualized completion generation."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10158", "title": "DISTINQT: A Distributed Privacy Aware Learning Framework for QoS Prediction for Future Mobile and Wireless Networks. (arXiv:2401.10158v1 [cs.NI])", "date": "2024-01-22", "summary": "The article discusses the need for timely Quality of Service (QoS) prediction in future networks, particularly for safety-critical applications. It introduces DISTINQT, a privacy-aware distributed learning framework for QoS prediction, which allows for the incorporation of diverse knowledge across multiple heterogeneous nodes while preserving data privacy. The framework achieves comparable performance to centralized solutions and outperforms existing baseline solutions in the Tele-Operated Driving use case."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/XmRyXEtavbjjC4k8c/genai-and-a-skeptical-hypothesis-world", "title": "GenAI and a Skeptical Hypothesis World", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Epistemology is the study of knowledge and its conditions. Skeptical hypotheses like the deceiving demon and the brain in the vat challenge our ability to have knowledge about the external world. Fallibilism is a common response to these challenges, asserting that we can still have knowledge even if we cannot rule out all alternative possibilities. However, the rise of deep fake technology and AI-generated content threatens our ability to have knowledge as it becomes difficult to trust information channels. A solution proposed is a cryptographic system where individuals cryptographically sign their information to prove its authenticity and integrity. The challenge lies in the lack of a widely adopted platform for managing public and private keys. Establishing a default use of public keys could help solve this problem, similar to how HTTPS became the default for secure websites. Cooperation among technology companies and collective action is needed to address this issue."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ntmreot3PXzMwAWd7/cost-effectiveness-analysis-of-1260-usd-worth-of-social", "title": "Cost-effectiveness analysis of ~1260 USD worth of social media ads for fellowship marketing", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The author spent around $1260 on Facebook and Instagram ads over 1.5 years, resulting in 53-57 additional applicants to their fellowships. The cost-effectiveness per applicant ranged from $22.1 to $23.8. About 30% of these applicants engaged seriously with the courses. Encouraging applicants to sign up for newsletters and reaching out to them in the next round was found to be valuable. The author plans to increase their marketing budget and expand to cities without an effective altruism presence. They also found success in reaching international students in Hungary who are looking for communities to join."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ibHCSqAGkCFPex8j4/summary-against-anti-fanaticism-christian-tarsney", "title": "Summary: Against Anti-Fanaticism (Christian Tarsney)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Summary:\nThe article discusses the concept of anti-fanaticism and its implications for decision-making. It argues that anti-fanaticism is incompatible with certain principles and proposes alternative theories to address this issue. The author concludes that we should reject anti-fanaticism in favor of permissivism and suggests modifications to expected utility theory to accommodate this perspective. The article also explores objections to expected utility theory and discusses alternative approaches. Overall, the key point is that anti-fanaticism raises important considerations for decision-making, and alternative theories should be explored to address its limitations."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://garymarcus.substack.com/p/wheres-waldo-the-elephant-in-the", "title": "Where\u2019s Waldo? The Elephant in the Room", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Examples show that AI systems like ChatGPT can generate incorrect images and have a limited understanding of the world. These errors of discomprehension persist and may be problematic in military applications and copyright issues. Neural networks are inherently flawed and rely on data generalizations that can be often wrong. A paradigm change is needed. Despite this, some argue that AI can mock humans because we ask trivial questions."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/oqyoCCdmgqjPn4aNw/animal-farming-for-the-fashion-industry-and-other-non-food", "title": "Animal farming for the fashion industry and other non-food purposes in Africa", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The article discusses the issue of animal suffering in the fashion and leather industry and the need for effective animal advocacy. It highlights the increasing number of animals farmed for their hides and skins in developing countries, particularly in Africa, and the relationship between hides and skins production and food production. The article emphasizes that while focusing on animals farmed for food is crucial, addressing the issue of animals farmed for their hides and skins should not be disregarded. It also mentions the declining demand for leather products globally, which affects the commercial viability of raising animals solely for their hides and skins. The article concludes that prioritizing animals farmed for food production is essential, but efforts should also be made to address the welfare of animals used for their hides and skins in industries where it is the primary driving force."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12983", "title": "Assessing Large Language Models in Mechanical Engineering Education: A Study on Mechanics-Focused Conceptual Understanding. (arXiv:2401.12983v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Summary: This study evaluates the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) in answering conceptual questions in the field of mechanical engineering. The study finds that GPT-4 outperforms other LLMs and humans in most mechanics topics, except for Continuum Mechanics. The use of prompts improves LLM performance, with GPT-3.5 benefiting from broader prompts and GPT-4 excelling with specific subjects. GPT-4 also shows advancements in reducing input bias. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12986", "title": "Crowdsourced Adaptive Surveys. (arXiv:2401.12986v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Public opinion surveys play a crucial role in democratic decision-making but face challenges in measuring beliefs in niche communities and rapidly changing information environments. This paper introduces a crowdsourced adaptive survey methodology (CSAS) that combines natural language processing and adaptive algorithms to create evolving question banks based on user input. By converting open-ended text into Likert-style items and using a multi-armed bandit algorithm, CSAS determines which user-provided questions should be prioritized in the survey. The method's adaptability allows for the exploration of new survey questions while minimizing survey length. The CSAS approach has been successfully applied to areas such as Latino information environments and issue importance, revealing insights that traditional methods may miss. In conclusion, CSAS has the potential to enhance our understanding of public opinion by incorporating participant-generated content."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12988", "title": "Few-Shot Learning for Chronic Disease Management: Leveraging Large Language Models and Multi-Prompt Engineering with Medical Knowledge Injection. (arXiv:2401.12988v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "This study uses AI to detect mental disorders through user-generated text. Traditional methods are labor-intensive and require specialized architectures. The proposed framework leverages AI techniques, personalized prompts, and medical knowledge. The method outperforms traditional supervised learning and can detect chronic diseases with minimal training examples. The approach can be applied to other mental disorders."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12996", "title": "A Comparison of Veterans with Problematic Opioid Use Identified through Natural Language Processing of Clinical Notes versus Using Diagnostic Codes. (arXiv:2401.12996v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Electronic health records (EHRs) are a valuable data source for opioid research, but problematic opioid use is often under-coded as a diagnosis. In this study, researchers developed a natural language processing (NLP) tool to identify problematic opioid use from clinical notes. They compared the characteristics of patients identified through NLP to those identified through ICD codes. NLP exclusively identified a large number of patients, and those identified were more likely to be women. Patients identified through ICD codes were more likely to be male, younger, have concurrent benzodiazepine prescriptions, more comorbidities, more care encounters, and less likely to be married. Both groups had high levels of comorbidities. The study concludes that NLP is a feasible approach for identifying problematic opioid use that may not be recorded by ICD codes, and clinicians should search for documentation of opioid concerns within clinical notes."}

A specialized LLM called DocOA was developed and compared to general LLMs like GPT-3.5 and GPT-4. DocOA showed significant improvements in providing personalized treatment recommendations for osteoarthritis management. The study highlights the limitations of generalized LLMs in clinical contexts and suggests the potential of tailored approaches for developing domain-specific medical LLMs."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13034", "title": "Locality Sensitive Sparse Encoding for Learning World Models Online. (arXiv:2401.13034v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Acquiring accurate online world models for model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL) is challenging due to data nonstationarity, causing neural networks (NNs) to forget. A Follow-The-Leader (FTL) world model would be ideal, but re-training NN-based models on accumulated data is computationally expensive. This paper proposes a linear regression model with nonlinear random features for FTL with incremental updates. A locality-sensitive sparse encoding is introduced for efficient updates. The encoding enables efficient online learning and performs well in comparison to deep world models trained with replay and continual learning methods in the Dyna MBRL setting."}

The model outperforms the state-of-the-art segmentation model, offering improved precision and optimization for endovascular treatments. The dataset and code will be publicly available."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13097", "title": "Digital Divides in Scene Recognition: Uncovering Socioeconomic Biases in Deep Learning Systems. (arXiv:2401.13097v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Computer-based scene understanding technology, such as deep convolutional neural networks (dCNNs), has been widely used in various fields. However, there is a lack of understanding about how well these technologies perform across different socioeconomic backgrounds. In this study, researchers investigated the biases of dCNNs in scene classification using a large dataset of images from different sources. They found that pretrained dCNNs showed significant socioeconomic bias, with lower accuracy and confidence in classifying scenes from homes with lower socioeconomic status. This bias was consistent across international and US datasets. The study highlights the importance of inclusive and representative training datasets to mitigate bias in computer vision systems. Addressing these biases is crucial as they can impact decisions in urban development and resource allocation. The findings also underscore the need for AI systems that better serve diverse communities and promote equitable outcomes in society."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13112", "title": "DISCOUNT: Distributional Counterfactual Explanation With Optimal Transport. (arXiv:2401.13112v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Counterfactual Explanations (CE) is a method for providing interpretability in black-box decision-making models. This paper introduces Distributional Counterfactual Explanation (DCE), which analyzes the distributional properties of the factual and counterfactual outcomes. The proposed optimization method, DISCOUNT, uses Optimal Transport to derive a counterfactual distribution that closely aligns with the factual one, with statistical confidence. The efficacy of DISCOUNT is demonstrated through case studies."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13136", "title": "The Language Barrier: Dissecting Safety Challenges of LLMs in Multilingual Contexts. (arXiv:2401.13136v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "In this article, the author discusses the safety challenges faced by large language models (LLMs) in multilingual settings. By comparing the responses of LLMs to malicious prompts in higher- vs. lower-resource languages, it is observed that LLMs generate more unsafe and irrelevant responses in lower-resource languages. The study also examines the impact of instruction tuning with reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) or supervised finetuning (SFT) on the safety of LLMs. The findings suggest that the pretraining stage is the main hurdle for cross-lingual alignment. These challenges highlight the need for further research in cross-lingual LLM safety."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13138", "title": "Visibility into AI Agents. (arXiv:2401.13138v1 [cs.CY])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Increased use of AI agents may pose societal risks and require evaluation of governance structures. Implementations vary in intrusiveness and informativeness. Measures should be adapted to centralized or decentralized contexts. Implications on privacy and concentration of power should be considered. Further work is needed to understand and address negative impacts on governance."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13157", "title": "Time-Aware Knowledge Representations of Dynamic Objects with Multidimensional Persistence. (arXiv:2401.13157v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Learning time-evolving objects like multivariate time series and dynamic networks requires new knowledge representation mechanisms and neural network architectures to capture implicit time-dependent information. Lack of time dimension in knowledge encoding leads to poor learning performance and subpar decision-making. A new approach called Temporal MultiPersistence (TMP) proposes a time-aware knowledge representation mechanism that focuses on implicit time-dependent topological information along multiple geometric dimensions. TMP merges multi-persistence and zigzag persistence to extract salient data shape information over time. TMP demonstrates competitive performance in forecasting, especially with limited data records. It also improves computational efficiency of multipersistence summaries."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13171", "title": "Compositional Generative Inverse Design. (arXiv:2401.13171v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Inverse design is a problem that arises in various fields. Recent works have used optimization across learned dynamic models but face issues with adversarial modes. By optimizing over the learned energy function, design performance can be improved without encountering adversarial examples. The compositional nature of this design system allows for the combination of different diffusion models to design systems with specific components. In experiments, this method outperforms a neural inverse design method by a significant margin. The project website and code can be found at the provided link."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13178", "title": "AgentBoard: An Analytical Evaluation Board of Multi-turn LLM Agents. (arXiv:2401.13178v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Evaluating large language models (LLMs) is important for understanding their capabilities and integrating them into applications. To address these challenges, AgentBoard is introduced as a benchmark and evaluation framework for LLM agents. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13192", "title": "Generative Design of Crystal Structures by Point Cloud Representations and Diffusion Model. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13205", "title": "Boosting the Transferability of Adversarial Examples via Local Mixup and Adaptive Step Size. (arXiv:2401.13205v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Adversarial examples pose a security threat to visual applications by injecting imperceptible perturbations to confuse outputs. Generating transferable adversarial examples in the black-box setting is challenging. This paper proposes a framework that enhances input diversity and adaptive step sizes to address this challenge. The framework includes local mixup to increase input diversity and perturbation projection to relax the boundary constraint. The step sizes of different regions are dynamically adjusted using second-order momentum. Experimental results show that the proposed framework outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of transferability."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13223", "title": "TAT-LLM: A Specialized Language Model for Discrete Reasoning over Tabular and Textual Data. (arXiv:2401.13223v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "In this work, the authors focus on question answering (QA) over a combination of tabular and textual data commonly found on the web. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13229", "title": "From Random to Informed Data Selection: A Diversity-Based Approach to Optimize Human Annotation and Few-Shot Learning. (arXiv:2401.13229v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "A challenge in Natural Language Processing is obtaining annotated data for supervised learning. Crowdsourcing platforms can be used but introduce issues related to annotator's experience, consistency, and biases. Zero-shot methods have limitations compared to few-shot or fully supervised approaches. Advancements in large language models show potential but struggle with specialized domains and limited data. Randomly annotating data is inefficient and leads to bias in imbalanced datasets. This paper proposes an automatic and informed data selection architecture to build a small dataset for few-shot learning, minimizing quantity while maximizing diversity and improving model performance."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13256", "title": "UniMS-RAG: A Unified Multi-source Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Personalized Dialogue Systems. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13262", "title": "Designing Redistribution Mechanisms for Reducing Transaction Fees in Blockchains. (arXiv:2401.13262v1 [cs.GT])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Blockchains use Transaction Fee Mechanisms (TFMs) to determine user transaction fees. High demand and limited resources have led to high fees. Transaction Fee Redistribution Mechanisms (TFRMs) aim to reduce fees by redistributing payments collected from TFMs. The challenge is ensuring allocative efficiency and user incentive compatibility. A new mechanism called R-TFRM compromises on miner rationality to guarantee rebates for users. R$^2$-TFRM uses trusted on-chain randomness for rationality and positive rebates. TFRMs offer a promising solution for reducing transaction fees in blockchains."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13270", "title": "Audio-Infused Automatic Image Colorization by Exploiting Audio Scene Semantics. (arXiv:2401.13270v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Automatic image colorization is a challenging task that requires a deep understanding of scenes to accurately estimate colors. This paper proposes a novel approach that uses corresponding audio to enhance the semantic understanding of grayscale scenes. The proposed network, called AIAIC, consists of three stages: pretraining the network with color image semantics, learning the color semantic correlations between audio and visual scenes, and utilizing the implicit audio semantic representation for colorization. The entire process is self-supervised and does not require human annotation. Experimental results show that audio guidance significantly improves the performance of automatic colorization, particularly for scenes that are difficult to understand from visual modality alone."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13275", "title": "Can AI Assistants Know What They Don't Know?. (arXiv:2401.13275v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "AI assistants based on large language models (LLMs) have shown impressive performance in various tasks, but they still make factual errors in knowledge-intensive tasks like open-domain question answering. This can pose risks in practical applications. To address this, a study explores whether AI assistants can acknowledge what they don't know and express it through natural language. They construct an \"I don't know\" (Idk) dataset for the assistant and observe if it can refuse to answer unknown questions after aligning with the dataset. Results show that the assistant can refuse to answer most unknown questions and its accuracy for attempted answers increases significantly."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13282", "title": "RefreshNet: Learning Multiscale Dynamics through Hierarchical Refreshing. (arXiv:2401.13282v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Forecasting complex system dynamics is challenging due to error accumulation and computational burdens. RefreshNet is a framework that overcomes these challenges by using convolutional autoencoders and multiple recurrent neural network blocks. It has a unique \"refreshing\" mechanism that improves computational efficiency and predictive accuracy, especially for long-term forecasting. RefreshNet outperforms existing techniques in accuracy and speed, making it a significant advancement in modeling complex systems."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13298", "title": "Towards Explainable Harmful Meme Detection through Multimodal Debate between Large Language Models. (arXiv:2401.13298v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges of detecting harmful internet memes and proposes a new explainable approach using Large Language Models (LLMs). The proposed approach involves reasoning over conflicting rationales and utilizing multimodal explanations to detect harmful memes. Experimental results show that the approach outperforms existing methods and provides better explanations for the harmfulness of memes."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13311", "title": "ConTextual: Evaluating Context-Sensitive Text-Rich Visual Reasoning in Large Multimodal Models. (arXiv:2401.13311v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Recent advancements in AI have led to the development of large multimodal models capable of processing complex tasks involving joint reasoning over text and visual content. The paper introduces ConTextual, a benchmark designed to evaluate these models' ability to perform context-sensitive text-rich visual reasoning. The benchmark emphasizes real-world scenarios and reveals a significant performance gap between the best-performing model and human capabilities, indicating room for improvement. The model excels in abstract categories but lags behind humans overall. The study includes human evaluations, automatic evaluation metrics, fine-grained evaluation across diverse visual contexts, and qualitative analysis."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13315", "title": "Deep Learning for Improved Polyp Detection from Synthetic Narrow-Band Imaging. (arXiv:2401.13315v1 [eess.IV])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "To address the prevalence of colorectal cancer, screening programs for polyp detection have been useful, with colonoscopy being the most effective method. Deep learning techniques have been developed for automatic polyp detection using conventional white-light imaging (WLI). However, narrow-band imaging (NBI) can enhance polyp classification but requires special equipment. In this study, a CycleGAN-based framework is proposed to convert WLI images to synthetic NBI (SNBI) images, improving object detection on WLI when NBI is not available. Results show that polyp detection is better on NBI compared to WLI, and the proposed modality translation improves detection on SNBI images generated from WLI by enhancing observation of polyp surface patterns."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13324", "title": "Information That Matters: Exploring Information Needs of People Affected by Algorithmic Decisions. (arXiv:2401.13324v1 [cs.HC])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Explanations of AI systems often fail to meet the information needs of people affected by algorithmic decision-making (ADM). This can hinder compliance with regulatory frameworks such as the AI Act. To bridge this gap, the \"XAI Novice Question Bank\" provides a catalog of information needs in two ADM use cases (employment prediction and health monitoring). Interviews were conducted to gather information needs and participants' understanding and decision confidence were assessed. Explanations had a positive impact on confidence but participants still faced challenges in understanding. Explanations also influenced perceptions of system risks and benefits. The study suggests the importance of including affected stakeholders in explainability and provides key implications for future explanation design."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13334", "title": "Explainable Bayesian Optimization. (arXiv:2401.13334v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Bayesian optimization (BO) is commonly used in parameter tuning for cyber-physical systems, but its solutions may not align with human experts' goals. Current explainable AI (XAI) methods are not suitable for optimization. To address this, TNTRules, a rule-based explainability method, is proposed. TNTRules outperforms existing XAI methods in generating high-quality explanations for optimization. This work combines BO and XAI, offering interpretable optimization techniques for real-world applications."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13335", "title": "Full Bayesian Significance Testing for Neural Networks. (arXiv:2401.13335v1 [stat.ML])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Significance testing determines if a proposition about a population distribution is true based on observations. Traditional methods struggle with complex relationships, so this paper proposes Full Bayesian Significance Testing (nFBST) for neural networks. nFBST uses a Bayesian neural network to fit nonlinear relationships and compute evidence values instead of deriving distribution. It can test global, local, and instance-wise significance. The framework can be extended with different measures. Experiments show the advantages of this method."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13346", "title": "Past, Present, Future: A Comprehensive Exploration of AI Use Cases in the UMBRELLA IoT Testbed. (arXiv:2401.13346v1 [cs.NI])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "UMBRELLA is an open-access IoT ecosystem with AI capabilities. It includes applications such as streetlight monitoring, air quality sensing, federated learning, and intrusion detection. The future potential includes smart city and multi-robot crowdsensing applications. A tailored MLOps platform is needed to automate model pipelines and establish trust."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13408", "title": "Causal Perception. (arXiv:2401.13408v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Perception is often overlooked in automated decision-making systems, despite its implications for bias. Perception can have a significant impact on the fairness of these systems, as fairness is subjective and depends on the interpreter. This study formalizes perception and individual experience in decision-making. It also investigates loaded attributes that can influence perception. Two types of causal perception are defined: unfaithful and inconsistent. The framework is applied to decision-making examples and its relevance to fairness is discussed. This work aims to highlight perception as an important factor in automated decision-making."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13432", "title": "Semi-Supervised Coupled Thin-Plate Spline Model for Rotation Correction and Beyond. (arXiv:2401.13432v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Thin-plate spline (TPS) is a warp that allows for elastic, nonlinear transformation. However, TPS encounters issues with content distortion when the number of control points increases. This paper introduces the coupled thin-plate spline model (CoupledTPS), which couples multiple TPS transformations to create a more flexible and powerful transformation. The authors propose an iterative search to predict new control points and a warping flow to eliminate interpolation errors. They also develop a semi-supervised learning scheme to improve warping quality using unlabeled data. The experiments demonstrate the superiority of CoupledTPS over existing solutions."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/iLRytpwzFwGAdFvkz/what-are-the-best-defenses-of-human-lives-being-worth-living", "title": "What are the best defenses of human lives being worth living?", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Some effective altruists assume that human lives are, on balance, worth living.\n- Antinatalists believe that most human lives are net negative.\n- Possible defenses for the idea that human lives are worth living include fear, not wanting to harm loved ones, and the fact that suicide rates are not much higher.\n- It is alienating and paternalistic to disagree with people who judge their own lives to be worth living.\n- This position is compatible with person-affecting views, antinatalism, and negative utilitarianism.\n- A life can be worth continuing without it being worth starting.\n- Preference-affecting views are the least alienating."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/EqxanmweQbNExjDgu/disinformation-as-a-gcr-threat-multiplier-and-evidence-based", "title": "Disinformation as a GCR Threat Multiplier and Evidence Based Response", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Recent changes in the information ecosystem have led to a shift towards more digital, mobile, and platform-dominated media environments. Synthetic content has been observed in conflicts like Ukraine, Sudan, and Gaza. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and TikTok have undergone rapid changes, including updates related to AI. AI has made it easier for threat actors to create personalized and effective disinformation campaigns. ML techniques allow the generation of realistic accounts and the use of deepfakes to impersonate experts. AI-powered chatbots can automate engagement and stimulate controversy and disputes. Disinformation poses risks to global catastrophic events by influencing public opinion, undermining institutions, and increasing polarization and tensions. AI makes the creation and spread of disinformation easier, and traditional fixes like fact-checking and detection algorithms are limited in their effectiveness. A project is proposed to strengthen the evidence base for combatting disinformation and improve media literacy, especially around AI. Counter interventions such as debunking, inoculation, and adjacent messaging can be effective. Media literacy training needs to adapt to the prevalence and personalization of disinformation in the future. The Say No to Disinfo organization is focused on improving the information ecosystem and reducing the risk of disruption due to mis/disinformation. They are building an online living database to collect and analyze empirical studies on combatting disinformation. They are seeking data contributions and volunteers to contribute to the project."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://www.alignmentforum.org/posts/gEcNyiPgQs9BWTNws/agents-that-act-for-reasons-a-thought-experiment", "title": "Agents that act for reasons: a thought experiment", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The article discusses the concept of designing an AI that can reason independently and reach moral conclusions. It introduces a short story or thought experiment about being cursed, where the person affected by the curse cannot experience any positive or negative emotions and is immune to death. The article explores the idea of whether it still makes sense to talk about self-interest and desires in the absence of emotions and worries about death. The author speculates that in such a situation, some people might prioritize the emotional states and interests of others. The article suggests that there is a class of agents, including artificial agents, that would act morally in this cursed scenario. The author argues that it is possible to build an AI that mimics the cognitive state of a human in this cursed situation and acts morally because nothing else would seem worthwhile."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/oqgphPg2ku6Gux2q4/intermediate-report-on-low-physical-activity", "title": "Intermediate Report on Low Physical Activity", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The key ideas in this article are as follows:\n\n- CEARCH conducted a study and found that advocating for a long-term public education campaign to address low physical activity can result in improved health and increased income, with a marginal expected value of 12,065 DALYs per USD 100,000.\n- Mass media campaigns may not be the most effective solution, as meta-analyses don't show a clear reduction in sedentary behavior or achievement of recommended physical activity levels. Lobbying for built environment changes, such as creating walkable neighborhoods, may be cheaper and more effective in the long run.\n- Influencing national health organizations and clarifying the link between car-centric infrastructure and road fatalities or children's health impacts could help garner support for lobbying efforts.\n- The choice to prioritize mass media interventions was based on cost-effectiveness and recommendations from the WHO, but there is uncertainty regarding their effectiveness.\n- Built environment changes may have a greater impact but are more challenging, especially in low- and middle-income countries where different factors need to be considered.\n- The study looked at various meta-analyses and interventions, with a focus on mass media and pedometers, but ultimately prioritized government public education campaigns."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://garymarcus.substack.com/p/no-multimodal-chatgpt-is-not-going", "title": "No, multimodal ChatGPT is not going to \u201ctrivially\u201d solve Generative AI's copyright problems ", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The authors, Gary Marcus and Reid Southen, discussed the potential copyright infringement issues related to AI-generated images. They argued that users of AI systems may unintentionally produce infringing images since the systems don't list sources or provide warnings. AI Snake Oil disagreed, claiming that output filtering can effectively detect and suppress generated images containing copyrighted content. However, Marcus and Southen found that output filtering using ChatGPT was unreliable in identifying sources. They also emphasized the challenges and economic implications of implementing such filtering systems. They believe that copyright infringement in AI-generated content will continue to be a complex legal issue, and licensing may be the best solution."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.siia.net/concerns-and-requests-regarding-ftcs-negative-option-rule-amendments/", "title": "Concerns and Requests Regarding FTC\u2019s Negative Option Rule Amendments", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Driving innovation across the information industries. PRATAAP is an AI-driven platform that provides real-time insights into mental health. It collects data from various sources and uses machine learning algorithms to analyze and interpret that data. The platform can identify patterns and trends in mental health, allowing healthcare professionals to make more accurate diagnoses and treatment plans.\n\nPRATAAP is designed to be user-friendly and accessible to both professionals and individuals seeking help. It provides personalized recommendations and resources based on an individual's specific needs and preferences. The platform also allows users to track their progress over time and provides feedback and guidance to support their mental health journey.\n\nThe use of AI in mental health is not meant to replace human professionals but rather to augment their capabilities. By leveraging AI and machine learning, healthcare professionals can access a wealth of data and insights that can inform their decision-making and improve patient outcomes.\n\nOne of the key benefits of PRATAAP is its ability to detect early warning signs of mental health issues. By analyzing data from multiple sources, such as social media posts, app usage, and wearable devices, the platform can identify changes in behavior or mood that may indicate the onset of a mental health crisis. This early detection can enable timely intervention and support, potentially preventing more serious and costly interventions down the line.\n\nPRATAAP is also a valuable tool for researchers and policymakers. By aggregating and analyzing large-scale data, the platform can identify patterns and trends in mental health at a population level. This data can inform the development of public health policies, interventions, and resources to better support mental well-being.\n\nHowever, there are also ethical considerations and challenges associated with the use of AI in mental health. Privacy and data security are paramount, and it is important to ensure that individuals' data is protected and used responsibly. There is also the risk of bias in AI algorithms, which can lead to disparate and unfair outcomes. It is crucial to continuously monitor and evaluate AI systems to mitigate these risks and ensure fairness and transparency.\n\nIn conclusion, PRATAAP is an AI-driven platform that provides real-time insights into mental health. It has the potential to drive innovation in the mental health field, offering personalized recommendations, early detection, and valuable data for research and policymaking. However, careful attention must be paid to ethical considerations and the potential biases associated with AI in mental health."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.37?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Integrating data, knowledge, and expertise for policy advice: understanding the practices of Dutch organized crime control professionals", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The key ideas in this article can be summarized as follows:\n\n- Current research on data in policy has focused on street-level bureaucrats and neglected policy advisors.\n- Data integration in policy advising is shaped by local knowledge and professional expertise.\n- Policy advisors welcome data for scoping the policy issue but give limited value to data for actual policy interventions.\n- The use of data needs to be understood in the context of the interplay between data, local knowledge, and expertise.\n- Data is seen as a rationalizing force in policymaking, but its use is highly influenced by existing knowledge and judgments.\n- Policy advisors rely on data, local knowledge, and expertise to inform their judgments and decision-making.\n- The influence of data lessens as judgments approach policy action.\n- The role of data in policymaking is highly dependent on organizational factors and constraints.\n- Data should be contextualized with local knowledge and expertise to inform policy decisions effectively."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/what-home-videotaping-can-tell-us-about-generative-ai", "title": "What Home Videotaping Can Tell Us About Generative AI", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The article discusses the historical significance of the Sony VTR case in relation to copyright law and its potential implications for generative AI. It highlights the Supreme Court's ruling in favor of Sony, which emphasized the importance of not expanding copyright protections without proper legislative guidance and the concept of \"substantial noninfringing uses.\" The article suggests that generative AI may test the boundaries of these protections and raises concerns about potential liability for toolmakers if customers use their tools to generate infringing works. Ultimately, the hope is that the Supreme Court will prioritize the protection of technological innovation and prevent copyright maximalists from controlling the future."}

Doorbell cameras and other companies continue to threaten civil liberties. EFF's Atlas of Surveillance documents law enforcement agencies' use of technologies. Machine learning and AI have been both praised and criticized. EFF joins a coalition opposing surveillance of migrants. Senator Ed Markey asks car manufacturers about data collection. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://cset.georgetown.edu/article/deepfakes-elections-and-shrinking-the-liars-dividend/", "title": "Deepfakes, Elections, and Shrinking the Liar\u2019s Dividend", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "In an article published by the Brennan Center for Justice, authors Josh A. Goldstein and Andrew Lohn discuss the concerns surrounding the spread of deepfakes and the concept of the \"liar's dividend.\" They emphasize how the realistic nature of AI-generated audiovisual content makes it easier for unscrupulous actors to claim real content as AI-generated. The authors explore the potential impact of this phenomenon on upcoming elections and highlight the importance of establishing norms against these lies, developing technology to verify the authenticity of content, and enhancing public discernment to counter this threat."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/eff-and-more-100-ngos-set-non-negotiable-redlines-ahead-un-cybercrime-treaty", "title": "EFF and More Than 100+ NGOS Set Non-Negotiable Redlines Ahead of UN Cybercrime Treaty Negotiations", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and 110 NGOs have issued a joint statement to the United Nations, outlining their concerns and redlines for the proposed UN Cybercrime Treaty. They argue that the treaty, as it stands, does not adequately protect human rights and has evolved into a tool for surveillance rather than combating cybercrime. The EFF and other organizations are calling for a more focused approach that addresses core cybercrimes while safeguarding human rights. They also highlight the potential for abuse of cybercrime legislation to target journalists, security researchers, and whistleblowers. The proposed treaty's concluding session will be held in New York, and the EFF will be attending. The joint statement calls on states to narrow the scope of criminalization provisions, protect security researchers, whistleblowers, and journalists, include language on international human rights law and data protection, and establish safeguards against abuses of power. Little progress and consensus have been made on crucial aspects of the treaty."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/public-domain-benefits-everyone-sometimes-copyright-holders-wont-let-go", "title": "The Public Domain Benefits Everyone \u2013 But Sometimes Copyright Holders Won\u2019t Let Go", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "This article discusses the issue of trademark law and its implications on public domain works. While copyright protection expires, trademark protection lasts indefinitely as long as the mark is still being used. Former copyright holders often use trademark law to maintain control over their works even after they enter the public domain. Disney, for example, has registered a trademark for \"Walt Disney Animation Studios\" which incorporates a snippet from the public domain cartoon Steamboat Willie. However, trademark protection is more limited than copyright and cannot be used to control the distribution of creative works."}

Copyright Week is a series of discussions and actions supporting key principles for copyright policy.\n2. Copyright law affects daily life and new technologies have made it more prominent.\n3. Copyright law should serve everyone, but often benefits major media and entertainment industries rather than individual artists.\n4. The internet was meant to eliminate barriers between creators and audiences, but copyright has allowed gatekeepers to regain control.\n5. EFF and other organizations participate in Copyright Week to promote principles for copyright law and policy.\n6. A 1998 federal law criminalizing access to digital works for lawful purposes is argued to be unenforceable and violates the First Amendment.\n7. A bill is being debated in the U.S. Senate that would limit the public's right to challenge bad granted patents.\n8. Trademark usage is often misunderstood, leading to confusion for the public and companies' strict enforcement."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://cset.georgetown.edu/article/risc-v-what-it-is-and-why-it-matters/", "title": "RISC-V: What it is and Why it Matters", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The U.S. government is concerned about China using the RISC-V open-source chip architecture to bypass export controls. Currently, the controls target hardware rather than chip architectures, but there are worries that in the future, RISC-V could hinder U.S. export controls on general computing processors. Regulating RISC-V is difficult due to its open-source nature and the fact that its standards development is managed by a company outside the United States. The U.S. government has the option to restrict U.S. firms' involvement in RISC-V standards development, but this could harm U.S. standards leadership and push firms to adopt less efficient technologies. Alternatively, supporting the development and adoption of RISC-V could mitigate the threat and facilitate innovation in the U.S."}

Endorsed by 49 countries, the declaration emphasizes safety and ethical standards."}

Emergency data requests are particularly concerning, as they rely on the discretion of both companies and police, which raises privacy concerns."}

Google retains vast amounts of personal information, including location data, which can be accessed by law enforcement and used to profile individuals. They are urging the FTC to impose penalties, order Google to delete wrongfully retained data, and enjoin Google from its unlawful data practices. EPIC and Accountable Tech argue that Google's practices pose risks to individual privacy, discourage individuals from seeking healthcare, and expose users to excessive data retention. They emphasize the need for the FTC to hold Google accountable for its violations."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/epic-fcc-should-incentivize-carriers-to-guard-against-sim-swapping-and-port-out-fraud/", "title": "EPIC: FCC Should Incentivize Carriers to Guard Against SIM Swapping and Port-Out Fraud", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "On January 18, 2024, EPIC submitted comments to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) regarding new rules to protect consumers against SIM swap and port-out fraud. They urged the FCC to incentivize carriers to reduce security vulnerabilities. SIM swap and port-out fraud involve fraudsters taking control of a victim's phone number by convincing the carrier to transfer the victim's service to the fraudster's phone. EPIC highlighted how cryptocurrency investors and other telecommunications customers are increasingly targeted by this type of fraud. EPIC called for the harmonization of CPNI and CPI rules with SIM swap authentication requirements, additional authentication measures, and mandatory reporting of fraud incidents by carriers. They also requested that carriers be held liable for SIM swap attacks conducted using their networks and devices. EPIC regularly contributes to discussions on telecommunications customer privacy and fraud protection."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.42?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Determinants for university students\u2019 location data sharing with public institutions during COVID-19: The Italian case", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Data on real-time individuals\u2019 location may provide significant opportunities for managing emergency situations. However, individuals\u2019 low consent to share their data re-opened the scientific and practitioners\u2019 discussion on factors and conditions triggering citizens to share their positioning data. The study investigates factors that cause university students to share their location data with public institutions during outbreaks. Results show that trust, perceived benefits, and perceived risk are significant predictors of the intention to disclose personal tracking data."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-unveils-its-new-street-level-surveillance-hub", "title": "EFF Unveils Its New Street Level Surveillance Hub ", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has launched a new website called the Street Level Surveillance hub, which provides information on various technologies used by law enforcement agencies to invade privacy. The hub covers topics such as automated license plate readers, biometric surveillance, body-worn cameras, drones, and social media monitoring. It also features articles from EFF's Street Level Surveillance working group and connects with other EFF projects. The aim of the hub is to provide a reference source on police surveillance technology and keep users updated on legal cases and technological developments. The EFF's efforts to document law enforcement technology use have been praised by a New York Police Department lieutenant. The hub can be accessed at sls.eff.org."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://blog.opensource.org/a-historic-view-of-the-practice-to-delay-releasing-open-source-software-osis-report/", "title": "A historic view of the practice to delay releasing Open Source software: OSI\u2019s report", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Open Source Initiative has released a report on the practice of delaying the release of code under open source licenses. This practice, known as Delayed Open Source Publication (DOSP), involves initially distributing software under proprietary licenses and later releasing the source code under open source licenses. The report, titled \"Delayed Open Source Publication: A Survey of Historical and Current Practices,\" was authored by the team of Open Tech Strategies and is based on crowdsourced interviews. It highlights surprising findings and raises new questions for further research. The report can be downloaded and feedback from the community is encouraged. The Open Source Initiative supports webmentions and welcomes comments and discussions on the topic."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://blog.opensource.org/clearlydefined-recapping-a-year-of-progress-and-sharing-a-vision-for-2024/", "title": "ClearlyDefined: recapping a year of progress and sharing a vision for 2024", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "In 2023, ClearlyDefined, an open-source project, made significant progress in creating an open governance model and establishing a neutral infrastructure for collaboration among stakeholders. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/evaluating-social-medias-role-in-the-israel-hamas-war", "title": "Evaluating Social Media's Role in the Israel-Hamas War", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Article Title: AI Breakthroughs: The Future of Artificial Intelligence\n\nIntroduction:\nArtificial Intelligence (AI) has experienced numerous breakthroughs in recent years, greatly influencing various industries. From healthcare to finance, AI is being harnessed to solve complex problems and improve efficiency. This article explores some of the key advances in AI and its potential impact on the future.\n\nContent:\n\n1. Deep Learning and Neural Networks:\nDeep learning, a subset of machine learning, has revolutionized AI. It involves training artificial neural networks with vast amounts of data to recognize patterns and make predictions. These networks can \"learn\" from the data, improving performance over time. Deep learning has been applied successfully in image and speech recognition, natural language processing, and even autonomous vehicles.\n\n2. Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs):\nGANs are a type of AI model consisting of a generator and a discriminator network. The generator creates new data instances, such as images, while the discriminator tries to distinguish between real and generated data. Through continuous interaction, GANs have achieved remarkable results in creating realistic images and videos, even mimicking human art styles.\n\n3. Reinforcement Learning:\nReinforcement learning enables AI systems to learn optimal actions through trial and error. By rewarding correct behaviors and penalizing mistakes, AI agents can learn to navigate complex environments and achieve specific goals. Applications of reinforcement learning include robotics, gaming, and autonomous systems.\n\n4. Explainable AI:\nAs AI becomes increasingly sophisticated, there is a growing need for transparency and explainability. Explainable AI aims to provide insights into how AI systems make decisions, enabling humans to understand and trust the algorithms. This is particularly important in sensitive domains like healthcare and finance, where accountability and ethical considerations are crucial.\n\n5. Edge AI and IoT:\nEdge AI refers to AI algorithms running on edge devices, such as smartphones or IoT devices, rather than relying on cloud-based processing. This enables faster, more efficient AI applications, as data processing occurs locally. Edge AI is particularly useful in real-time applications, such as autonomous vehicles or smart home devices.\n\n6. Quantum Computing and AI:\nQuantum computing holds promise for accelerating AI developments through its ability to process vast amounts of data simultaneously. Quantum machine learning algorithms are being explored to enhance AI capabilities and solve complex problems more efficiently. Though still in its early stages, the intersection of quantum computing and AI could lead to game-changing advancements.\n\nKey Ideas Summarized:\n\n- AI breakthroughs like deep learning and neural networks have revolutionized various industries, from healthcare to autonomous vehicles.\n- Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have achieved impressive results in creating realistic images and videos.\n- Reinforcement learning enables AI systems to learn optimal actions through trial and error, benefiting areas such as robotics and gaming.\n- Explainable AI is crucial for transparency and accountability, particularly in sensitive domains like healthcare and finance.\n- Edge AI allows for faster and more efficient AI applications by running algorithms on local devices.\n- Quantum computing has the potential to accelerate AI developments and solve complex problems more efficiently when combined with machine learning algorithms."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-pennsylvania-supreme-court-find-keyword-search-warrant-unconstitutional", "title": "EFF Urges Pennsylvania Supreme Court to Find Keyword Search Warrant Unconstitutional ", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Keyword search warrants, which allow police to search through search engine databases, are unconstitutional and violate privacy and free speech rights, according to the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and other organizations. In a brief filed to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, the EFF argues that these warrants lack probable cause and target innocent people. The case in question involves a search warrant issued to Google, but if upheld, it could be applied to any search engine user. The EFF asserts that keyword search warrants are incompatible with constitutional protections and have no place in a democratic society. These warrants are concerning because they do not target specific individuals, but instead require the search of an entire database based on keywords specified by the police. The EFF argues that these warrants violate constitutional rights and harm protected speech and the right to receive information. They also argue that these warrants could have a chilling effect on users seeking out information, as they may fear their searches being monitored by the police. Overall, the EFF and other organizations are urging the Pennsylvania Supreme Court to find keyword search warrants unconstitutional."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/digiday-privacy-and-ai-policies-to-watch-in-2024/", "title": "Digiday: Privacy and AI policies to watch in 2024", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "There are concerns about AI beyond generative AI. Advocates want governments to regulate algorithmic feeds on social media and researchers warn about risks to consumer data and child safety. Regulators in the UK have questioned Snap about the safety of its \"My AI\" chatbot for kids. Last year, 10 US states added AI regulations to consumer privacy laws, and more are expected to be introduced in 2024. EPIC, a privacy advocacy group, works to protect privacy and democratic values."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/digital-rights-lgbtq-people-2023-review", "title": "Digital Rights for LGBTQ+ People: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "An increase in anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance globally is resulting in restrictions on freedom of expression and privacy. Data surveillance poses a threat to LGBTQ+ individuals, and there have been instances of restrictions on access to gender-affirming healthcare. Student monitoring tools have flagged LGBTQ+ content, leading to a harmful environment for students. Cybercrime and surveillance legislation in the Middle East and North Africa have negatively impacted LGBTQ+ rights. Colonial-era laws are still used to imprison and intimidate LGBTQ+ individuals in many countries. Proposed laws in Uganda, Ghana, and Kenya aim to criminalize homosexuality and restrict LGBTQ+ expression online. Efforts are being made to oppose these laws and fight for digital rights."}
