{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/taking-back-web-decentralization-2023-review", "title": "Taking Back the Web with Decentralization: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The internet is becoming increasingly centralized, leading to a pushback from users who want more autonomy. Users are turning to decentralized platforms in search of privacy and free expression. The rise of federated microblogging platforms like Mastodon and Bluesky has been significant, with Meta (formerly Facebook) also entering the space. Interoperability and the need for common protocols are key challenges in the decentralized social media landscape. The European Union's Digital Markets Act aims to promote interoperability among messaging platforms. Decentralized web initiatives like DWeb Camp have gained attention, as well as the exploration of blockchain applications beyond finance. Content moderation is a complex issue in the decentralized space, but community-level moderation and task forces like the one created by the Atlantic Council are providing solutions. The decentralization movement is growing, with new services, protocols, and governance models emerging. There is a need for comprehensive data privacy reforms and protection of online free speech."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/states-attack-young-peoples-constitutional-right-use-social-media-2023-year-review", "title": "States Attack Young People\u2019s Constitutional Right to Use Social Media: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Legislatures in over half of the country have introduced bills to limit young people's use of social media, with some proposals blocking adults' access as well. However, many of these laws have been blocked for violating the First Amendment. California's Age Appropriate Design Code Act (AADC) set the stage for these regulations, but it has also been blocked. States like Utah, Arkansas, and Texas have passed social media regulations for young people, but they also face legal challenges. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes age verification requirements and advocates for comprehensive data privacy legislation instead. EFF warns that laws that restrict online content based on age can impede everyone's right to access information and violate privacy rights. In 2023, there has been an increase in anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives globally, and Google has tightened its control over online tracking and ad-targeting technology. EFF has also fought against attempts to undermine encryption in Europe. Throughout the year, EFF has worked to protect digital rights at the state level across the country."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/trenches-broadband-policy-2023-year-review", "title": "In the Trenches of Broadband Policy: 2023 Year In Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "EFF (Electronic Frontier Foundation) advocates for affordable, accessible internet access for all. Monopolistic ISPs are hindering the construction of infrastructure to maintain control over the broadband market. New York City Mayor Eric Adams abandoned plans for public fiber infrastructure and instead introduced a subsidy plan for existing ISPs. California also reduced the miles of fiber infrastructure to be built, excluding underserved communities. The FCC received its fifth commissioner, allowing them to address net neutrality and digital discrimination. The fight for affordable, accessible internet will require investment in physical infrastructure and nondiscrimination rules. The article also discusses network neutrality, breaking up ad-tech companies, banning surveillance ads, and opening up app stores. The author emphasizes the importance of oversight for companies controlling internet access. Oakland passed a law giving renters a choice of internet service providers."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/equitable-access-law-got-stronger-year", "title": "Equitable Access to the Law Got Stronger: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Public.Resource.Org won a victory in September when the D.C. Circuit appeals court ruled that non-commercial copying of codes and standards incorporated into the law is not copyright infringement. This decision allows Public Resource, a nonprofit organization, to continue posting these laws online for free public access. The court emphasized that the purpose of the copying is to provide the public with a comprehensive repository of the law. It also acknowledged that Public Resource's online postings offer more equitable access compared to the limited accessibility of standards organizations' reading rooms. This ruling has significance in ensuring that the law remains accessible to all and allows for greater participation in government."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/surveillance-self-defense-2023-year-review", "title": "Surveillance Self-Defense: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Surveillance Self-Defense (SSD) has provided expert guidance for security and privacy for 14 years and has seen a number of updates and changes. This year, they tackled updates for Signal and WhatsApp, introduced new guides for choosing a password manager and using Tor on mobile devices, and provided guidance on passkeys and quirks in encrypted messaging apps. They also discussed a credential stuffing attack on 23andMe, Google's Privacy Sandbox feature, securing Android tablets, and Apple's Advanced Data Protection. Meta rolled out end-to-end encryption for Messenger, and EFF worked on explaining new consumer security technologies. {"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/identifying-privacy-risks-and-implementing-best-practices-for-body-related-data-in-immersive-technologies/", "title": "Identifying Privacy Risks and Implementing Best Practices for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The Future of Privacy Forum has developed a Risk Framework for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies to help organizations protect people's privacy in the collection and use of body-related data.\n- Organizations should analyze the unique risks associated with body-related data and implement data practices that earn the public's trust.\n- Organizations should ensure that their use of body-related data is fair, ethical, and responsible, as this data can provide significant insights into an individual's personal life.\n- Organizations should assess the risks their data practices raise and implement legal, technical, and policy safeguards to minimize privacy risks.\n- Best practices should be intentional, comprehensive, and collaborative, and should be evaluated regularly as technology and regulations change.\n- Risk-based approaches can help organizations prioritize user privacy and develop best practices for body-related data in immersive technologies."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/explaining-the-crosswalk-between-singapores-ai-verify-testing-framework-and-the-u-s-nist-ai-risk-management-framework/", "title": "Explaining the Crosswalk Between Singapore\u2019s AI Verify Testing Framework and The U.S. NIST AI Risk Management Framework", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and the U.S.'s National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) have published a \"Crosswalk\" that aligns IMDA's AI Verify testing framework with NIST's AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF). This mapping document aims to harmonize international AI governance frameworks and reduce industry costs in meeting multiple requirements. The AI Verify framework allows organizations to assess the responsible and trustworthy deployment of their AI systems, while the AI RMF provides voluntary guidance on managing AI risks. The Crosswalk helps users understand how adopting one framework can meet the criteria of the other. This collaboration sets an example for future international cooperation in AI governance."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/fpf-in-2023-a-year-in-review/", "title": "FPF in 2023: A Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) expanded globally and domestically in 2023, focusing on AI. FPF provided training and hosted discussions on AI-related topics. They closely followed developments in data protection and privacy in various regions, such as Asia, the European Union, Africa, and Latin America. FPF also engaged in discussions and events worldwide, including conferences in Washington, DC, Brussels, Tokyo, Singapore, Bermuda, and Tel Aviv. They provided in-depth analysis and explanations of privacy laws in different countries, such as India's Digital Personal Data Protection Act. FPF also played a key role in informing regulatory agencies and state legislatures on privacy in emerging technologies like AI. They analyzed and commented on privacy laws in various US states and recognized privacy research with the Privacy Papers for Policymakers Award. FPF focused on the protection of children online and provided recommendations for schools and districts. They also addressed issues related to age assurance technologies and youth privacy policy. FPF released a risk framework for handling body-related data in immersive technologies and explored the intersection of immersive technology with AI, advertising, and education. They examined open banking and data-sharing for research, producing case studies and recommendations. FPF organized peer-to-peer meetings and calls for senior executives working on data protection compliance issues. Overall, FPF emphasized collaboration across sectors and disciplines to advance practical safeguards for data uses that benefit society."}
{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/risk-framework-for-body-related-data-in-immersive-technologies/", "title": "Risk Framework for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum has released a risk framework for body-related data in immersive technologies. The framework helps organizations structure the collection, use, and transfer of body-related data in technologies like extended reality and virtual worlds. It guides organizations through documenting their data practices, complying with laws, evaluating privacy and safety risks, and implementing best practices. The framework is not limited to immersive technologies and can be useful for organizations handling body-related data in other contexts. It is important for organizations to understand their data practices to identify privacy risks, ensure legal compliance, and communicate about their practices. Organizations should proactively identify and minimize risks, assess the fairness and ethics of their data practices, and implement best practices across the data lifecycle. They should also evaluate and update their practices regularly. Subscribing to the FPF newsletter can provide updates and information about upcoming events."}

State-level activity on privacy increased in 2023 with the number of states with comprehensive privacy laws growing. Enforcement of state privacy laws has been scarce, but indicators suggest that public enforcement may increase in 2024. {"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/what-ive-been-reading-november", "title": "What I've been reading - November", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Title: The Promises and Perils of Artificial Intelligence\n\nWith the rapid advancement of technology, artificial intelligence (AI) has become a topic of great interest and concern. AI, the ability of machines to imitate human intelligence and perform tasks that typically require human intelligence, holds enormous potential but also poses significant challenges.\n\nOne of the key promises of AI is its potential to revolutionize various industries and improve our daily lives. For example, AI-powered algorithms can analyze vast amounts of data to provide valuable insights and predictions in fields such as healthcare, finance, and transportation. With AI, doctors can diagnose diseases more accurately, financial institutions can detect fraud more effectively, and self-driving cars can navigate roads more safely.\n\nHowever, along with these promises come potential perils. One major concern is the ethical implications of AI. As AI systems become more sophisticated, they may make decisions that have unintended consequences or exhibit biased behavior. This raises questions about who is accountable for the outcomes generated by AI algorithms and how to ensure fairness and transparency in their decision-making processes.\n\nAnother challenge is the impact of AI on the job market. While AI can automate repetitive and mundane tasks, it also raises concerns about potential job displacement. As machines become more capable, some jobs may no longer require human involvement, leading to unemployment and economic inequality. The challenge lies in finding ways to harness the benefits of AI while mitigating its negative impact on employment.\n\nAdditionally, privacy and security are significant concerns in the age of AI. As AI systems collect and analyze vast amounts of personal data, there is a risk of data breaches and unauthorized access. Safeguarding individuals' privacy and developing robust security measures are crucial to prevent misuse of personal information and protect against cyber threats.\n\nIn conclusion, AI holds considerable promise in transforming various industries and enhancing our lives. However, it also presents significant challenges, including ethical considerations, job displacement, and privacy concerns. Addressing these challenges will require careful planning, collaboration between policymakers and industry leaders, and the development of comprehensive regulations and guidelines to ensure the responsible and beneficial use of AI technology.\n\nKey ideas:\n- AI has the potential to revolutionize industries and improve daily lives.\n- Ethical implications, such as transparency and accountability, need to be addressed.\n- The impact of AI on the job market and potential unemployment should be considered.\n- Privacy and security measures are crucial in the age of AI."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/7-reasons-why-social-media-disinformation", "title": "\ud83d\udcc8 7 Reasons why social media disinformation is on the rise", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Disinformation is spreading faster and becoming more viral, with additional incentives for fabricating false information. {"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/tiktoks-345m-fine-might-not-be-enough", "title": "TikTok's \u20ac345M fine might not be enough", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) has fined TikTok \u20ac345 million for privacy violations, specifically related to GDPR obligations regarding children's data. The DPC found infringements on several GDPR articles, including lawfulness, transparency, purpose limitation, and data minimization. The European Data Protection Board (EDPB) supported this decision and emphasized the importance of clear privacy settings and limiting data processing. TikTok argued that the criticisms are no longer relevant as they have made changes to their practices. However, there are still concerns about TikTok's privacy user experience (UX) and its impact on users' best interests. The article also discusses the need for companies to prioritize privacy UX, as fines and harm to their brand can occur if they fail to do so."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13255", "title": "Constructing a fully homomorphic encryption scheme with the Yoneda Lemma. (arXiv:2401.13255v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The Yoneda Lemma is applied to redefine the foundations of homomorphic cryptosystems. Several widely used systems are shown to derive from the Yoneda Lemma. This leads to the development of the Yoneda Encryption Scheme, which provides a unified framework for homomorphic encryption. A new fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) scheme is introduced that can process encrypted multiplications and additions without additional techniques. This opens up possibilities for using model theory and forcing techniques in cryptography to design FHE schemes."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13262", "title": "Designing Redistribution Mechanisms for Reducing Transaction Fees in Blockchains. (arXiv:2401.13262v1 [cs.GT])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Blockchains use Transaction Fee Mechanisms (TFMs) to determine transaction fees. High demand and limited resources have led to high fees. Transaction Fee Redistribution Mechanisms (TFRMs) aim to reduce fees by redistributing collected payments. It is challenging to apply TFRMs due to unconfirmed transactions and strategic manipulation. The proposed \\emph{Robust} TFRM (\\textsf{R-TFRM}) compromises miner rationality to guarantee rebates. The \\emph{robust} and \\emph{rational} TFRM (\\textsf{R}$^2$\\textsf{-TFRM}) uses trusted randomness to ensure rationality and positive rebates. TFRMs offer a promising solution to reduce transaction fees in public blockchains."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13327", "title": "Generating Synthetic Health Sensor Data for Privacy-Preserving Wearable Stress Detection. (arXiv:2401.13327v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Smartwatch health sensor data is being used for smart health applications and patient monitoring, including stress detection.\n- Medical data is sensitive and resource-intensive to acquire for research.\n- A privacy-aware method is introduced to synthesize multi-sensor smartwatch health readings related to stress moments.\n- Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Differential Privacy (DP) are used to protect patient information during model training.\n- Quality assessments are used to ensure the integrity of the synthetic data.\n- The synthetic data is used to enhance machine learning models for stress detection.\n- The GAN-based augmentation methods improve model performance in both non-private and private training scenarios.\n- Differentially private synthetic data has the potential to optimize utility-privacy trade-offs, especially when real training samples are limited."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13578", "title": "WPDA: Frequency-based Backdoor Attack with Wavelet Packet Decomposition. (arXiv:2401.13578v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Key ideas in this article:\n\n- Backdoor attacks are a security threat to deep neural networks (DNNs) in image classification.\n- The proposed attack injects a backdoor into the model by manipulating training data.\n- Existing data poisoning-based attacks have low success rates and are easily defended against.\n- The novel frequency-based backdoor attack uses Wavelet Packet Decomposition (WPD) to analyze the frequency distribution of the dataset.\n- The attack selectively injects trigger information into key frequency regions.\n- The method has a high attack success rate and can bypass most defense methods.\n- Visualization analyses are provided to explain the effectiveness of the attack."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13584", "title": "Securing the Invisible Thread: A Comprehensive Analysis of BLE Tracker Security in Apple AirTags and Samsung SmartTags. (arXiv:2401.13584v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- This study analyzes the security landscape of Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) tracking systems, specifically Apple AirTags and Samsung SmartTags.\n- The study explores various attack vectors such as physical tampering, firmware exploitation, signal spoofing, eavesdropping, jamming, app security flaws, Bluetooth security weaknesses, location spoofing, threats to owner devices, and cloud-related vulnerabilities.\n- AirTags prioritize user privacy but suffer from device authentication challenges, leading to successful spoofing instances.\n- SmartTags are designed to prevent beacon spoofing but raise concerns about cloud security and user privacy.\n- Both devices lack secure boot processes, making them vulnerable to OS modification and potential attacks.\n- The paper predicts that future BLE tracking systems will enhance security features to comply with evolving privacy regulations and integrate into the broader IoT ecosystem."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.10227", "title": "Adversarial Detection by Approximation of Ensemble Boundary. (arXiv:2211.10227v4 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "A method of detecting adversarial attacks in Deep Neural Networks is proposed using a Walsh coefficients-based ensemble. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02344", "title": "TrojanPuzzle: Covertly Poisoning Code-Suggestion Models. (arXiv:2301.02344v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Automatic code suggestion tools like GitHub Copilot have revolutionized software engineering, but they are vulnerable to data poisoning attacks. These attacks involve injecting malicious data into the model's training, influencing its suggestions at runtime. Previous attacks could be detected and removed, but new attacks called COVERT and TROJANPUZZLE can bypass static analysis by hiding the poison data in out-of-context regions like docstrings. TROJANPUZZLE is particularly advanced, as it suggests the entire malicious payload without explicitly including suspicious parts, making it difficult to detect. These attacks have serious implications for practitioners using code-suggestion models."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12236", "title": "The Surprising Harmfulness of Benign Overfitting for Adversarial Robustness. (arXiv:2401.12236v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Recent studies show that large machine learning models can generalize well even when trained on noisy data. However, this study reveals that benign overfitting, where the model fits the data almost perfectly, can be harmful when dealing with adversarial manipulation. The min-norm estimator in overparameterized linear models is vulnerable to adversarial attacks. Additionally, there is a trade-off between the standard risk and the adversarial risk in ridge regression estimators. These findings also align with observations in deep neural networks. In practice, while the true target function may be robust against adversarial attacks, overfitted neural networks are not."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12383", "title": "A New Class of Algorithms for Finding Short Vectors in Lattices Lifted from Co-dimension $k$ Codes. (arXiv:2401.12383v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "We introduce algorithms for finding short vectors in lattices, using packings and projections. We use sorting and Euclidean reduction to converge projections to zero. With large input sets, we can obtain short lattice vectors. Our approach works for high dimensional lattices and yields shorter vectors for larger dimensions. We also present extensions and generalizations of our method."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12391", "title": "Approximation of Pufferfish Privacy for Gaussian Priors. (arXiv:2401.12391v1 [cs.IT])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "This paper discusses the approximation of pufferfish privacy when the adversary's belief of published data is Gaussian distributed. The use of Monge's optimal transport plan allows for the achievement of $(\u03b5, \u03b4)$-pufferfish privacy by calibrating additive Laplace noise to the differences in mean and variance of the conditioned Gaussian distributions. The method is applicable to private summation or average queries, with sufficient conditions provided for approximating $\u03b5$-statistical indistinguishability in sensitive data. The approach is further extended to arbitrary prior beliefs trained by Gaussian mixture models, achieving $(\u03b5,\u03b4)$-pufferfish privacy by calibrating noise to a convex combination of mean and variance differences between Gaussian components."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12436", "title": "Wasserstein Differential Privacy. (arXiv:2401.12436v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Differential privacy has made progress in privacy-preserving machine learning, but existing frameworks lack certain conditions to become reliable metrics. We propose Wasserstein differential privacy, a framework that satisfies important properties and performs better than others. We introduce the Wasserstein accountant, a privacy accounting method for stochastic gradient descent scenarios. Experiments show that Wasserstein accountant provides stable privacy budgets and reduces overestimation. Code available on GitHub."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12443", "title": "Patch2QL: Discover Cognate Defects in Open Source Software Supply Chain With Auto-generated Static Analysis Rules. (arXiv:2401.12443v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "The article discusses the issue of cognate defects in the open source software ecosystem and proposes a technique for detecting these defects. The technique involves generating SAST rules by extracting syntax and semantic information from code versions and comparing them. A prototype tool called Patch2QL was implemented and used to identify vulnerabilities in popular upstream software, as well as numerous potential security issues. The technique outperforms general-purpose SAST and signature-based mechanisms in detecting cognate defects."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12542", "title": "Multi-Party Private Set Intersection: A Circuit-Based Protocol with Jaccard Similarity for Secure and Efficient Anomaly Detection in Network Traffic. (arXiv:2401.12542v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "We present a circuit-based protocol for multi-party private set intersection (PSI) that allows m parties to compute the intersection of their datasets without revealing additional information. Our protocol builds upon the two-party Sort-Compare-Shuffle (SCS) protocol and exhibits acceptable performance. It completes in just 19 seconds with 7 parties and set sizes of 2^12. Circuit-based protocols like ours have an advantage over custom protocols for more complex computation. We showcase this advantage by incorporating a module for calculating the Jaccard similarity metric, which can be used in network traffic analysis for anomaly detection. Our protocol is versatile and preserves privacy while efficiently identifying abnormal patterns in network flow."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12578", "title": "ToDA: Target-oriented Diffusion Attacker against Recommendation System. (arXiv:2401.12578v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Recommendation systems are important for web services but are vulnerable to attacks that manipulate user profiles. This article proposes a novel Target-oriented Diffusion Attack model (ToDA) that uses diffusion models to craft deceptive user profiles for biased recommendations. ToDA incorporates a pre-trained autoencoder and a Latent Diffusion Attacker (LDA) to introduce noise and steer recommendations towards targeted items. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of ToDA and highlight the power of generative models in this context."}

SCORPION also collects user data and has positive evaluation results."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12633", "title": "Heterogeneity- and homophily-induced vulnerability of a P2P network formation model: the IOTA auto-peering protocol. (arXiv:2401.12633v1 [cs.SI])", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "IOTA is a distributed ledger technology that uses an auto-peering algorithm to connect peers based on their \"Mana\" reputation. This paper aims to assess the vulnerability of the IOTA network to eclipse attacks. The study interprets the auto-peering algorithm as a random network model and analyzes its properties. It also presents a potential strategy for attackers to eclipse a significant portion of the network and estimates the associated costs and damage. The IOTA auto-peering network is categorized as a type of homophile random network."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09050", "title": "Determining Distributions of Security Means for WSNs based on the Model of a Neighbourhood Watch. (arXiv:2212.09050v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Neighbourhood watch allows communities to distribute security tasks among members. Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) need security protocols to prevent eavesdropping and tampering. A distributed security scheme for WSNs aims to increase defense against attacks. The framework uses undirected graphs to partition WSNs into distinct security means. The problems are challenging but can be solved using linear programs. Random unit disk graphs are used to evaluate the computability of the programs."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03510", "title": "Supervising Smart Home Device Interactions: A Profile-Based Firewall Approach. (arXiv:2310.03510v3 [cs.NI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Internet of Things (IoT) devices, like Smart Home networks, are lacking in security, leading to recent attacks. The IETF's MUD standard aims to simplify and secure IoT devices on networks using MUD files. However, MUD is not sufficient to describe traffic patterns and interactions in modern Smart Home platforms. This article introduces a new language that allows more expressive device profiles and considers traffic interdependencies. The language can be translated into efficient firewall code using NFTables to block unauthorized traffic. The authors evaluate the approach on Smart Home device traffic and find that it effectively blocks unwanted traffic with minimal latency."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10787", "title": "Hybrid Online Certificate Status Protocol with Certificate Revocation List for Smart Grid Public Key Infrastructure. (arXiv:2401.10787v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Hsu et al. (2022) proposed a secure cryptographic scheme for smart grid meters using a public key infrastructure. They developed a mechanism called Certificate Management over CMS to establish secure protocols for enrollment and certificate status. However, their implementation had a single OCSP server handling all queries. In response, we introduced a Hybrid Online Certificate Status Protocol to improve efficiency and scalability in smart grid PKI environments with thousands of end-meters. Simulations showed increased efficiency and a more robust architecture."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.11748", "title": "GI-PIP: Do We Require Impractical Auxiliary Dataset for Gradient Inversion Attacks?. (arXiv:2401.11748v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-25", "summary": "Deep gradient inversion attacks pose a serious threat to Federated Learning. Existing methods rely on impractical assumptions and violate the data partitioning principle. A new method called GI-PIP is proposed, which uses anomaly detection models to capture the underlying distribution from limited data. Experimental results show that GI-PIP achieves high PSNR recovery using significantly less data compared to GAN-based methods. GI-PIP also exhibits superior distribution generalization. This approach poses a substantial threat to real-world FL."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZQma8TmR6S8GcLbt9/epistemic-hell", "title": "Epistemic Hell", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Summarized key ideas:\n- The article discusses three examples of situations where common sense and logical reasoning have led to incorrect conclusions: the detoxification technique of manioc in indigenous societies, the history of the cure for scurvy, and the understanding of heredity in livestock breeding.\n- These examples highlight the challenges of navigating through epistemic hells, where appearances and intuition can be misleading.\n- The article emphasizes the importance of statistical data, random experimentation, and unlearning prior knowledge in escaping epistemic hells.\n- The potential existence of epistemic hells in fields like physics and consciousness is also mentioned.\n- The article suggests that a revolutionary breakthrough often requires a quantum leap to an entirely new region of thought."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/63hbH7exm3xrW2gzr/rand-report-finds-no-effect-of-current-llms-on-viability-of", "title": "RAND report finds no effect of current LLMs on viability of bioterrorism attacks", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Existing AI models do not make it easier to plan bioterrorism attacks, according to a RAND experiment. The experiment involved \"red teams\" role-playing as non-state actors trying to plan a biological attack. The teams had access to the internet and an AI assistant, and their plans were scored for feasibility. The average viability of the plans generated with AI assistance was statistically indistinguishable from those created without AI assistance. None of the submitted plans were deemed viable. The study also found that historical evidence shows a very low percentage of terrorist attacks involving biological weapons. The experiment was carried out with safeguards in place, but it's unclear how it would apply to open-source models where safeguards could be removed. The methodology could have been improved by including non-experts in the study. The findings provide a positive update on the dangers of AI models used in bioterrorism planning. Further research could be done to assess the capabilities of future models."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZeXoCJ426CocFzxJq/doing-a-basic-life-focused-cost-benefit-analysis", "title": "Doing a Basic Life-Focused Cost-Benefit Analysis", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Key ideas in this article: \n- This post provides a simplified procedure for conducting a cost-benefit analysis using life-years as the unit of analysis.\n- The analysis focuses on the time cost rather than just the monetary cost, as the time cost is often larger for most policies.\n- To estimate costs, consult the operational plan and consider the time spent by different individuals involved in implementing the policy.\n- Benefits can be estimated by looking at studies or conducting expert elicitation to determine health benefits.\n- Convert the benefits into life-years gained by using DALY values for different illnesses or conditions.\n- Compare the annualized cost to the annualized life-years gained to determine if the policy passes the cost-benefit test."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/asi4mi7xJj7ue8DhX/surgery-works-well-without-the-fda", "title": "Surgery Works Well Without The FDA", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Most drugs in clinical trials are less effective or safe than existing options, so releasing everything onto the market would do more harm than good. Companies test and release competitive products in other industries, but pharmaceuticals are different because their characteristics are discovered rather than engineered. Surgery, which doesn't have FDA oversight, faces similar information problems as pharmaceuticals but still functions well. The WHO claims that surgical interventions account for 13% of the world's total disability-adjusted life years. The FDA and other regulatory bodies are important for medicine, and comparing surgery to the drug market is not ideal. Pharmaceutical companies releasing dud or dangerous drugs might not ruin their business, as seen with examples like Wyeth and Celltech. However, the potential downsides outweigh the benefits of removing medical regulators."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/BaoA3gz7xRaqn764J/gaia-network-an-illustrated-primer", "title": "Gaia Network: An Illustrated Primer", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The Gaia Network is a decentralized system that aims to connect causal models to improve scientific efficiency, decision-making, and AI safety through collective intelligence. It goes beyond just AI safety and can have a transformative impact on various use cases. The network can make science more effective and efficient by improving accountability, reducing inefficiencies, and aggregating posterior distributions from different studies into pooled distributions. It can also enhance decision-making processes by providing quantitative impact metrics, aiding in supply chain management, and guiding investment portfolios. The Gaia Network can serve as a distributed AI scientist, evaluating the safety of high-stakes actions and incorporating epistemic humility into its evaluations. Ultimately, it aims to tackle AI safety as a fringe benefit of pursuing knowledge and better decision-making. The network has the potential to address global challenges and enable coordinated strategies for a positive-sum and cooperative future. Although ambitious, the capabilities of the Gaia Network can be implemented with existing technology and are already being explored and developed by organizations and individuals in the Gaia Consortium. The goal is to establish an open and collaborative R&D effort to build these capabilities."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13672", "title": "Transforming Agriculture with Intelligent Data Management and Insights. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13697", "title": "Toward Robust Multimodal Learning using Multimodal Foundational Models. (arXiv:2401.13697v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Multimodal sentiment analysis tasks often assume complete multimodal data, but real-world scenarios often have incomplete data.\n- CLIP-based multimodal foundational models have shown impressive performance, but they can't handle scenarios with missing modalities.\n- The proposed framework, TRML, addresses this issue by using generated virtual modalities to replace missing modalities.\n- TRML aligns the semantic spaces between the generated and missing modalities.\n- The model captures the semantics of missing modalities by leveraging the aligned cross-modal semantic space.\n- Experiments show the superiority of TRML on three benchmark datasets for multimodal sentiment analysis."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13713", "title": "EMP: Effective Multidimensional Persistence for Graph Representation Learning. (arXiv:2401.13713v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Topological data analysis (TDA) is important in machine learning and is used for tasks such as manifold learning and graph classification. Persistent homology (PH) is a key technique in TDA that captures the evolution of structures in data. However, existing PH tools only consider a single parameter. To address this limitation, the Effective Multidimensional Persistence (EMP) framework is introduced, allowing the simultaneous variation of multiple scale parameters. EMP integrates descriptor functions and produces expressive data summaries that align well with machine learning models. The framework is proven to be stable and shows superior performance in graph classification compared to other methods."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13716", "title": "Can I trust my fake data -- A comprehensive quality assessment framework for synthetic tabular data in healthcare. (arXiv:2401.13716v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Ensuring safe adoption of AI tools in healthcare requires access to sufficient data. Synthetic data has been suggested as a solution to address privacy and regulatory concerns. However, there are competing metrics with differing taxonomies for evaluating the quality of synthetic data. A comprehensive literature review was conducted on quality evaluation metrics for synthetic data in the context of healthcare. Based on this review, a conceptual framework for quality assurance was developed, which includes dimensions such as fairness and carbon footprint. The framework was benchmarked against a practical case from the Dutch National Cancer Registry. The authors propose that increasing transparency and reducing safety risks will build trust in synthetic data and accelerate the development of trustworthy AI tools in healthcare. The literature review showed a lack of emphasis on algorithmic fairness and carbon footprint metrics, with a focus instead on statistical similarity and a scarcity of sequential logic detection. A consensus-backed framework that encompasses all relevant quality dimensions can provide assurance for safe and responsible real-life applications of synthetic data."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13722", "title": "Proactive Emotion Tracker: AI-Driven Continuous Mood and Emotion Monitoring. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13751", "title": "A Systematic Approach to Robustness Modelling for Deep Convolutional Neural Networks. (arXiv:2401.13751v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Convolutional neural networks are widely used in various fields but increasing model size doesn't necessarily lead to better performance. The number of hidden layers in the ResNet model is examined on different datasets, testing parameters like model size, floating point precision, and data noise level. A method is proposed to approximate the failure rate of a model using induced failures, which helps determine if the cost of training a model outweighs the cost of attacking it. Empirical measurements show that larger models are not significantly more robust against attacks but are more expensive to train."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13752", "title": "Explaining Image Classifiers. Additionally, the article suggests that Halpern's definition is capable of addressing challenges related to explaining absence and rare events in image classifiers."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13770", "title": "AlphaMapleSAT: An MCTS-based Cube-and-Conquer SAT Solver for Hard Combinatorial Problems. (arXiv:2401.13770v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "AlphaMapleSAT is a new SAT solving method that uses Monte Carlo Tree Search and Cube-and-Conquer techniques to efficiently solve difficult combinatorial problems. It introduces a deductively-driven MCTS-based lookahead cubing technique, which performs a heuristic search to find effective cubes while keeping the cubing cost low. AlphaMapleSAT is compared to the March CnC solver on challenging problems, showing significant speed improvements in parallel and sequential elapsed real time."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13827", "title": "Traffic Learning and Proactive UAV Trajectory Planning for Data Uplink in Markovian IoT Models. The authors present a learning-based framework that predicts traffic arrival and optimizes the trajectory and scheduling of multiple UAVs. They compare two traffic predictors, forward algorithm (FA) and long short-term memory (LSTM), and propose a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach to optimize the policy of each UAV. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13849", "title": "TPD: Enhancing Student Language Model Reasoning via Principle Discovery and Guidance. (arXiv:2401.13849v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown impressive reasoning abilities, but transferring these capabilities from larger models to smaller ones is challenging. Existing approaches rely on fine-tuning data or continuous interactions with a superior teacher LLM. We propose Teaching via Principle Discovery (TPD), a teacher-student framework that mimics human learning. The teacher LLM generates instructions and corrective principles based on the student LLM's errors, guiding instruction refinement and example selection. TPD does not require further intervention once the student model starts making inferences. In experiments, TPD significantly improves the student model's performance, achieving an average improvement of 6.2%."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13883", "title": "Domain-Independent Dynamic Programming. (arXiv:2401.13883v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Combinatorial optimization problems can be solved using model-based paradigms like mixed-integer programming (MIP) and constraint programming (CP). We propose a new paradigm called domain-independent dynamic programming (DIDP), which decouples modeling and problem solving. We introduce the Dynamic Programming Description Language (DyPDL) to define DP models based on a state transition system. Heuristic search algorithms can be used to solve DyPDL models, and we propose seven DIDP solvers. Experimental comparisons show that DIDP outperforms MIP and CP solvers in various combinatorial optimization problem classes."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13904", "title": "Empowering Machines to Think Like Chemists: Unveiling Molecular Structure-Polarity Relationships with Hierarchical Symbolic Regression. (arXiv:2401.13904v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) is a vital method for analyzing molecular polarity. However, interpreting predictive models for TLC, particularly those powered by artificial intelligence, is difficult. Current approaches struggle to balance expressiveness and interpretability. To address this, a new method called Unsupervised Hierarchical Symbolic Regression (UHiSR) has been introduced. UHiSR combines hierarchical neural networks and symbolic regression to automatically identify chemical-intuitive polarity indices and discover interpretable equations linking molecular structure to chromatographic behavior."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13913", "title": "Spectral Clustering for Discrete Distributions. (arXiv:2401.13913v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Discrete distribution clustering (D2C) is traditionally solved using Wasserstein barycenter methods, which assume that clusters can be well represented by barycenters. However, this assumption may not hold in real applications. In this study, a new framework based on spectral clustering and distribution affinity measures is proposed for D2C. The framework utilizes maximum mean discrepancy and Wasserstein distance to improve clustering accuracy. To enhance scalability, linear optimal transport is used to efficiently construct affinity matrices on large datasets. The proposed methods have theoretical guarantees for success in clustering distributions and have shown superior performance in terms of accuracy and efficiency in experiments with synthetic and real data."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13935", "title": "A New Paradigm for Counterfactual Reasoning in Fairness and Recourse. (arXiv:2401.13935v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Counterfactual reasoning is important in auditing and understanding AI systems. The traditional approach is to imagine and simulate hypothetical interventions. However, interventions on legally-protected characteristics like race may not fit this paradigm. A new approach, called backtracking counterfactuals, considers alternate initial conditions while keeping these characteristics fixed. This allows for addressing social concerns without relying on demographic interventions."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13968", "title": "Dynamic Long-Term Time-Series Forecasting via Meta Transformer Networks. (arXiv:2401.13968v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "A new approach called Meta-Transformer Networks (MANTRA) is proposed to solve the challenges of long-term time-series forecasting. MANTRA uses fast and slow learners to handle dynamic learning environments. Fast learners learn different aspects of data distributions and adapt quickly to changes, while slow learners tailor suitable representations to fast learners. Experimental results show that MANTRA outperforms baseline algorithms by at least 3% in both multivariate and univariate settings. Source codes for MANTRA are available on GitHub."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13979", "title": "Leeroo Orchestrator: Elevating LLMs Performance Through Model Integration. (arXiv:2401.13979v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "We propose an architecture that uses multiple trained LLMs to create a state-of-the-art model. The framework includes an orchestrator that selects the best LLMs for optimal task execution. We generated training data through a loop of query generation, orchestration, and evaluation. Our evaluation showed that our Leeroo orchestrator performed as well as the Mixtral model at two-thirds of the cost. Increasing the allowed cost resulted in a 5% increase in accuracy, reaching 75.9%. Integrating GPT4 into the model pool further improved performance, with Leeroo matching GPT4 at half the cost and even exceeding its results with a 25% cost reduction. This architecture has the potential to create cost-effective LLMs with superior performance through the synergy of multiple models."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13986", "title": "Towards Consistent Natural-Language Explanations via Explanation-Consistency Finetuning. (arXiv:2401.13986v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Large language models (LLMs) often generate convincing explanations, but they can be inconsistent. This can lead to different explanations for related questions. To address this, a method called explanation-consistency finetuning (EC-finetuning) has been proposed. It involves adapting LLMs to generate more consistent explanations by finetuning them on synthetic data. EC-finetuning has shown a 10.0% improvement in explanation consistency on four finetuning datasets and also generalizes well to out-of-distribution datasets. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13996", "title": "Investigate-Consolidate-Exploit: A General Strategy for Inter-Task Agent Self-Evolution. (arXiv:2401.13996v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "This paper introduces Investigate-Consolidate-Exploit (ICE), a strategy that enhances AI agents' adaptability and flexibility through inter-task self-evolution. ICE promotes knowledge transfer between tasks for genuine self-evolution, similar to human experience learning. It investigates planning and execution trajectories, consolidates them into simplified workflows and pipelines, and exploits them for improved task execution. Experiments on the XAgent framework show ICE's effectiveness, reducing API calls by 80% and decreasing the model's capability demand. When combined with GPT-3.5, ICE performs as well as raw GPT-4 across agent tasks. This self-evolution approach represents a paradigm shift in agent design, contributing to a more robust AI community, ecosystem, and closer to full autonomy."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14003", "title": "ConstraintChecker: A Plugin for Large Language Models to Reason on Commonsense Knowledge Bases. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14011", "title": "CMMU: A Benchmark for Chinese Multi-modal Multi-type Question Understanding and Reasoning. (arXiv:2401.14011v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Multi-modal large language models have achieved remarkable progress in understanding and reasoning abilities. However, evaluating their domain-specific knowledge remains challenging. To address this, a new benchmark called CMMU is introduced for multi-modal and multi-type question understanding and reasoning in Chinese. CMMU consists of 3,603 questions in 7 subjects, spanning from primary to high school knowledge. The benchmark includes multiple-choice, multiple-response, and fill-in-the-blank questions, posing greater challenges for language models. A rigorous evaluation strategy called ShiftCheck is proposed to assess multiple-choice questions by reducing position bias and analyzing its impact. The benchmark results show that CMMU significantly challenges the latest multi-modal language models."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14067", "title": "Ta'keed: The First Generative Fact-Checking System for Arabic Claims. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14079", "title": "From Requirements to Architecture: An AI-Based Journey to Semi-Automatically Generate Software Architectures. {"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14086", "title": "Generating Likely Counterfactuals Using Sum-Product Networks. (arXiv:2401.14086v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Decisions made by AI systems need to be explained due to user demand and recent regulations. Counterfactual explanations, which consider the \"distance from the sample\", are commonly used but often result in unlikely explanations. A system using mixed-integer optimization (MIO) is proposed to provide high-likelihood explanations. This system uses a Sum-Product Network (SPN) to estimate the likelihood of a counterfactual. Numerical comparisons against other methods for generating counterfactual explanations are provided."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14089", "title": "GQHAN: A Grover-inspired Quantum Hard Attention Network. (arXiv:2401.14089v1 [quant-ph])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Quantum Machine Learning (QML) models struggle with discerning the significance of quantum data, but a proposed Grover-inspired Quantum Hard Attention Mechanism (GQHAM) aims to address this issue. GQHAM overcomes non-differentiability with a Flexible Oracle (FO) and an Adaptive Diffusion Operator (ADO). The FO uses Flexible Control (FC) to handle discrete choices, visualized with a Quantum Hard Attention Score (QHAS). A trainable ADO boosts the generality and flexibility of GQHAM. Experimental findings show that GQHAM outperforms existing quantum soft self-attention mechanisms in accuracy and learning ability. GQHAM is also robust to noise. Overall, GQHAM enriches the Quantum Attention Mechanism (QAM) and promotes the development of quantum computer vision."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/YmKgsg3PGyetiwnBA/rounding-up-effectively-at-supermarkets", "title": "Rounding Up Effectively at Supermarkets", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Most people don't choose to round up their purchases for charity at checkout. The effectiveness of this practice is debated, but it still diverts a significant amount of money to charities. The selection process for charities needs to be improved to focus on highly-effective ones. It would be challenging but worthwhile to try and change this system. This project would involve social change, engaging the non-EA community, and learning about their attitudes towards effective giving. It could be attempted by students or volunteers."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/hxFzsJ96izYTdkFPJ/premeditatio-malorum-e-o-summum-malum-ou-por-que-o-fim-do", "title": "Premeditatio malorum e o summum malum \u2013 ou por que o fim do mundo pode n\u00e3o ser o \u201cfim do mundo\u201d", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Ancient stoics practiced a mental exercise called premeditatio malorum, visualizing negative outcomes. In modern times, imagining the collapse of civilization and human extinction can evoke anxiety. However, contemplating these scenarios can help prevent disasters. The extinction of the human race would result in the loss of potential future value. Preserving aspects of our culture and expanding to other planets could mitigate these risks. The Fermi paradox suggests that advanced species may have been hit by a \"Great Filter.\" If humans become extinct, it is important to leave behind records for other intelligent life forms. While some may find these speculations speculative, considering these risks seriously could make the world safer and less divided. Stoics admire those who can contemplate the end of the world without regretting their actions."}

The author plans to increase their marketing budget and expand to cities where there is no EA presence yet. {"category": "AI", "url": "https://garymarcus.substack.com/p/wheres-waldo-the-elephant-in-the", "title": "Where\u2019s Waldo? The Elephant in the Room", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Key Ideas:\n\n1. Examples demonstrate that AI systems like ChatGPT can confidently generate images that do not meet requirements, showing a lack of understanding of how the world works.\n2. Errors of discomprehension, where neural network-based systems behave bafflingly, are persistent and may become more concerning in military applications.\n3. Generative AI for source attribution and copyright issues can yield unreliable results due to statistical approximation.\n4. Gary Marcus has long been concerned about the limitations of neural networks, especially as they are increasingly used in real-world applications.\n5. The inherent flaws of technology based on neural networks result in frequent errors, necessitating a paradigm change.\n6. Understanding token or pixel ordering is not equivalent to real understanding, as the correct use of language is distinct from the arrangement of tokens or pixels."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.48?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Inferring social networks from unstructured text data: A proof of concept detection of hidden communities of interest", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses an approach to infer social networks using textual data and topic modeling. The method involves fitting a topic model to the texts produced by actors and measuring topic profile correlations between actors. This allows for the identification of hidden communities of interest, which are groups of actors sharing similar semantic contents but whose social relationships may be unknown. The article presents a case study using a corpus of academic articles in the philosophy of science and shows how the proposed approach can be used to map and analyze actor communities over time. The results demonstrate the evolution and specialization of actor communities in the field of philosophy of science. The approach has implications for understanding the interests and claims of different actor groups in various policy contexts."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.38?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Predicting social assistance beneficiaries: On the social welfare damage of data biases", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Cash transfer programs are a common tool for reducing poverty in low- and middle-income countries. These programs use prediction models to target beneficiaries. However, bias in the data and unstable weights in the prediction models can lead to underestimation of welfare losses and disadvantage smaller households. It is important to consider the characteristics of targeted households and address biases in the data to ensure that social protection systems are fair and transparent. There is a need for greater transparency in the targeting process and a broader discussion on the implications and fairness of using prediction models in social protection programs."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.42?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Determinants for university students\u2019 location data sharing with public institutions during COVID-19: The Italian case", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses a study on the factors that influence university students' intention to share their location data with public institutions during health emergencies, specifically during the COVID-19 pandemic. The study finds that trust in public institutions, perceived benefits, and perceived risks are significant predictors of the intention to share location data. The perceived benefits and perceived risks have a stronger impact on willingness to share data than trust. The study suggests that public institutions should focus on communication strategies to highlight the benefits of sharing data and implement strategies to reduce perceived risks. The findings can help policymakers understand and influence the social acceptance of services that utilize location data for managing emergency situations."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-unveils-its-new-street-level-surveillance-hub", "title": "EFF Unveils Its New Street Level Surveillance Hub ", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has launched a new website called the Street Level Surveillance hub. The hub provides information on various technologies used by law enforcement to invade privacy, such as drones, biometric surveillance, and social media monitoring. The website also offers analysis and articles on law enforcement's use and abuse of these technologies. The hub aims to educate the public and provide a reference source for recognizing police surveillance technology. The EFF hopes that community groups, advocacy organizations, and concerned individuals will use the hub to stay updated on legal cases and technological developments."}

The report, titled \"Delayed Open Source Publication: A Survey of Historical and Current Practices,\" examines the history and various approaches companies have taken to balance open source freedoms with their investments in software development. The research was conducted by Open Tech Strategies and funded by a donation from Sentry and the financial contributions of OSI individual members. The report reveals surprising findings and raises new questions that warrant further research. Readers are encouraged to download and share the report."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-pennsylvania-supreme-court-find-keyword-search-warrant-unconstitutional", "title": "EFF Urges Pennsylvania Supreme Court to Find Keyword Search Warrant Unconstitutional ", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and other organizations argued that keyword warrants used by police to search through search engine databases are unconstitutional and violate privacy rights. The case in question involves a keyword search warrant issued to Google, which could potentially be applied to any user using any search engine. The EFF argued that these warrants are incompatible with constitutional protections for privacy and freedom of speech and expression. The warrants require providers to search their entire reserve of user data to identify any users or devices who searched for specific keywords, even without specific suspects. The EFF contended that these warrants violate both the Pennsylvania Constitution and the Fourth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. They are also harmful because they target protected speech and the right to receive information. The brief filed by the EFF, National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers (NACDL), and Pennsylvania Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers (PACDL) aims to challenge the constitutionality of keyword search warrants."}

Several states in the U.S. have added AI regulations to consumer privacy laws, and more are expected to be introduced in 2024."}

The Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) has filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission, citing violations of federal standards for responsible automated decision-making systems. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/states-attack-young-peoples-constitutional-right-use-social-media-2023-year-review", "title": "States Attack Young People\u2019s Constitutional Right to Use Social Media: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Legislatures in over half of the US states aimed to restrict young people's use of social media, with some proposals even blocking adults from accessing the same platforms. These laws were blocked in some states for infringing on the First Amendment rights. California's Age Appropriate Design Code Act (AADC) set the stage for these regulations, and similar laws were passed in states like Utah, Arkansas, and Texas. The severity and components of these laws vary, but they often introduce age verification requirements that infringe on privacy and free speech. Federal courts have blocked some of these laws for violating the First Amendment. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes these laws and advocates for comprehensive data privacy legislation instead. There were also attempts to regulate social media for young people at the federal and international levels. The year 2024 is expected to bring court battles that will determine the future of young people's online access. In addition to social media regulation, the article touches on other issues such as anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives and attempts to undermine encryption. The EFF has been working to protect digital rights at the state level throughout the year."}

However, the dedication to closing the digital divide is wavering, with monopolistic ISPs trying to maintain control over the broadband market. In New York City, Mayor Eric Adams abandoned plans for public fiber infrastructure and instead introduced a subsidy plan for big ISPs. A community-based ISP was even asked to dismantle their network. California also reduced the number of miles of fiber infrastructure to be built, leaving out underserved communities. The Federal Communications Commission is finally addressing net neutrality and digital discrimination. The fight for affordable and accessible internet will require investment in physical infrastructure and adherence to nondiscrimination rules. The article also mentions network neutrality and the negative impact of network usage fees."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/7-essential-tips-to-protect-your-privacy-in-2024/", "title": "7 Essential Tips to Protect Your Privacy in 2024", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Almost everything we do online involves companies collecting personal information about us. FPF worked with stakeholders to provide training and discuss the impact of AI. FPF played a key role in informing regulatory agencies and state legislatures on privacy, especially in emerging technologies like AI. They provided recommendations and submitted comments on privacy laws and developments in various U.S. states. FPF recognized leading privacy research with the Privacy Papers for Policymakers Award and focused on the protection of children online. They also addressed the privacy implications of immersive technologies, open banking, and data sharing for research. FPF engaged in peer-to-peer meetings and calls with senior executives in data protection compliance. Overall, FPF's work in 2023 had a significant impact on the privacy community and society, emphasizing collaboration across sectors for practical data safeguards."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/five-big-questions-and-zero-predictions-for-the-u-s-state-privacy-landscape-in-2024/", "title": "Five Big Questions (and Zero Predictions) for the U.S. State Privacy Landscape in 2024", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The United States is the only G20 nation without a national framework for personal data privacy. State-level activity on privacy has increased, with the number of states with comprehensive privacy laws growing. There are still differences between state privacy laws, but they generally adhere to the same framework. Two states, Kentucky and New York, have proposed alternative privacy frameworks. Artificial Intelligence (AI) regulation is also a focus, with different approaches being taken in California. Enforcement of privacy laws has been limited, but there are signs of regulatory interest. Litigation around privacy laws, such as the California Age Appropriate Design Code Act, could impact the broader privacy landscape. Expect more privacy proposals and developments at the state level in the coming year."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/call-for-nominations-14th-annual-privacy-papers-for-policymakers/", "title": "Call for Nominations: 14th Annual Privacy Papers for Policymakers", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) is inviting privacy scholars and authors to submit papers for their annual Privacy Papers for Policymakers (PPPM) Award. The award aims to bring relevant privacy research to the attention of policymakers in the U.S. Congress and international data protection agencies. It is open to authors who have completed top privacy research in the last year, proposing short-term solutions or new means of analysis that could have real-world policy impact. There is also a student paper award available. Winning authors will have the opportunity to present their work at an annual event with policymakers and privacy leaders in 2024, and the winning papers will be published and distributed to policymakers. The deadline for submissions is October 20th, 2023, with a separate deadline for student submissions on November 3rd, 2023."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13691", "title": "PQCMC: Post-Quantum Cryptography McEliece-Chen Implicit Certificate Scheme. (arXiv:2401.13691v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses the use of the elliptic curve Qu-Vanstone (ECQV) implicit certificate scheme in security credential management systems and secure vehicle-to-everything communication. It highlights the vulnerability of elliptic-curve cryptography to quantum computing attacks and the need for post-quantum cryptography methods. The article proposes a post-quantum cryptography McEliece-Chen (PQCMC) based on an efficient random invertible matrix generation method to issue pseudonymous certificates. Mathematical models and security evaluations are provided to validate the key expansion process and demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed scheme. The article concludes that the implicit certificate scheme based on post-quantum cryptography is a viable solution to counter quantum computing threats."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13692", "title": "Local Privacy-preserving Mechanisms and Applications in Machine Learning. (arXiv:2401.13692v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses Local Differential Privacy (LDP) and its importance in addressing privacy concerns in crowdsensing. LDP offers strong privacy protection in data collection and processing by locally altering user data before sending it to the server. There are various LDP adaptations aimed at improving the tradeoff between utility and privacy. Machine learning is a major application for privacy-preserving mechanisms. The article provides a comprehensive analysis of LDP, its models, adaptations, and privacy mechanisms, and explores its applications in machine learning."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13715", "title": "A tabu search-based LED selection approach safeguarding visible light communication systems. (arXiv:2401.13715v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses a study on the secrecy performance of a visible light communication (VLC) channel with an eavesdropper. The researchers formulated a problem to maximize the sum secrecy rate by selecting optimal LEDs for each user. They introduced a tabu search-based algorithm to address the complexity of the problem. Additionally, they developed three LED selection strategies to reduce computational complexity. The results showed that the proposed algorithm outperformed the strategies, approaching the global optimal value."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13815", "title": "SoK: Game-Theoretic Cybersecurity: Assumptions, Models, Gaps, and Bridges. (arXiv:2401.13815v1 [cs.GT])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Game theory, originally developed for economics, has been used to study cyber attacks and defenses. However, game theory's roots in economic systems limit its application to the malicious behaviors seen in the cyber domain. This study examines the cybersecurity problems that have been analyzed using game theory, the assumptions made, and the proposed models and solutions. It identifies the technical gaps that need to be filled to make game-theoretic cybersecurity models more effective and explores possible solutions."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13848", "title": "A V2X-based Privacy Preserving Federated Measuring and Learning System. (arXiv:2401.13848v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Future autonomous vehicles will generate a large amount of data through sensors, which can be used for real-time decision-making and improving the road network. A proposed system aims to exchange this data between vehicles and create a predictive model using federated learning. The system improves learning performance and ensures privacy."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13854", "title": "Embedding Attack Project (Work Report). (arXiv:2401.13854v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "This report summarizes experiments on Membership Inference Attacks (MIA) conducted by the Embedding Attack Project. The experiments evaluated two MIA strategies on six AI models, and found that overfitting, early embedding layers, and deeper model layers affect vulnerability to privacy leaks. Additionally, compromising both embeddings and training labels increases MIA success, and reducing MIA does not necessarily reduce PIA."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13952", "title": "Randomized Response with Gradual Release of Privacy Budget. (arXiv:2401.13952v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Key ideas: \n\n- An algorithm has been developed to gradually relax the Differential Privacy (DP) guarantee of a randomized response. \n- The output from each relaxation maintains the same probability distribution and identical utility as the standard approach. \n- The algorithm can be applied to any Local Differential Privacy (LDP) mechanisms relying on randomized response. \n- It has been integrated into RAPPOR, a crowdsourcing tool, to optimize the utility of estimating data frequency. \n- The algorithm also facilitates the relaxation of the DP guarantee for mean estimation. \n- Numerical experiments have validated the utility and DP guarantee of the algorithm."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14005", "title": "Cyber-Twin: Digital Twin-boosted Autonomous Attack Detection for Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks. (arXiv:2401.14005v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges faced by Vehicular Ad-hoc NETworks (VANETs) in terms of cybersecurity, particularly in vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communications. It proposes a cyber-twin framework that combines digital twin technology with AI to enhance the security and sustainability of Roadside Units (RSUs) in VANETs. The framework allows for real-time monitoring and efficient threat detection, improving RSU security. It also improves computational efficiency, leading to increased energy efficiency and extended hardware durability. The results show significant enhancements in resource management and attack detection. Overall, the framework aims to develop secure and sustainable vehicular communication systems for smart cities in the future."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14031", "title": "Sparse and Transferable Universal Singular Vectors Attack. (arXiv:2401.14031v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses research on adversarial attacks and vulnerabilities in machine learning models. The authors propose a sparse universal white-box adversarial attack method based on truncated power iteration. They analyze the method using the ImageNet benchmark and achieve comparable results to dense baselines with a high fooling rate while only damaging 5% of pixels. They also demonstrate that the perturbations created are transferable to different models without significantly decreasing the fooling rate. The findings highlight the vulnerability of current models and the need for robust machine learning systems."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14076", "title": "Quantum Resistant Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption Scheme with Flexible Access Structure. (arXiv:2401.14076v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "We introduce a new CP-ABE scheme with a flexible access structure, utilizing an access tree for fine-grained access control. Security is provable under the R-LWE problem. CP-ABE allows encryption with attribute-based access policies. Our scheme extends CP-ABE by introducing a customizable access structure. Security is ensured by relying on the R-LWE problem. Our scheme operates in the standard model, enhancing practicality. Extensive simulations show the effectiveness and scalability of our approach."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14090", "title": "A Modular Approach to Automatic Cyber Threat Attribution using Opinion Pools. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14098", "title": "Carry Your Fault: A Fault Propagation Attack on Side-Channel Protected LWE-based KEM. (arXiv:2401.14098v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Post-quantum cryptographic algorithms based on learning with errors (LWE) have been vulnerable to physical attacks. This research proposes a new fault attack on side-channel secure masked implementation of LWE-based key-encapsulation mechanisms. The attack exploits the Arithmetic-to-Boolean (A2B) conversion algorithmic modification used for masking. The attack allows for key recovery attacks on Kyber and possibly Saber. This is the first attack that targets an algorithmic component instead of relying solely on the randomness introduced by masking. The attack was validated through simulations and electromagnetic (EM) fault-based testing on an STM32 platform."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14232", "title": "AR-GAN: Generative Adversarial Network-Based Defense Method Against Adversarial Attacks on the Traffic Sign Classification System of Autonomous Vehicles. It achieved consistent high performance under various adversarial attack types, even with no prior knowledge of the attacks. AR-GAN consists of a denoising generator and a classifier. It outperformed benchmark defense methods in white-box attacks and maintained high performance under increased perturbation magnitudes."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14296", "title": "\"All of Me\": Mining Users' Attributes from their Public Spotify Playlists. (arXiv:2401.14296v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Playlists on platforms like Spotify offer valuable insights into users' attributes.
