Results showed that certain musical characteristics are associated with users' demographics, habits, and personality traits. For example, individuals high in openness have diverse playlists, while females prefer Pop and K-pop genres. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14319", "title": "A Quantum \"Lifting Theorem\" for Constructions of Pseudorandom Generators from Random Oracles. (arXiv:2401.14319v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The article discusses the quantum security of pseudorandom generators (PRGs) constructed from random oracles. It presents a \"lifting theorem\" that proves the unconditional security of PRGs against classical and quantum adversaries. Additionally, it demonstrates that pseudo-deterministic quantum-oracle algorithms can be simulated by computationally unbounded classical-oracle algorithms with a polynomial increase in query numbers. This implies that the lifting theorem applies even when PRGs themselves utilize quantum queries."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.12989", "title": "HyperQB: A QBF-Based Bounded Model Checker for Hyperproperties. (arXiv:2109.12989v5 [cs.LO] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "HyperQB is a bounded model checker that uses a QBF-based technique to handle hyperproperties. It takes a NuSMV model and a HyperLTL formula as input and can be used for bug hunting or synthesis. It has been successfully applied in various case studies, including information-flow security and path planning for robots. HyperQB is compared to other tools for model checking hyperproperties."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.03301", "title": "EvadeDroid: A Practical Evasion Attack on Machine Learning for Black-box Android Malware Detection. (arXiv:2110.03301v4 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Researchers have developed EvadeDroid, an adversarial attack that can effectively evade black-box Android malware detectors in real-world scenarios. By using a collection of problem-space transformations derived from benign donors, EvadeDroid can manipulate malware instances to appear benign. This manipulation technique is an optimization algorithm that finds and injects optimal sequences of transformations into malware apps. The empirical evaluations show that EvadeDroid can deceive various malware detectors with high evasion rates, and it is able to preserve its stealthiness against popular commercial antiviruses."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.01372", "title": "Refined Bitcoin Security-Latency Under Network Delay. (arXiv:2212.01372v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "We have conducted a study on the security-latency bounds of Nakamoto consensus, specifically focusing on the security of a block after it reaches a certain depth in the chain. By analyzing the competition between adversarial and honest chains in three different phases, we have been able to improve the existing bounds in this field. Our analysis includes determining the probability distribution of the growth of adversarial chains and utilizing random walks to model each phase, resulting in more accurate bounds. Overall, this research contributes new upper and lower bounds for blockchains with small values of \u03bb\u0394."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01622", "title": "Private, fair and accurate: Training large-scale, privacy-preserving AI models in medical imaging. (arXiv:2302.01622v3 [eess.IV] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Artificial intelligence (AI) models are being used more in medicine, but protecting sensitive medical data is crucial. Differential privacy (DP) is the best way to ensure privacy during model training, but it can negatively impact accuracy and fairness. This study evaluated the effect of privacy-preserving training on AI models in terms of accuracy and fairness. Two datasets were used: one of clinical chest radiographs and one of 3D abdominal computed tomography (CT) images for classifying pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The study compared non-private deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with privacy-preserving (DP) models. The privacy-preserving models had slightly lower accuracy but did not increase discrimination based on age, sex, or co-morbidity. This study shows that privacy-preserving training can be effectively used for diagnostic deep learning models in real-life clinical datasets."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01757", "title": "RS-Del: Edit Distance Robustness Certificates for Sequence Classifiers via Randomized Deletion. (arXiv:2302.01757v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Randomized smoothing offers certified robustness against adversarial examples, mainly for continuous input classifiers like images. However, there is limited work on discrete sequence classifiers, such as for source code. This study introduces randomized smoothing for discrete sequence classifiers, using randomized deletion edits to provide certified robustness against edit distance-bounded adversaries. The proposed mechanism, RS-Del, is effective against deletion, insertion, and substitution edits. The proof of certification focuses on longest common subsequences rather than the traditional approach. In a case study on malware detection, the RS-Del mechanism achieves a certified accuracy of 91% at an edit distance radius of 128 bytes for the MalConv malware detection model."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02373", "title": "Secure and Effective Data Appraisal for Machine Learning. (arXiv:2310.02373v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Discreetly selecting and evaluating training data is important for an unfettered data market.\n- Multi-Party Computation (MPC) can be used to safeguard the privacy of data and models.\n- Previous research suggested that MPC-based evaluation of Transformer models is resource-intensive.\n- This paper introduces an innovative approach that makes data selection practical using MPC.\n- The approach involves using simplified low-dimensional MLPs trained on a limited subset of data.\n- The proposed method substantially reduces evaluation time, from thousands of hours to mere tens of hours.\n- There is only a slight decrease in accuracy when training with the selected data."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2311.07266", "title": "Network-assist free self-testing of genuine multipartite entangled states. (arXiv:2311.07266v2 [quant-ph] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Self-testing is a method for certifying quantum states and measurements in a device-independent way. \u0160upi\u0107 et al. introduced a novel method for self-testing any pure entangled quantum state, but it relies on network assistance and bipartite entangled measurements. We propose a true device-independent self-testing scheme for genuine multipartite pure entangled states, using a generalized Hardy-type non-local argument. Our scheme only involves local operations and classical communication and does not rely on bipartite entangled measurements or network assistance. We also provide a device-independent bound for the maximum probability of success in our scheme."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13255", "title": "Constructing a fully homomorphic encryption scheme with the Yoneda Lemma. (arXiv:2401.13255v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "This article presents a new approach to asymmetric cryptography's homomorphic cryptosystems using the Yoneda Lemma. It shows how popular systems like ElGamal, RSA, Benaloh, Regev's LWE, and NTRUEncrypt are derived from the Yoneda Lemma. This leads to a new encryption framework called the Yoneda Encryption Scheme, where encryption and decryption are explained through bijective maps. The article also suggests a unified model theory framework for reasoning about homomorphic and fully homomorphic encryption schemes. Additionally, it introduces a practical fully homomorphic encryption scheme that can process encrypted multiplications and additions without additional techniques. This opens up possibilities for using model theory and forcing techniques in cryptography."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13399", "title": "Real-time Risk Metrics for Programmatic Stablecoin Crypto Asset-Liability Management (CALM). {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13516", "title": "Delocate: Detection and Localization for Deepfake Videos with Randomly-Located Tampered Traces. (arXiv:2401.13516v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Deepfake videos pose a challenge for detection methods due to their realistic nature and subtle tampering traces. To address this, a new model called Delocate is proposed, which can recognize and localize unknown domain deepfake videos. Delocate consists of two stages: recovering and localization. In the recovering stage, regions of interest are randomly masked and real faces are reconstructed without tampering traces, resulting in good recovery for real faces and poor recovery for fake faces. In the localization stage, the recovery output and forgery ground truth mask are used as supervision to guide the localization process, focusing on fake faces with poor recovery to locate tampered regions. Experimental results demonstrate that Delocate excels in localizing tampered areas and enhances cross-domain detection performance."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13578", "title": "WPDA: Frequency-based Backdoor Attack with Wavelet Packet Decomposition. (arXiv:2401.13578v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Key ideas: \n\n- This article discusses a security threat called backdoor attack against deep neural networks (DNNs) used for image classification.\n- The attacker aims to inject a backdoor into the model by manipulating training data, which can be activated by a specific trigger during inference.\n- Existing data poisoning-based attacks struggle at low poisoning ratios, increasing the risk of detection by defense methods.\n- The proposed method uses Wavelet Packet Decomposition (WPD) to analyze the frequency distribution of the dataset and inject the trigger into key frequency regions.\n- The method achieves a high Attack Success Rate (ASR) of 98.12% on CIFAR-10 with an extremely low poisoning ratio of 0.004%.\n- The method is stealthy, precise, and capable of bypassing most existing defense methods.\n- Visualization analyses are provided to explain the effectiveness of the method."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13653", "title": "HetDAPAC: Distributed Attribute-Based Private Access Control with Heterogeneous Attributes. (arXiv:2401.13653v1 [cs.IT])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "Verifying user attributes for fine-grained access control in databases is crucial in attribute-based authentication systems. These systems can either have a single central authority verifying all attributes or multiple independent authorities verifying individual attributes. The central setup is more communication efficient but compromises user attribute privacy. A recent study proposed a distributed multi-authority setup where each server verifies only one attribute, increasing the achievable rate compared to previous research. However, this offloading of attributes to a central server for verification sacrifices the privacy of a few non-sensitive attributes."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02344", "title": "TrojanPuzzle: Covertly Poisoning Code-Suggestion Models. (arXiv:2301.02344v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "With tools like GitHub Copilot, automatic code suggestion is now a reality. However, these tools are susceptible to data poisoning attacks where malicious data is injected into their training. Previous attacks could be detected and filtered out, but our new attacks, COVERT and TROJANPUZZLE, bypass static analysis by hiding the malicious data in out-of-context regions like docstrings. This makes them harder to detect and filter out, posing a significant risk for code-suggestion models."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12234", "title": "A Lightweight FPGA-based IDS-ECU Architecture for Automotive CAN. (arXiv:2401.12234v1 [cs.AR])", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "In this article, researchers present a consolidated ECU architecture for vehicles that incorporates an Intrusion Detection System (IDS) for the Automotive Controller Area Network (CAN). {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2023/12/nist-calls-information-support-safe-secure-and-trustworthy-development-and", "title": "NIST Calls for Information to Support Safe, Secure and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence", "date": "2024-01-27", "summary": "The U.S. Department of Commerce's National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has issued a Request for Information (RFI) to assist in implementing the responsibilities outlined in the Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of AI. NIST is seeking feedback from industry, academia, and civil society to develop guidelines, standards, and testing environments for AI systems that promote safe and responsible development. The RFI specifically addresses areas such as AI red-teaming, generative AI risk management, reducing synthetic content risks, and advancing responsible global technical standards. NIST aims to engage with the broader AI community and gather different perspectives to establish an unbiased scientific understanding of AI. {"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZQma8TmR6S8GcLbt9/epistemic-hell", "title": "Epistemic Hell", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas in the article:\n- The article describes examples of \"epistemic hells\" where reasoning, logic, and common sense lead to incorrect conclusions or hinder scientific progress. Examples include the detoxification process of manioc in indigenous societies, the discovery and cure of scurvy, and the understanding of heredity.\n- In these cases, cultural practices, common beliefs, and misleading evidence prevent individuals from reaching the truth.\n- The article suggests that escaping these epistemic hells requires a combination of luck, extraordinary datasets, and radical shifts in thinking.\n- The author also mentions the potential for similar epistemic hells in fields like physics, cosmology, and the study of consciousness.\n- It proposes strategies such as engineering serendipity, collecting extensive datasets, and starting from first principles to break free from epistemic hells."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZeXoCJ426CocFzxJq/doing-a-basic-life-focused-cost-benefit-analysis", "title": "Doing a Basic Life-Focused Cost-Benefit Analysis", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "How to do a simple cost-benefit analysis using life-years as the unit of analysis: \n1. Focus on time cost rather than monetary cost, as it is usually larger.\n2. Estimate costs by looking at everyone affected by the policy and multiplying their time spent by the number of people in that role.\n3. Include line staff, customers/patients, managers/executives, and any other affected parties.\n4. Divide the initial time estimates by five (or turnover time if less than 5 years) and add it to the yearly time to get the total annualized time cost.\n5. Divide the hours by 2000 for the annualized full-time equivalent (FTE) cost.\n6. Estimate benefits by finding evidence of health benefits or doing an expert elicitation.\n7. Convert benefit estimates into life-years gained using DALY values.\n8. If there are monetary benefits, divide them by the GDP per capita of the receiving country.\n9. Compare the annualized FTE cost to the annualized life-years gained.\n10. If the FTE cost is less than the life-year benefit, the policy passes the cost-benefit test.\n11. If the FTE cost is greater, it's not recommended as a priority. If it's more than five times the benefit, it fails the test.\n12. Consider presenting uncertainties if available and additional caveats if social benefits are a significant factor."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/asi4mi7xJj7ue8DhX/surgery-works-well-without-the-fda", "title": "Surgery Works Well Without The FDA", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas in this article include:\n- Pharmaceutical companies are unlikely to release ineffective or dangerous drugs because it would harm their brand and business.\n- Surgeries do not have the same level of regulation as pharmaceuticals but still show evidence of working well and improving over time.\n- The problems faced by surgery are similar to those faced by pharmaceuticals, suggesting that a well-functioning market could exist without the FDA.\n- The WHO claims that surgical interventions account for 13% of the world's total disability-adjusted life years (DALYs).\n- There may be downsides to doing away with medical regulators and potential benefits to having faster and cheaper medication.\n- Pharmaceutical companies that have withdrawn drugs have not necessarily been financially ruined, raising questions about the risk of producing inefficient or dangerous drugs."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/BaoA3gz7xRaqn764J/gaia-network-an-illustrated-primer", "title": "Gaia Network: An Illustrated Primer", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The Gaia Network is a decentralized system that aims to improve scientific efficiency, decision-making, and AI safety through collective intelligence. It connects causal models and allows researchers to share and aggregate their findings, resulting in improved science and more effective decision-making. The network enables scientists to set priors for their studies based on the pooled distributions of previous research, eliminating the need for manual meta-analyses. It also provides metrics for evaluating the impact of scientific studies and can be used to guide funding decisions. In addition to scientific applications, the Gaia Network can be used in various decision-making processes, such as farming operations and supply chain management. The network can help simulate outcomes and estimate probabilities based on different factors and assumptions. It also has the potential to address AI safety concerns by serving as a distributed AI scientist that evaluates high-stakes actions. While the proposal is ambitious, it highlights the potential for leveraging collective intelligence and data-sharing to drive progress in various fields."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13713", "title": "EMP: Effective Multidimensional Persistence for Graph Representation Learning. (arXiv:2401.13713v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Topological data analysis (TDA) is becoming popular in machine learning for tasks like manifold learning and graph classification. Persistent homology (PH) is a key technique in TDA, but current tools only analyze data using a single filter parameter. To address this limitation, the Effective Multidimensional Persistence (EMP) framework is introduced. EMP allows for the exploration of data by simultaneously varying multiple scale parameters and integrating descriptor functions into the analysis process. EMP provides highly expressive data summaries that align well with diverse machine learning models. The framework is theoretically guaranteed and stable. Tests show that EMP outperforms other methods on benchmark datasets for graph classification."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13770", "title": "AlphaMapleSAT: An MCTS-based Cube-and-Conquer SAT Solver for Hard Combinatorial Problems. (arXiv:2401.13770v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "AlphaMapleSAT is a new SAT solving method that uses Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) and Cube-and-Conquer (CnC) techniques to efficiently solve combinatorial problems. It introduces deductively-driven MCTS-based lookahead cubing, which performs a deeper heuristic search to find effective cubes while keeping the cost low. The method is compared against the March CnC solver and shows significant speedup in solving challenging problems."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13802", "title": "Investigating the Efficacy of Large Language Models for Code Clone Detection. (arXiv:2401.13802v1 [cs.SE])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Large Language Models (LLMs) have been successful in natural language processing and software engineering tasks. They are commonly used in prompt-based zero/few-shot paradigms. This study explores the use of LLMs for Code Clone Detection (CCD), a non-generative task. The researchers built a dataset and used ChatGPT to detect code clones. The results showed that ChatGPT outperformed baselines in cross-language CCD and achieved similar performance to fully fine-tuned models in mono-lingual CCD. The difficulty level of problems and prompts had an impact on ChatGPT's performance. The study provides insights and future directions for using LLMs in CCD."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13827", "title": "Traffic Learning and Proactive UAV Trajectory Planning for Data Uplink in Markovian IoT Models. (arXiv:2401.13827v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Age of Information (AoI) measures data freshness in IoT networks.\n- Traditional resource management schemes result in high AoI, energy consumption, and low reliability.\n- Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) as flying base stations (BSs) can minimize AoI, save energy, and improve throughput.\n- The paper presents a learning-based framework that estimates traffic arrival based on Markovian events.\n- The framework optimizes UAV trajectory and scheduling policy.\n- Two traffic predictors, forward algorithm (FA) and long short-term memory (LSTM), are compared.\n- A deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach optimizes the policy of each UAV.\n- The proposed algorithm outperforms a random-walk (RW) baseline model in terms of AoI, scheduling accuracy, and transmission power."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13848", "title": "A V2X-based Privacy Preserving Federated Measuring and Learning System. (arXiv:2401.13848v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Future autonomous vehicles will use sensors to generate data that can be used not only for self-driving algorithms but also to assist other vehicles and infrastructure in real-time decision-making. This data can be exchanged through Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) technologies. Predicting the state of the road network can help mitigate road congestion, balance parking lot usage, and optimize traffic flow, leading to reduced transportation costs and environmental impact. A proposed federated measurement and learning system enables vehicles to share real-time data through Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) communication and creates a predictive model of the transportation network through federated learning (FL) over the Vehicle-to-Network (V2N) link. An evaluation using a non-IID dataset shows that the FL scheme improves learning performance and prevents eavesdropping."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13913", "title": "Spectral Clustering for Discrete Distributions. (arXiv:2401.13913v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Discrete distribution clustering is often solved using Wasserstein barycenter methods, but these methods assume clusters can be well represented by barycenters, which may not be the case in real applications. This article proposes a framework for D2C based on spectral clustering and distribution affinity measures. Linear optimal transport is used to construct affinity matrices efficiently on large datasets. The proposed methods have theoretical guarantees for successful clustering of distributions and outperform baselines in terms of accuracy and efficiency in experiments on synthetic and real data."}
{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13920", "title": "LocMoE: A Low-overhead MoE for Large Language Model Training. However, it has limitations such as load imbalance and high latency. To address these issues, a new routing strategy that combines load balance and locality is proposed. This strategy reduces inter-node communication and training time. The modifications are implemented on the PanGu-Sigma model and experiments show improved training time without affecting model accuracy."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14066", "title": "CreativeSynth: Creative Blending and Synthesis of Visual Arts based on Multimodal Diffusion. (arXiv:2401.14066v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Large-scale text-to-image generative models have made significant progress in synthesizing high-quality images. However, there are two challenges when it comes to artistic image editing: crafting detailed textual prompts and maintaining artistic style during modifications. To address these challenges, a unified framework called CreativeSynth has been developed. CreativeSynth uses a diffusion model and integrates multimodal features with customized attention mechanisms. It allows for the importation of real-world semantic content into art, enabling precise manipulation of image style and content without compromising the original model parameters. Evaluations show that CreativeSynth enhances fidelity and preserves the aesthetic essence of artistic images, bridging the gap between generative models and artistic finesse. CreativeSynth is like a custom digital palette for artists."}

{"category": "AI", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14089", "title": "GQHAN: A Grover-inspired Quantum Hard Attention Network. (arXiv:2401.14089v1 [quant-ph])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- Current Quantum Machine Learning (QML) models struggle with handling extensive quantum datasets.\n- Hard Attention Mechanism (HAM) is a potential solution to this problem, but it faces the challenge of non-differentiability.\n- A Grover-inspired Quantum Hard Attention Mechanism (GQHAM) is proposed to address the non-differentiability issue by using a Flexible Oracle (FO) and an Adaptive Diffusion Operator (ADO).\n- GQHAM includes a specially defined Quantum Hard Attention Score (QHAS) that allows for discrete choices to be visualized.\n- GQHAM also incorporates a trainable ADO to enhance its generality and flexibility.\n- A Grover-inspired Quantum Hard Attention Network (GQHAN) is constructed based on GQHAM for Fashion MNIST binary classification and outperforms existing quantum soft self-attention mechanisms in terms of accuracy and learning ability.\n- GQHAN is more robust to noise in experiments, making it a promising solution for quantum computer vision and processing large-scale data."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.48?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Inferring social networks from unstructured text data: A proof of concept detection of hidden communities of interest", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The article proposes a method to infer social networks directly from textual data and topic profiles. This measure would undermine the city's surveillance ordinance that requires approval and transparency for new technologies. It would give the police free rein to deploy any surveillance technology without accountability or democratic control. {"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/what-home-videotaping-can-tell-us-about-generative-ai", "title": "What Home Videotaping Can Tell Us About Generative AI", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas in the article:\n\n- The reaction to the introduction of the first videotape recorder (VTR) in 1975 was similar to today's anxieties surrounding AI.\n- The Supreme Court ruling in the Sony VTR case set a precedent for liability of machine manufacturers under copyright law.\n- The ruling emphasized the importance of not expanding copyright protections and the concept of \"substantial noninfringing uses\" for technology.\n- Generative AI toolmakers may face liability if their tools are used to generate infringing works, but their tools may also have substantial noninfringing uses.\n- The Supreme Court could overturn the Sony ruling in future cases involving AI.\n- There is hope for a future that avoids control of technology by copyright maximalists."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/ftc-bars-x-mode-selling-sensitive-location-data", "title": "FTC Bars X-Mode from Selling Sensitive Location Data ", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The FTC has taken action against another location data broker, InMarket, for selling users' location data to third parties. The FTC's complaint highlights the dangers posed by this industry, as location data can easily be correlated to specific individuals. The proposed order from the FTC includes rules to protect the public from this company. X-Mode has disputed the FTC's statements and asserted that no data misuse was found. The FTC has made a strong case that the brokering of location data is unfair and unlawful. This sends a signal to other location data brokers to reassess their business models. The FTC has recently taken other actions to protect data privacy, including limiting Rite Aid's use of face recognition and fining Amazon's Ring. There has been an increase in anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance, impacting both online and offline communities. Legislatures in many states have introduced bills to restrict young people's use of social media. Politicians across Europe have attempted to undermine encryption, but efforts to protect private communication have been made. EFF has worked to improve digital rights in various states across the country."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.siia.net/navigating-legal-practical-and-ethical-realms-in-data-broker-regulation/", "title": "Adopting a Risk-Based Approach to the Regulation of Data Practices", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The Software and Information Industry Association (SIIA) has released a white paper on the regulation of data brokers. It highlights the legal, practical, and ethical considerations involved in regulating these entities. Privacy discussions often overlook the advantages and challenges of data brokers, as well as their impact on consumer privacy. The paper emphasizes the importance of data in the development and adoption of artificial intelligence (AI)."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/epic-calls-on-doj-and-dhs-to-create-robust-framework-of-safeguards-for-surveillance-tech/", "title": "EPIC Calls On DOJ and DHS to Create Robust Framework of Safeguards for Surveillance Tech", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "EPIC submitted comments urging DOJ and DHS to center vulnerable communities in guidance on surveillance technologies. They argued for ceasing use of facial recognition due to systemic issues and harm to democracy. EPIC provided recommendations for safeguards and principles to assess risks. They oppose facial recognition and advocate for transparency and oversight in automated decision-making. EPIC engages in complaints, FOIA requests, and research to expose surveillance technology use by law enforcement."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/press-act-will-protect-journalists-when-they-need-it-most", "title": "The PRESS Act Will Protect Journalists When They Need It Most", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The House of Representatives has passed the PRESS Act, a federal shield bill that would protect journalists from government surveillance and limit the forced disclosure of sources. Currently, federal law lacks these protections, which has had serious consequences for journalists and the public's right to access information. The bill has bipartisan support and is in line with existing shield laws in 49 states and the District of Columbia. The government's surveillance of journalists has hindered their ability to gather news and deterred sources from coming forward. The PRESS Act has a broad definition of journalism and is supported by various press and rights groups. It is crucial for the protection of democracy and the freedom to gather and publish information."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.siia.net/online-speech-and-ai/", "title": "Online Speech and AI", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "As discussed in the OMB AI Draft Memo, AI can have an impact on individuals' rights and safety. There should be a targeted risk assessment model for rights-impacting AI. Content moderation is important for online platforms, and AI can assist in making unbiased decisions and reducing moderation costs. Existing content moderation strategies already address issues of blocking or limiting protected speech. The government should acknowledge the history of content moderation by private companies. Technology companies will continue to moderate harmful content online, with or without the use of AI."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.38?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Predicting social assistance beneficiaries: On the social welfare damage of data biases", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Cash transfer programs are widely used to alleviate poverty in low- and middle-income countries. These programs often rely on prediction models to target benefits to the poorest households. However, biases in the data used for these models can lead to underestimation of welfare losses, particularly for smaller households. There is a need for greater transparency and accountability in the targeting procedures of these programs."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/how-to-defend-independent-technology-research-from-corporate-and-political-opposition", "title": "How to Defend Independent Technology Research from Corporate and Political Opposition", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "A coalition for independent technology research, established by a group of researchers including J. Nathan Matias and Ethan Zuckerman, aims to defend the right to conduct unbiased research on the impacts of digital technologies. The coalition is comprised of individuals from civil society, academia, and media organizations and advocates for enabling conditions that allow researchers to work without interference. Their work is particularly important in combatting false and misleading claims advanced by those interested in public health and elections. The coalition has faced opposition in the form of lawsuits and legislative harassment, including attacks on disinformation researchers. The campaign to discredit independent researchers has led to a chilling effect and obstacles to accessing data, as well as closures of tools used for studying social media. The coalition's priorities include crisis response support for researchers facing attacks, advocacy for access to data, and strategic communications to highlight the value and importance of independent research. Interested individuals can apply to join the coalition through their website."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.siia.net/siia-statement-on-european-commission-intention-to-block-amazon-irobot-acquisition/", "title": "SIIA Statement on European Commission Intention to Block Amazon iRobot Acquisition", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The European Commission plans to block Amazon's acquisition of iRobot due to concerns about competition. This decision reflects a worrying trend of competition authorities preventing pro-competition deals. Amazon's intention was to provide capital to iRobot to better compete with rivals, not to own a competing brand. Blocking the merger harms innovation, small businesses, and consumers' choices."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/effs-2024-inout-list", "title": "EFF\u2019s 2024 In/Out List ", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "EFF, an organization focused on digital rights, shares its goals for 2024. They advocate for affordable and future-proof internet access for all, a privacy-first agenda to prevent mass data collection, decentralized social media platforms, end-to-end encrypted messaging services, and the right to free expression online. They also highlight the need to address the negative impacts of artificial intelligence, ad surveillance, speech and privacy restrictions under the guise of child protection, unchecked cross-border data sharing, and the use of internet access as a bargaining chip in conflicts. EFF calls for changes in laws to protect journalists and prevent government surveillance. They express concern about human rights violations in the UAE and increased anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance worldwide. In 2023, there was a lack of comprehensive data privacy reforms and efforts to restrict young people's use of social media. The right to free expression was also threatened, especially during global conflicts. EFF urges the Supreme Court to clarify standards for government influence on social media censorship."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/epic-fcc-should-incentivize-carriers-to-guard-against-sim-swapping-and-port-out-fraud/", "title": "EPIC: FCC Should Incentivize Carriers to Guard Against SIM Swapping and Port-Out Fraud", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "On January 18, 2024, EPIC submitted comments to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) praising new rules that enhance consumer protection against SIM swap and port-out fraud. They urged the FCC to incentivize carriers to reduce security vulnerabilities further. SIM swap and port-out fraud involve fraudsters taking control of a victim's phone number by convincing a carrier to transfer the victim's phone service to the fraudster's phone. EPIC highlighted the growing incidents of fraud targeting cryptocurrency investors and telecommunications customers. They called for harmonization of rules and authentication requirements, as well as requiring carriers to report fraud and hold them liable for SIM swap attacks. EPIC regularly comments on regulations to safeguard privacy and combat fraud."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.42?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Determinants for university students\u2019 location data sharing with public institutions during COVID-19: The Italian case", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas:\n\n- Data on individuals' real-time location can be valuable in managing emergency situations, such as virus outbreaks.\n- Low consent from individuals to share their data has affected the adoption of contact tracing apps during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n- Trust, perceived benefits, and perceived risks are significant factors influencing individuals' intention to share location data during outbreaks.\n- Public institutions should focus on enhancing trust, communicating the benefits of data sharing, and reducing perceived risks to encourage individuals to share their data.\n- The study provides insights for policymakers to understand and influence the social acceptance of location data sharing services during health emergencies."}

Among them is human rights defender Ahmed Mansoor, who criticized internet censorship and surveillance in the country. Mansoor had previously been arrested and sentenced to prison in 2011 but was released early. In 2018, he was convicted again and sentenced to ten years in prison under the UAE's cybercrime law. Human rights organizations are calling for his release. The UAE's use of counter-terrorism laws to restrict free expression is a concern, as it can justify disproportionate state surveillance. The proposed UN Cybercrime Treaty could further restrict free expression and empower states to access and share user data. There is a need to change laws to protect journalists and the LGBTQ+ community from intolerance and censorship. Legislatures in many countries have targeted young people's use of social media, limiting their access to popular sites. Congress has failed to pass comprehensive data privacy reforms. The right to free expression is most fragile for marginalized groups, and conflicts like the war in Palestine have threatened speech. The Supreme Court should clarify standards for government involvement in social media censorship."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-pennsylvania-supreme-court-find-keyword-search-warrant-unconstitutional", "title": "EFF Urges Pennsylvania Supreme Court to Find Keyword Search Warrant Unconstitutional ", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Keyword warrants that allow police to search through search engine databases are unconstitutional, violate privacy rights, and target freedom of speech, according to the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and other organizations. The EFF, along with the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers (NACDL) and the Pennsylvania Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers (PACDL), argued in a brief filed to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania that keyword warrants are incompatible with Constitutional protections. These warrants involve a massive invasion of privacy as they require search engine providers, like Google, to search their entire database to identify users who have searched for specific keywords without targeting specific individuals. The EFF argues that this violates privacy rights and freedom of speech. They also state that if search engine providers can be forced to disclose users' search queries, it will discourage users from seeking out information online. This case, known as Commonwealth v. Kurtz, is only the second case of its kind to reach a state's highest court and has implications for all search engine users."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/digiday-privacy-and-ai-policies-to-watch-in-2024/", "title": "Digiday: Privacy and AI policies to watch in 2024", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "There are concerns about AI beyond generative AI. Critics want governments to regulate algorithmic feeds on social media and address risks posed by large language models to consumer data and child safety. Last year, 10 U.S. states introduced AI regulations as part of consumer privacy laws, with more expected in 2024."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://epic.org/statescoop-automated-public-benefit-fraud-detection-used-by-states-subject-of-new-ftc-complaint/", "title": "StateScoop: Automated public-benefit fraud detection used by states subject of new FTC complaint\u00a0", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "An automated system called \"Fraud Detect\" by Thomson Reuters is facing a complaint by the Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) for incorrectly identifying public benefits fraud and violating federal rules. EPIC claims that the system uses personal data to power an opaque algorithm that alerts administrators of potentially fraudulent activity. The adoption of this tool has allegedly caused millions of legitimate claimants to be denied access to public benefits. EPIC argues that Thomson Reuters has failed to show that its algorithm meets federal standards for responsible automated decision-making systems. They have urged the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to investigate, secure an injunction, and seek the deletion or destruction of the system."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/digital-rights-lgbtq-people-2023-review", "title": "Digital Rights for LGBTQ+ People: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "An increase in anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance is impacting individuals and communities worldwide, leading to online and offline discrimination and censorship. Data surveillance poses a significant threat to LGBTQ+ people, while legislation in several countries restricts their rights and freedoms. Student monitoring tools in the US have flagged LGBTQ+ content, creating a harmful environment. Cybercrime and surveillance legislation in the Middle East and Africa also threatens LGBTQ+ rights. Colonial-era laws in many countries contribute to the persecution of LGBTQ+ individuals. Efforts to criminalize homosexuality, restrict freedom of expression, and censor online content continue to be prevalent. However, there is optimism that LGBTQ+ activists and allies will continue to fight against censorship and discrimination in the future."}

{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/taking-back-web-decentralization-2023-review", "title": "Taking Back the Web with Decentralization: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The article discusses the growing trend of decentralization in the internet and social media. Users are leaving centralized platforms like Twitter and turning to smaller, independently operated projects in the \"IndieWeb.\" This decentralization movement is seen in the growth of federated microblogging platforms like Mastodon and Bluesky. Surprisingly, Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, also joined the fediverse by launching Threads, a microblogging site using the ActivityPub protocol. The article also mentions the importance of sustainable and well-moderated decentralized platforms and highlights the need for privacy and content moderation in these spaces. Additionally, it addresses the development of protocols and libraries that enable decentralized services and the potential of blockchain technology beyond financial uses. The article concludes by expressing optimism for the future of decentralization and the continued work in the space."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/states-attack-young-peoples-constitutional-right-use-social-media-2023-year-review", "title": "States Attack Young People\u2019s Constitutional Right to Use Social Media: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Legislatures in many states have proposed laws that aim to restrict young people's use of social media by implementing age verification requirements and parental consent. Some of these laws have been blocked for violating the First Amendment, but others are set to go into effect. The Age Appropriate Design Code Act in California set the stage for these regulations, but its constitutionality is currently being appealed. Similar laws have been passed in Utah, Arkansas, and Texas, with some of them also facing legal challenges. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes age verification requirements and advocates for comprehensive data privacy legislation instead. They argue that these laws infringe on individuals' rights to access information and impinge on privacy and speech rights. The EFF has been actively involved in fighting against these laws and will continue to do so in court battles that will likely determine young people's access to the internet in the future. Additionally, the article briefly mentions other issues such as anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives and attempts to undermine encryption by politicians. EFF has also been working on improving digital rights policies at the state level across the country."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/first-lets-talk-about-consumer-privacy-2023-year-review", "title": "First, Let\u2019s Talk About Consumer Privacy: 2023 Year in Review ", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas in the article:\n- Enacting strong consumer data privacy legislation is essential for addressing online harms and protecting consumer privacy.\n- Well-written privacy laws address the root source of corporate surveillance and can withstand constitutional scrutiny.\n- The EFF advocates for comprehensive consumer data privacy laws, fights against bad laws, and protects existing sectoral privacy laws.\n- The EFF has filed amicus briefs in lawsuits challenging laws that require age verification and access restrictions to online content.\n- They also support strong existing sectoral privacy laws that protect data like video watch history, biometrics, and broadband use records.\n- Anti-LGBTQ+ intolerance, corporate paternalism, ad-tracking technology, and societal limitations on social media use were major issues in 2023.\n- Politicians attempted to undermine encryption and access private communication, but the EFF pushed back.\n- The EFF works to improve policy at the state level to protect digital rights.\n- The EFF has a 4-star rating on Charity Navigator."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/trenches-broadband-policy-2023-year-review", "title": "In the Trenches of Broadband Policy: 2023 Year In Review", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "EFF has been advocating for affordable and accessible internet access for all. However, there are challenges in bridging the digital divide, with monopolistic ISPs trying to maintain control over the broadband market. Efforts to invest in public fiber infrastructure have been abandoned in favor of subsidizing ISPs. Similar commitment issues to bridge the digital divide have been observed in other places as well. On a federal level, the FCC is working on net neutrality and digital discrimination rulemaking. The fight for affordable and accessible internet will require political will and investment in physical infrastructure."}
{"category": "Technology", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/kids-online-safety-shouldnt-require-massive-online-censorship-and-surveillance", "title": "Kids Online Safety Shouldn\u2019t Require Massive Online Censorship and Surveillance: 2023 Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key Ideas:\n- Congress has failed to pass comprehensive data privacy reforms and has instead focused on legislation intended to restrict young people's use of popular sites and apps.\n- The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) is a censorship bill that would require websites and apps to take action against content that politicians believe could harm minors.\n- KOSA has not been passed into law due to opposition from digital rights groups and individuals.\n- The Protecting Kids on Social Media Act combines elements from other bills aimed at protecting children online, but the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes it for its age verification mandates and parental consent requirements.\n- The fight against these bills has mobilized young people and highlighted the need to protect online rights from censorship and surveillance.\n- Several countries have also introduced anti-LGBTQ+ initiatives that restrict freedom of expression and privacy online.\n- Google and its subsidiaries have tightened their control over online innovation under the guise of user benefit.\n- Many state legislatures have introduced bills to limit young people's access to social media, often blocking adults' access as well.\n- Politicians in Europe have attempted to undermine end-to-end encryption, but efforts to protect privacy have pushed back against these attempts."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/fpf-in-2023-a-year-in-review/", "title": "FPF in 2023: A Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "2023 was a year in which the Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) expanded its global presence and engaged in various activities related to AI and data privacy. They also facilitated peer-to-peer meetings for senior executives working on data protection compliance. Overall, FPF's work aimed to advance practical safeguards for data uses that benefit society."}

Artificial Intelligence (AI) regulation has also gained attention, with California leading the way in creating rules for the use of automated decision-making technology. There are overlapping approaches within California that may cause tension. Enforcing privacy laws has been limited so far, but there are indicators of forthcoming enforcement actions. Litigation surrounding the California Age Appropriate Design Code Act may impact the broader privacy landscape. Expect more privacy proposals in the coming year, with a focus on advancing and securing new privacy rights and protections."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/7-reasons-why-social-media-disinformation", "title": "\ud83d\udcc8 7 Reasons why social media disinformation is on the rise", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Disinformation is becoming more widespread and viral, with several factors contributing to its spread. Algorithmic feeds on social media platforms prioritize posts that capture attention, leading to filter bubbles and the spread of fake news. Virality-fostering feeds, like those seen on TikTok, incentivize the posting of false information to gain attention. Lack of algorithmic transparency and accountability allows fake news to freely circulate. AI-deepfakes make it easier for bad actors to create believable false content. Monetization programs on social networks incentivize the creation of viral content, including fake news, for monetary gain. The lack of a \"fact-check culture\" on social media platforms, where metrics determine the visibility and legitimacy of posts, further contributes to the spread of disinformation. The consequences of social media disinformation can be significant, especially in the context of wars and social conflicts. To combat disinformation, individuals should only trust credible sources and verify information before sharing it. However, current approaches, such as the Digital Services Act, may not be sufficient in addressing the problem."}

The article criticizes 23andMe for not implementing stronger security measures, such as 2-factor authentication, and highlights the immutability of genetic data once leaked. It also mentions that 23andMe is being sued for the incident. The key ideas can be summarized as follows:\n1. Genetic data breaches raise privacy and security concerns.\n2. Leaked genetic data can lead to ethnic targeting and harm.\n3. 23andMe should have implemented stronger security measures.\n4. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13692", "title": "Local Privacy-preserving Mechanisms and Applications in Machine Learning. (arXiv:2401.13692v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The article discusses the importance of Local Differential Privacy (LDP) in addressing privacy concerns related to data generated by intelligent devices. LDP excels at protecting individual privacy during data collection and processing by altering data locally before sending it to the server. There are various adaptations of LDP aimed at improving the tradeoff between utility and privacy. Additionally, the article explores the application of privacy-preserving mechanisms, such as LDP, in machine learning."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13815", "title": "SoK: Game-Theoretic Cybersecurity: Assumptions, Models, Gaps, and Bridges. (arXiv:2401.13815v1 [cs.GT])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Game theory, originally used in economics, is being applied to study cyber attacker and defender behaviors. However, it is limited by its roots in economic systems. In this article, the major cybersecurity problems studied using game theory are systematized, highlighting the assumptions, models, and proposed solutions. The article also identifies technical gaps that need to be addressed for game-theoretic cybersecurity models to be more effective. Potential solutions to bridge these gaps are explored."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14076", "title": "Quantum Resistant Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption Scheme with Flexible Access Structure. (arXiv:2401.14076v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "We propose a new CP-ABE scheme with a flexible access structure. The scheme uses an access tree for fine-grained access control. It is secure and based on the R-LWE problem. Our scheme extends CP-ABE and allows for complex access policies. It operates in the standard model and is practical for real-world use. Simulations show its effectiveness and scalability for secure data access control."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14098", "title": "Carry Your Fault: A Fault Propagation Attack on Side-Channel Protected LWE-based KEM. (arXiv:2401.14098v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Post-quantum cryptographic algorithms, like learning with errors (LWE), are vulnerable to physical attacks. The proposed attack exploits fault propagation in the Arithmetic-to-Boolean (A2B) conversion used for masking. It demonstrates key recovery attacks on Kyber by exploiting data dependency in A2B. This attack is the first to exploit an algorithmic component for easing masking. Simulated and electromagnetic fault-based validations were performed on an STM32 platform."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14296", "title": "\"All of Me\": Mining Users' Attributes from their Public Spotify Playlists. They conducted a survey with 739 users and analyzed over 10,000 playlists to identify recurring musical characteristics associated with users' demographics, habits, and personality traits. They found that a user's Spotify playlists can provide insights into their real-life attributes, such as openness or preferred music genres. They also developed predictive models for users' attributes using a DeepSet application, which performed better than baseline models in most cases."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.01372", "title": "Refined Bitcoin Security-Latency Under Network Delay. (arXiv:2212.01372v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "We have conducted a study on security-latency bounds for Nakamoto consensus, specifically focusing on the security of a block after it becomes k-deep in the chain. Through our analysis, we have improved upon existing bounds by examining the competition between adversarial and honest chains in three distinct phases. By studying the probability distribution of the growth of adversarial chains when a target block reaches a depth of k in the chain, we were able to model each phase with random walks, resulting in tighter bounds than previously established. By combining the results from all three phases, we have derived new upper and lower bounds for blockchains with small {\u03bb\u0394}."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01757", "title": "RS-Del: Edit Distance Robustness Certificates for Sequence Classifiers via Randomized Deletion. (arXiv:2302.01757v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Randomized smoothing is a method used to create classifiers that are robust against adversarial examples. Previous work has mainly focused on continuous inputs like images, but there is limited research for classifiers with discrete or variable-size inputs. This study adapts randomized smoothing for discrete sequence classifiers, using random deletion edits to provide certified robustness against edit distance-bounded adversaries. The proof of certification is based on longest common subsequences instead of the traditional Neyman-Pearson approach. The approach was tested on malware detection, achieving a certified accuracy of 91% at an edit distance radius of 128 bytes."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2311.07266", "title": "Network-assist free self-testing of genuine multipartite entangled states. (arXiv:2311.07266v2 [quant-ph] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Self-testing is a way to certify quantum states and measurements in a device-independent manner. It is based on input-output measurement statistics with minimal knowledge of internal workings. While self-testing works for bipartite pure entangled states, it is more complicated for multipartite pure entangled states. However, a new self-testing method has been introduced that relies on network assistance and bipartite entangled measurements. We propose a self-testing scheme for genuine multipartite pure entangled states that does not depend on bipartite measurements or network assistance. Our scheme uses local operations and classical communications and also provides a device-independent bound for maximum probability of success."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.09209", "title": "Username Squatting on Online Social Networks: A Study on X. (arXiv:2401.09209v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Adversaries target unique identifiers for squatting attacks. Social networks are also plagued with similar usernames. Researchers design a measurement study on OSNs, revealing squatted usernames being suspended or likely bots. Impersonation attempts are prevalent with squatted accounts, causing confusion and negative impact on OSNs. A framework called SQUAD is developed to detect suspicious squatted accounts with high accuracy."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13199", "title": "Why People Still Fall for Phishing Emails: An Empirical Investigation into How Users Make Email Response Decisions. {"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13262", "title": "Designing Redistribution Mechanisms for Reducing Transaction Fees in Blockchains. (arXiv:2401.13262v1 [cs.GT])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Blockchains use Transaction Fee Mechanisms (TFMs) to determine transaction fees. High demand and limited block resources result in high transaction fees. Transaction Fee Redistribution Mechanisms (TFRMs) using VCG payments as rebates can help reduce fees. Classic redistribution mechanisms ensure Allocative Efficiency (AE) and User Incentive Compatibility (UIC). However, applying RMs in TFMs is not straightforward. A new mechanism called Robust TFRM (R-TFRM) compromises on an honest miner's rationality to guarantee rebates. Robust and rational TFRM (R^2-TFRM) uses trusted on-chain randomness to ensure miner's rationality and positive rebates. TFRMs show promise in reducing transaction fees in public blockchains."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13327", "title": "Generating Synthetic Health Sensor Data for Privacy-Preserving Wearable Stress Detection. (arXiv:2401.13327v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Smartwatch health sensor data is used in smart health applications and patient monitoring, including stress detection. However, acquiring this sensitive data for research purposes is challenging. To address this, the article proposes a method to generate synthetic health data using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Differential Privacy (DP) safeguards. The synthetic data is assessed for quality and compared to the original data. Testing shows that the synthetic data improves model performance, both in non-private and private training scenarios. Differentially private synthetic data has the potential to optimize utility-privacy trade-offs when real training samples are limited."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13410", "title": "How to Forget Clients in Federated Online Learning to Rank?. (arXiv:2401.13410v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Data protection laws such as the GDPR allow users to request the removal of their data from learned models. This paper explores how to remove a client's contributions in a Federated Online Learning to Rank system without compromising the model's effectiveness. The challenge lies in measuring whether the client's contributions have indeed been unlearned. The researchers propose a method involving a poisoning attack to evaluate the impact of unlearning. Experimental results showcase the effectiveness and efficiency of this unlearning strategy."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13575", "title": "CNN architecture extraction on edge GPU. (arXiv:2401.13575v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Neural networks are versatile and have state-of-the-art results in various applications. They are also used in resource-constrained environments like embedded devices. This article explores the susceptibility of neural network implementations to reverse engineering, specifically on the NVIDIA Jetson Nano microcomputer through side-channel analysis. The attack involves implementing popular convolutional neural network architectures on the GPU of Jetson Nano and analyzing the electromagnetic radiation during inference. The analysis reveals that neural network architectures can be easily distinguished using deep learning-based side-channel analysis."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.13584", "title": "Securing the Invisible Thread: A Comprehensive Analysis of BLE Tracker Security in Apple AirTags and Samsung SmartTags. (arXiv:2401.13584v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The study analyzes the security landscape of Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) tracking systems like Apple AirTags and Samsung SmartTags.\n- Various attack vectors and vulnerabilities in these systems are examined, including physical tampering, firmware exploitation, signal spoofing, and cloud-related vulnerabilities.\n- The cryptographic methods used in these systems are also evaluated for their security implications.\n- The findings indicate that while BLE trackers offer utility, they also pose significant security risks.\n- Apple AirTags have device authentication challenges, leading to successful spoofing instances.\n- Samsung SmartTags raise concerns about cloud security and user privacy.\n- The design focus on battery life conservation in these trackers leaves them susceptible to attacks due to the absence of secure boot processes.\n- Future enhancements in these systems are predicted to focus on bolstering security features in response to evolving privacy regulations and integration into the IoT ecosystem."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.10227", "title": "Adversarial Detection by Approximation of Ensemble Boundary. (arXiv:2211.10227v4 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "A new method of detecting adversarial attacks is proposed using an ensemble of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) and Walsh coefficients. The hypothesis is that high curvature decision boundaries allow for the discovery of adversarial perturbations. The difference in Walsh coefficient approximation between clean and adversarial images can be used for detection. The approach has potential application in any domain."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.03419", "title": "Synthesizing Physical Backdoor Datasets: An Automated Framework Leveraging Deep Generative Models. (arXiv:2312.03419v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Backdoor attacks on deep neural networks are a growing concern, especially in real-world prediction systems. Physical backdoor attacks, using trigger objects in the real world, are challenging to study due to the lack of suitable datasets. This paper presents a recipe using generative modeling to create a malicious, physical backdoor dataset. The recipe involves suggesting triggers, generating poisoned samples, and refining the most plausible ones. The created dataset enables impressive attack success rates on real physical world data and is similar to previous physical backdoor attack studies. This paper provides researchers with a toolkit for studying physical backdoors in their labs."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.10387", "title": "Bypassing a Reactive Jammer via NOMA-Based Transmissions in Critical Missions. (arXiv:2401.10387v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Wireless networks can be vulnerable to radio jamming attacks. A study analyzes the impact of a reactive jammer on network metrics such as reliability, transmission delay, and effective sum rate. Results show that by lowering transmit power, the impact of reactive jamming can be mitigated. An optimization problem is formulated to maximize effective sum rate while maintaining reliability and latency constraints. Adjusting allocated transmit power can bypass the jammer's effects without the need for packet re-transmission."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.12236", "title": "The Surprising Harmfulness of Benign Overfitting for Adversarial Robustness. (arXiv:2401.12236v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "Recent studies show that large machine learning models trained on noisy data have good generalization capabilities. However, this study uncovers a surprising result - even if the ground truth is robust to adversarial examples and the overfitted model is benign, this overfitting process can be harmful when faced with adversarial manipulation. The study proves that the min-norm estimator in an overparameterized linear model always leads to adversarial vulnerability in the \"benign overfitting\" setting. Additionally, there is an asymptotic trade-off between the standard risk and the \"adversarial\" risk in ridge regression estimators, meaning that both risks cannot be small simultaneously. Similar results are observed in two-layer neural tangent kernel models. This finding provides theoretical insights into the phenomenon observed in practice where true target functions are robust, but overfitted neural networks are not."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2024/01/nist-offers-guidance-measuring-and-improving-your-companys-cybersecurity", "title": "NIST Offers Guidance on Measuring and Improving Your Company\u2019s Cybersecurity Program", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "NIST has released a draft guidance on measuring and improving information security. The publication aims to help organizations develop an effective program and create information security measures that are based on data. The guidance encourages moving from qualitative risk descriptions to quantitative ones, using numerical details. It also emphasizes the importance of communication using metrics to bridge gaps between technical teams and management. The publication consists of two volumes, with one providing guidance for information security specialists and the other aimed at the C-suite. NIST is seeking public comments on the draft, and they are proposing the establishment of a Community of Interest for collaboration and knowledge sharing in information security measurement."}

{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2023/12/nist-calls-information-support-safe-secure-and-trustworthy-development-and", "title": "NIST Calls for Information to Support Safe, Secure and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has issued a Request for Information (RFI) to assist in implementing the Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of AI. NIST is responsible for developing guidelines, facilitating the development of standards, and providing testing environments for the evaluation of AI systems. The RFI specifically asks for information on AI red-teaming, generative AI risk management, reducing the risk of synthetic content, and advancing responsible global technical standards for AI development. The goal is to develop industry standards around AI safety, security, and trust. The responses to the RFI will support NIST's efforts to evaluate AI technologies and develop guidelines in accordance with the Executive Order. Stakeholders from industry, academia, government, and civil society are invited to provide input. The deadline for responses is February 2, 2024."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2023/12/metis-data-exchange-ecosystem-seeks-your-input", "title": "The METIS Data Exchange Ecosystem Seeks Your Input", "date": "2024-01-28", "summary": "NIST and CHIPS are seeking feedback on a draft publication for building a data exchange ecosystem in the microelectronics industry. This ecosystem, called METIS, aims to provide stakeholders with access to research results from the CHIPS Metrology Program. The goal is to support America's security and commercial competitiveness by disseminating the outcomes of microelectronics research. The CHIPS Metrology Program is a collaborative effort between NIST, industry, government agencies, and academic institutions to address measurement challenges in microelectronics manufacturing. METIS will ensure that NIST's research results are available while also protecting intellectual property and U.S. security interests. The METIS concept leverages NIST's expertise in data management and aims to shepherd the research process and provide security controls. Stakeholders are encouraged to submit comments on the draft publication by January 31, 2024. Learn more about the CHIPS Metrology Program and CHIPS for America."}

{"category": "Education", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15081", "title": "Can generative AI and ChatGPT outperform humans on cognitive-demanding problem-solving tasks in science?. (arXiv:2401.15081v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "This study compares the performance of ChatGPT and GPT-4 with students on science assessments, finding that the AI tools consistently outperformed most students. However, the AI tools were not sensitive to increased cognitive demands, indicating the need for changes in educational objectives to cultivate advanced cognitive skills. The study also suggests the need for innovative assessment practices that focus on creativity and analytical skills to avoid negative effects of AI on testing efficiency."}
{"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.15098v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Continual reinforcement learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks, preserving previous knowledge and using it for future learning. Existing methods focus on transferring low-level knowledge and neglect the hierarchical structure of human cognitive control. To address this, the Hi-Core framework proposes a two-layer approach: high-level policy formulation using a Large Language Model (LLM) for goal-setting, and low-level policy learning through RL guided by high-level goals. The framework also includes a knowledge base for hierarchical knowledge transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show that Hi-Core outperforms existing baselines in diverse CRL tasks."}
{"category": "Mathematics", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15103", "title": "PruneSymNet: A Symbolic Neural Network and Pruning Algorithm for Symbolic Regression. (arXiv:2401.15103v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Symbolic regression aims to derive interpretable expressions from data. A new neural network, PruneSymNet, is proposed for symbolic regression. The network is differentiable and can be trained using gradient descent. A greedy pruning algorithm is used to extract subnetworks, ensuring accurate data fitting. Beam search helps find multiple candidate expressions, with the one with the smallest loss chosen as the final result. The algorithm outperforms current popular algorithms in terms of accuracy."}
{"category": "Enhancement", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15105", "title": "Diffusion Enhancement for Cloud Removal in Ultra-Resolution Remote Sensing Imagery. The framework utilizes an ultra-resolution benchmark called CUHK-CR to design and evaluate CR models, incorporates progressive texture detail recovery, and adjusts feature fusion weights dynamically. A coarse-to-fine training strategy accelerates convergence and reduces computational complexity. Experimental results demonstrate that the DE framework surpasses other DL-based methods in terms of perceptual quality and signal fidelity."}

{"category": "Science", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15122", "title": "A Multi-Grained Symmetric Differential Equation Model for Learning Protein-Ligand Binding Dynamics. They introduce a novel physics-informed multi-grained group symmetric framework, including a BindingNet model that captures multi-level interactions and an augmented neural differential equation solver. Experimental results demonstrate that NeuralMD achieves a 2000x speedup over standard MD simulation, outperforms other ML approaches by up to 80% in stability, and provides more stable binding predictions."}

{"category": "Optimization", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15196", "title": "Regularized Q-Learning with Linear Function Approximation. (arXiv:2401.15196v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas of the article:\n- Reinforcement learning algorithms use regularization to promote exploration and robustness.\n- Convergence properties of certain algorithms (e.g. soft Q-learning) with functional approximation are not well understood.\n- The paper presents a single-loop algorithm that minimizes the projected Bellman error with finite time convergence guarantees.\n- The algorithm operates on two scales: slower scale for updating target network and faster scale for approximating Bellman backups.\n- The proposed algorithm converges to a stationary point in the presence of Markovian noise, under certain assumptions.\n- The article provides a performance guarantee for policies derived from the algorithm."}

{"category": "Healthcare", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15337", "title": "Deep Learning with Information Fusion and Model Interpretation for Health Monitoring of Fetus based on Long-term Prenatal Electronic Fetal Heart Rate Monitoring Data. (arXiv:2401.15337v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Long-term fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring is crucial but lacks standards.
