{"category": "Graph Theory", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.06189", "title": "Query Complexity of Tournament Solutions. (arXiv:1611.06189v4 [cs.DS] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "A tournament is a directed graph where there is exactly one edge between every pair of vertices. Finding the best set of vertices in a tournament is a well-studied problem in social choice theory. In many applications, such as selecting the best drugs from a set, the edges of the tournament are only implicitly given and determining the orientation of an edge is costly. We want to find the best set of vertices by querying as few edges as possible. This paper focuses on studying this problem for various tournament solutions. The set of Condorcet non-losers in a tournament can be found by querying a specific number of edges, and this is the minimum number of edges that need to be queried. Other popular tournament solutions require querying a quadratic number of edges in the worst case. However, if the size of the top cycle in the tournament is small, all tournament solutions can be found by querying a certain number of edges."}
{"category": "Algorithms", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.07497", "title": "One head is better than two: a polynomial restriction for propositional definite Horn forgetting. (arXiv:2009.07497v3 [cs.AI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Logical forgetting is a complex problem, even in simple cases. One way to forget is by replacing variables with the body of each related clause. This can be done in polynomial time for single-head cases. Some formulae can be simplified to be single-head. This article introduces a semantical characterization of single-head equivalence. There are two necessary conditions for equivalence. These conditions are sufficient when the formula is inequivalent. All acyclic formulae are inequivalent. The article also presents an incomplete algorithm for turning a formula into single-head. If successful, forgetting can be done in polynomial time and produces a smaller formula. The algorithm is complete for inequivalent formulae."}
{"category": "Machine Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.00783", "title": "Computer Vision Self-supervised Learning Methods on Time Series. (arXiv:2109.00783v4 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Self-supervised learning (SSL) has been successful in computer vision. Siamese network architecture is commonly used but may result in feature collapse. Can computer vision SSL frameworks be effective on time series data? Evaluations on UCR and UEA archives show they can. A new method is proposed, improving on VICReg by enhancing the covariance term and adding an iterative normalization layer for faster model convergence."}
{"category": "Biology", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.00999", "title": "DeepAutoPIN: An automorphism orbits based deep neural network for characterizing the organizational diversity of protein interactomes across the tree of life. (arXiv:2203.00999v2 [q-bio.MN] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The evolution of protein interaction networks (PINs) across different species and phyla is not well understood.\n- A study analyzed 4,738 PINs from 16 different phyla to identify phyla-specific architectural features and evolutionary constraints on network topologies.\n- Results showed contrasting orbit usage profiles (OUPs) in networks from different domains of life and phyla, indicating non-random wiring patterns shaped by evolutionary constraints.\n- PINs exhibited subtle but significant variations in wiring patterns that allowed for differentiation among different superfamilies.\n- A deep neural network was trained on differentially expressed orbits, achieving a prediction accuracy of 85%."}
{"category": "Economics", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.10469", "title": "Formal Contracts Mitigate Social Dilemmas in Multi-Agent RL. (arXiv:2208.10469v4 [cs.AI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) can lead to sub-optimal behavior when individual and group incentives diverge. This study proposes using formal contracting to overcome this issue. The augmentation of Markov games with binding transfers of reward can ensure socially optimal behavior. The experiment shows that rich contract spaces lead to higher welfare and the methodology addresses issues of exploration."}
{"category": "Intellectual Property", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03563", "title": "SSL-WM: A Black-Box Watermarking Approach for Encoders Pre-trained by Self-supervised Learning. (arXiv:2209.03563v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Recent success in Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) has led to the need for verifying the ownership of these models to prevent theft and unauthorized commercialization. Existing solutions are not suitable for SSL models as they require knowledge of downstream tasks and labels during watermark embedding. To address this, a black-box watermarking solution called SSL-WM is proposed. SSL-WM maps watermarked inputs to an invariant representation space, allowing detection of embedded watermarks by any downstream classifier. Experimental results show SSL-WM can effectively verify ownership of stolen SSL models across various tasks and is robust against attacks. It can also evade detection from watermark detection approaches, making it a promising tool for protecting the ownership of SSL models."}
{"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.07661", "title": "On the Relation between Sensitivity and Accuracy in In-context Learning. (arXiv:2209.07661v3 [cs.CL] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "In-context learning (ICL) is unreliable due to oversensitivity to prompts. Previous studies underestimated ICL sensitivity due to label bias. ICL sensitivity negatively affects accuracy. A new method called SenSel selectively predicts to improve performance. SenSel outperforms other baselines in abstention decisions."}

(arXiv:2210.01751v6 [cs.AI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Analogical proportions are fundamental in analogical reasoning. This paper explores the mathematical foundations of analogical proportions, introducing proportoids as sets with a 4-ary analogical proportion relation. The study focuses on proportion-preserving mappings and relations."}
{"category": "Machine Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14164", "title": "No-Box Attacks on 3D Point Cloud Classification. (arXiv:2210.14164v3 [cs.CV] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Adversarial attacks pose challenges for DNN analysis of 3D point clouds. Existing methods rely on access to the DNN model to identify important points for generating attacks. This paper proposes a \"no-box\" attack that predicts adversarial points without DNN access. Using 14 point cloud features and multiple linear regression, a suitable combination of features predicts adversarial points for different networks. The attack is transferable to unseen models and provides insight into DNNs for point cloud classification."}

{"category": "Business", "url": "https://solrashidi.substack.com/p/never-select-a-use-case-based-on", "title": "NEVER Select a Use Case Based on BUSINESS VALUE (BV)! There are 9 Other Key Considerations.", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Business Value refers to the tangible and intangible benefits that contribute to a company's profitability and success. It can include increased revenue, cost savings, market share growth, customer satisfaction, brand reputation, and more. However, determining business value is subjective and varies among stakeholders. When selecting use cases, complexity and criticality should be considered. Complexity factors include stakeholder involvement, resource availability, data accessibility and integrity, dependencies on other functions, and infrastructure. Criticality involves assessing competitive threats, market consolidation, government regulations and fines, exposure and press, and alignment with strategic priorities. It is important to rate and assess each use case based on value, feasibility, and ability to deliver. Minimizing barriers to success is crucial."}

This study developed a deep CNN model for automated classification of COVID-19 rapid antigen test device (RATD) images. The model achieved high accuracies on simulated and real datasets, highlighting its potential for large-scale testing and tracking systems. Challenges in dataset limitations and class imbalances were addressed through data augmentation and the use of StyleGAN2-ADA to generate simulated RATD images. The research contributes to the deployment of large-scale testing and tracking systems and offers insights into the potential applications of AI in mitigating outbreaks like COVID-19. {"category": "Misunderstanding", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZQma8TmR6S8GcLbt9/epistemic-hell", "title": "Epistemic Hell", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The article discusses three examples of epistemic hell, where logic and scientific investigation lead to misleading results.\n- The first example is the detoxification technique of bitter manioc in indigenous Tukanoan societies, where the steps of the process are causally opaque and cannot be readily inferred.\n- The second example is the discovery and cure of scurvy, where the simple solution of consuming vitamin C-rich foods was repeatedly lost and misunderstood over centuries.\n- The third example is the confusion and lack of understanding in heredity and genetics for millennia, despite centuries of farming animals and observing pedigrees.\n- The article highlights that being stuck in an epistemic hell requires radical and unconventional approaches to escape, such as engineering serendipity, assembling extraordinary datasets, and unlearning prior thinking."}
{"category": "Economics", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZeXoCJ426CocFzxJq/doing-a-basic-life-focused-cost-benefit-analysis", "title": "Doing a Basic Life-Focused Cost-Benefit Analysis", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "In this article, the author provides a simplified framework for conducting a cost-benefit analysis using life-years as the unit of analysis. The focus is primarily on the time cost rather than the monetary cost of implementing a policy. To estimate costs, the author recommends consulting the operational plan and considering the time spent by different individuals involved in the policy. Benefits can be estimated through studies or expert elicitation, and should be converted into life-years gained. The article also suggests comparing the annualized full-time equivalent (FTE) cost to the annualized life-years gained to determine if the policy passes the cost-benefit test. Additionally, the author discusses the estimation of the disvalue of a policy that curtails people's freedom. The article concludes by addressing the reasoning behind the FTE cost threshold for prioritizing policies."}
{"category": "Regulation", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/asi4mi7xJj7ue8DhX/surgery-works-well-without-the-fda", "title": "Surgery Works Well Without The FDA", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The key ideas in this article are:\n\n1. The FDA is often criticized for its regulation of pharmaceuticals, with arguments that it slows down the development and availability of new drugs.\n2. The comparison is made between the regulation of cars and computers, which are less likely to release inferior products, and pharmaceuticals, which require human testing and are more challenging to evaluate.\n3. The article points out that surgery, which is not regulated by the FDA, has seen improvements and advancements over time, suggesting that a well-functioning market can exist without strict regulatory oversight.\n4. The author argues that surgery can serve as a better counterfactual for pharmaceutical markets than consumer tech or cars.\n5. There are challenges in both surgery and pharmaceuticals, but non-governmental mechanisms such as competition, insurance companies, hospital systems, and ethical boards can provide consumer protection without the need for strict FDA regulations.\n6. The article concludes that abolishing the FDA could lead to a well-functioning, self-improving market for medical treatments, resulting in faster and cheaper medication availability. However, the author acknowledges the importance of the FDA and regulatory bodies in ensuring safety and monitoring side effects."}
{"category": "Collaboration", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/BaoA3gz7xRaqn764J/gaia-network-an-illustrated-primer", "title": "Gaia Network: An Illustrated Primer", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The Gaia Network is a decentralized system that connects causal models to improve scientific efficiency, decision-making, and AI safety. It works by pooling and aggregating posterior distributions from different studies to update priors for parameters in scientific models. This allows researchers to access and incorporate the latest information from other studies, making science more effective and efficient. The Gaia Network also has applications in pragmatic impact, such as aiding decision-making in various domains like agriculture and business. It can provide quantitative impact metrics and help guide investments and strategies. Additionally, the Gaia Network has the potential to serve as a distributed AI scientist, evaluating the safety of high-stakes actions. The network can be implemented with existing technology and has the potential to transform the way we do science and make decisions. The success of the Gaia Network would require extensive coordination and adoption by different stakeholders, which may pose challenges. The proposal is ambitious and complex, and its implementation and adoption remain uncertain."}

{"category": "Standards", "url": "https://techpolicy.press/how-to-assess-ai-governance-tools", "title": "How to Assess AI Governance Tools", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Setting standards and evaluations for the safety of AI systems is still in progress. The World Privacy Forum conducted a review of AI governance tools and found faulty fixes that could undermine fairness and explainability. The nonprofit organization also found that 38% of the AI governance tools reviewed included problematic AI measurement methods. The report emphasized the need for better assessment processes in evaluating AI fairness and explainability. It also highlighted the challenge of integrating data privacy and AI systems, as current frameworks may not adequately address the complexity of AI. The involvement of large tech companies in shaping AI governance tools was addressed, with the report recommending the prevention of conflicts of interest and the incorporation of external evaluations. The report mentioned several notable AI governance tools, including Open Loop by Meta and the Chilean government's procurement process, which includes responsible AI considerations. The report also discussed measurement methods such as the 80% rule and popular metrics like SHAP and LIME, noting concerns about their applicability in assessing AI fairness and explainability. The involvement of organizations like the OECD in shaping AI governance was highlighted, with the report acknowledging their positive contributions while also addressing certain problematic aspects. The report concluded that ongoing research and updates are necessary in this rapidly evolving field."}

{"category": "Decision-making", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.37?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Integrating data, knowledge, and expertise for policy advice: understanding the practices of Dutch organized crime control professionals", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The research focuses on the integration of data, local knowledge, and professional expertise in the work of policy advisors, specifically in the context of a Dutch law enforcement network for tackling organized crime. The study found that policy advisors rely on data sources to scope policy issues but give limited value to data when it comes to actual policy interventions. The weight given to data is highly situational and shaped by the existing local and expert knowledge of policy advisors. The study emphasizes the importance of understanding data use for policy advice and highlights the need to build upon a contextual understanding of how data, local knowledge, and expertise interact. The findings demonstrate the discretionary role of policy advisors in the use of data and challenge the belief that data is a rationalizing force in policymaking."}

{"category": "Media", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/press-act-will-protect-journalists-when-they-need-it-most", "title": "The PRESS Act Will Protect Journalists When They Need It Most", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The House of Representatives has passed the PRESS Act, a federal shield bill that would protect journalists from government surveillance and restrict the disclosure of their sources. The bill has bipartisan support and is necessary to address the lack of federal protections for journalists. The surveillance of journalists has had a chilling effect on their ability to gather news and has discouraged sources from coming forward. The PRESS Act has a broad definition of journalism and is supported by various press and rights groups. It is crucial for protecting both professional journalists and citizens' right to gather and publish information. Legislatures in many states have also targeted young people's use of social media, while federal legislation on data privacy reforms has been inadequate. The right to free expression is especially vulnerable for marginalized groups, and conflicts around the world have led to threats against speech."}

{"category": "Regulation", "url": "https://www.siia.net/online-speech-and-ai/", "title": "Online Speech and AI", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "As discussed in the OMB AI Draft Memo, AI can impact individuals' rights and safety. OMB should limit the scope of high-risk AI assessments and cover specific impacts under a different risk assessment model. Integrating AI into content moderation tools can lead to less biased decisions and lower costs. The First Amendment limits the government's ability to block protected speech, but technology companies can continue to moderate harmful content."}
{"category": "Poverty", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.38?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Predicting social assistance beneficiaries: On the social welfare damage of data biases", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The article discusses the use of cash transfer programs as a common anti-poverty tool in low and middle-income countries. These programs typically use prediction models to target beneficiaries, but the analysis argues that targeting assessments should consider the characteristics of misclassified households in order to build social protection systems that align with local redistributive preferences and reduce discriminatory biases. The study finds that bias in the data, such as label bias and unstable proxy means testing weights, leads to underestimation of welfare losses and disadvantages certain groups more than others. The paper highlights the need for transparency in targeting procedures and calls for a broader discussion on the implications and application of cash transfer programs."}

It aims to create enabling conditions for researchers to carry out their work and has a focus on advocating for data access, providing crisis response support to researchers facing attacks, and engaging in strategic communications. The coalition is globally minded and is working towards expanding its membership and influence beyond the US and Europe.\nSummarized: The Coalition for Independent Tech Research supports independent research on the impact of technology and defends researchers' right to conduct their work. They focus on advocating for data access and providing support to researchers facing attacks. The coalition aims to expand its global membership and influence."}

{"category": "Privacy", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.42?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Determinants for university students\u2019 location data sharing with public institutions during COVID-19: The Italian case", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas: \n- Trust, perceived benefits, and perceived risk are significant predictors of the intention to share location data during health emergencies.\n- University students show a higher willingness to share data when they trust public institutions and perceive higher benefits.\n- Perceived risk has a negative impact on the intention to share data, while perceived benefits have a positive impact.\n- Communication strategies should focus on highlighting the benefits of sharing location data and reducing the perceived risks.\n- Involving third-party trustworthy organizations and utilizing decentralized technologies can increase trust and reduce perceived risks."}

{"category": "Searches", "url": "https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-urges-pennsylvania-supreme-court-find-keyword-search-warrant-unconstitutional", "title": "EFF Urges Pennsylvania Supreme Court to Find Keyword Search Warrant Unconstitutional ", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Keyword warrants that allow police to search through search engine databases are unconstitutional, violating free speech and privacy rights. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), along with other organizations, filed a brief to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania challenging the constitutionality of a keyword search warrant issued by the police to Google. These warrants require search engine providers to search their entire user data to identify anyone who searched for specific keywords specified by the police. The EFF argues that these warrants violate the Pennsylvania Constitution and the Fourth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. If upheld, these warrants could have implications for users of any search engine."}

{"category": "Digital Rights", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/12/taking-back-web-decentralization-2023-review", "title": "Taking Back the Web with Decentralization: 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas in this article:\n\n- The internet has become centralized and controlled by a few large platforms, leading to a push for decentralization.\n- Mastodon and Bluesky are examples of federated microblogging platforms that have gained momentum as alternatives to Twitter.\n- Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, has launched Threads, a microblogging site using the ActivityPub protocol.\n- Reddit faced backlash and protests from its moderators and developers, leading users to seek refuge in decentralized alternatives like Lemmy and Kbin.\n- Decentralized social media platforms have their own challenges in content moderation, but community-level moderation and Task Forces are working towards solutions.\n- The year 2023 saw advancements in decentralized services, protocols, and governance models, with more exploration and alternatives emerging.\n- The Supreme Court should clarify standards for government influence on social media censorship.\n- Spritely and Veilid are projects aiming for fully peer-to-peer applications, going beyond current models of decentralization.\n- The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and other organizations are advocating for digital rights and challenging legislation that restricts online activities, particularly for young people."}

{"category": "Ethics", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/when-generative-ai-copyright-and", "title": "\ud83d\udc41\ufe0f When Generative AI, copyright, and privacy meet", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas in this article:\n- AI companies rely on web scraping to develop and train large language models, which raises legal issues related to privacy and copyright.\n- Copyright issues are relevant from a privacy perspective because if scraping is restricted, AI companies will have to find other sources of data, potentially involving personal data and new data protection implications.\n- Tech companies may rely on the legitimate interest reasoning to train AI systems through scraping, but this interpretation deserves further analysis.\n- AI governance professionals will be in demand to ensure AI compliance with privacy laws and regulations.\n- Victim blaming has no place in privacy, especially when dealing with sensitive data breaches.\n- Companies should take responsibility for data breaches and put measures in place to protect users.\n- Facebook's new mobile setting prompting users to allow link history raises concerns about privacy and consent, as it pressures users to agree and lacks clear information on the consequences."}
{"category": "Data Privacy", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/fpf-in-2023-a-year-in-review/", "title": "FPF in 2023: A Year in Review", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "In 2023, the Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) expanded its presence globally and domestically. It convened industry experts, academics, and advocacy groups to explore data protection and privacy issues in the context of AI. FPF closely followed privacy developments in various regions, including India, Asia-Pacific, and the European Union. It provided in-depth analysis, training, and hosted webinars on AI-related topics. FPF also engaged with state legislatures in the US on privacy issues, provided timely analysis on state privacy laws, and recognized leading privacy research through an awards program. FPF addressed the protection of children online and published recommendations for schools and districts. It also focused on privacy in immersive technologies and open banking. FPF emphasized the importance of collaboration across sectors and believed in advancing practical safeguards for beneficial data uses."}
{"category": "Framework", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/risk-framework-for-body-related-data-in-immersive-technologies/", "title": "Risk Framework for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum has released a Risk Framework for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies to help organizations manage the privacy and safety risks associated with collecting and using body-related data. This framework assists organizations in documenting their data practices, complying with laws, evaluating risks, and implementing best practices. It is applicable not only to immersive technologies but also to other contexts involving body-related data. Organizations should proactively identify and minimize risks, assess the fairness and ethics of their data practices, and implement safeguards to ensure statutory compliance and minimize privacy risks. This should be done through comprehensive adoption of best practices and ongoing evaluation to maintain effectiveness."}
{"category": "Legislation.", "url": "https://fpf.org/blog/five-big-questions-and-zero-predictions-for-the-u-s-state-privacy-landscape-in-2024/", "title": "Five Big Questions (and Zero Predictions) for the U.S. State Privacy Landscape in 2024", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Entering 2024, the United States is the only G20 nation without a comprehensive national framework for personal data. State-level activity on privacy has accelerated, with the number of states with comprehensive commercial privacy laws increasing. Key questions for 2024 include whether any state will adopt an alternative regulatory framework, the impact of California's privacy laws, the regulation of AI systems, and the enforcement of privacy laws. There are differences between state privacy laws, but a clear blueprint for enacting protections for personal data held by businesses is emerging. The first wave of state privacy laws may have seen little enforcement due to the ability for businesses to cure violations, but indicators suggest that enforcement actions may increase in 2024. The Washington My Health, My Data Act will take effect, and its litigation landscape may shape privacy enforcement. Existing privacy laws may be revised, and the ongoing litigation involving the California Age Appropriate Design Code Act may impact the broader US privacy landscape. More privacy proposals can be expected in the upcoming state sessions."}

{"category": "Misinformation", "url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/7-reasons-why-social-media-disinformation", "title": "\ud83d\udcc8 7 Reasons why social media disinformation is on the rise", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Disinformation is spreading faster and becoming more viral on social media platforms due to various factors. Algorithmic feeds, which show curated posts based on algorithms, promote filter bubbles and help fake news spread rapidly. Virality-fostering feeds, similar to TikTok's algorithm, incentivize the posting of alarming and false information. Lack of algorithmic transparency allows the free circulation of fake news, without giving users control over filtering them. Additionally, the absence of accountability mechanisms for spreading misinformation further contributes to the problem. The proliferation of AI-deepfakes, the monetization of user content, and the lack of a fact-check culture on social media also play a role in worsening disinformation. These algorithmic-based systems have harmful consequences, particularly in the context of wars and social conflicts. To address this issue, it is crucial to only follow and share posts from credible sources and verify information before sharing it."}

The company is being sued for its failure to adequately protect customer data. Protecting genetic privacy is crucial to prevent harm and hate. Users should be educated about privacy risks before opting into features. In addition, there is information about privacy job opportunities, live conversations with experts, and an upcoming AI book club meeting. The article also briefly mentions October GDPR fines and their implications for data protection."}

However, most watermarks fail against model extraction attacks. {"category": "Threats.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15321", "title": "Localization of Dummy Data Injection Attacks in Power Systems Considering Incomplete Topological Information: A Spatio-Temporal Graph Wavelet Convolutional Neural Network Approach. (arXiv:2401.15321v1 [eess.SY])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The dummy data injection attack (DDIA) is a significant threat to power systems, as it is difficult to detect due to its close proximity to legitimate data. Existing research often overlooks the non-Euclidean spatial attributes of power grid data, leading to inaccurate attack localization. To address this, a study proposes a comprehensive approach that includes a mathematical model of the DDIA, temporal and spatial attention matrices to capture spatio-temporal correlations, and a localization method based on graph neural networks. Rigorous analysis demonstrates the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed DDIA model."}
{"category": "Machine Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15335", "title": "L-AutoDA: Leveraging Large Language Models for Automated Decision-based Adversarial Attacks. {"category": "Adversarial.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1902.08412", "title": "Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks via Meta Learning. (arXiv:1902.08412v2 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Deep learning models for graphs have made significant progress in various tasks, but their robustness remains largely unknown. A study was conducted to investigate training-time attacks on graph neural networks for node classification by perturbing the graph structure. The study used meta-gradients to optimize the graph as a hyperparameter. Experiment results demonstrated that even small perturbations to the graph led to a significant decrease in performance for graph convolutional networks, and these perturbations could even affect unsupervised embeddings. Surprisingly, the algorithm's perturbations caused the graph neural networks to perform worse than a basic baseline that disregarded relational information. Notably, these attacks did not require any prior knowledge or access to the target classifiers."}
{"category": "Ownership", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03563", "title": "SSL-WM: A Black-Box Watermarking Approach for Encoders Pre-trained by Self-supervised Learning. (arXiv:2209.03563v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Recent success in Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) has led to its widespread use in Computer Vision (CV) and Natural Language Processing (NLP). However, SSL models can be stolen and commercialized, making it necessary to verify ownership. Existing solutions for ownership protection are not applicable to SSL models. To address this, a black-box watermarking solution called SSL-WM is proposed. SSL-WM maps watermarked inputs to an invariant representation space, allowing detection of embedded watermarks by any downstream classifier. SSL-WM is evaluated on various tasks and models, demonstrating its effectiveness in verifying ownership of stolen SSL models. It is also robust against attacks and can evade watermark detection approaches."}
{"category": "Cybersecurity", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03622", "title": "Deep Learning Models for Detecting Malware Attacks. {"category": "Analysis", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14164", "title": "No-Box Attacks on 3D Point Cloud Classification. (arXiv:2210.14164v3 [cs.CV] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Adversarial attacks in deep neural networks (DNNs) are a challenge for analyzing input signals. In the case of 3D point clouds, methods have been developed to identify key points that are important for network decisions. These points are crucial for generating adversarial attacks. Typically, these methods require access to the DNN model itself. However, this paper proposes a \"no-box\" attack, where adversarial points can be predicted without access to the target DNN model. The study defines 14 point cloud features and uses multiple linear regression to examine if these features can be used for predicting adversarial points. The experiments show that a combination of these features can predict adversarial points in four different networks with high accuracy. The proposed attack is also transferable to unseen models. Furthermore, the results provide insights into the decision-making process of DNNs for point cloud classification."}
{"category": "Communication", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09049", "title": "Perfectly Covert Communication with a Reflective Panel. (arXiv:2212.09049v4 [cs.IT] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "This article discusses the concept of \\emph{perfect} covert communication in wireless networks using Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces (IRS). The goal is to hide communication from unwanted listeners, even if they have knowledge of the codebook, timings, and channel characteristics. The article defines perfect covertness, provides a necessary and sufficient condition for it in IRS-assisted communication, and presents an optimization problem. The probability of finding a solution for two IRS elements is analyzed, and a closed form is derived. The article also investigates the problem of more than two IRS elements and proves that the probability of a zero-detection solution approaches 1 as the number of elements increases. An iterative algorithm to find a perfectly covert solution is provided and its convergence is proven. Simulations show that even a small number of IRS elements can achieve a positive rate for the legitimate user while having zero probability of detection for unwanted listeners."}
{"category": "Detection", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08767", "title": "Masked Language Model Based Textual Adversarial Example Detection. (arXiv:2304.08767v3 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Adversarial attacks can trick machine learning models by making slight modifications to inputs, posing a threat to their reliability. A new method called Masked Language Model-based Detection (MLMD) can detect adversarial examples by exploring changes in the data manifold. MLMD is easy to use and is not limited to specific tasks or attack methods. Experimental results show that MLMD performs well, outperforming or matching the state-of-the-art defenses. This approach offers a fresh perspective on capturing the changes in the data manifold caused by adversarial examples."}

{"category": "Network Attacks", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10565", "title": "Measurement Based Evaluation and Mitigation of Flood Attacks on a LAN Test-Bed. (arXiv:2305.10565v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The article discusses intrusion detection schemes (IDS) using Machine Learning (ML) to address the vulnerability of the Internet of Things (IoT) to network attacks. These IDS have high attack detection accuracy and can be easily installed on servers communicating with IoT devices. However, they are seldom tested under realistic operational conditions where system overload caused by attacks may hinder IDS processing. The article presents an experimental study of UDP Flood Attacks on a Local Area Network Test-Bed, revealing that severe attacks overload the server, paralyzing IDS detection. To combat this issue, the article proposes an IDS design that makes decisions based on a small number of incoming packets, dropping attacking traffic within milliseconds of an attack starting to avoid congestion-induced paralysis. \n\nKey ideas:\n- Intrusion detection schemes using Machine Learning address IoT's vulnerability to network attacks.\n- These IDS have high attack detection accuracy and easy installation on servers communicating with IoT devices.\n- IDS are seldom tested under realistic operational conditions with system overload caused by attacks.\n- An experimental study of UDP Flood Attacks shows severe attacks overload the server, paralyzing IDS detection.\n- A proposed IDS design makes decisions based on a small number of packets to drop attacking traffic quickly and avoid congestion-induced paralysis."}
{"category": "MachineLearning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09189", "title": "High-Resolution Convolutional Neural Networks on Homomorphically Encrypted Data via Sharding Ciphertexts. (arXiv:2306.09189v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (DCNNs) like ResNet-20 have been evaluated on encrypted, low-resolution data using RNS-CKKS homomorphic encryption. The evaluation methods have been extended to handle larger dimensions and multiple channels. Improved efficiency and simplified image format have been achieved, resulting in faster encrypted inference times. Regularization techniques have been used to enhance efficiency and accuracy during the training process. These techniques have been applied to successfully evaluate DCNNs on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets, achieving high accuracy."}
{"category": "Networking", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09959", "title": "Hummingbird: Fast, Flexible, and Fair Inter-Domain Bandwidth Reservations. (arXiv:2308.09959v3 [cs.NI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The article discusses the lack of quality-of-service guarantees for real-time applications on the current Internet. It introduces Hummingbird, a lightweight bandwidth-reservation system that improves upon previous designs. Hummingbird enables flexible reservations with guarantees and addresses the incentivization of network providers. It represents reservations as tradeable assets, allowing fair and efficient resource allocation. {"category": "Camouflage", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04036", "title": "One-to-Multiple Clean-Label Image Camouflage (OmClic) based Backdoor Attack on Deep Learning. (arXiv:2309.04036v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Image camouflage has been used to create poisoned images with backdoors for deep learning models, but the limitation is that one attack image can only fit one input size. This work proposes OmClic, which allows for one attack image to fit multiple input sizes, making it more efficient. The camouflaging algorithm targets five input sizes simultaneously, creating visually imperceptible attack images. Evaluations show that OmClic is successful in different settings and achieves high backdoor performances. It also reduces the attack budget compared to the baseline camouflage-based backdoor attack. The attack images created with OmClic can be used on different model architectures for backdoor implantation."}

{"category": "Linguistics", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02446", "title": "Low-Resource Languages Jailbreak GPT-4. However, our research shows that large language models (LLMs) can be bypassed by translating unsafe inputs into low-resource languages. {"category": "Adversarial", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10483", "title": "Passive Inference Attacks on Split Learning via Adversarial Regularization. (arXiv:2310.10483v4 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Key ideas:\n1. Split Learning (SL) is an alternative to traditional federated learning.\n2. SDAR is a novel attack framework against SL with an honest-but-curious server.\n3. SDAR uses auxiliary data and adversarial regularization to learn a decodable simulator of the client's private model.\n4. SDAR can effectively infer the client's private features under vanilla SL and both features and labels under U-shaped SL.\n5. SDAR achieves comparable attack performance to active attacks in challenging scenarios where existing passive attacks struggle.\n6. On CIFAR-10, at the deep split level of 7, SDAR achieves private feature reconstruction with less than 0.025 mean squared error and label inference accuracy of over 98% in the U-shaped setting."}

{"category": "Cryptography", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11526", "title": "Commitments from Quantum One-Wayness. (arXiv:2310.11526v4 [quant-ph] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "In this article, the author discusses the concept of one-way functions in classical cryptography and their importance in creating secure cryptosystems. They explore the idea that even weaker assumptions than one-way functions may be sufficient in a quantum world, such as one-way state generators. The article presents a study on the use of one-way state generators in quantum cryptography and concludes that they can indeed be used to achieve quantum bit commitments and secure multi-party computation. The author also introduces a new primitive called a quantum one-way puzzle and demonstrates its implication in quantum bit commitments."}

{"category": "Vulnerabilities", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2311.07550", "title": "Tabdoor: Backdoor Vulnerabilities in Transformer-based Neural Networks for Tabular Data. (arXiv:2311.07550v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are promising but vulnerable to backdoor attacks in tabular data, including transformer models. The study analyzes and experiments on these attacks, finding high susceptibility in transformer-based DNNs. The attacks are successful even with minimal changes to feature values. The study verifies the generalizability of the attack to other models like XGBoost and DeepFM. Defenses are evaluated, with Spectral Signatures identified as the most effective. Urgent action is needed to address these vulnerabilities and secure DNN models against backdoors in tabular data."}
{"category": "Security", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.11156", "title": "Generalizing Speaker Verification for Spoof Awareness in the Embedding Space. (arXiv:2401.11156v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Automatic speaker verification (ASV) systems are vulnerable to spoofing attacks. Counteracting these attacks often requires a separate spoofing countermeasure module, which adds computational and utilization efforts. An alternative approach is to use a monolithic ASV system that handles both imposter and spoofing attacks. In this article, the authors propose a generalized standalone ASV (G-SASV) that leverages limited training data from a spoofing countermeasure module to enhance the backend in the embedding space. They use a deep neural network-based backend classifier and conduct the study through domain adaptation and multi-task integration of spoof embeddings. The experiments show significant improvements in performance on the ASVspoof 2019 logical access dataset, particularly in the spoofed conditions."}

(arXiv:2401.14427v1 [cs.SE])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The learnware paradigm allows users to reuse existing well-trained models instead of building new ones. {"category": "Transparency", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14446", "title": "Black-Box Access is Insufficient for Rigorous AI Audits. (arXiv:2401.14446v1 [cs.CY])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "External audits of AI systems are increasingly seen as important for AI governance. The effectiveness of an audit depends on the level of system access given to auditors. Current audits mostly have black-box access, where auditors can only query the system and observe the outputs. However, white-box access, which allows auditors to examine the inner workings of the system, and outside-the-box access, which includes information about the system's training and deployment, provide more thorough evaluation and scrutiny. The limitations of black-box audits and the advantages of white- and outside-the-box audits are discussed, along with safeguards for these audits. Transparency about access and methods is necessary to properly interpret audit results. White- and outside-the-box access allow for significantly more scrutiny than black-box access alone."}
{"category": "Communication", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14520", "title": "Mitigating Smishing: Challenges and Future Work. It provides an overview of ideas to mitigate smishing considering these challenges."}
{"category": "Blockchain", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14527", "title": "Unsealing the secrets of blockchain consensus: A systematic comparison of the formal security of proof-of-work and proof-of-stake. (arXiv:2401.14527v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The article discusses the debate surrounding the choice of consensus mechanism in decentralized information systems using blockchain networks. It highlights the recent transition of Ethereum from proof-of-work (PoW) to proof-of-stake (PoS), which has intensified the discussion. While energy consumption and decentralization are often emphasized, research has also examined the formal security aspects of both approaches. However, existing work has not structured the knowledge comprehensively. To address this gap, the article conducts a systematic literature review of 26 research articles. The findings reveal that PoW-based consensus with the longest chain rule offers the strongest formal security guarantees. However, PoS can achieve similar guarantees by addressing the tradeoff between safety and liveness through hybrid approaches."}
{"category": "Development", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14635", "title": "Signing in Four Public Software Package Registries: Quantity, Quality, and Influencing Factors. (arXiv:2401.14635v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Many software applications use third-party packages, but verifying authorship is challenging. This study examines signing practices across different platforms and finds that mandating signature adoption and providing dedicated tools improves the quantity and quality of signatures. Once a maintainer starts signing, they tend to continue. However, signing adoption is primarily influenced by registry policy rather than public knowledge of attacks or engineering standards. This emphasizes the importance of registry managers and signing infrastructure."}
{"category": "Child Protection", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14713", "title": "A safety risk assessment framework for children's online safety based on a novel safety weakness assessment approach. (arXiv:2401.14713v1 [cs.CY])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "This paper addresses the issue of children's online safety in the digital age. Existing regulations fail to adequately protect children from online risks and criminal incidents. Most security and privacy assessment approaches focus on businesses, neglecting the unique challenges faced by children. To address this gap, the authors propose a safety risk assessment approach tailored to children's online safety. The approach utilizes automated mathematical reasoning to evaluate potential weaknesses in online services and applications. This framework can aid designers in creating safer systems and assist auditors and users in understanding the risks associated with existing services. Further research should focus on age-appropriate warnings and education materials for children and parents."}
{"category": "Data", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14840", "title": "GuardML: Efficient Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning Services Through Hybrid Homomorphic Encryption. (arXiv:2401.14840v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Machine Learning has privacy concerns due to malicious attacks. Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning (PPML) methods, such as Homomorphic Encryption (HE), can address these concerns. Hybrid Homomorphic Encryption (HHE) combines HE and symmetric cryptography for better scalability. A PPML scheme using HHE for end devices preserves privacy while enabling secure learning. An HHE-based PPML application for classifying heart disease showed promising results with minimal accuracy reduction. HHE integration in PPML offers a secure and privacy-conscious future for machine learning on constrained devices."}
{"category": "Collaboration", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14884", "title": "P3LS: Partial Least Squares under Privacy Preservation. (arXiv:2401.14884v1 [stat.ML])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Modern manufacturing value chains require intelligent orchestration of processes across company borders for maximum profits and sustainability.\n\nPrivacy concerns hinder the implementation of integrated, data-informed decision-making approaches.\n\nA new technique called Privacy-Preserving Partial Least Squares (P3LS) regression enables cross-organizational data integration and modeling while maintaining privacy.\n\nP3LS uses a singular value decomposition (SVD) based PLS algorithm and random masks to protect data privacy.\n\nP3LS can vertically integrate process data along value chains and improve prediction performance on key performance indicators.\n\nP3LS and PLS model components are numerically equivalent on simulated data.\n\nA mechanism is proposed to determine the relevance of contributed data, allowing for quantifying participants' contributions."}
{"category": "Explainability.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14886", "title": "Coca: Improving and Explaining Graph Neural Network-Based Vulnerability Detection Systems. (arXiv:2401.14886v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based vulnerability detection systems have been successful but lack explainability. A framework called Coca is proposed to enhance the robustness of GNN models and provide concise and effective explanations for vulnerability detection. Coca consists of a Trainer and Explainer component, which improve the model's robustness and generate crucial code statements for explanations. Experimental results show that Coca mitigates spurious correlations and provides high-quality explanations."}
{"category": "Adversarial", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14961", "title": "End-To-End Set-Based Training for Neural Network Verification. (arXiv:2401.14961v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Neural networks can be easily manipulated, so we need to train them to be robust against attacks. We have developed a new training method that uses sets of perturbed inputs to create more robust networks. This approach simplifies the process of verifying the network's robustness and often produces better results than existing methods."}
{"category": "Exploitation", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14979", "title": "Creating a vulnerable node based on the vulnerability MS17-010. (arXiv:2401.14979v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "A demonstration has shown the creation of a vulnerable node using the MS17-010 vulnerability. The vulnerability affects SMBv1 protocol on Windows operating systems. The exploitation methodology is explained and represented using a Meta Attack Language graph. The attacker uses a Python script with the Metasploit Framework. Basic security measures for systems using SMBv1 are recommended."}
{"category": "Networking", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15038", "title": "Physical Layer Encryption for Industrial Ethernet in Gigabit Optical Links. (arXiv:2401.15038v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Industrial Ethernet is a widely used technology for collecting and transmitting large amounts of data in factory floors and critical infrastructures. This article introduces a new encryption method for high-speed optical communications in these networks. The method involves symmetric streaming encryption at the Physical Coding Sublayer level using a Format Preserving Encryption blockcipher in Counter mode. The system has been simulated and implemented in an FPGA, showing secure encryption without introducing latency or reducing throughput."}
{"category": "Networking", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15039", "title": "Chaotic Encryption Applied to Optical Ethernet in Industrial Control Systems. (arXiv:2401.15039v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Ethernet has become popular in industrial control systems due to its advantages, including high bandwidth and resistance to interference. This article discusses the need for encryption in optical Ethernet links and proposes a solution using symmetric streaming encryption. The system has been tested and shown to successfully hide the traffic pattern from eavesdroppers without introducing any space overhead. The encryption allows for secure transmission of Ethernet traffic over optical links."}
{"category": "Verification", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15041", "title": "Computationally Bounded Robust Compilation and Universally Composable Security. (arXiv:2401.15041v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Universal Composability (UC) is difficult to prove, but a connection between UC and Robust Compilation (RC) can help verify UC proofs using mechanized equality tools. This paper extends the UC-RC connection to the computational setting and generalizes it to arbitrary equalities, allowing for the mechanization of proofs for computational UC security. CryptoVerif is used to demonstrate the power of this approach by proving the computational UC security of parts of the Wireguard protocol. The framework itself is verified in Isabelle/HOL."}
{"category": "Anonymization", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15048", "title": "Unrecognizable Yet Identifiable: Image Distortion with Preserved Embeddings. (arXiv:2401.15048v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Biometric authentication systems face challenges in privacy and security. This article introduces an image distortion technique that maintains identifiability by neural networks while making facial images unrecognizable. The reliability of biometrics recognition neural networks is explored by measuring the maximal degree of image distortion. The method is compared to previous approaches and is shown to be effective in preserving AI feature representation while distorting the images."}
{"category": "Biometrics.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.11291", "title": "A Survey of PPG's Application in Authentication. (arXiv:2201.11291v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Biometric authentication is popular for its convenience and security, but early versions were vulnerable to spoofing attacks. Recently, using unobservable physiological signals like Photoplethysmogram (PPG) has emerged as a potential solution. PPG measures changes in blood flow and has been used clinically to diagnose heart-related issues. Researchers are exploring the use of PPG signals in cyber security applications due to their unique advantages. However, research on PPG-based authentication is still in its early stages, and the lack of systematization is hindering progress. A comprehensive study of PPG-based authentication is conducted to identify limitations and suggest future research directions."}

{"category": "Awareness", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10148", "title": "Privacy Perceptions and Behaviors of Google Personal Account Holders in Saudi Arabia. (arXiv:2308.10148v2 [cs.CY] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Privacy perceptions and behaviors in non-Western societies, specifically in Saudi Arabia, were investigated through interviews with 30 Google personal account holders. Results showed that while participants had some level of awareness about Google's data practices and controls, many were only vaguely aware and had not used the available controls. Participants were surprised by the data that had been saved. While participants found Google's use of their data for service improvement acceptable, they found its use for ad purposes unacceptable. The study highlights the need for improved techniques to inform and remind users about privacy settings, user-friendly interfaces, and further research on privacy concerns in non-Western cultures."}
{"category": "Computational", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13773", "title": "Solving the insecurity problem for assertions. (arXiv:2308.13773v2 [cs.LO] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "The article discusses the \"insecurity problem\" in the verification of cryptographic protocols. The authors demonstrate that when considering a finite number of sessions, this problem is NP-complete. They introduce the concept of simulating protocol executions with bounded communication size. However, the analysis becomes challenging when both terms and logical statements about terms are considered. The authors extend previous techniques to address this problem, specifically when protocols involve equality on terms and existential quantification. They conclude that this problem is also in NP."}
{"category": "Advancements", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.02003", "title": "A Survey on Large Language Model (LLM) Security and Privacy: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. (arXiv:2312.02003v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-01-29", "summary": "Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT and Bard are highly advanced AI systems that have made significant advancements in natural language understanding and generation. They have proven to be extremely useful in various domains such as search engines, customer support, and translation. LLMs have also gained attention in the security community, where they have been used to uncover security vulnerabilities and demonstrate their potential in security-related tasks. This paper explores the impact of LLMs on security and privacy. It discusses the positive effects they have on code security and data privacy, as well as the risks and threats associated with their use. The paper categorizes the findings into \"The Good\" (beneficial applications of LLMs), \"The Bad\" (offensive applications), and \"The Ugly\" (LLM vulnerabilities and defenses). The authors highlight that LLMs have shown promise in enhancing code security and data privacy, but also note that they can be exploited for various attacks, particularly at the user-level. The paper identifies areas where further research is needed, including model and parameter extraction attacks and safe instruction tuning. The authors hope that their work will contribute to a better understanding of LLMs' potential in both strengthening and compromising cybersecurity."}

The publication can be used alongside any risk management framework and provides a flexible approach for developing information security measures. It is important for organizations to move towards quantitative descriptions of risk to enhance communication and resource allocation. The guidance is open for public comments until March 18, 2024. NIST is also proposing the establishment of a Community of Interest (CoI) for information security measurement to share expertise and improve knowledge in this field."}
