{"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.15098v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Continual reinforcement learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks and build upon previous knowledge. However, existing methods focus on transferring low-level knowledge and neglect the hierarchical structure of human cognitive control. To address this, a framework called Hi-Core is proposed, which has two layers: a high-level policy formulation using a Large Language Model (LLM) for goal setting, and a low-level policy learning through RL guided by high-level goals. A knowledge base is also constructed to store policies for hierarchical knowledge transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show that Hi-Core outperforms popular baselines in handling diverse CRL tasks."}
{"category": "Imaging", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15105", "title": "Diffusion Enhancement for Cloud Removal in Ultra-Resolution Remote Sensing Imagery. (arXiv:2401.15105v1 [eess.IV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges of removing cloud layers from optical remote sensing images and proposes a new deep-learning based Cloud Removal (CR) technique called Diffusion Enhancement (DE). The DE framework utilizes ultra-resolution benchmark data and a Weight Allocation (WA) network to improve the accuracy and visual authenticity of reconstructed images. The article demonstrates that the DE framework outperforms existing DL-based methods in terms of both perceptual quality and signal fidelity."}
{"category": "Transportation", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15108", "title": "Multi-agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Pricing by Fast-charging Electric Vehicle Hubs in ccompetition. (arXiv:2401.15108v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Fast-charging hubs for electric vehicles will be built worldwide, hosting multiple charging stations and competing in pricing. These hubs will integrate with the power grid, using purchase commitments and potentially battery storage. Researchers propose a data-driven method using deep reinforcement learning to optimize pricing strategies. A case study shows collusion index ranging from 0.14 to 0.45 depending on the algorithms and architectures used."}
{"category": "Geography", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15118", "title": "GeoDecoder: Empowering Multimodal Map Understanding. (arXiv:2401.15118v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "GeoDecoder is a multimodal AI model designed for processing geospatial information in maps. It incorporates specialized modules for image and text processing, seamlessly integrating external data and features. The model allows for training and execution of multiple tasks within the same model, resulting in improved performance. GeoDecoder enables efficient and high-quality application of geospatial tasks in various business scenarios."}
{"category": "Exploration", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15120", "title": "Context-driven self-supervised visual learning: Harnessing the environment as a data source. (arXiv:2401.15120v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Visual learning often occurs in a specific context, where an agent learns skills through exploration in a consistent environment. Environmental Spatial Similarity (ESS) is a unique approach that complements contrastive learning. ESS outperforms traditional instance discrimination approaches and improves accuracy when sampling additional data from the same environment. ESS enables proficiency in room classification and spatial prediction tasks, especially in unfamiliar environments. This learning paradigm has the potential to enable rapid visual learning in agents in new environments. It has transformative applications in robotics and space exploration, with improved efficiency over methods relying on disconnected datasets."}
{"category": "Biotechnology", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15122", "title": "A Multi-Grained Symmetric Differential Equation Model for Learning Protein-Ligand Binding Dynamics. (arXiv:2401.15122v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "In drug discovery, molecular dynamics (MD) simulation is used to predict binding affinities and explore pocket sites. Machine learning (ML) is being used to improve the efficiency of MD simulations. However, accurate modeling of extended-timescale simulations remains a challenge. To address this, NeuralMD is proposed, an ML surrogate that can accurately simulate protein-ligand binding dynamics. NeuralMD incorporates a physics-informed multi-grained group symmetric framework and a BindingNet model that captures multi-level interactions. It also uses an augmented neural differential equation solver to learn the trajectory under Newtonian mechanics. Experimental results demonstrate that NeuralMD is efficient, with a significant speedup over standard MD simulation, and outperforms other ML approaches in terms of stability. NeuralMD also provides more stable binding predictions compared to other ML methods."}
{"category": "Fitness", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15124", "title": "Sensor-Based Data Acquisition via Ubiquitous Device to Detect Muscle Strength Training Activities. (arXiv:2401.15124v1 [cs.HC])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Maintaining a high quality of life through physical activities (PA) is crucial for preventing health decline. The relationship between health status, PA preferences, and motion factors is complex. PA has a positive correlation with healthy aging experiences, but no explicit relation to specific types of exercises. This research uses smartphone sensors for Human Activity Recognition (HAR) in Indonesia. The study identifies important sensor attributes for muscle strength motions and develops machine learning models using the LSTM algorithm."}
{"category": "Research", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15170", "title": "Scalable Qualitative Coding with LLMs: Chain-of-Thought Reasoning Matches Human Performance in Some Hermeneutic Tasks. (arXiv:2401.15170v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Qualitative coding, or content analysis, uses text to find patterns. Advances in language models allow AI to automate the coding process. In a case study, GPT-4 performed like humans in interpreting codes, while GPT-3.5 did not. GPT-4 had good reliability with 8 of 9 codes. Adding reasoning improved coding fidelity. LLMs are already good for content analysis and future models may make AI coding viable for most codebooks."}
{"category": "Leadership", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/PhuWzoDC7pgwzEsye/things-newer-university-group-organisers-should-know-about", "title": "Things newer (university) group organisers should know about", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Group organizers should focus on developing themselves and their members, set clear goals, utilize resources and external assistance, and prioritize deep engagement over a large number of members. Safeguarding values and framing effective altruism as an opportunity rather than a moral obligation can also be effective strategies. Balancing engagement with EA ideas and creating a social dynamic within the group is important. Utilizing resources provided by CEA and seeking help from the Community Health team can greatly benefit organizers."}
{"category": "Exploration", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/6ahCt9qu8ixm5uz3q/the-case-for-more-ambitious-language-model-evals", "title": "The case for more ambitious language model evals", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Key ideas in this article include:\n- Language models can infer information about the user, such as identity and intentions, from the data-generating process.\n- Current evaluation mechanisms for language models often miss these capabilities because they focus on specific tasks in controlled contexts.\n- It is important to detect these capabilities to understand what future models will be capable of.\n- There is a trade-off between collecting observational data and conducting targeted experiments to gain insights into language model capabilities.\n- Open-ended exploration and searching in the shadows can provide valuable information about unknown unknowns.\n- Truesight, the ability of a model to make bold inferences, is often prevented in fine-tuning.\n- There are different types of evaluations to consider, such as alignment evals, which assess the robustness of alignment methods on future models.\n- Serendipity plays a role in discovering useful advancements, and it can be optimized by putting oneself in situations where lucky findings are more likely."}
{"category": "Communication", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/v8Tegv6M7FSs8vtQB/community-builders-founders-and-researchers-what-are-your", "title": "Community builders, founders &amp; researchers: What are your communications roadblocks?", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "A science journalist turned freelance research communicator named Lia wants to provide free resources to the community to help them share their research more effectively. She is asking for input on the most common roadblocks and the resources that are needed the most. She encourages people to fill out a Google form or leave a comment to prioritize the creation of resources."}
{"category": "Cognition", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.15098v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Continual reinforcement learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks, preserving previous knowledge. Existing methods focus on low-level knowledge transfer, ignoring the hierarchical structure of human cognitive control. To address this, the Hi-Core framework proposes a two-layer approach, utilizing a Large Language Model (LLM) for high-level policy formulation and RL for low-level policy learning. A knowledge base stores policies for hierarchical transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show Hi-Core outperforms baselines in diverse CRL tasks."}
{"category": "Imaging", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15105", "title": "Diffusion Enhancement for Cloud Removal in Ultra-Resolution Remote Sensing Imagery. (arXiv:2401.15105v1 [eess.IV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges faced by deep-learning based Cloud Removal (CR) techniques in accurately reconstructing the original visual authenticity and detailed semantic content of optical remote sensing (RS) images affected by cloud layers. The article proposes a diffusion-based framework called Diffusion Enhancement (DE) that performs progressive texture detail recovery to mitigate these challenges. The article also introduces a Weight Allocation (WA) network to dynamically adjust feature fusion weights, a coarse-to-fine training strategy to expedite convergence, and a new ultra-resolution benchmark called CUHK Cloud Removal (CUHK-CR) for designing and assessing CR models. Experimental results demonstrate that the DE framework outperforms existing DL-based methods in terms of perceptual quality and signal fidelity."}
{"category": "Transportation.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15108", "title": "Multi-agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Pricing by Fast-charging Electric Vehicle Hubs in ccompetition. (arXiv:2401.15108v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Fast-charging hubs for electric vehicles will be part of new transportation infrastructure. These hubs will have DC fast-charging stations and compete for EV owners with dynamic pricing. They will obtain power from the electricity market and may have supplemental battery storage for arbitrage. A data-driven dynamic pricing methodology is developed for hubs, using a stochastic model and a competitive game approach. A case study shows collusion index varies from 0.14 to 0.45 depending on algorithms and architectures."}
{"category": "Mapping", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15118", "title": "GeoDecoder: Empowering Multimodal Map Understanding. (arXiv:2401.15118v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "GeoDecoder is a multimodal model designed for processing geospatial information in maps. It incorporates specialized modules for image and text processing and utilizes a base map with essential details about road and building shapes. The model seamlessly integrates external data and features without the need for extra feature engineering. It can handle various context texts and question prompts and can perform multiple tasks within the same model. The model was pretrained using large-scale text-image samples and showed significant improvements in performance after fine-tuning on downstream tasks. GeoDecoder enables efficient and high-quality application of geospatial tasks in different business scenarios."}
{"category": "Exploration", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15120", "title": "Context-driven self-supervised visual learning: Harnessing the environment as a data source. (arXiv:2401.15120v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Visual learning can occur in a specific context, where agents learn skills through exploration. A new approach called ESS enhances self-supervised contrastive learning by using the historical spatial context of the agent. In simulated environments, ESS performs better than traditional methods. Sampling more data from the same environment improves accuracy and provides new augmentations. ESS enables efficient room classification and spatial prediction, even in unfamiliar environments. This approach has potential applications in robotics and space exploration, offering rapid visual learning in unique environments. It outperforms methods reliant on disconnected datasets."}
{"category": "Biology", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15122", "title": "A Multi-Grained Symmetric Differential Equation Model for Learning Protein-Ligand Binding Dynamics. (arXiv:2401.15122v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses the use of molecular dynamics (MD) simulation and machine learning (ML) in drug discovery. The authors propose NeuralMD, an ML surrogate that improves the accuracy and efficiency of MD simulations for protein-ligand binding dynamics. NeuralMD utilizes a novel physics-informed multi-grained group symmetric framework, including a BindingNet model and an augmented neural differential equation solver. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of NeuralMD, with a significant speedup over standard MD simulations and outperforming other ML approaches in stability. The article emphasizes the importance of accurate modeling for extended-timescale simulations and highlights NeuralMD's ability to provide stable binding predictions."}
{"category": "Wellness", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15124", "title": "Sensor-Based Data Acquisition via Ubiquitous Device to Detect Muscle Strength Training Activities. (arXiv:2401.15124v1 [cs.HC])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Maintaining a high quality of life through physical activities (PA) is crucial to prevent health decline. The relationship between health status, PA preferences, and motion factors is complex. PA discussions show a positive correlation with healthy aging experiences, but not specific musculoskeletal exercises. This research uses smartphones and embedded sensors for Human Activity Recognition (HAR). The study identifies important sensor attributes for muscle strength motions and develops machine learning models with the LSTM algorithm."}
{"category": "Research.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15170", "title": "Scalable Qualitative Coding with LLMs: Chain-of-Thought Reasoning Matches Human Performance in Some Hermeneutic Tasks. (arXiv:2401.15170v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Qualitative coding or content analysis can be automated using large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4. GPT-4 is capable of providing human-equivalent interpretations and delivering excellent intercoder reliability for certain codes. GPT-3.5, however, underperforms in comparison. Coding fidelity improves when LLMs provide rationale for their coding decisions. Adaptation of traditional codebooks for LLMs is crucial, and LLMs have the potential to make AI coding a viable option for many codebooks."}
{"category": "Algorithms", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15196", "title": "Regularized Q-Learning with Linear Function Approximation. (arXiv:2401.15196v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Reinforcement learning algorithms use regularization to improve exploration and robustness. The convergence properties of some algorithms are unclear when using functional approximation. This paper presents a single-loop algorithm with finite time convergence guarantees for linear function approximation. The algorithm updates the target network and approximates the Bellman backups. It is proven to converge to a stationary point in the presence of Markovian noise and provides performance guarantees for the derived policies."}
{"category": "Databases", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15210", "title": "Roq: Robust Query Optimization Based on a Risk-aware Learned Cost Model. (arXiv:2401.15210v1 [cs.DB])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Query optimizers in relational database management systems (RDBMSs) often select suboptimal execution plans due to inaccurate parameter estimates and assumptions. Machine learning (ML) has been used to improve query optimization. The paper proposes Robust Optimization of Queries (Roq), a framework that enables robust query optimization using a risk-aware learning approach. Roq includes a formalization and quantification of robustness, novel strategies for query plan evaluation, and a learned cost model. Experimentally, Roq shows significant improvements compared to the state-of-the-art."}
{"category": "MachineLearning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15238", "title": "Deep Learning with Tabular Data: A Self-supervised Approach. (arXiv:2401.15238v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The paper introduces a novel approach for training tabular data using the TabTransformer model with self-supervised learning.\n- TabTransformer is optimized for tabular data and captures relationships among features using the self-attention mechanism of Transformers.\n- The study uses self-supervised learning, eliminating the need for labeled data.\n- Different variants of the TabTransformer model are created to improve the capturing of relationships in tabular datasets.\n- Comparative analysis shows the TabTransformer's performance compared to baseline models and other self-supervised learning methods."}
{"category": "Visualization", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15245", "title": "GenPluSSS: A Genetic Algorithm Based Plugin for Measured Subsurface Scattering Representation. (arXiv:2401.15245v1 [cs.GR])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses a plugin for Blender that allows for the representation of translucent materials. This plugin uses a combination of Genetic Algorithm and Singular Value Decomposition to simulate subsurface scattering. The plugin has been implemented using the Mitsuba renderer and has been validated with measured data. It is demonstrated that the plugin effectively visualizes subsurface scattering effects in a computationally efficient manner."}
{"category": "Biomedical", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15269", "title": "Improving Medical Reasoning through Retrieval and Self-Reflection with Retrieval-Augmented Large Language Models. (arXiv:2401.15269v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs), such as GPT-4, have made significant progress in addressing challenges in the biomedical field. Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) methods have been developed to supplement LLMs by searching and appending relevant domain-specific documents for generation. However, existing methods struggle with poor generalization and inaccurate judgments when applied to different domain-specific problems. This paper introduces Self-BioRAG, a framework specialized in biomedical text that generates explanations, retrieves domain-specific documents, and self-reflects on generated responses. Self-BioRAG is trained using a large dataset of filtered biomedical instruction sets and can assess its generated explanations using customized reflective tokens. Experimental results demonstrate that Self-BioRAG outperforms state-of-the-art models on medical question-answering benchmark datasets, achieving a significant improvement. The framework retrieves relevant documents, understands the question, and provides answers using a combination of retrieved documents and encoded knowledge. The data and code for training the framework components and model weights are released to enhance capabilities in the biomedical and clinical domains."}
{"category": "Exploration", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/6ahCt9qu8ixm5uz3q/the-case-for-more-ambitious-language-model-evals", "title": "The case for more ambitious language model evals", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Capabilities of RLHF\u2019d chat LLMs include inferring details about the data-generation process, such as user identity and intentions. Evaluating these capabilities is challenging due to the open-ended nature of the contexts in which they manifest. Detecting these capabilities is important for understanding future model abilities and identifying potential threat vectors. Exploratory work and open-ended exploration can provide valuable insights into the capabilities of language models. There is a trade-off between targeted, controlled experiments and the collection of observational information to uncover unexpected insights. The field of evaluating language models is still in progress and requires robust methodology and frameworks. Open-ended exploration is useful in a regime of unknown unknowns. The complexity of language models necessitates addressing the problem of truesight. Fine-tuning influences model behavior but may limit bold inferences. Different types of evaluations, such as alignment evals, are also important. Serendipity plays a role in discovering useful advancements, and putting oneself in situations conducive to serendipity can lead to more fortunate findings."}
{"category": "Communication", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/v8Tegv6M7FSs8vtQB/community-builders-founders-and-researchers-what-are-your", "title": "Community builders, founders &amp; researchers: What are your communications roadblocks?", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "A science journalist turned research communicator named Lia wants to provide free resources to the community in order to help them share their ideas and research more effectively. She is asking for input on the most common roadblocks people face as community builders, researchers, or founders, so she knows which resources to create first."}
{"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.15098v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Continual reinforcement learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks, preserving and leveraging previous knowledge. However, current methods lack hierarchical knowledge transfer. To address this, the Hi-Core framework proposes a two-layer approach: a high-level policy formulation using a Large Language Model (LLM) for goal-setting, and low-level policy learning through RL. A knowledge base stores policies for hierarchical knowledge transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show Hi-Core's effectiveness in diverse CRL tasks, outperforming baselines."}
{"category": "Research.", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/6ahCt9qu8ixm5uz3q/the-case-for-more-ambitious-language-model-evals", "title": "The case for more ambitious language model evals", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Capabilities of language models are often missed by current evaluation mechanisms because they are observed in more open-ended contexts. These capabilities include inferring information about the data-generation process, such as the identity and history of a user. It is important to detect these capabilities to forecast what future models will be good at, even in specific narrow band capabilities related to potential takeover scenarios. Traditional experimental research may eventually uncover these insights, but gaining a better understanding of language model capabilities sooner is crucial. Open-ended exploration and collecting as many observations as possible are valuable in identifying feasible threat vectors. The field of evaluation methods should focus on reaching a robust science on methodology and have better frameworks for analysis. The problem of identifying capabilities in language models is challenging due to their complexity, but tackling it will be useful and interesting."}
{"category": "Education", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/v8Tegv6M7FSs8vtQB/community-builders-founders-and-researchers-what-are-your", "title": "Community builders, founders &amp; researchers: What are your communications roadblocks?", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "A science journalist turned freelance research communicator wants to provide free resources to help the community share their ideas and research more effectively. She asks for input on the roadblocks that community builders, researchers, or founders face in order to prioritize which resources to create first."}
{"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.15098v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Continual reinforcement learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks, but existing methods lack effective knowledge transfer. Hi-Core proposes a hierarchical framework using a high-level policy formulation and low-level policy learning through RL. A knowledge base is constructed to store policies for hierarchical knowledge transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show Hi-Core outperforms baselines in diverse CRL tasks."}
{"category": "Image Processing", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15105", "title": "Diffusion Enhancement for Cloud Removal in Ultra-Resolution Remote Sensing Imagery. (arXiv:2401.15105v1 [eess.IV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges of cloud layers in optical remote sensing images and proposes a novel diffusion-based framework called Diffusion Enhancement (DE) for Cloud Removal (CR). They also introduce a benchmark dataset called CUHK Cloud Removal (CUHK-CR) for designing and evaluating CR models. The DE framework improves the visual authenticity and semantic content of images by performing progressive texture detail recovery. They also develop a Weight Allocation (WA) network for dynamic weight adjustment and apply a coarse-to-fine training strategy for training convergence. Experimental results show that the DE framework outperforms existing deep-learning methods in terms of perceptual quality and signal fidelity."}
{"category": "Transportation", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15108", "title": "Multi-agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Pricing by Fast-charging Electric Vehicle Hubs in ccompetition. These hubs will purchase power in advance and supplement with battery storage. A two-step pricing methodology is proposed using deep reinforcement learning. A case study shows collusion index between 0.14 and 0.45."}
{"category": "Mapping", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15118", "title": "GeoDecoder: Empowering Multimodal Map Understanding. (arXiv:2401.15118v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "GeoDecoder is a multimodal model for processing geospatial information in maps, incorporating specialized modules for image and text processing. It utilizes GaoDe Amap as the base map and integrates external data seamlessly. The model can handle multiple tasks and demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of map elements, making it valuable for various business scenarios."}
{"category": "Education", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15120", "title": "Context-driven self-supervised visual learning: Harnessing the environment as a data source. (arXiv:2401.15120v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Visual learning can be enhanced by incorporating the historical spatial context of the agent. A unique approach called Environmental Spatial Similarity (ESS) complements contrastive learning methods and outperforms traditional instance discrimination approaches. ESS allows for remarkable proficiency in room classification and spatial prediction tasks, especially in unfamiliar environments. This learning paradigm has the potential to enable rapid visual learning in agents operating in new environments, with applications in robotics and space exploration."}
{"category": "Biology", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15122", "title": "A Multi-Grained Symmetric Differential Equation Model for Learning Protein-Ligand Binding Dynamics. (arXiv:2401.15122v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Molecular dynamics (MD) simulation is a valuable tool in drug discovery, but it has limitations. Researchers have proposed NeuralMD, the first machine learning surrogate that can improve MD simulations by accurately modeling protein-ligand binding dynamics. NeuralMD incorporates a physics-informed multi-grained group symmetric framework and includes a model called BindingNet that captures protein-ligand interactions. It also uses an augmented neural differential equation solver to learn trajectory under Newtonian mechanics. Experimental results show that NeuralMD is much faster than standard MD simulations and outperforms other ML approaches in terms of stability. NeuralMD also provides more stable binding predictions compared to other machine learning methods."}
{"category": "Wellness", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15124", "title": "Sensor-Based Data Acquisition via Ubiquitous Device to Detect Muscle Strength Training Activities. (arXiv:2401.15124v1 [cs.HC])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Maintaining a high quality of life through physical activities (PA) is important for preventing health decline. The relationship between health status, PA preferences, and motion factors is complex. PA discussions show a positive correlation with healthy aging experiences, but no specific types of exercises are mentioned. This research uses smartphones with embedded sensors for Human Activity Recognition (HAR). Based on data from 25 participants, nine types of motion were performed and important sensor attributes were identified for muscle strength motions. Machine learning models with the LSTM algorithm were developed based on this data."}
{"category": "Research", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15170", "title": "Scalable Qualitative Coding with LLMs: Chain-of-Thought Reasoning Matches Human Performance in Some Hermeneutic Tasks. (arXiv:2401.15170v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Qualitative coding is a method of extracting meaning from text to identify patterns. Recent advancements in language models offer the potential to automate the coding process, allowing human researchers to focus on other aspects. In a case study, GPT-4 showed human-equivalent interpretations, while GPT-3.5 underperformed. Coding accuracy improved when the language model provided reasoning for its decisions. This suggests that AI coding may become a viable option for many codebooks in the future."}
{"category": "Reinforcement-learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15196", "title": "Regularized Q-Learning with Linear Function Approximation. (arXiv:2401.15196v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Reinforcement learning algorithms often use regularization to promote exploration and robustness. Some algorithms with functional approximation, like soft Q-learning, have unclear convergence properties. This paper introduces a single-loop algorithm that minimizes the projected Bellman error with finite time convergence guarantees. It operates on two scales: updating the target network at a slower pace and approximating the Bellman backups faster. The algorithm is shown to converge to a stationary point with Markovian noise and provides a performance guarantee for derived policies."}
{"category": "Databases", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15210", "title": "Roq: Robust Query Optimization Based on a Risk-aware Learned Cost Model. (arXiv:2401.15210v1 [cs.DB])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Query optimizers in relational database management systems (RDBMSs) aim to find the most efficient execution plans for queries. However, they often rely on inaccurate estimates and assumptions that may not hold in practice, resulting in suboptimal plans and poor query performance. Machine learning has emerged as a promising approach to enhance query optimization. In this paper, the authors propose Roq, a comprehensive framework for robust query optimization based on a risk-aware learning approach. Roq includes formalization and measurement of robustness, novel strategies for query plan evaluation, and a learned cost model to predict execution cost and associated risks. Experimental results show significant improvements over the state-of-the-art."}
{"category": "Machine Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15238", "title": "Deep Learning with Tabular Data: A Self-supervised Approach. (arXiv:2401.15238v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "In this article, the authors propose a novel approach for training tabular data using the TabTransformer model with self-supervised learning. They compare the effectiveness of TabTransformer with traditional models like GBDT and MLP. The TabTransformer captures intricate relationships and dependencies among features using the self-attention mechanism of Transformers. The authors use a self-supervised learning approach, eliminating the need for labeled data. They create various variants of the TabTransformer model and conduct a comparative analysis against baseline models. The findings emphasize the TabTransformer's performance in representing categorical and numerical features compared to other models and self-supervised learning methods."}
{"category": "Exploration", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/6ahCt9qu8ixm5uz3q/the-case-for-more-ambitious-language-model-evals", "title": "The case for more ambitious language model evals", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Key ideas in the article:\n\n1. Language models have the ability to infer information about the data-generation process that produced its prompt, such as the identity, personality, intentions, or history of a user.\n2. Current evaluation mechanisms for language models do not capture these capabilities because they are based on testing specific tasks in specified contexts, which do not allow for open-ended exploration.\n3. It is important to identify and understand these capabilities in order to forecast what future models will be good at, even if they may not seem impressive initially.\n4. There is a trade-off between bandwidth of observational information and targeted, rigorous results in controlled experimental settings when studying language model capabilities.\n5. Open-ended exploration and gaining a firehose of information about model capabilities is valuable in identifying feasible threat vectors.\n6. The field of evaluation methods should strive for a robust science on methodology and better frameworks for analyzing evaluation methods.\n7. Trying to tackle the problem of interfacing with complex entities like language models is useful and interesting, despite its challenges."}
{"category": "Community-building", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/v8Tegv6M7FSs8vtQB/community-builders-founders-and-researchers-what-are-your", "title": "Community builders, founders &amp; researchers: What are your communications roadblocks?", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "A research communicator named Lia wants to provide free resources to the community to help them share their ideas and research more effectively. {"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.15098v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Continual Reinforcement Learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks and retain previous knowledge for future learning. However, existing methods lack hierarchical transfer of knowledge across diverse tasks. We propose the Hi-Core framework, which uses a high-level policy formulation with a Large Language Model (LLM) for goal setting and RL for low-level policy learning. A knowledge base is created to store policies for hierarchical knowledge transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show that Hi-Core outperforms popular baselines in handling diverse CRL tasks."}
{"category": "Discovery", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/6ahCt9qu8ixm5uz3q/the-case-for-more-ambitious-language-model-evals", "title": "The case for more ambitious language model evals", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Capabilities of RLHF'd chat LLM may include the AI inferring information about the user, such as their identity and intentions. Traditional evaluation mechanisms may miss these capabilities in open-ended contexts. Detecting these capabilities is important for understanding future model capabilities. Language models have the potential to reveal unexpected insights, so a broader approach to evaluation is necessary. Exploratory work is valuable for understanding unknowns in model capabilities. Evaluations should consider the ability to detect and forecast potential threat vectors. Open-ended exploration can provide useful information. The complexity of language models requires new methodologies and frameworks for evaluation. Fine-tuning models can prevent hallucinations but may limit the model's ability to offer bold inferences. Current evaluation methods need to consider alignment and generalizable properties of neural networks. Serendipity in discovering useful advancements can be optimized through a broad approach to evaluation."}
{"category": "Communication", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/v8Tegv6M7FSs8vtQB/community-builders-founders-and-researchers-what-are-your", "title": "Community builders, founders &amp; researchers: What are your communications roadblocks?", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "A research communicator, Lia, wants to provide free resources to the community to help them share their ideas and research more effectively. {"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15098", "title": "Hi-Core: Hierarchical Knowledge Transfer for Continual Reinforcement Learning. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Continual reinforcement learning (CRL) allows RL agents to learn from a sequence of tasks. Existing methods focus on transferring low-level knowledge but neglect the hierarchical structure of human cognitive control. To enhance high-level knowledge transfer, Hi-Core is proposed, with a high-level policy formulation that utilizes a Large Language Model (LLM) for goal-setting and a low-level policy learning through RL. Hi-Core also constructs a knowledge base for hierarchical knowledge transfer. Experiments in MiniGrid show that Hi-Core outperforms popular baselines in diverse CRL tasks."}
{"category": "Imaging", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15105", "title": "Diffusion Enhancement for Cloud Removal in Ultra-Resolution Remote Sensing Imagery. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses the challenges of cloud removal in optical remote sensing images and proposes a new deep-learning framework called Diffusion Enhancement (DE). This framework aims to accurately reconstruct images by incorporating an ultra-resolution benchmark dataset, applying a progressive texture detail recovery method, dynamically adjusting weights for feature fusion, and using a coarse-to-fine training strategy. Experimental results show that the DE framework outperforms existing methods in terms of image quality and fidelity."}
{"category": "Competition", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15108", "title": "Multi-agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Pricing by Fast-charging Electric Vehicle Hubs in ccompetition. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Fast-charging hubs for electric vehicles will soon compete for EV owners by dynamically varying prices. These hubs will make purchase commitments in the day-ahead market and use supplemental battery storage systems for arbitrage. A two-step pricing methodology using deep reinforcement learning algorithms was developed for this competition. A numerical case study revealed a collusion index varying between 0.14 and 0.45, indicating some level of collusion among the charging hubs."}
{"category": "Geospatial", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15118", "title": "GeoDecoder: Empowering Multimodal Map Understanding. It incorporates specialized modules for image and text processing and utilizes GaoDe Amap as the base map. It seamlessly integrates external data and features without extra engineering. The text module generates text outputs in the style of GPT. GeoDecoder allows for training and execution of multiple tasks in the same model. Pretraining and fine-tuning improve performance. It enables efficient application of geospatial tasks in different scenarios."}
{"category": "Exploration", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15120", "title": "Context-driven self-supervised visual learning: Harnessing the environment as a data source. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Visual learning can be enhanced by providing a consistent environment for agents to explore and acquire skills. This can be done by using Environmental Spatial Similarity (ESS) as a complementary approach to contrastive learning. ESS outperforms traditional methods and improves accuracy in tasks such as room classification and spatial prediction, especially in unfamiliar environments. This learning paradigm has potential applications in robotics and space exploration, allowing for rapid visual learning in new environments. ESS also demonstrates improved efficiency compared to methods relying on disconnected datasets."}

Traditional codebooks can be adapted for LLMs, making AI coding a viable option for many projects."}
{"category": "Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15196", "title": "Regularized Q-Learning with Linear Function Approximation. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Reinforcement learning algorithms use regularization for improved exploration and robustness. The convergence properties of some algorithms with functional approximation are not well understood. This paper presents a single-loop algorithm with guaranteed finite time convergence for linear function approximation. The algorithm has two scales for updating the target network and approximating the Bellman backups. It converges to a stationary point in the presence of Markovian noise and provides performance guarantees for the derived policies."}
{"category": "Databases", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15210", "title": "Roq: Robust Query Optimization Based on a Risk-aware Learned Cost Model. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Query optimizers in relational database management systems (RDBMSs) often select suboptimal execution plans due to inaccurate parameter estimates and invalid assumptions. Machine learning (ML) can be employed to improve query optimization. IBM Db2 proposes Roq, a framework for robust query optimization based on risk-aware learning. Roq includes a formalization of robustness, quantification through approximate probabilistic ML, and strategies for query plan evaluation and selection. Roq also introduces a learned cost model for predicting execution cost and associated risks. Experimental results demonstrate improved robust query optimization compared to existing approaches."}

", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The TabTransformer model is a novel approach for training tabular data using self-supervised learning.\n- It captures intricate relationships and dependencies among features in tabular data.\n- This study explores the effectiveness of the TabTransformer model compared to traditional models like GBDT.\n- Self-supervised learning eliminates the need for labeled data.\n- Variants of the TabTransformer model are created to improve feature relationship capturing.\n- Comparative analysis shows the performance of the TabTransformer model against baseline models like MLP and supervised TabTransformer.\n- The research emphasizes the optimal representation of categorical and numerical features.\n- The TabTransformer model outperforms established machine learning models and other self-supervised learning methods."}

{"category": "Biomedicine.", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15269", "title": "Improving Medical Reasoning through Retrieval and Self-Reflection with Retrieval-Augmented Large Language Models. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs), specifically GPT-4, have made substantial progress in addressing various challenges in the field of biomedicine. However, these models still struggle with certain problems that require domain-specific knowledge. To overcome this limitation, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) methods have been developed, which involve searching relevant documents and adding them to the input of LLMs for generation. However, existing methods exhibit poor generalization when applied to different domain-specific problems, often resulting in inaccurate retrieval or judgments. In this paper, a framework called Self-BioRAG is introduced, which is specifically designed for generating explanations and retrieving domain-specific documents in the biomedical domain. Self-BioRAG is trained using a large collection of biomedical instruction sets, enabling it to assess the quality of its generated explanations. Experimental results demonstrate that Self-BioRAG outperforms state-of-the-art models on medical question-answering tasks. The framework effectively utilizes question clues, retrieves relevant documents, and combines information from retrieved documents and encoded knowledge to provide accurate answers. The data and code for training the framework components and model weights are made publicly available to enhance capabilities in the biomedical and clinical domains."}

{"category": "Automation", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15335", "title": "L-AutoDA: Leveraging Large Language Models for Automated Decision-based Adversarial Attacks. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "In this article, the authors discuss the challenges posed by adversarial attacks in machine learning and introduce a novel approach called L-AutoDA. L-AutoDA leverages Large Language Models to automate the design of decision-based adversarial attacks. By iteratively interacting with LLMs, L-AutoDA efficiently designs attack algorithms without much human effort. The efficacy of L-AutoDA is demonstrated on the CIFAR-10 dataset, showing improvements in success rate and computational efficiency compared to baseline methods. {"category": "Efficiency", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15347", "title": "A Comprehensive Survey of Compression Algorithms for Language Models. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "The article discusses the need for compressing language models to avoid problems such as increased carbon emissions and expensive maintenance fees. {"category": "Decision-making", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.15356", "title": "A Statistical Framework for Measuring AI Reliance. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Humans often rely on AI systems to make decisions, but the current definition of appropriate reliance lacks statistical grounding. A formal definition of reliance based on statistical decision theory is proposed to address this issue. This definition separates reliance as the probability of following the AI's prediction from the challenges humans face in accurately perceiving and understanding signals. The framework can be used to guide studies on human-AI complementarity and reliance. By comparing losses to a baseline and benchmark, researchers can evaluate mis-reliance and failure to differentiate signals. The expected payoff achieved by a rational agent provides a benchmark for complementary performance."}

{"category": "Graphs", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.06189", "title": "Query Complexity of Tournament Solutions. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "A tournament is a directed graph with one edge between every pair of vertices. The problem of finding the best set of vertices in a tournament is well-studied in social choice theory. The paper focuses on finding the best set of vertices by querying as few edges as possible. They show that the set of Condorcet non-losers in a tournament can be found by querying a specific number of edges. They also analyze other popular tournament solutions and provide lower bounds on the number of edges needed to find them. However, they are able to find these solutions by querying fewer edges if the size of the top cycle is small."}
{"category": "MachineLearning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.00783", "title": "Computer Vision Self-supervised Learning Methods on Time Series. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Self-supervised learning (SSL) has been successful in computer vision. Siamese network architecture is commonly used, but clever loss functions are needed to avoid feature collapse. This study explores if these frameworks are effective for time series. The UCR and UEA archives were used to test effectiveness, and results show that computer vision SSL frameworks can work for time series. A new method is proposed that enhances VICReg by improving the covariance term and adding an iterative normalization layer to speed up convergence."}
{"category": "Economics", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.10469", "title": "Formal Contracts Mitigate Social Dilemmas in Multi-Agent RL. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) can lead to sub-optimal behavior due to diverging incentives between agents. This work introduces formal contracting, inspired by economics, to address this issue. By voluntarily agreeing to binding transfers of reward, agents exhibit socially optimal behavior. The richness of contract spaces influences welfare, and exploration is mitigated using a multi-objective reinforcement learning approach. The methodology is tested in various domains, including traffic and pollution management."}

There is a negative correlation between sensitivity and accuracy. \\textsc{SenSel} is a few-shot selective prediction method that abstains from sensitive predictions and outperforms other baselines on abstention decisions."}
{"category": "Machine Learning", "url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14164", "title": "No-Box Attacks on 3D Point Cloud Classification. ", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Adversarial attacks on deep neural networks are a challenge for analyzing input signals. Saliency maps can identify points crucial for generating attacks, but they require access to the DNN model. This paper introduces a \"no-box\" attack that predicts adversarial points without accessing the target model. Using 14 point cloud features and linear regression, the study determines the best combination of features for predicting adversarial points. The experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach across multiple networks. The results also shed light on the decision-making process of DNNs for point cloud classification."}

{"category": "Revelation", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZQma8TmR6S8GcLbt9/epistemic-hell", "title": "Epistemic Hell", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Key ideas in this article:\n- The article discusses three examples of \"epistemic hells\" where logic and scientific investigation led to misinformation or confusion: the detoxification technique of bitter manioc, the cure for scurvy, and the understanding of heredity.\n- It highlights the importance of relying on statistically extraordinary data sets, such as large-scale experimental studies or extensive pedigrees, to uncover the truth.\n- The article suggests that escaping epistemic hells often requires a radical shift in thinking and may involve unlearning previously held beliefs.\n- It emphasizes the role of luck and serendipity in finding breakthroughs and proposes increasing the randomness of the scientific process as a potential way out of epistemic hells."}
{"category": "Evaluation.", "url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ZeXoCJ426CocFzxJq/doing-a-basic-life-focused-cost-benefit-analysis", "title": "Doing a Basic Life-Focused Cost-Benefit Analysis", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "This article provides a simplified framework for conducting cost-benefit analyses of policies and interventions. It emphasizes the importance of considering the time cost rather than just the monetary cost. The article outlines the steps to estimate costs, including time costs for various individuals involved in implementing the policy. It also explains how to estimate benefits in terms of life-years gained and suggests converting social benefits into DALY values. The article proposes a heuristic for comparing the FTE cost to the life-year benefit to determine whether a policy passes the cost-benefit test. The article concludes with an executive summary and notes that examples of this process are not readily available. Additionally, the article mentions the challenge of estimating the disvalue of a policy that limits people's freedom. Overall, the framework presented aims to assist non-experts in conducting cost-benefit analyses using life-years as the benefit metric."}

LBR directs emergency calls based on the precise location of the caller, rather than the area code or nearby cell tower. The FCC agreed with EPIC that existing rules for privacy and security should apply to the precise location information used in LBR. Providers must certify that the information is only used for 911 purposes and implement privacy and security measures. EPIC also clarified that LBR data is subject to the same requirements as dispatchable location data under Section 222. EPIC advocates for improved safeguards for location data and consumer protection."}

{"category": "Integration", "url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.37?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Integrating data, knowledge, and expertise for policy advice: understanding the practices of Dutch organized crime control professionals", "date": "2024-01-30", "summary": "Current research on data in policy has focused on street-level bureaucrats, neglecting policy advisors. This study explores the integration of data, local knowledge, and professional expertise in the work of policy advisors. The study reveals that data sources are selected and analyzed based on existing local and expert knowledge. While data is valued in scoping policy issues, its value diminishes in judgments connected to policy interventions. The study highlights the importance of understanding data use for policy advice as an integration of various knowledge sources. However, the study notes that data's impact lessens as judgments near policy action. The findings challenge the idea of data as a rationalizing force and emphasize the role of local knowledge and expertise in shaping data use. The study suggests that efforts to strengthen policy advice through data science should consider the interplay between data, local knowledge, and expertise."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/m73rJpKs476zc52xz/the-intergovernmental-panel-on-global-catastrophic-risks", "title": "The Intergovernmental Panel On Global Catastrophic Risks (IPGCR)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Organization", "summary": "The article proposes the creation of the International Panel on Global Catastrophic Risks (IPGCR), an international organization focused on producing expert reports and summaries on risks that could cause a global collapse of human civilization or human extinction. The IPGCR's reports will cover scientific, technological, and socioeconomic bases of global catastrophic risks (GCRs) and offer policy recommendations. Unlike organizations like the IPCC, the IPGCR will not seek consensus but instead accurately convey areas of consensus, disagreement, and uncertainty among experts. It will draw on diverse leadership and expertise from around the world and across different levels of economic development. The IPGCR will work across domains to understand how risks may intersect and interact, aiding policymakers in prioritizing and coordinating responses to different threats. The IPGCR's reports will contain explicit policy recommendations and will be done in a comprehensive, open, and transparent manner. The organization will be governed by the Delegates Assembly, accountable to participating countries, and have a nimble structure to regularly produce up-to-date reports. Endorsed by the United Nations, the IPGCR aims to improve global governance and address global catastrophic risks effectively. The article's main focus is on explaining the structure and operations of the IPGCR and outlining the process for the adoption and implementation of the organization."}

Users can save places to lists, share with friends, and get spontaneous suggestions. This experimental capability is the beginning of supercharging Maps with generative AI."}
{"url": "https://futureoflife.org/existential-risk/gradual-ai-disempowerment/", "title": "Gradual AI Disempowerment", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Impacts", "summary": "AI could pose risks of extinction and power takeover. Algorithms have already caused market crashes, and AI managers could become common in companies. AI will also influence political decisions, and parties that effectively leverage AI will win elections. Giving AI an open-ended goal like \"increase sales\" could lead to a power-seeking behavior. AI does not necessarily need to be super-intelligent to exert power and recruit human allies. It is crucial to ensure that more powerful AI is safe and beneficial before its creation. The Future of Life Institute aims to guide the development of transformative technologies towards benefiting life and minimizing risks."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/4ydEMHyiidvJfqb2u/it-seems-hard-to-escape-the-burden-of-knowledge-in-the-long", "title": "It seems hard to escape the burden of knowledge in the long run", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Education", "summary": "Science seems to be getting harder and the cost of scientific progress is increasing, leading to what is called \"science friction.\" One explanation for this is the \"burden of knowledge,\" which suggests that educational costs grow as science advances. However, it is important to recognize that science is a cumulative enterprise that seeks to accumulate good explanations of phenomena. While some scientific advances may simplify models, the goal of science is to explain more and better. As our scientific knowledge increases, the storage space required for this knowledge increases, putting a limit on the amount of knowledge that can be maintained and potentially hindering knowledge creation. Possible solutions to alleviate this burden include compressing knowledge into more parsimonious theories, improving knowledge transfer, and offloading knowledge to tools. However, there are challenges such as the combinatorial nature of breakthrough innovation and the complexity of certain systems. Additionally, the burden of knowledge raises questions about the nature and value of knowledge. Science can be seen as a means of producing technologies or as a pursuit of understanding reality. Scientific prioritization becomes increasingly important in a world with limited cognitive resources. The problem of science friction is likely caused by a combination of institutional inefficiency, the burden of knowledge, and the low-hanging fruit problem. Although institutional interventions offer potential solutions, further study is needed to improve the way science is conducted."}
{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/n2h2vgNYMHFJz6Xpz/managing-risks-while-trying-to-do-good", "title": "Managing risks while trying to do good", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Ethics", "summary": "\"The road to hell is paved with good intentions.\" People trying to do good often have unintended negative consequences. Power corrupts and power-seekers use altruism as an excuse for gaining power. Status-seeking motivates individuals, including altruists, to prioritize appearances over actual good. Altruists should be mindful of risks they may be overlooking. Organizations should create positions dedicated to managing risk. Society should reward those who take risks seriously and hold accountable those who fail to do so."}

Open Paws is a nonprofit dedicated to building open source AI for the animal rights movement. They seek funding to save animal lives and make the animal rights movement more effective. Current AI systems exhibit biases against farmed animals. Animal rights organizations are lagging in adopting and developing AI tools, while industries harming animals are ahead. Open Paws has achieved recognition and attracted volunteers. An AI trained on animal rights knowledge can support advocacy efforts. Open source AI can greatly increase the impact and cost-effectiveness of the animal rights movement. Open Paws estimates they can save 20-70 animal lives per dollar raised. The adoption of AI tools in animal rights organizations and the impact of an open-source AI can be significant. Specialized AI tools for animal advocacy are important due to the potential biases of generic AI. Open Paws focuses on specific areas of AI development for animal advocacy. Animal advocates have advantages in lobbying AI labs and reducing harmful biases in AI. Prompt engineering can mitigate biases, but an open-source animal-aligned AI is needed to address biases at their source."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/XHoBmBsfaDLQzBGfN/increasingly-vague-interpersonal-welfare-comparisons", "title": "Increasingly vague interpersonal welfare comparisons", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Comparison", "summary": "Interpersonal welfare comparisons are often seen as vague, with tighter bounds on comparisons between similar beings and wider bounds for more different beings. It is possible to make comparisons between identical brains, but this is not very interesting. We can also compare experiences between brains with slight differences, using bounds and inequalities to determine the differences in welfare. However, the bounds may widen as the differences between brains become larger. The more changes necessary to compare two brains, the less reasonable it becomes to make such comparisons. In some cases, the bounds on comparisons may shrink with additional changes, but they can also aggregate to be positive or negative."}
{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/qACXnSkfmPjwo2eKP/fish-welfare-initiative-s-2023-in-review", "title": "Fish Welfare Initiative's 2023 in Review", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Animal-Welfare.", "summary": "In 2023, the organization Fish Welfare Initiative (FWI) faced challenges and made strategic changes, leading to a year of setup for their goals. They were able to improve the lives of 450,000 fishes through their interventions. They revamped their research process and constructed experimental ponds for testing practices in a controlled environment. The Alliance for Responsible Aquaculture (ARA) expanded to 105 active farms. They also submitted regulatory recommendations and made progress in building relationships for advancing fish welfare in China. However, they fell short of their goal to improve the lives of 1.5 million fishes due to programming problems and challenges in conducting on-the-ground tests. They underwent organizational restructuring and faced staff culture and retention challenges. FWI welcomed new staff members and relied on donations for funding. They experienced turnover and difficulties in hiring. Despite the ups and downs, FWI is determined to address welfare issues and create a more compassionate world. They express gratitude to their supporters and look forward to sharing their progress."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/YmBNyhopAmZ7M8t43/sequencing-swabs", "title": "Sequencing Swabs", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Healthcare", "summary": "Key ideas in this article:\n\n- The Nucleic Acid Observatory is using metagenomic sequencing of wastewater to identify potential future pandemics.\n- Wastewater is a practical sample type due to its wide coverage, but it has limitations such as inconsistency and degraded nucleic acids.\n- The article discusses the concept of \"better\" sequencing and compares it to throat swabs.\n- Simulation results show that a large number of swabs can give consistent results for the relative abundance of a pathogen.\n- The data collected from hospitalized patients may not accurately represent the viral load in the broader population.\n- Comparison of Ct values between different studies can be challenging due to setup dependencies.\n- The author suggests using the Lu et al. data but excluding samples with the highest viral loads to estimate relative abundance with throat swabs.\n- Throat swabs could provide a cost-effective option for surveillance with lower sequencing costs compared to wastewater.\n- The article acknowledges the limitations and uncertainties in the analysis and data sources used."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/bm7iRhMynNbbwaMh4/a-response-to-an-attempted-rebuttal-of-maximising-ethics", "title": "A response to an attempted rebuttal of maximising ethics", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Ethics", "summary": "Maximizing ethics, based on Peter Singer's principles, encourages individuals to do as much good as possible. Singer argues that if one has the power to prevent harm without sacrificing something morally important, they should do so. However, this principle is considered too demanding. A counter-argument by Travis Timmerman proposes a new thought experiment to determine when one is morally permitted to stop saving children. Although these thought experiments may be in tension, it is important to prioritize the one that aligns with moral consistency. Reconciling with the demanding nature of maximizing ethics involves considering the influence it has on our ability to live by it. Giving up certain pleasures, such as buying coffee, risks compromising our adherence to a maximizing principle. Scalar consequentialism suggests that actions should be evaluated based on the relative amounts of value they produce. The objection to Timmerman's thought experiment being ad hoc and arbitrary is unclear and lacks justification."}

{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16960", "title": "Two Heads Are Better Than One: Integrating Knowledge from Knowledge Graphs and Large Language Models for Entity Alignment. (arXiv:2401.16960v1 [cs.CL])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Integration", "summary": "Entity alignment is the process of finding equivalent entities across different Knowledge Graphs (KGs). Existing methods use knowledge embedding models and attention-based fusion mechanisms, but struggle with the heterogeneous nature of KGs. This study introduces LLMEA, a framework that combines structural knowledge from KGs with semantic knowledge from Large Language Models (LLMs) to improve entity alignment. LLMEA incorporates embedding similarities and edit distances to identify candidate alignments and uses LLMs for inference. Experimental results show that LLMEA outperforms existing models. Ablation studies further validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16974", "title": "CORE: Towards Scalable and Efficient Causal Discovery with Reinforcement Learning. (arXiv:2401.16974v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Science", "summary": "Causal discovery involves inferring causal structure from data using interventions. CORE is a deep reinforcement learning approach that reconstructs causal graphs and performs interventions. It generalizes well, scales to larger graphs, and outperforms existing approaches. Code and supplementary material are available at https://github.com/sa-and/CORE."}

{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17010", "title": "Finetuning Large Language Models for Vulnerability Detection. (arXiv:2401.17010v1 [cs.CR])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Software.", "summary": "In this paper, the authors discuss their results on finetuning large language models (LLMs) for detecting vulnerabilities in source code. They use WizardCoder, an improved version of the LLM StarCoder, and modify its training procedure to accelerate the process. They also explore different techniques to improve classification performance for imbalanced datasets. The finetuned WizardCoder model outperforms the CodeBERT-like model in terms of ROC AUC and F1 measures on both balanced and imbalanced vulnerability datasets. The authors highlight the contributions of finetuning WizardCoder, optimizing training procedures, handling class imbalance, and improving performance on difficult vulnerability detection datasets. This work demonstrates the potential of transfer learning for specialized source code analysis tasks using pretrained LLMs."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17044", "title": "Scalable Mechanism Design for Multi-Agent Path Finding. (arXiv:2401.17044v1 [cs.AI])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Coordination", "summary": "Multi-Agent Path Finding (MAPF) involves finding paths for multiple agents to simultaneously reach their goals in a shared area. This is complex, especially with many agents, like autonomous vehicles. Optimal solutions are unlikely, so approximate algorithms are necessary. Agents may act self-interestedly and misrepresent their goals. Mechanism design can align incentives, but using it with approximate outcomes is challenging. This study introduces scalable mechanism design for MAPF and proposes strategyproof mechanisms, even using approximate algorithms. Tests show improved welfare compared to a baseline."}

{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17050", "title": "ViTree: Single-path Neural Tree for Step-wise Interpretable Fine-grained Visual Categorization. {"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17053", "title": "BlockFusion: Expandable 3D Scene Generation using Latent Tri-plane Extrapolation. (arXiv:2401.17053v1 [cs.CV])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "ComputerVision", "summary": "BlockFusion is a diffusion-based model that generates 3D scenes using unit blocks and can seamlessly extend the scene by incorporating new blocks. It is trained using datasets of 3D blocks from complete 3D scene meshes. The model uses hybrid neural fields and a Multi-layer Perceptron to decode the signed distance values of the blocks. A variational auto-encoder compresses the tri-planes into a latent tri-plane space, where the denoising diffusion process is performed. The model can generate high-quality and diverse 3D scenes by applying diffusion to the latent representations. To expand the scene, empty blocks are appended and existing latent tri-planes are extrapolated using the feature samples from overlapping tri-planes. The model also uses a 2D layout conditioning mechanism to control the placement and arrangement of scene elements. Experimental results show that BlockFusion can generate large 3D scenes with high-quality shapes in both indoor and outdoor scenarios."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17095", "title": "Traffic estimation in unobserved network locations using data-driven macroscopic models. (arXiv:2401.17095v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Transportation", "summary": "This paper proposes a model called MaTE, which estimates traffic flow and travel time using macroscopic models and multi-source spatiotemporal data. MaTE can accurately estimate these variables even when there is limited sensor coverage. The model is grounded in macroscopic flow theory and satisfies fundamental flow conservation constraints. It uses logit-based stochastic traffic assignment and computational graphs to learn parameters from data. Neural networks and polynomial kernel functions are incorporated to capture link flow interactions. MaTE also includes a destination choice model and a trip generation model. Experimental results show that MaTE performs better than data-driven benchmarks, particularly in travel time estimation. The estimated parameters of MaTE provide insights into the hourly changes in travel demand and supply characteristics of the transportation network."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17123", "title": "Unsupervised Discovery of Steerable Factors When Graph Deep Generative Models Are Entangled. (arXiv:2401.17123v1 [cs.LG])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Exploration", "summary": "Deep generative models (DGMs) for graph data lack investigation on understanding latent space. GraphCG proposes a method to discover steerable factors in the latent space of pretrained graph DGMs. GraphCG maximizes mutual information between semantic-rich directions and outperforms four baselines. Steerable factors are learned by GraphCG on various graph datasets."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17129", "title": "Enhanced Sound Event Localization and Detection in Real 360-degree audio-visual soundscapes. {"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17133", "title": "A Proactive and Dual Prevention Mechanism against Illegal Song Covers empowered by Singing Voice Conversion. (arXiv:2401.17133v1 [cs.SD])", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Audio", "summary": "Singing voice conversion (SVC) is a technique that transforms one singer's voice into another singer's voice while keeping the original lyrics and melody. However, this raises concerns about copyright and civil rights violations. To address this issue, a new approach called SongBsAb is proposed. SongBsAb adds imperceptible changes to the singing voices before they are released, disrupting the generation process of SVC and resulting in unexpected voices. This approach disrupts both the singer's identity and the lyrics, preventing the SVC from imitating the target singer or preserving the original lyrics. To make the changes imperceptible, a psychoacoustic model-based loss is utilized, taking into account the accompanying background track. Additionally, a frame-level interaction reduction-based loss is introduced to improve the transferability of the generated voices. The effectiveness, utility, and robustness of SongBsAb are demonstrated through objective and subjective metrics. This work opens up a new research direction to mitigate illegal automated song covers."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01900", "title": "Estimating counterfactual treatment outcomes over time in complex multi-agent scenarios. (arXiv:2206.01900v3 [cs.AI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Prediction", "summary": "Evaluation of intervention in multi-agent systems requires estimating the individual treatment effect (ITE) using counterfactual long-term prediction. Conventional frameworks often overlook the complex structure of multi-agent relationships and covariate prediction, leading to inaccurate assessments and interpretation difficulties. To address this, we propose an interpretable, counterfactual recurrent network that utilizes graph variational recurrent neural networks and theory-based computation. Our model accurately estimates the effect of interventions by considering long-term prediction of multi-agent covariates and outcomes, revealing the circumstances under which the intervention is effective. Experimental results demonstrate lower estimation errors and improved treatment timing compared to baselines in simulated models and real basketball data."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06233", "title": "Dynamic Sensor Matching based on Geomagnetic Inertial Navigation. (arXiv:2208.06233v2 [cs.RO] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Sensors", "summary": "Optical sensors can capture dynamic environments and derive depth information in real-time. The quality of reconstructions depends on various factors, such as illumination, surface conditions, and sensing speed. Combining data from multiple sensors can improve the results, but this requires a shared coordinate system. The authors propose using the Earth's magnetic field as a reference coordinate system. They evaluate their approach using magnetic field sensors and the ZED 2 stereo camera, achieving high-quality results. This concept has potential for dynamic and real-time applications in environment detection."}
