{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18136", "title": "Machine-learned Adversarial Attacks against Fault Prediction Systems in Smart Electrical Grids. (arXiv:2303.18136v2 [cs.CR] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Energy", "summary": "Smart electrical grids rely on fault detection tasks, which have significant economic and critical consequences. Data-driven approaches, like machine learning, are increasingly used in smart grid applications such as defect detection and load forecasting. However, the security and robustness of these algorithms in the context of smart grid applications have not been thoroughly investigated. This study examines the vulnerabilities of deep neural network methods used in smart grids to adversarial perturbations. Furthermore, the weaknesses of current machine learning algorithms in smart grids are demonstrated through studies on fault localization and type classification under different adversarial attacks."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10163", "title": "Large Language Models Leverage External Knowledge to Extend Clinical Insight Beyond Language Boundaries. (arXiv:2305.10163v4 [cs.CL] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Medicine", "summary": "Objectives: Evaluate Chinese medical context for language models and develop a framework to enhance their performance.\n\nMethods: Used CNMLE-2022 as benchmark, collected medical knowledge and questions, and implemented in-context learning framework (KFE) with LLMs.\n\nResults: Applying KFE improved performance of LLMs, exceeding qualification threshold and human scores.\n\nConclusion: In-context learning enhances LLMs, reducing language barriers and benefiting healthcare globally."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11863", "title": "Scaling laws for language encoding models in fMRI. (arXiv:2305.11863v4 [cs.CL] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Neuroscience", "summary": "Transformer-based unidirectional language models, particularly larger ones like those from the OPT and LLaMA families, show improved performance in predicting brain responses to natural language compared to smaller models like GPT-2. Brain prediction performance scales logarithmically with model size, as seen in other contexts, and increasing the size of the fMRI training set also leads to improved performance. Acoustic encoding models using HuBERT, WavLM, and Whisper show similar improvements. These findings suggest that larger models and datasets can greatly enhance our understanding of language processing in the brain and have practical applications in decoding."}

This study adapts on-policy RL to the DQD framework and proposes improvements for efficient optimization and skill discovery. The new algorithm, PPGA, achieves state-of-the-art results, including a 4x improvement in reward on the humanoid domain."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01685", "title": "MKOR: Momentum-Enabled Kronecker-Factor-Based Optimizer Using Rank-1 Updates. {"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05284", "title": "Simple and Controllable Music Generation. (arXiv:2306.05284v3 [cs.SD] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Creativity", "summary": "We present MusicGen, a single Language Model (LM) that can generate compressed discrete music tokens. MusicGen can generate high-quality mono and stereo samples conditioned on textual description or melodic features, allowing for better control over the output. {"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.01750", "title": "On CNF formulas irredundant with respect to unit clause propagation. (arXiv:2309.01750v3 [math.CO] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Mathematics", "summary": "Two CNF formulas are equivalent if they behave the same way with unit clause propagation (UCP). A formula is irredundant if removing any clause makes it not equivalent to the original. The ratio of the size of an irredundant formula and the smallest equivalent formula is at most n^2. A ucp-irredundant formula for a symmetric definite Horn function can be larger than the smallest equivalent formula by a factor of n/ln(n), implying a lower bound on the ratio."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02169", "title": "Dual Relation Alignment for Composed Image Retrieval. (arXiv:2309.02169v2 [cs.CV] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Multimedia", "summary": "Composed image retrieval has improved due to cross-modal modeling. There are two types of relations: explicit (reference image & complementary text-target image) and implicit (reference image & target image-complementary text). Existing methods focus on the explicit relation, neglecting the implicit relation. A new framework, dual relation alignment, integrates both relations to fully exploit correlations in triplets. It performs well in composed image retrieval tasks."}

{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17401", "title": "Adversarial Machine Learning in Latent Representations of Neural Networks. (arXiv:2309.17401v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Robustness.", "summary": "Distributed neural networks can decrease the computational burden and latency of mobile devices and edge computing. However, their resilience against adversarial attacks is still an open problem. This paper analyzes the robustness of distributed networks and introduces measurements for distortion and robustness. Findings show that latent features are more robust than input representations and that robustness depends on feature dimension and generalization capability. Experimental results confirm that compressed latent representations can greatly reduce the success rate of adversarial attacks compared to attacks on input space."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00863", "title": "Syllable-level lyrics generation from melody exploiting character-level language model. (arXiv:2310.09499v2 [cs.CL] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Efficiency", "summary": "Key ideas: \n- Large Language Models (LLMs) from the GPT family have achieved great performance in text generation tasks.\n- The size of LLMs hinders their practical use due to high latency.\n- This work proposes a method to prune LLMs to at least 50% sparsity without retraining, improving efficiency.\n- The method allocates sparsity based on sensitivity, reducing pruning errors and maintaining overall sparsity.\n- The method is compatible with quantization, allowing for further compression of LLMs."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14336", "title": "Learning Interpretable Rules for Scalable Data Representation and Classification. (arXiv:2310.14336v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "MachineLearning", "summary": "Rule-based models, such as decision trees, are transparent and expressive but difficult to optimize due to discrete parameters. To address this, we propose Rule-based Representation Learner (RRL), which learns interpretable non-fuzzy rules for data representation and classification. We apply Gradient Grafting, a novel training method, to optimize the discrete model using gradient descent. RRL outperforms other interpretable approaches, allowing a trade-off between accuracy and model complexity. Code available at: github.com/12wang3/rrl."}

{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17807", "title": "Clover: Closed-Loop Verifiable Code Generation. (arXiv:2310.17807v2 [cs.AI] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Software", "summary": "The article discusses the use of large language models for code generation in software development and the need for methods to ensure the correctness of generated code. The Clover paradigm is proposed as a solution, which uses consistency checking to verify code correctness. The Clover paradigm integrates formal verification tools and large language models to perform consistency checks among code, docstrings, and annotations. The article provides theoretical analysis and empirical results showing the effectiveness and feasibility of Clover. Experimental results show that large language models are successful in generating formal specifications and the consistency checker has a high acceptance rate for correct instances and zero tolerance for incorrect ones."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2311.11482", "title": "Meta Prompting for AGI Systems. Meta Prompting allows language models to generate new prompts recursively, increasing their autonomous and adaptive capabilities. {"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.15964", "title": "Semantic Guidance Tuning for Text-To-Image Diffusion Models. (arXiv:2312.15964v2 [cs.CV] UPDATED)", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Artistic.", "summary": "Recent advancements in Text-to-Image (T2I) diffusion models have been successful in generating high-quality images with zero-shot generalization. However, these models often struggle to accurately represent specific attributes. To address this, a training-free approach is proposed to modulate the guidance direction of diffusion models during inference. The approach decomposes prompt semantics into concepts and monitors the guidance trajectory in relation to each concept. Deviations from prompt semantics are correlated with divergence from concepts, so the technique steers the guidance direction towards any concept that the model diverges from. Experimental results show that this method improves the semantic alignment of generated images in response to prompts."}
{"url": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2312.17163", "title": "FENet: Focusing Enhanced Network for Lane Detection. Future directions include collecting on-road data and integrating dual frameworks based on human perception principles for further advancements. The code for the research is available on GitHub."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/co2vza9voCn9GPqaS/adam-smith-meets-ai-doomers", "title": "Adam Smith Meets AI Doomers", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Economics", "summary": "Markets, driven by self-interest, have created an interconnected global economy. However, market weaknesses become apparent when addressing AI existential risks. Externalities, such as pollution, challenge market efficiency as individual incentives don't align with the collective good. While local externalities can be resolved through negotiations, city-wide or global externalities require government interventions. Politicians' short-term focus further hinders sustainability efforts. The pursuit of profit drives the development of AI, but the potential catastrophic consequences pose an externality that markets struggle to address. Collusion among AI firms may be necessary to regulate AI development and mitigate risks, although it comes with its own dangers."}
{"url": "https://ainowinstitute.org/publication/what-can-we-learn-from-the-fda-model-for-ai-regulation", "title": "What can we learn from the FDA model for AI regulation?", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Regulation", "summary": "The AI Now Institute conducted a deep dive into the FDA's regulatory approach to the pharmaceutical and medical devices industries as a basis for considering AI governance. The group discussed the need for optimizing regulatory design for information production in AI, the lack of consensus on efficacy, the importance of pre-market approval, and the challenges of post-market surveillance. They also emphasized the need for greater transparency in the AI market, the funding model for regulatory agencies, and stronger monitoring and compliance activities within AI firms. The AI Now Institute will release a more detailed report on their findings later this spring."}

An exhaustive search of 5,000 variables found a more accurate model that includes education, discrimination, and political power. {"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/ABGL4FRGzfEcAxg26/explaining-impact-markets", "title": "Explaining Impact Markets", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Collaboration", "summary": "Impact markets, where philanthropists offer prizes for solving problems while investors fund promising teams, could accelerate solutions to global issues. This model allows brilliant teams to be both capable and funded, resolving the problem of underfunding. By setting up prizes for various problems, philanthropists can create an \"impact market\" where investors profit from supporting the right teams. This approach can be more effective than traditional philanthropy grants. Investors decide to invest based on their assessment of the team's likelihood of success and the potential return on their investment. Overall, impact markets offer a marketplace for philanthropies, investors, and teams to collaborate on altruistic projects."}

{"url": "https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/SnGqab3noXLmJzQCs/lower-suffering-egg-brands-available-in-the-sf-bay-area", "title": "Lower-suffering egg brands available in the SF Bay Area", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Sustainability", "summary": "The author researched egg brands in the San Francisco Bay Area that treat chickens more humanely. They recommend brands like Fifth Crow Farm, Alexandre Kids, Burroughs Family Farms, Stueve Organic, and St. John Family Farms. The author acknowledges that certifications like Animal Welfare Approved (AWA) are limited and evaluated each brand based on specific criteria. They also caution against brands that may seem humane but still engage in harmful practices. The author emphasizes the importance of considering animal suffering and suggests resources like The Cornucopia Institute's scorecards and the Animal Welfare Approved store locator. The author notes that different dishes create varying levels of animal suffering, with eggs and chicken causing significant harm. They address concerns about keel bone fractures in egg-laying hens and the issue of male chick culling. The author expresses interest in in-ovo sexing and alternative feeding options for hens. They conclude by stating that even brands like Vital Farms are better than conventional egg brands, but choosing the more humane options can significantly reduce suffering."}
{"url": "https://epic.org/epic-endorses-senate-bill-for-investigating-and-measuring-the-environmental-impacts-of-ai/", "title": "EPIC Endorses Senate Bill for Investigating and Measuring the Environmental Impacts of AI", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Sustainability", "summary": "EPIC has endorsed a Senate bill called the Artificial Intelligence Environmental Impacts Act of 2024. The bill aims to study and quantify the environmental impact of AI. It instructs the Environmental Protection Agency to conduct a study and the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop measurement and reporting standards. AI's environmental impact is believed to be significant due to the large amounts of energy and water required by AI systems. The bill intends to create transparency and pressure technology companies to develop AI products in accordance with public health and safety."}

{"url": "https://epic.org/release-report-state-laws-are-failing-to-protect-privacy/", "title": "RELEASE: Report: State Laws are Failing to Protect Privacy", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Legislation", "summary": "Report finds that state privacy laws are failing to protect consumers due to the influence of Big Tech. Nearly half of the states with comprehensive privacy laws received a failing grade, with none receiving an A. Industry lobbying has weakened consumer privacy protections in legislation across the country. Most privacy laws allow companies to continue collecting personal data and using it as they wish. The report suggests that laws should prevent unnecessary data collection and use, but currently, no privacy law does this effectively. Some states are considering stronger consumer privacy legislation that limits data collection to what is necessary for the service provided. EPIC and U.S. PIRG Education Fund advocate for privacy and consumer protection."}

Google has implemented its own encryption using the Signal protocol, but it is not universally available. The language used is too broad and may cover low-risk applications. The AI Executive Order should focus on enhancing law enforcement efficiency while protecting privacy and civil liberties. The use case for facial recognition technology should be further delineated based on risk assessment. Clarification is needed for surveillance-related risk assessments and the conduct of cyber intrusions. The focus should be on law enforcement purposes that directly impact individuals' rights. {"url": "https://blog.opensource.org/fixing-a-gap-in-the-sep-regulation/", "title": "Fixing a gap in the SEP regulation", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Regulation", "summary": "OSI recommends adding a waiting period for patent claims registered under the proposed Standard Essential Patent Regulation (SEP-R). The presence of royalty-due patents in standards is due to a requirements-led standardization process. Patents are not inherent to standardization and should be regulated for societal benefit. Some standards are encumbered by patents, leading to barriers to entry in resulting markets. OSI supports the proposed regulation but is concerned about a potential loophole that could bias the market. They propose a waiting period before patent royalties can be claimed after registering a patent as essential. The waiting period should be at least two years."}
{"url": "https://www.siia.net/in-the-news-we-must-protect-kids-online-but-bills-currently-before-congress-fail-to-meet-the-needs-of-the-american-public/", "title": "IN THE NEWS: We Must Protect Kids Online, But Bills Currently Before Congress Fail to Meet the Needs of the American Public", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Parenting", "summary": "Congress prioritizes protecting children online in 2024, but proposed legislative solutions don't ensure their safety. {"url": "https://epic.org/fcc-adopts-epic-recommendations-to-safeguard-911-location-based-routing-data/", "title": "FCC Adopts EPIC Recommendations to Safeguard 911 Location-Based Routing Data", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Emergency Services", "summary": "On January 25, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) adopted a new rule called Location-Based Routing (LBR) for 911 calls. LBR directs emergency calls to the nearest call center based on the precise location of the caller, instead of relying on area codes or nearby cell towers which can be inaccurate. The FCC agreed with EPIC (Electronic Privacy Information Center) that privacy and security rules should apply to the precise location information used in LBR. Providers are required to certify that they will only use the information for 911 purposes unless they have consent or are legally required to use it otherwise. EPIC also ensured that the same confidentiality requirements for dispatchable location data apply to LBR data. EPIC advocates for improved safeguards for location data and the privacy of emergency assistance requests."}

{"url": "https://techpolicy.press/how-to-assess-ai-governance-tools", "title": "How to Assess AI Governance Tools", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Regulation", "summary": "Setting standards and evaluations for the safety of AI systems is still a work in progress. The World Privacy Forum reviewed various AI governance tools and found that many include faulty AI fixes that can undermine fairness and explainability. Kate Kaye, Deputy Director of the World Privacy Forum, discussed the findings and emphasized the need for strong assessment processes for measurement methods used in AI governance. She also highlighted the importance of considering data privacy in the context of AI, as current frameworks may not adequately address the challenges posed by AI systems. Kaye mentioned several examples of AI governance tools, including the implementation of responsible AI considerations in government procurement processes in Chile and the use of off-label measurement methods like the 80% rule and SHAP/LIME in various AI governance tools. The involvement of large tech companies in shaping these governance tools was noted, with policymakers often relying on industry for guidance. The report also highlighted the role of organizations like the OECD in developing governance frameworks and the need for better evaluation and documentation in this field. The ongoing research aims to stay updated on the proliferation of AI governance tools and frameworks. Noteworthy documents mentioned include the work of the Masakhane Research Foundation in developing contextually relevant data sets for AI training and New Zealand's robust process for evaluating algorithms with a focus on privacy and indigenous data considerations."}

{"url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/what-home-videotaping-can-tell-us-about-generative-ai", "title": "What Home Videotaping Can Tell Us About Generative AI", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Debates", "summary": "We are participating in Copyright Week, supporting copyright policies that promote creativity and innovation. The introduction of the videotape recorder in 1975, similar to today's AI anxieties, led to debates about copyright infringement. The Supreme Court ruled in Sony's favor, emphasizing the need for copyright law to keep up with technological innovation and the importance of substantial non-infringing uses. This ruling protected new creativity and influenced technological innovation. However, generative AI may challenge this protection, as toolmakers could be held liable for the misuse of their tools. The question arises whether these tools have substantial non-infringing uses. If any cases reach the Supreme Court, they could potentially overturn the Sony ruling. Congress may also intervene, or settlements may be reached in ongoing litigation. We hope that copyright maximalists do not control our technological future."}
{"url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/ftc-bars-x-mode-selling-sensitive-location-data", "title": "FTC Bars X-Mode from Selling Sensitive Location Data ", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Regulation", "summary": "The FTC announced a successful enforcement action against InMarket, a location data broker that sells people's location data to advertisers and police. The FTC's complaint highlighted the dangers of this industry, as the company collects and sells raw location data that can be easily correlated to specific individuals. The proposed order by the FTC contains rules to protect the public from this company. Selling a person's location data can expose them to harassment, discrimination, and physical violence. X-Mode, the company that was targeted by the FTC, disputed the implications of the settlement, stating that there was no instance of data misuse. The FTC has made a strong case that brokering location data is unfair and unlawful. The enforcement action serves as a warning to other location data brokers to examine their business models. The FTC has taken other actions to protect data privacy, such as limiting Rite Aid's use of facial recognition and fining Amazon's Ring for data security failures."}

{"url": "https://www.siia.net/online-speech-and-ai/", "title": "Online Speech and AI", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Regulations", "summary": "As per the OMB AI Draft Memo, AI can have an impact on individuals' rights and safety. The scope of assessments for high-risk AI should be limited and specific impacts on people's fundamental rights should be covered separately. The use of AI in online speech moderation is a debated topic, but existing content moderation strategies can already address issues of blocking, removing, or limiting protected speech. Integrating AI into content moderation tools could lead to less biased decisions and reduce moderation costs. The First Amendment protects such practices in the private sector, but limits the federal government's ability to restrict protected speech. The use case mentioned in the AI Draft Memo should specifically refer to government-run websites and platforms. Technology companies will continue to moderate harmful content online, with or without AI, within their rights."}
{"url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.38?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Predicting social assistance beneficiaries: On the social welfare damage of data biases", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Inequality", "summary": "Cash transfer programs are commonly used in low- and middle-income countries to alleviate poverty. These programs rely on prediction models to target beneficiaries. However, biases in the data and instability in the prediction models can lead to substantial underestimation of welfare losses. Measurement errors and biases in the data can disadvantage certain groups, particularly smaller households. It is important to consider the characteristics of misclassified households to ensure social protection systems align with local redistributive preferences and do not have hidden discriminatory biases. There is a need for transparency and accountability in targeting procedures to avoid unfair practices and to build trust in the allocation of funds. The use of data-driven decision-making systems in public policy should be carefully monitored for biases and potential discrimination. Further research is needed to explore alternative targeting approaches and to incorporate fairness considerations in social protection systems."}
{"url": "https://techpolicy.press/how-to-defend-independent-technology-research-from-corporate-and-political-opposition", "title": "How to Defend Independent Technology Research from Corporate and Political Opposition", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Community", "summary": "The Coalition for Independent Tech Research, founded in October 2022, aims to support independent researchers studying the impacts of technology on society and defend their right to conduct research without interference. The coalition is composed of individuals from civil society, academia, and media organizations who work independently from the tech industry. Its priorities include providing crisis response support for researchers facing attacks, advocating for access to data and resources needed for research, and engaging in strategic communication to highlight the value of independent tech research. The coalition is globally ambitious and seeks to expand its membership and impact beyond the US and Europe. Those interested in getting involved can apply to become members through the coalition's website."}
{"url": "https://www.siia.net/siia-statement-on-european-commission-intention-to-block-amazon-irobot-acquisition/", "title": "SIIA Statement on European Commission Intention to Block Amazon iRobot Acquisition", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Competition", "summary": "The European Commission intends to block Amazon's acquisition of iRobot due to concerns about restricting competition. This decision is seen as a trend of blocking pro-competition deals. It is argued that Amazon's goal was to provide capital infusion to iRobot for better competition rather than owning a competing brand. {"url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/effs-2024-inout-list", "title": "EFF\u2019s 2024 In/Out List ", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Digital Rights.", "summary": "Key Ideas:\n1. EFF advocates for affordable and accessible internet access for all, without geographic or socioeconomic divisions.\n2. EFF supports a privacy-first approach to prevent mass collection of personal information by corporations and governments.\n3. EFF promotes decentralized social media platforms to ensure user control and protect privacy and free expression.\n4. EFF emphasizes the importance of end-to-end encrypted messaging services and opposes content scanning by governments.\n5. EFF defends the right to free expression online without barriers or borders.\n6. EFF opposes the use of artificial intelligence and automated systems for policing and surveillance.\n7. EFF highlights the negative impacts of ad surveillance based on tracking online behavior.\n8. EFF opposes speech and privacy restrictions under the pretext of child protection.\n9. EFF advocates against unchecked cross-border data sharing disguised as cybercrime protections.\n10. EFF opposes the use of internet access as a bargaining chip in conflicts and geopolitical battles."}
{"url": "https://epic.org/press-release-epic-accountable-tech-urge-ftc-to-investigate-googles-failed-promise-to-delete-sensitive-location-data/", "title": "PRESS RELEASE: EPIC, Accountable Tech Urge FTC to Investigate Google\u2019s Failed Promise to Delete Sensitive Location Data", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Complaint.", "summary": "The Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) and Accountable Tech have filed a complaint against Google for failing to delete location records of users' visits to sensitive facilities, such as abortion clinics. Google had publicly promised to delete this information but failed to do so. The retention of personal location data by companies like Google poses privacy risks and could be accessed by law enforcement. The complaint calls on the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to investigate Google for unfair and deceptive practices. EPIC and Accountable Tech are requesting civil penalties, the disgorgement of wrongfully retained data, and an injunction against Google's location data practices. EPIC and Accountable Tech emphasize the need for the FTC to hold Google accountable for its violations and not rely solely on Google's promises. Both organizations have a history of advocating for privacy rights and addressing privacy violations. Accountable Tech is a nonprofit organization that advocates for structural reforms in the information ecosystem. EPIC is a public interest research center that focuses on safeguarding privacy rights in the digital age."}

{"url": "https://www.siia.net/siia-launches-data-policy-advisory-council-to-advance-thought-leadership-on-information-and-data-policy-cutting-edge-issues/", "title": "SIIA Launches Data Policy Advisory Council to Advance Thought Leadership on  Information and Data Policy Cutting Edge Issues", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Collaboration", "summary": "The Software & Information Industry Association (SIIA) has created the Data Policy Advisory Council (DPAC), which brings together thought leaders to discuss data policy issues. The Council includes academics, civil society and policy advocates, business leaders, and legal professionals. They aim to study the ecosystem of personal information publication and explore policies that promote consumer privacy while maintaining the health of the industry. The DPAC will provide insights, education, and recommendations for policymakers and the public on data policy. SIIA members will have the opportunity to discuss their businesses with academics and legal thought leaders, while academics will learn about current business practices. The Council will also examine the national security benefits and risks of partnering with government entities. The discussions held by the Council will assist SIIA in offering specific policy recommendations to regulate data use while protecting privacy and security. The launch of the Council is seen as an opportunity to add nuance and expand the conversation on the benefits and risks of data use and its regulation. The Council had its first meeting, covering topics such as data ownership, data use by private and government entities, rights protection, informational injury, and mechanisms to address data-related harms. SIIA is an association representing technology, data, and media companies globally, aiming to drive innovation and growth through various initiatives and collaborations."}
{"url": "https://techpolicy.press/questioning-openais-nonprofit-status", "title": "Questioning OpenAI's Nonprofit Status", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Oversight", "summary": "The recent corporate governance issues at OpenAI, including the dismissal and reinstatement of Sam Altman as CEO, have raised concerns about the company's structure. OpenAI's deletion of language prohibiting military use of its technology and its relationship with Microsoft are also being questioned. Public Citizen, a nonprofit consumer advocacy organization, has raised concerns about OpenAI's nonprofit status and its potential deviation from its nonprofit purposes. The organization has written a letter to the California Attorney General requesting an investigation into OpenAI's structure. If OpenAI is found to no longer serve a nonprofit purpose, it could be stripped of its nonprofit status. The organization's valuation, which is approaching $100 billion, raises questions about its governance. If OpenAI loses its nonprofit status, it will be required to pay out its assets to a new charitable foundation. Public Citizen hopes that the Attorney General will investigate and take appropriate action. They believe that the control and governance of AI are crucial, and if decisions are solely in the hands of for-profit corporations, there could be a negative impact on society."}

{"url": "https://www.siia.net/administration-must-reverse-course-on-digital-trade-our-national-security-and-economic-interests-demand-it/", "title": "Administration Must Reverse Course on Digital Trade \u2013 Our National Security and Economic Interests Demand It", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Concerns", "summary": "The Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) has withdrawn from digital trade negotiations at the World Trade Organization (WTO), which has raised concerns about harm to national security and the economy. The USTR cited the need for \"policy space\" for domestic debates on digital regulation, but critics believe it is an attempt to weaken \"Big Tech\" companies. {"url": "https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/dap.2023.44?rft_dat=source%3Ddrss", "title": "Bus Rapid Transit: End of trend in Latin America?", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Transportation.", "summary": "There has been a significant growth in the implementation of Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) systems around the world, particularly in Latin America. However, these systems face operational and financial challenges, leading to concerns about their ability to provide quality services. Key issues include overcrowding, lack of reliability, fare evasion, safety and security problems, and poor maintenance. These problems are often the result of institutional and financial constraints, rather than issues with the BRT mode itself. Recommendations for improving BRT include permanent management and investment, attention to data and technology innovation, urban integration, and public participation. Despite these challenges, BRT remains an important component of sustainable mobility networks and can help address the global transit crisis. The number of cities implementing BRT has declined in recent years, following a trend similar to the deployment of tramways in the early 20th century. BRT systems are now part of public transport systems in 187 cities worldwide, with Latin America leading in terms of the number of systems, kilometers, and passengers. However, there has been a decline in the number of new cities adopting BRT and the number of kilometers added in the last five years. This decline follows a common pattern of innovation adoption. BRT faces several contentious issues, including institutional arrangements, competition for road space, and the misperception of buses as a low-quality mode. Challenges in BRT planning and implementation include lack of capacity and alignment among stakeholders, perceptions of BRT as a lower quality mode compared to rail systems, and opposition from advocates for nonmotorized transport. These challenges are not exclusive to BRT but are common in mobility improvement projects in developing countries. Despite these challenges, BRT has the potential to contribute to sustainable mobility and can be part of integrated transit systems. Innovation and technology, such as the use of electric buses, real-time data, and automation, can help improve BRT operations and service quality. Attention to urban impacts and community engagement is also crucial to winning public acceptance and support. However, the current downward trend in transit ridership and new public transportation projects, as well as transit reforms, pose additional challenges to the expansion and improvement of BRT systems."}

CSET is a research center within Georgetown University providing data-driven analysis on emerging technologies."}
{"url": "https://www.siia.net/what-is-rights-safety-impacting-ai/", "title": "What is Rights &amp; Safety Impacting AI", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Regulation", "summary": "The White House has released an Executive Order and a memorandum on the development and use of AI in the United States. The memorandum outlines two categories of AI risks: safety-impacting AI and rights-impacting AI. However, the definitions provided are broad, potentially discouraging the adoption of new technologies by the government. The EU AI Act offers a narrower definition of high-risk AI. It is recommended that a more risk-based approach be taken and that the definitions of safety-impacting and rights-impacting AI be refined. AI should only be considered rights-impacting if it directly affects decisions already regulated by laws such as non-discrimination and consumer protection. AI used to determine government services and benefits should be subject to higher scrutiny."}
{"url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/privacy-badger-puts-you-control-widgets", "title": "Privacy Badger Puts You in Control of Widgets", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Browser Extension", "summary": "Privacy Badger 1 has introduced click-to-activate placeholders for embedded tweets, replacing potentially tracking widgets. Privacy Badger aims to protect user privacy by blocking and replacing widgets on websites. This feature allows users to restore the original widget when needed. Privacy Badger follows the footsteps of Flashblock and ShareMeNot, which also replaced insecure or privacy-invasive elements with placeholders. However, widget replacement is not perfect and may have some issues. Users can report problems and contribute to improving the feature. Privacy Badger emphasizes making privacy easy for all users. It fights against non-consensual surveillance. Users can install Privacy Badger from privacybadger.org."}

{"url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/01/ai-watermarking-wont-curb-disinformation", "title": "AI Watermarking Won't Curb Disinformation", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Authentication.", "summary": "Generative AI allows for the quick production of images and words, but there is a need to distinguish between AI-generated and human-generated content. Watermarking schemes have been proposed but have proven to be easily removable. Manipulating the least perceptible bits of an image can create a watermark, but it is not robust against editing. Content authenticity, adding metadata to camera-generated images, is a more workable solution. Watermarking text-based generative AI is even more challenging as it must be robust against modification. Detection tools for watermarked text can either be publicly available, making them less useful, or kept secret, hindering their scalability. Current detection tools for AI-generated content are inaccurate. It is unlikely that state-sponsored disinformation campaigns would use watermarking. Watermarking AI-generated content may have limited use, but it is uncertain if it will ultimately succeed."}

{"url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/the-data-protection-manifesto", "title": "\ud83d\udea8 The Data Protection Manifesto", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Ethics", "summary": "The article discusses the importance of focusing on the spirit of data protection rather than just the letter of the law. {"url": "https://fpf.org/blog/the-garden-state-joins-the-comprehensive-privacy-grove/", "title": "The Garden State Joins the Comprehensive Privacy Grove", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Legislation", "summary": "New Jersey has become the 13th US state to implement a comprehensive privacy law. The law, known as S332, bears resemblance to other privacy frameworks, but also contains unique provisions. One controversial provision pertains to a possible private right of action, with concerns that the removal of certain language could open up the possibility of private lawsuits. S332 also requires controllers to conduct a data protection assessment before initiating high-risk processing activities. It does not include a revenue threshold for applicability, which sets it apart from other frameworks. The law also includes carve outs for certain data types, such as health information subject to HIPAA. Rulemaking is also provided for in the law, and individuals are able to designate an authorized agent. S332 requires controllers to allow individuals to opt-out of processing for targeted advertising or sale of personal data through a universal opt-out mechanism. The law also provides increased privacy protections for adolescents, and defines sensitive data and biometric data with expanded categories. Lastly, S332 includes an expanded right to delete with respect to third party data."}

These bills are in addition to the ongoing legal challenge faced by the California Age-Appropriate Design Code Act. {"url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/snapchats-abusive-dark-patterns", "title": "\ud83d\udc7b Snapchat's abusive dark patterns", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Exploitation", "summary": "Snapchat, a popular instant messaging app, has been criticized for its paid subscription service, Snapchat+, which includes features that exploit teenagers' vulnerabilities. These features, known as dark patterns, can have harmful effects on teenagers' mental health and privacy. They include features such as Friend Solar System, where users can see their friends' close relationships and obsess over their popularity, and Friend Snapscore Change, which encourages comparison and insecurity among users. Furthermore, Extended Best Friends List discloses users' 16 best friends, leading to privacy concerns and a focus on social status. These dark patterns not only exploit teenagers' vulnerabilities but also harm their mental health and financial well-being as they are available through a paid subscription. Snapchat has faced previous privacy issues, including inappropriate messages from its AI chatbot and deceptive practices related to image expiration and geolocation data. It is essential for companies like Snapchat to prioritize user well-being and fairness over profit and address these exploitative features."}
{"url": "https://www.luizasnewsletter.com/p/when-generative-ai-copyright-and", "title": "\ud83d\udc41\ufe0f When Generative AI, copyright, and privacy meet", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Legislation", "summary": "In this article, Luiza Jarovsky discusses the legal implications of web scraping for developing and training large language models (LLMs). {"url": "https://fpf.org/blog/fpf-in-2023-a-year-in-review/", "title": "FPF in 2023: A Year in Review", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Advocacy", "summary": "In 2023, the Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) expanded its global presence and worked on various AI-related initiatives. They organized events, provided training on AI topics, and engaged in discussions about the impact of AI technology. FPF closely followed privacy and data protection developments in different regions, including Asia, the European Union, Africa, and Latin America. They also played a key role in informing regulatory agencies and state legislatures on privacy in emerging technologies like AI. FPF provided recommendations and comments on privacy laws and regulations at both federal and state levels. They also focused on privacy protection for children online and published research on youth privacy policies. FPF addressed the growing interest in immersive technologies and released a risk framework for body-related data in immersive technologies. They examined open banking ecosystems and published a compendium on data sharing for research. FPF also facilitated peer-to-peer meetings and calls for senior executives working on data protection compliance. Overall, FPF's work in 2023 had a significant impact on the privacy community and society at large."}
{"url": "https://fpf.org/blog/risk-framework-for-body-related-data-in-immersive-technologies/", "title": "Risk Framework for Body-Related Data in Immersive Technologies", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Framework.", "summary": "The Future of Privacy Forum has released a risk framework for body-related data in immersive technologies. The framework helps organizations handle body-related data, comply with laws, and evaluate privacy and safety risks. It is useful for organizations working on immersive technologies as well as those handling body-related data in other contexts. Organizations should proactively identify and minimize risks, assess the fairness and ethics of their data practices, and implement best practices. They should also evaluate and assess these practices regularly."}
{"url": "https://fpf.org/blog/five-big-questions-and-zero-predictions-for-the-u-s-state-privacy-landscape-in-2024/", "title": "Five Big Questions (and Zero Predictions) for the U.S. State Privacy Landscape in 2024", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Governance", "summary": "Key ideas in this article include:\n\n1. The United States is the only G20 nation without a comprehensive national framework for governing personal data.\n2. State-level activity on privacy dramatically increased in 2023, with the number of states with comprehensive commercial privacy laws rising.\n3. California is playing a significant role in establishing rules for the business use of AI systems.\n4. Enforcement of state privacy laws has been scarce, but indicators suggest that there may be increased enforcement activity in 2024.\n5. Legislative engagement on privacy matters is ongoing, with states amending and expanding existing laws.\n6. There are concerns about the constitutionality of wide-reaching state privacy laws.\n7. Ongoing litigation involving the California Age Appropriate Design Code Act (AADC) may impact the broader U.S. privacy landscape.\n8. More state privacy proposals can be expected in the coming year."}
{"url": "https://fpf.org/blog/a-blueprint-for-the-future-white-house-and-states-issue-guidelines-on-ai-and-generative-ai/", "title": "A Blueprint for the Future: White House and States Issue Guidelines on AI and Generative AI", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Legislation", "summary": "Key ideas from the article:\n- Eight US states and the White House have published executive orders to support the responsible and ethical use of AI, including generative AI.\n- The state and federal EOs have different scopes, but most charge agencies with creating a task force to study AI and offer recommendations.\n- The White House and California have issued the most prescriptive EOs, with specific mandates and reports tailored to different agencies.\n- Most state EOs focus on generative AI, with a few states covering broader AI systems as well.\n- The White House EO charges certain agencies with creating binding guidelines and standards, while other states focus on studying AI and providing recommendations.\n- The EOs will have an impact on industry, with new requirements and opportunities arising in the coming years."}

The webinar featured speakers from legal, regulatory, and industry backgrounds. The US has seen active legislative efforts in children's privacy, with 11 states enacting bills and 35 considering legislation. France and the European Union consider safety as part of privacy regulation, and the UK has implemented the Age Appropriate Design Code. Age assurance and verification methods are still evolving, with no one-size-fits-all solution. Digital education for parents and developing resources for online services to avoid burdening parents are important aspects of addressing youth privacy. Innovations and privacy-by-design approaches are also critical. The resolution of First Amendment issues surrounding privacy regulation will be debated. Harmonizing laws and providing clear guidance can assist companies in complying effectively. Resources and recommendations from the webinar are available for further information."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17538", "title": "Post-Quantum Cryptography for Internet of Things: A Survey on Performance and Optimization", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Cryptography", "summary": "The development of quantum computing poses a threat to modern cryptography. To counter this, researchers have proposed post-quantum cryptography (PQC) based on problems that even quantum computers cannot efficiently solve. However, implementing PQC on resource-constrained devices, such as IoT devices, can be challenging due to their limited computational power. This paper surveys the performance of PQC on such devices and explores recent proposals to optimize PQC algorithms. While PQC may be feasible for lightweight IoT, standardization is lacking in optimization proposals. Coordinated research is needed to ensure an efficient and secure migration to IoT in the post-quantum era."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17618", "title": "Beyond Control: Exploring Novel File System Objects for Data-Only Attacks on Linux Systems", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Exploits", "summary": "The article discusses the deployment of control-flow integrity and the challenges faced in discovering and exploiting non-control data in OS kernels. The authors present their contributions in discovering critical non-control objects in the file subsystem of the Linux kernel and analyzing their exploitability. They propose a custom analysis and testing framework to identify promising candidate objects and categorize them based on exploit strategies. The advantage of these objects is that they can be exploited without requiring KASLR, making the exploits simpler and more reliable. The authors evaluate the exploitability of the file system objects using real-world CVEs and develop multiple exploits against the kernel with state-of-the-art mitigations."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17628", "title": "Elephants Do Not Forget: Differential Privacy with State Continuity for Privacy Budget", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Privacy-enhancing", "summary": "Current differentially-private (DP) systems lack support to track privacy budget on a dataset, which allows for replay, rollback, and fork attacks. ElephantDP is a proposed system that aims to provide the same guarantees as a trusted curator in an untrusted environment. It relies on a state continuity module and a Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) to execute DP code and update the budget. ElephantDP provides liveness and DP confidentiality. The implementation uses Intel SGX as a TEE and shows low overheads for larger datasets and complex DP queries."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17746", "title": "Logit Poisoning Attack in Distillation-based Federated Learning and its Countermeasures", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Collaboration", "summary": "Distillation-based federated learning is a collaborative approach where clients share logit vectors instead of private model parameters, reducing privacy invasion risks. Existing poisoning attacks target model parameters, not logit vectors, resulting in inefficiency. This study introduces a two-stage logit poisoning scheme that maximizes information entropy and scales shuffled logit vectors. A defense algorithm calculates the distance between benign and uploaded vectors, effectively countering the attack. Extensive experiments prove the threat and effectiveness of the proposed attack and defense algorithms."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17819", "title": "QTFlow: Quantitative Timing-Sensitive Information Flow for Security-Aware Hardware Design on RTL", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Hardware", "summary": "Contemporary EDA tools prioritize power, performance, and area optimization over security. Manual security analysis often misses design vulnerabilities. Security-aware EDA tools use information flow analysis to find leaks. Current techniques struggle with sequential circuits and timing channels. QTFlow is an effective framework for quantifying hardware information leaks in the design phase, reducing false positives and addressing timing issues."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.18024", "title": "Benchmarking Private Population Data Release Mechanisms: Synthetic Data vs. TopDown", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Data Privacy", "summary": "Differential privacy is commonly used to protect hierarchical, tabular population data. Current methods, like the TopDown algorithm, have limitations in answering queries they were not optimized for. An alternative is to generate synthetic data, which can be optimized for specific queries and allows for arbitrary queries later on. A comparison between the TopDown algorithm and private synthetic data generation was conducted. The results show that the TopDown algorithm achieves better privacy-fidelity tradeoffs for in-distribution queries. Guidelines for practitioners and the synthetic data research community are suggested."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17523", "title": "Game-Theoretic Unlearnable Example Generator", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Adversarial ", "summary": "Unlearnable example attacks aim to reduce the accuracy of deep learning by adding imperceptible perturbations to training samples. Solving this optimization problem for deep neural networks is difficult, so a game-theoretic perspective is used to formulate the attack. Game equilibria are proven to exist, and a new attack method called Game Unlearnable Example (GUE) is proposed. GUE effectively poisons the model and can generalize well to unseen data. Code for the implementation is available on GitHub."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.01713", "title": "SoK: Fully Homomorphic Encryption Accelerators", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Technology", "summary": "Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) is a technology used for privacy-preserving computing, but it is inefficient due to complex polynomial computations and time-consuming operations. Researchers and industries have proposed 14 FHE accelerators to address this challenge, including cuHE/cuFHE, nuFHE, HEAT, HEAX, HEXL, HEXL-FPGA, 100$\\times$, F1, CraterLake, BTS, ARK, Poseidon, FAB, and TensorFHE. {"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11643", "title": "On Cross-Layer Interactions of QUIC, Encrypted DNS and HTTP/3: Design, Evaluation and Dataset", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Encryption", "summary": "Every web session involves a DNS resolution. DNS encryption has recently gained traction with the standardization of DNS over TLS (DoT) and DNS over HTTPS (DoH). Utilizing QUIC to encrypt web communications and DNS resolution is a promising opportunity. This paper evaluates the benefit of using QUIC for DNS resolution (DoQ) and web content delivery (H3) with 0-RTT. Comparisons are made between different combinations of H3 and DoH/DoQ, as well as unencrypted DNS over UDP (DoUDP). When using H3 1-RTT, page load times with DoH can be significantly longer compared to unencrypted DNS with DoUDP. However, the cost of encryption can be reduced when using coalesced encrypted connections (DoQ + H3 0-RTT), resulting in faster page load times. Overall, utilizing QUIC for encrypted communication on the internet is the best option."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.14527", "title": "Unsealing the secrets of blockchain consensus: A systematic comparison of the formal security of proof-of-work and proof-of-stake", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Consensus", "summary": "Key ideas:\n- The choice of consensus mechanism in decentralized information systems is a controversial topic.\n- Ethereum's transition from proof-of-work (PoW) to proof-of-stake (PoS) has sparked more debate.\n- The focus is usually on energy consumption and decentralization, but formal security aspects are also important.\n- Previous research has not comprehensively studied the security properties of PoW and PoS.\n- A systematic literature review of 26 research articles shows that PoW with the longest chain rule has the strongest security guarantees.\n- PoS can achieve similar guarantees by addressing the tradeoff between safety and liveness through hybrid approaches."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16732", "title": "Flash: A Hybrid Private Inference Protocol for Deep CNNs with High Accuracy and Low Latency on CPU", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Efficiency", "summary": "Flash is a hybrid protocol that combines homomorphic encryption and secure two-party computation to reduce the latency of private inference for deep CNN models. It achieves this by using a low-latency convolution algorithm and a novel data encoding scheme. Flash also replaces the standard ReLU activation function with a polynomial, improving inference accuracy and reducing communication cost. The protocol's end-to-end latency is less than 1 minute, and it significantly outperforms prior art in terms of latency and communication cost. It can even achieve this level of performance for ImageNet classification."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16759", "title": "Sandi: A System for Accountability and Applications in Direct Communication", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Trust", "summary": "Sandi is an AI system designed to enhance trust in online communication. It uses a privacy-preserving reputation system where registered senders request cryptographic tags to attach to their messages. Message receivers can use the sender's score to determine trustworthiness. Sandi aims to benefit both senders and receivers by improving message reactions and enabling better choices in interactions. The system ensures privacy and security for all parties involved. Additionally, a game-theoretic analysis proves that Sandi encourages rational senders to reduce inappropriate messages."}

{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16906", "title": "Quantum-Secure Hybrid Blockchain System for DID-based Verifiable Random Function with NTRU Linkable Ring Signature", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Cryptography", "summary": "We present a secure smart contract-based Verifiable Random Function (VRF) model using post-quantum encryption. {"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16919", "title": "Bit-flipping Decoder Failure Rate Estimation for (v,w)-regular Codes", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Communication", "summary": "Closed form estimates of the decoding failure rate of iterative decoders for low- and moderate-density parity check codes have gained interest in the research community. This interest has increased due to the use of iterative decoders in post-quantum cryptosystems. A new technique is proposed to accurately estimate the decoding failure rate of a two-iterations bit flipping decoder. The technique successfully estimates the bit flipping probabilities and syndrome weight distribution. Results are numerically validated and used to estimate the decoding failure rate of LEDAcrypt parameters, showing significant improvements. This allows for a reduction in public key and ciphertext sizes without compromising security. The analyzed two-iterations decoder is also applicable in BIKE, providing strong guarantees."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16947", "title": "WGAN-AFL: Seed Generation Augmented Fuzzer with Wasserstein-GAN", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Security", "summary": "The article discusses the importance of addressing software security vulnerabilities, especially in sectors like national defense and finance. It introduces the concept of fuzz testing as an automated software testing technology for detecting vulnerabilities. However, it highlights the challenges faced by previous fuzzers, specifically the sensitivity of fuzzing performance to initial input seeds. In order to overcome this issue, the article proposes WGAN-AFL, which utilizes a generative adversarial network (GAN) trained on high-quality test cases to obtain high-quality initial input seeds. The use of the Wasserstein GAN (WGAN) architecture helps to improve the quality of the generated seeds and addresses drawbacks like mode collapse and training instability. Experimental results demonstrate that WGAN-AFL outperforms the original AFL in terms of code coverage, new paths, and vulnerability discovery, indicating the effectiveness of enhancing seed quality with WGAN-AFL."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16982", "title": "ActDroid: An active learning framework for Android malware detection", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Malware detection", "summary": "Key Ideas:\n- Android malware detection is crucial due to the frequent release of new malware.\n- Active online learning is used to label applications quickly and affordably.\n- The framework achieves high accuracy and requires a small amount of labelled training data.\n- The framework also compensates for concept drift between the release and labelling of an application.\n- The trade-offs between using different feature sets to classify malware are explored."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16993", "title": "Randomized Key Encapsulation/Consolidation", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Cryptography", "summary": "This article discusses the bridge between two encryption key sharing topics: Key Consolidation and Quantum-safe Key Encapsulation. The proposed scheme adds complexity to extracting useful data from leaked information. It adapts the secrecy level based on the similarity of common randomness and can encapsulate a Quantum-safe encryption key when no common randomness is available. The scheme offers improvements compared to the McEliece cryptosystem."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17010", "title": "Finetuning Large Language Models for Vulnerability Detection", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Software.", "summary": "This article discusses the use of large language models (LLMs) for identifying vulnerabilities in source code. The authors introduce WizardCoder, an improved LLM, and adapt it for vulnerability detection through finetuning. They also explore different training techniques to enhance performance and address class imbalance. The finetuned WizardCoder model outperforms CodeBERT-like models in terms of ROC AUC and F1 measures on both balanced and imbalanced vulnerability datasets. The contributions of the study include improving the training speed of WizardCoder, optimizing training procedures and regimes, handling class imbalance, and enhancing performance on challenging vulnerability detection datasets. Overall, the article highlights the potential of transfer learning by finetuning pretrained LLMs for specialized source code analysis tasks."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17136", "title": "Systematically Assessing the Security Risks of AI/ML-enabled Connected Healthcare Systems", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Healthcare.", "summary": "The use of machine learning in healthcare is increasing but poses security risks, especially in connected systems. A case study demonstrates an attack on a blood glucose monitoring system, exploiting a vulnerability in Bluetooth communication. Current risk assessment techniques are insufficient, requiring new methods to analyze the security of AI-enabled health devices."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16596", "title": "PrIsing: Privacy-Preserving Peer Effect Estimation via Ising Model", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Modeling", "summary": "The Ising model is being used as a network-based model for capturing dependencies in agents' outputs, particularly in healthcare and social sciences. However, privacy concerns have been raised regarding the confidentiality of agents' responses. To address this, a new algorithm called $(\\varepsilon,\u03b4)$-differentially private algorithm has been developed to protect the privacy of individual agents' outcomes. This algorithm allows for accurate estimation of the natural parameter using a single network and has established regret bounds. Its performance has been evaluated on synthetic datasets as well as real-world networks involving HIV status and political leaning of online blogs."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16649", "title": "Using Motion Forecasting for Behavior-Based Virtual Reality (VR) Authentication", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Authentication", "summary": "Task-based behavioral biometric authentication in VR environments uses motion trajectories as unique signatures. Deep learning-based approaches perform well with complete trajectories but struggle with smaller segments. This work introduces a method that predicts future user behavior using Transformer-based forecasting, improving authentication performance. By leveraging the idea that users are unlikely to dramatically change their behavior during a task, the forecasted trajectory is used for authentication. Using a ball throwing dataset, the approach reduces the authentication error rate by an average of 23.85%."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16742", "title": "Generative AI-based closed-loop fMRI system", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Ethics", "summary": "Generative AI has become widely used but there are concerns about its potential misuse in influencing decision-making. DecNefGAN is a framework that combines generative AI and neural reinforcement to study how humans can counteract the influence of malicious AI."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.16766", "title": "Detection and Recovery Against Deep Neural Network Fault Injection Attacks Based on Contrastive Learning", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Resilience", "summary": "Deep Neural Network (DNN) models are vulnerable to Fault Injection Attacks (FIAs) that disrupt their performance. This article introduces Contrastive Learning (CL) into the training and inference pipeline to improve DNN resilience under FIAs. The proposed framework, CFDR, enables real-time detection and fast recovery with only a small amount of unlabeled testing data. Evaluation with the CIFAR-10 dataset demonstrates promising results."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17127", "title": "Personalized Differential Privacy for Ridge Regression", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Privacy-enhancing technologies.", "summary": "The article discusses the need for privacy in machine learning applications and introduces a new method called PDP-OP that allows for individual per data point privacy levels. The PDP-OP method is shown to improve privacy-accuracy trade-offs in differential privacy and outperforms other personalized privacy techniques."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17133", "title": "A Proactive and Dual Prevention Mechanism against Illegal Song Covers empowered by Singing Voice Conversion", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Music", "summary": "Singing Voice Conversion (SVC) is a technique to convert one singer's voice into another's. However, this raises concerns about copyright and civil rights infringement. In response, SongBsAb introduces perturbations to the singing voices to interfere with the SVC process, resulting in unexpected voices. This approach disrupts both the singer's identity and the lyrics, preventing imitation of the target singer. The imperceptibility of the perturbations is improved using a psychoacoustic model and the backing track. The transferability is enhanced through a frame-level interaction reduction-based loss. The effectiveness, utility, and robustness of SongBsAb are demonstrated through objective and subjective metrics. This work contributes to the research on mitigating illegal automated song covers."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17252", "title": "Quantum $X$-Secure $B$-Byzantine $T$-Colluding Private Information Retrieval", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Cryptography", "summary": "Key ideas in the article:\n\n1. This study addresses the challenges posed by Byzantine servers in a quantum private information retrieval (QPIR) context.\n\n2. The capabilities of quantum Byzantine servers are greater than classical ones due to the quantum encoding procedure.\n\n3. Quantum Byzantine servers can apply any reversible operation on their qudits, enabling them to generate any error.\n\n4. The article proposes a resilient scheme against these manipulations, achieving superdense coding gain in all cases."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.17264", "title": "Proactive Detection of Voice Cloning with Localized Watermarking", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Audio", "summary": "In the field of speech generative models, there is a need for protecting against voice cloning. AudioSeal is an audio watermarking technique that detects AI-generated speech. It uses a generator/detector architecture and a novel perceptual loss to achieve better imperceptibility. AudioSeal outperforms existing models in terms of robustness and speed, making it suitable for large-scale and real-time applications."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18136", "title": "Machine-learned Adversarial Attacks against Fault Prediction Systems in Smart Electrical Grids", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Vulnerabilities", "summary": "Fault detection in smart electrical grids has significant implications on society. Data-driven methodologies, including machine learning, have been increasingly used in applications such as defect detection and load forecasting. However, the security of these algorithms in the smart grid scenario is not well understood. This study investigates the challenges associated with the security of machine learning applications in the smart grid. The study shows that the deep neural network method used in smart grids is vulnerable to adversarial perturbation. Additionally, the weaknesses of present machine learning algorithms in smart grids to various adversarial attacks are demonstrated through fault localization and type classification studies."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10565", "title": "Measurement Based Evaluation and Mitigation of Flood Attacks on a LAN Test-Bed", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Networks", "summary": "The article discusses the vulnerability of the Internet of Things (IoT) to network attacks and the effectiveness of Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) in providing accurate attack detection. It highlights the lack of evaluation of IDS in operational conditions that are heavily impacted by attack overload. The article presents a testbed using a Local Area Network to assess the impact of UDP Flood Attacks on an IoT Server and its IDS. It demonstrates that attacks overwhelm the server and incapacitate its IDS. To address this issue, the article proposes a mitigation scheme that rapidly detects attacks and drops packets within milliseconds of the attack initiation. This scheme is experimentally evaluated."}
{"url": "https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11515", "title": "Towards Differential Privacy in Sequential Recommendation: A Noisy Graph Neural Network Approach", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Recommendation", "summary": "Users are increasingly concerned about online privacy due to frequent privacy breaches. Existing differentially private recommender systems only consider static and independent interactions, limiting their applicability to dynamic and dependent behaviors. Additionally, little attention has been given to protecting sensitive user features. The proposed DIPSGNN framework addresses these limitations by incorporating a noisy Graph Neural Network approach, achieving differential privacy in sequential recommendation with dependent interactions. The framework protects sensitive user features and captures user preferences simultaneously, demonstrating superiority over existing systems in terms of privacy and accuracy."}
{"url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2024/01/nist-offers-guidance-measuring-and-improving-your-companys-cybersecurity", "title": "NIST Offers Guidance on Measuring and Improving Your Company\u2019s Cybersecurity Program", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Measurement", "summary": "The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has released draft guidance on measuring and improving information security in organizations. The publication, NIST Special Publication (SP) 800-55 Revision 2: Measurement Guide for Information Security, aims to help organizations develop an effective program for measuring information security and presenting meaningful data to stakeholders. The guidance encourages organizations to move from qualitative descriptions of risk to quantitative measurements, using hard data to communicate security performance. The two-volume document is designed for information security specialists and the C-suite, providing guidance on how to prioritize, select, and evaluate security measures. NIST is seeking public comments on the draft until March 18, 2024, and is also proposing the establishment of a Community of Interest (CoI) for information security measurement."}
{"url": "https://blog.google/technology/research/our-first-trust-safety-research-awards-grantees/", "title": "Our first Trust &amp; Safety Research Awards grantees", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Academic", "summary": "We are announcing the recipients of our Trust & Safety Research Awards. These grants support academics working to create positive societal impact with technology. The awards provide grants of up to $100,000 each for research related to Trust & Safety in technology. The awardees will study and propose solutions to pressing questions in tech policy, such as child and teen safety and combating misinformation. Trust & Safety is an emerging field that focuses on product safety and societal impacts of technology. We collaborate with researchers and experts from various disciplines to mitigate tech risks and drive positive outcomes for society. Our goal is to bridge the gap between academic researchers and technologists to improve outcomes for the ecosystem as a whole."}
{"url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2023/12/nist-calls-information-support-safe-secure-and-trustworthy-development-and", "title": "NIST Calls for Information to Support Safe, Secure and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Standards", "summary": "The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has issued a Request for Information (RFI) to assist in the implementation of its responsibilities under the Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI). The goal is to develop guidelines, standards, and testing environments for the safe and responsible use of AI. Feedback from industry, academia, and civil society is being solicited to develop industry standards around AI safety, security, and trust. The deadline for responses is February 2, 2024, and the information collected will inform the drafting of guidance to be released for public comment."}
{"url": "https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2023/12/metis-data-exchange-ecosystem-seeks-your-input", "title": "The METIS Data Exchange Ecosystem Seeks Your Input", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Research", "summary": "NIST and CHIPS are seeking comments on the draft of Special Publication 1000-2 ipd, which outlines the vision for a data exchange ecosystem called METIS. METIS aims to make federally funded scientific research in the CHIPS Metrology Program available to the public, industry, and the scientific community. The CHIPS Metrology Program aims to address measurement challenges in microelectronics manufacturing. The goal of METIS is to provide stakeholders with access to CHIPS Metrology research results and catalyze breakthroughs in U.S. semiconductor manufacturing. METIS leverages existing data management systems within NIST and ensures security and control in the research process."}
{"url": "https://blog.google/technology/safety-security/10-million-cybersecurity-program-in-europe/", "title": "A $10 million program to train students in cybersecurity across Europe", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Education", "summary": "Google has announced a $10 million cybersecurity skilling program in partnership with the European Cyber Conflict Research Incubator. The program aims to address the talent shortage of cybersecurity professionals in Europe, with a particular focus on increasing diversity in the field. The program will provide cybersecurity training to universities across Europe and support local community organizations in building their online protections. Google.org will provide funding, course content, and training to eight universities. The program expects to enroll over 1,600 students and reach at least 3,200 organizations in the first two years. The program will also fund the creation of educational resources, including a flexible cybersecurity curriculum, offered in multiple European languages."}

{"url": "https://5stars217.github.io/2023-10-26-introducing-offsec-ml-framework/", "title": "Introducing the Offsec ML Playbook v0.1", "date": "2024-02-01", "category": "Manipulation", "summary": "A database of offensive machine learning techniques and attacks is available that can help organizations target and manipulate ML models. The playbook includes methods such as poisoning ground truths, distributing malware in models, and launching repeated character sequence attacks. More verified techniques and proofs of concept are expected to be added, with a focus on supply chain attacks and payload distribution methods. The database will also provide information on the transferability of techniques to other ML models."}
